description:
Mindset: come here for dimly lit hole-in-the-wall / grungy vibes. Expect it to be cozy or cramped -- you know yourself the best.

Food: beer (hey, it's an izakaya, and see below)

Other food: I would approach this place not as a meal but a place to chill/chat. While there are plenty of "Japanese tapas" in the form of skewers and okonomiyaki (my favs here), etc., I would think of them as pairing to your beers and overall experience. Difficult to become full here unless you plan on making it rain. Or maybe that's just how SF is.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
Small authentic izakaya with a Beatles theme. Small paid public parking lot nearby. Great variety of items on the menu.

Would recommend okonomiyaki, Mayo scallion chicken skewers, and tsukune meatballs. Of course there are many other good items too. Only downside is a lot of the items come out slightly burnt, a few dishes were like this so I think they overcook it a bit on purpose.
author: Tom P.

description:
Ooof, I came here because the images on Yelp were sooo enticing. Service was also great despite us coming in a bit after last call. I intially made a reservation for 9ish , but I was running mad late, but they still graciously accomodated for us anyway! 
I got the Omakase, and the mushroom stuffed w chicken was my favorite of the seven. I want to come back and try everything else on the menu so i can give a more thoughtful review.. 
The place is super vibey, its a pretty fun place to chill out and people watch. I'll be back!!
author: Khanh D.

description:
This place is the definition of hidden gem hole in the wall. From the outside, this restaurant is so unassuming that we almost walked right past it.Thankfully we didn't because this place was BOMB.

The inside is also pretty small so it fills up fast but you can put yourself on the waitlist on yelp ahead of time. So convenient and you don't have to wait!

FYI they have a "secret menu" and we ordered a set from there called the Saikyo Set as well as other skewers.

SAIKYO SET $25 - it came with a chicken gizzard, heart, skin, liver, and cartilage skewer. GET THIS ONE, it's a must. My favorites were the gizzard, heart and liver. The gizzard and heart were perfect and not too chewy, and the liver was amazingly soft and rich and DELICIOUS. 

BEEF TONGUE $8 - The individual meats comes with two skewers. This was probably my favorite of the night. It was amazingly flavorful and perfect texture, not too chewy like some other places make it!

CHICKEN WING $6 - This one was kind of salty for my liking but I think it also comes with some thigh pieces that were classic and great for tasting the char flavor on the meat. 

OKONOMIYAKI $18 - To be honest, not worth the price but it tasted like I expected and made a good addition to our overall meal so we weren't just eating meat the whole time.

I'm already thinking about when I can come back ...
author: Angela P.

description:
Lovely little hole-in-the-wall that seems like it's been here forever. Think I read somewhere this is second-generation now, continuing a tradition of great yakitori and unapologetically weird decor.

I've had this place bookmarked forever and was stoked when my friend wanted to take me here. It's popular and tiny so prepare to wait. Pro tip: get on the waitlist remotely on yelp!

Big menu of goodies, and a wide variety of sakes too. You can even do a sale flight! We ordered everything.. wings (twice!), gizzards, bacon-wrapped enoki (impossible to bite thru), shishitos, pork belly, beef tongue, calamari, takoyaki, okonomiyaki (ours was a bit undercooked), ramen... couple bottles of sake (there were 4 of us!)... I'd say almost everything was a hit, or I'd order everything again except the enoki. Go crazy. 

Service was really friendly and helpful, but given how busy they were, drink orders were forgotten. When I did get my oolong cocktail I was disappointed.. kinda just tasted like diluted tea, which is what it is I suppose.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Yakitori heaven is what I have to say about this place. It was totally a surprise to me and I'm glad to have found it as it is one of the best meals i've had in SF in a while. It is a tiny hole in the wall place, typically with a line and cramped seating but I could care less as the food is amazing. The service here is fast and effeicent like a lot of japanese places and they use yelp for the wait list so you can put yourself down before you get there to minimize the wait.
The food here is yakitori, ramen, and Japanese apps/snacks. Haven't tried the ramen but the yakitori and apps/snacks are legit. My favorite yakitori is the chicken wing which is butterflied and seasoned perfectly. The beef belly and the yuzu chicken are also favorites. Tired some of the more adventurous bits like skin, heart, tendon, cartilage and to be honest they weren't that bad, a little bit chewier but good. I definitely recommend you explore the yakitori menu as you may be surprised like I was how a lot of things taste better then what you'd expect. The apps here are good as well, tried the gyoza, takoyaki, and oknomiyaki and all were good. Not amazing but good. Keep in mind this is a yakitori place so they are really good at that stuff and the other things on the menu are ok. I left here full and happy and found myself a few days later craving the yakitori, that's how's delicious I thought this place was.
author: Peter P.

description:
This place is pretty much hidden and safe from the world lol.

Located on 8th street and Clement, you wouldn't even think about this place compared to the other stuff around but don't knock it till you try it.

Pros:
- Friendly waiter  (it wasn't busy when I came with my cousin ) So he pretty much told us what was good.
- Very homely feeling when you're there with an interesting interior.
- Their menu has ramen, yakitori, appetizers and such. 
- Oldies are played so that's always cool

Cons:
- Wait time is pretty long so.. get there early.
- Super small interior, so not so great for big parties.
- Food is on the pricier spectrum.
- Parking around the area is always a con lol.

I haven't been here in YEARS so I'm not sure if everything has changed or not. But their okonomiyaki was really good, not too flat but not super thick.
author: Jerianne G.

description: Came here with friends as we were all craving ramen. The ramen was nothing memorable but maybe I should come back and try the yakitori.
author: Sophia L.

description:
You either will die reading all of this or it will be beneficial.

I like to remember things so yes, it's a long one.. 

Take-aways:

GET THE:
-Crispy Chewy Soft Skin
- Yakitori Omakase Dinner

-----

Last night was my second experience here. The first with a friend and the latter with my cousins. It was Saint Patty's and honestly, we weren't going out for the holiday festivities (we actually forgot), but the Richmond was nice because.. even near the bars and the food places: it was 'dead': nothing packed, just the usual numbers. (If you want crazy: try the Castro and other areas.. or go to DTSJ like San Pedro Square). It was really nice not dealing with crazy people. We did walk to a local bar while we waited for our spot here (they said about 30 minutes and they called us). 

It's a very small establishment with Beatle's memorabilia all over the place and Beatle's music playing in the background. I really like this place. My cousin and his girlfriend LOVE this place, but my other cousin has never gone. And it is sadly closed on Sundays (we were trying to go last Sunday after trying out couches at Living Spaces). So we did a raincheck and went last night.  

-

Anyways to the food..

2nd experience:

I ordered the beef tongue (comes in a set of two skewers). It was really good. And I appreciated that it was prepared differently than the beef tongue that I would also receive in my dinner set mentioned below. My dinner set was randomized so I didn't know I would be getting the 'same' thing, but it wasn't remotely the same. So thumbs up. 

------

I also got the Yakitori Omakase Dinner which is one of their specials: 
7 assorted yakitori skewers (chef's choice so it varies on any given day)

My assortments came with a delicious beef tongue, 
plum soaked beef with herbs (that was my favorite), 
orka (everyone loved this, but I thought it was okay),
pork (my cousin Kyle's favorite, but I'm not huge on charcoaled meats),
mushrooms (super delicious), 
chicken meatball, and 
salmon (my cousin Syd's favorite and it was good but it's not my go-to).

*beef tounge isn't as chewy as the leunga of a burritto so if you were wondering on texture, I can't do super chewy meats, I think if you've never had tounge: it's a good starting dish to get here. It's really good.

The dinner comes is served with rice, miso soup and organic spring green mix salad.  The miso is really good here, they make it different than any place I've ever been too. They have enokitake mushrooms in their miso and it's not a super salty broth or anything, it's just dead-on good. 

**veggie choice available for the assortments 

--------

We also got Okonomiyaki (japanese style pizza pancake topped with traditional tonkatsu sauce, mayo, aonori and red ginger), it's vegetarian, very similar to a Korean seafood/non-seafood pancake. I liked it, but if you don't like Korean savory pancakes in general you won't like this, it's the same texture.

------

My cousins got the Combination (I don't believe this is on the menu, but written on one of the boards on the wall) & Karaage Ramen. The ramens were good. This isn't really the right place to get Ramen, but it's good with the food we had.. we did order a lot.. so you might want to tone it down a notch. 

-----

One cousin got a sake flight (where they choose for you, but there's a lot of other options where it's not a surprise) and they enjoyed it. 

I just choose not drink so I can't comment on anything. 

----

One cousin got 2 Spicy Mentai Caviar Mayo Chicken, so all four of us got a skewer and it was really good. 

-----

First experience:

Got the takoyaki, crispy chicken wings (super small, my friend was disappointed.. I think it was typical sizing), I got the Crispy Chewy Soft Skin (comes in two) and that's my absolute favorite.
author: Lilian L.

description: So good! This was my second time here and their food just gets better and better. We got here early to beat the crowd as it is a tiny place. Ordered the chicken set (heart,liver, bone, gizzard and skin), steak belly, yuzu wings, ochazuke, habanero chicken, and seaweed wrapped soy sauce butter mochi. I'm still thinking about the food, so good!
author: Al T.

description:
Gah this place is so good!! Especially when it comes to yakitori. Must gets are the chicken cartilage skewers and the crispy soft chicken skin. 
LET ME TELL YOU GUYS, chicken skin is the sh*t. It is the new bacon. It is the better, well improved bacon. It is grilled to perfection at Halu and if you've never had chicken skin before, try it here. It will blow your mind and your taste buds and make you question why isn't chicken skin served with your morning pancakes and OJ. Why isn't chicken skin more of a thing you guys?! 

I digress. This is supposed to be about halu and not just chicken skin. The skewers are delicious and usually come two per order. Their hamachi kami is pretty delicious too if youre looking for something other than yakatori. 

Restaurant is small and intimate, adorned with Beatles decorations everywhere. If you're dining alone or in a pair, consider sitting at the bar to cut down on your wait time.  

And guys, get the chicken skin skewers.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Halu has been sitting in my bookmarks for at least 2 years. I've never tried it because either it was closed (Monday and Sundays per their Yelp page) or the line was too long.

While known for its yakitori (Japanese grilled skewer items), I was craving ramen, so I got ramen and tried the okonamiyaki (Japanese pizza/pancake).

I ordered:
-cha siu ramen: It satisfied my basic ramen craving, but it's definitely not the best ramen. The egg was too salty, and the broth wasn't rich and more on the watery side
-okonamiyaki: This was good and worth a try if you haven't had it before. It's like Japanese pizza, made with egg, flour, cabbage, etc. You can even slice it into little triangular slices. 

Both items were split between 2 people, and we felt satisfied. 

Service was good, but the place is small, so come earlier than later, because by the time I left, there was a line trailing outside the door.
author: Corinna T.

description: The food here is truly delicious, but every time we order take out from them we debate ever returning. Customer service is pretty terrible - today, for example, we ordered take out and showed up 40 minutes later to pick it up. They  told us they forgot to process our order and to please come back 40 minutes later without a single sorry or accommodation. It is unfortunate, as it is the best ramen in the area - but they have zero care for their customers.
author: Britta V.

description: Hands down, one of my favorite places. Every bite that I took was something to really drool for. The price was definitely on the higher end, but I'd love to come back and enjoy this meal again. The skewers are a little small but man, every single bite packs a tasteful punch! Really, just try all of the them. The beef belly was so plump, the gizzard had a rubbery yet satisfying taste to it. The okonomyaki was pretty good, but I wish it were a tad cheaper. Funny thing is that I went to another spot and the okonomyaki was more expensive. So... Might actually be a good deal (?) The vibe inside is that of a Japanese restaurant. You can really sense the intimacy of the restaurant between customers. I think anyone would really enjoy their meal here. :)
author: Janan D.

description:
Great small spot. Went right when they open and experience no wait. 
Service was good. We ordered from the yakitori menu and all were very tasty and fresh. Price is reasonable as per yakitori  order comes with 2 skewers. 
Will definitely come back,  but probably try the  yakitori omikase set.
author: Maria M.

description:
I always come here and order Chasumen (+$1 for spicy). The slices of pork belly in the ramen is good and I like the firm texture and thickness of the ramen. The broth is usually pretty good but I have to admit the broth wasn't as good as I remembered it from before the last time I went. Maybe it was off that day. I love the variety of sides/yakitori and specials they have to offer on the menu and posted on the wall. Their beef tongue and wasabi chicken is good. 

The wait times are long as the restaurant is tiny, but if put your phone number down with your name you can walk around the neighborhood and they will call you when your table is ready. However don't stray too far from the restaurant because you may lose your table if you take too long to come back.
author: Donna M.

description:
The place itself is small.  It only has about 7 tables with a booth that can fit 5-6 people.  A lot of the reviews said their yakitori is super good.  Well, it's true!  They're super good! 
We ordered the yakitori omakase, okonomiyaki, takoyaki, porridge (since there's no ramen), erichan and karaage.  
The takoyaki was bomb!  I wish I took a picture of it.  They're so good and we were super hungry, no one took a picture .  The yakitori of course was awesome!  Erichan and porridge were on the salty side but savory.  The karaage and the okonomiyaki was also good.  Although, my friend said she's had better some place else.
Overall, their food is great, the service was also good and fast.  Their waitresses stride from customers to customers.  This place is small and gets packed.  Not good for big groups.
author: Bash B.

description: Classic rock and grilled yakitori are combined to make a unique yet authentic experience in this Inner Richmond Japanese spot. Many folks opt for the combo menus, but I prefer to pick my own, so we went for the salmon, ginko nuts, meat balls, shisho plum chicken, okra, shrimp tempura, beef belly and kurobuta sausage. All yakitori were grilled perfectly, and since we ordered off the beaten path, ours were all freshly grilled. I'd say the salmon, ginko, meat balls and okra were my favorite. The Japanese couple sitting next to me were enjoying ramen instead, and were very happy that this place does a more toned-down ramen, Japanese style versus the overhyped and Americanized ramen places mushrooming all over the city-- big hint that I will take. My only concern here is the price-- it's a lot cheaper in Japan, but hey, it's boom-time SF.  I'll be back.
author: Brian J.

description:
There was a little bit of a wait to get in so we decided to go grab some drinks while our name was placed on the waitlist. It was definitely worth it and we will be back for both the food, drinks, great service, and atmosphere. The place is a little small, but it packs a big punch with its flavors and welcoming vibe. We ordered a few rounds of sake, the unfiltered being my favorite, and they were chilled nicely and tasted great. We got a variety of skewers to share and everything was delicious.

Tako Wasabi Marinated Octopus, Geso Age Calamari, Chashu Men, Spicy Mentai Caviar Mayo Chicken, Shiso Beef Steak, Juicy Tsukune Chicken Stuffed Mushroom, Eggplant with Soy Sauce and Ginger, Crunchy Gizzards.

The only thing they were out of that we wanted to try were the hearts. Overall a very nice place to bring anyone and try. The servers were also amazing and very patient and informative. Definitely worth the wait and trip there. You got to find this little gem because it's a bit hidden. You will not be disappointed.
author: Camera P.

description:
Servers were friendly and helpful. However, it was a huge mistake that they've decided to write down the tip and total amount for us on our receipt. We have six people and we were aware that 18% gratuity is preferred for parties of six or more. First, it's just NOT right to decide how much should be tipped for YOUR customer as tip is supposedly VOLUNTARY based on the service. Second, servers wrote down 20% gratuity instead of 18%. The situation felt like we were FORCED to give tips whatsoever.

The food was also okay, not incredibly impressive. Skewers were somewhat burnt and overly priced, ramen broth wasn't hot enough. Overall, the food doesn't really deserve its price. This is not a place where somebody who has had authentic Japanese food would go to, at least not for its food and service. 

HALU MANAGEMENT: Please do not do this ever again, it's just morally wrong and dishonest. You should let the customers decide how much they want to tip + total (there is a reason signatures are required).
author: Kandice T.

description:
So my first review was almost 8 years ago. I totally didn't dive into the yakitori back then during my initial review. Boy, did I miss out. After frequent visits, from then to now, I totally fell in love with the yakitori. By far the best in the city. 

Everything is good on the menu. I mean, everything. And I have tried it all. 

My favorite has to be the okra and the eggplant. I can eat those everyday. Beef belly, beef tongue, and chicken skin are a must. 

The Eri-Chan special is delicious. To try explain what it is based off of eating it for many years, the Edi-Chan special is mochi pan fried in butter, then wrapped in seaweed. So chewy and soft, so flavorful and warms the body. 

The Okonomiyaki is pretty standard to other Okonomiyaki. Don't get me wrong, it's good. Good that I order it almost Everytime I'm there. It will fill you up for sure. 

On a busy night, it can get pretty hectic and busy, so keep track with your order. Erika and Sayaka are awesome and keep the vibe going. It was cool to see their pops Shig at work when I first was there. It makes me happy to see after all the years, the cool vibe is still the same. 

Playlist is always on point in there and paying respect to the guardian in the restroom is always cool. (If you have ever been, I hope you know what I'm talking about.) 

Continue the good work Halu! And I will continue to eat all the skewers and food you have to offer!
author: A L.

description: Cute, quirky izakaya style japanese restaurant with great yakitori.  Went here last night with some friends, lots of laughs, sake and skewers were had.  Tiny little restaurant (just like those in Japan!) but I believe you can add yourself to the wait list via Yelp.
author: Clarissa P.

description: The best. Nothing more to say. I've literally never had anything bad here. Steak, chicken, tendon, shiitake... I could go on. Just go.
author: James W.

description:
A small, popular neighborhood venue, Halu offers an extensive menu of yakitori, ramen, and other Japanese dishes and has quite the wait during peak times, but when I visited recently, maybe they were resting on their laurels a bit, at the expense of execution. 

The famed bacon-wrapped mochi was borderline edible; the bacon was a bit too crisp, while the mochi was rather tough, instead of being delightfully gooey and easily chewy. I literally had to yank all of it forcefully with my teeth off the skewers. The karaage ramen was decent, although I'm not sure if soaking the karaage in the broth is something they do by design, because it renders what I think of as the otherwise delightfully crispy chicken into a soggy affair. Even a simple glass of water tasted soapy.

Service was kind of perfunctory, although I recognize that the waitresses were somewhat slammed during a peak period. If it's a battle between Halu in the Inner Richmond and, say, Sozai over in the Inner Sunset, I'd say Sozai wins out.
author: Vincent L.

description: This place use to be pretty good 5 years ago or so but tonight's dinner a lot of the food was pretty salty. Hit or miss or new chef. Service is ok. Overall 3 star. Small place, kids friendly, gets pack, long wait and better to come when they first open at 5pm.
author: Christy V.

description:
I've been to Halu twice and loved everything we ordered. I'm not sure what we ordered, but it was all great and the service is so friendly. This place is small and gets crowded so I only like to go here with 1, maybe 2 other people at a time but I don't like large group dinners very much anyways so who cares.

Anyways I decided I needed to give 5 stars to this place because it is quickly becoming THE standard by which I judge other places. I've gone elsewhere and recently been disappointed by:
Takoyaki - I'm not sure how they get them so good here but everywhere else is either skimping on the ingredients or too pancakey 
Yakitori, but especially the chicken skin - someone else said it's the new bacon and I can't disagree when I have it at Halu. So crispy on the outside!
Oolong shochu drink (can't remember what it is called) - never had it until I came here. When I was in Hawaii I saw it on a menu and ordered it again and it was not as good.

Long story short: trust the recommendations of your server, don't bring a large group.
author: Katies F.

description:
I found this place by searching for restaurants that are unique in San Francisco. Halu did not disappoint. We did walk right past it since it is nondescript and small, but don't let that fool you - they know what they are doing with their food.

We both got ramen, and even though I can handle my spice, I probably should have stuck with mild, so just be warned. Regardless it was very tasty and they have a nice selection of different sake and different Japanese drinks to choose from.

It's a very small place, so take note of the potential wait. We made it just in time to snag a table at 6:30 on a weekday.
author: Jason G.

description: I really like this place, not like the masses of Japanese places at all. Early Classic Rock and Killer Food, Yes
author: Dave R.

description:
I love this place but my last experience here has been terrible. We came here at 7:00PM on a Friday night and checked in. Waitress told us the wait is about an hour which was cool since we just went around the corner to Steins to grab a few drinks. We headed back around the 50 min mark just to be safe. Checked in again and she told us another 30 mins. 

After another 30 mins passed, checked in again and told us another 30-40 mins wait. At this point we're like huh? We checked the name list and it looks like they've been filling seats for 2-4 versus trying to save a table for 6. If they didn't want to sit 6, should've just told us from the get go. Spent over 2+ hours until we got finally called. Based on the list, they sat over 14 covers after us. Horrible judgement at filling tables and fairness. 

5 stars for the food but 1 star for their planning and rudeness.
author: Vince L.

description:
By bff took me here for the first time when I visited because I was craving yakitori. It was pretty crowded but we were lucky and got seated right away. I used the restroom before sitting down and ordering, and wow... It was a party in there with lights and music lol (see video). I also got stuck inside the restroom because I was getting out of the door when a staff member was getting out of the employee door and wedged the door.  It's funny now but not funny if you're claustrophobic.

I thoroughly enjoyed everything we ordered except the flavored soju. It was wayyyyy too sweet and difficult to finish. They ran out of every beer except some brand we've never heard of so that was strange. 

Anyway, we had the meatballs (flavorful and juicy), heart & gizzards (fave!), chicken, okra, and takoyaki. I'd go back and order all of them again! The decor, music, and efficiency are all pluses to a pleasant evening.
author: Mintz L.

description:
Halu is definitely one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in SF. It is a little on the pricier end, but portions are large and the food is so delicious! We ordered the karaage ramen, chashu ramen, okonomiyaki, and bacon wrapped mochi. It was a lot for two people, but to the surprise of our waitress (who warned us it was a lot!), we finished everything but half of the okonomiyaki. 

Seating is limited here- we called in advance to check if there were any open tables, and when we arrived, were seated right away. The interior of the restaurant is small and retro styled - It makes for a cozy, intimate meal. 

As for the food, the okonomiyaki was hot and delicious, and I actually liked it more than the ones we had in Osaka, Japan. I enjoyed that it was lighter in flavor and not drenched in mayo. The portion was huge and can be a meal in itself, rather than an appetizer.... Same for the ramen, the portions were large! The noodles were thin and the broth light as well. The karaage was crispy on the outside and the meat moist - I would definitely suggest taking the karaage out of the bowl ASAP, so it doesn't get soggy in the broth. Alternatively, request for the karaage to come in a separate plate.  The bacon wrapped mochi was also delicious, though not special. My favorites of the meal were definitely the okonomiyaki and ramen. 

Overall, great Japanese restaurant - will be coming back!
author: Christine L.

description: Cute restaurant with an interesting interior. I enjoyed all their skewers from chicken hearts to livers, they were all well seasoned. Their ramen was decent, good broth, good noodles, but nothing memorable. Will be back for more!
author: Sui N.

description: Best hidden ramen place in the city. It's a hole in the wall, only about 6 tables so the wait can be super long, but the ramen is delicious so can be worth the wait!
author: Jenn A.

description:
"Been around the world and ay-yai-yai, THIS IS NOT GOOD RAMEN."

Everything was lackluster. Egg was so salty that is was ludicrous. The noodles were just so boring. What's to say about this shoyu broth besides one-dimensional? 

Nobody should have to wait 30 minutes in line for Halu. 

Nobody should have to wait 20 minutes to receive a bowl of basic ramen after ordering. 

Yes, the karaage (how dare you autocorrect me to KARATE!!) was good, but honestly not good enough. 

I should have figured since they focus more on izakaya it seems. 

Come for drinks and bites. 

Oh, well. Right?
author: Aren A.

description:
Late review (I finally decided to review the spots on my recent places list), but this spot is delicious.  It is quite small so be prepared to wait, but the wait is definately worth it. Plus, the size creates an intimate feeling that you can't beat for a date. The music is good and the food is good. I Iive in Glen Park so it's quite the trek, but I plan to go again. Can't believe I never went here when this use to be my neighborhood. 

One of my new favorite spots.
author: Mel M.

description: This little hideaway is one of the things that make SF so fun. It;s the kinda place you might find on some random street in Osaka, serving japanese tapas to small groups of friends drinking beer before heading out on the town. Yakitori is a must and you'll have no trouble finding other small bites, get the sampler and keep it simple. or ask for the "secret menu" . Okonomiyaki  a bit on the pricy side for what it is., but tasty. I'd take friends and guests here while touring the Clement street/ Richmond scene. The decor is rock & roll from days past with Beatles featured prominently. Funky and fun. It can get crowded fast  as there are only about 25-30 seats. Two people  food tab with a large beer each   $ 60-70- all in.
author: Aaron Z.

description: Halu was such a great surprise! A friend told me about this quirky restaurant in the inner Richmond and it did not disappoint! I had a flight of sake, the edamame, karaage chicken, and their ramen with fried chicken in it.
author: Billy T.

description: We came here on a late weekday, looking for something to eat. As we walked in, I saw all kinds of Beatle posters and thought it was very unique that it was Beatle themed. I ordered a bowl of ramen along with my dad, and it was filled with a variety of different and tasty flavors. The food was definitely not a disappointment, but the service and space in the restaurant was. I felt like I was in an elevator with 40 other people. Overall, not a bad experience, and I really look forward to visiting this place again.
author: Paolo Q.

description: Halu is a small yakitori and ramen restaurant with a cool Beatles feel. We ordered a few different yakitoris and the chicken kaarage was my favorite. Everything else seemed a bit too salty, including the Chasu Ramen. A bit on the pricier side without being fully satisfied and filled.
author: Grace L.

description:
I really enjoyed Halu! I've tried a lot of yakitori/skewer spots in San Francisco, and Halu has some of the largest skewer variety I've seen. While Halu is a little weaker in some areas (e.g., ramen, which I found bland), they excel with their meats.

I enjoyed all of the skewers that I tried, but it's worth mentioning that beef belly skewer is one of the most delicious skewers I have ever had. It's absolutely unforgettable--melt-in-your-mouth fatty goodness and incredible flavor.

Would definitely come back for more skewers and to try the okonomiyaki. Come early; it's tiny, and there'll likely be a wait.
author: Kelly R.

description: A small establishment with a big menu all over the place, literally. They have a menu but have menu specials written in every corner. I had to take pictures so I can see them instead of staring at strangers. The food and drinks were unique and flavorful. We had the beef belly, chicken scallions, bacon wrapped scallops, Gyoza, karaage, mochi wrapped with seaweed nori, and butter corn Ramen. Everything was delicious but our least favorite was the bacon wrapped scallops. Must order items are beef belly, Gyoza, karaage and mochi wrapped seaweed nori. We had the sesame shochu and a 3 year old whiskey. The waitresses were nice and attentive. Can't wait to go back.
author: Minh H.

description:
Smallest door in the world lol! This place is TINY and there's a long wait because of that reason. Gotta put your name down or try to come when they open! Others told us that usually the line is usually out the door, but we got lucky on a Friday night when they just opened :) 

Ordered the okinomiyaki, two skewer sets, fried squid and the karage ramen. 

My favorite out of all of them was probably the fried squid! It was SOOO good and I have such a soft spot for fried food. It came in about 4 large pieces, so delicious and chewy!

The okinomiyaki was pretty good too. My second favorite of our meal. It was really tasty and reminds me of like a thick version of a Korean pancake.

The skewers were delicious as well, but definitely on the salty side. Realllly salty. We ordered the 7 set skewers and a special set of 4 (consisted of innards !). They were great with a side of beer and I enjoyed them

The karage in the ramen was good as well and the ramen was okay. It came in a decent portion and we shared everything on our table family style. :)

I really enjoyed the atmosphere of this place, maybe because it was tiny and felt really homely.
author: Melanie T.

description:
Funktown, USA, this place is cool. The mixture of the rock music, Beatles décor, and expansive menu makes for the perfect date night. It's small and unassuming from the outside. Hiding a few doors down from Clement, I would have probably walked by and not even noticed if it hadn't been for yelp. There are probably 6-10 tables and a very small bar that seats maybe 8 people.

We got lucky when we walked in at 730 and were seated right away. Honestly, the ramen is 3 stars. There is truly nothing special about it. I got the Karage ramen, spicy, and it definitely satiated my cravings. Gyoza are more like wontons, but good nonetheless. We also had fried chicken thighs, and those were fabulous. 

My advice: bring your hot date here for some warm ramen on a typical, cold SF night. The place is tiny, so the two of you will have to sit close together to talk. 2 blocks away is an ice cream shop where you can get dessert.
author: Steph D.

description:
I've only been here once but the chicken karaage ramen was really yummy. It has a very dive bar/hole in the wall feel decorated floor to ceiling with The Beatles memorabilia, and it's awesome. Very cozy, good vibes, great sake, cheap beer, and somewhat of an easy area to find parking.

When I came it was for an early dinner during the week. There were a few empty seats in the dining area but I sat at the bar and, instantly, it felt like a place I would spend a lot of time in if I lived closer. I haven't been here during a rush but the food came fairly quick. It doesn't strike me as the best place for large groups due to its size. Personally, I'd go on a weekday by myself or with a few friends, sit at the bar or a table, drink some beers, and eat yakitoki, which was very good.
author: Skye J.

description: Had some time to kill nearby and was hungry so figured I'd give this place a try. It was a Saturday evening and the space is small so if you need a table for more than just yourself, there may be a wait. That being said, I was by myself so was seated at the bar area immediately. The decor is really interesting; a mix of Beatles memorabilia and other musician posters which is the opposite of what i would expect for a Japanese place but, hey, it definitely is unique. I got the Karaage Ramen, which I've never had before, and it was pretty good. It wasn't the most amazing ramen I've ever had but hit the spot on a cold day and tasted good. I just wish they had a bigger space/more seating; I ended up feeling like I was holding up other people who needed two seats. That being said, it's a decent place if you're craving ramen in the area.
author: Pooja C.

description: Although I've been living in sf my whole life I never heard of this place until my special one took me here on are first date...small izakaya/ramen joint, worth the wait if you know what your getting into...the chicken skin,beef tendon and tako yaki balls hit the spot and check out there varieties mochi offerings..the karaage ramen is a must try as well
author: jonathan h.

description:
Very upset, messed up our bill which would've made us pay more. 
They wrote the bill by hand which was hard to read, so if we didn't check it carefully, we will pay the extra bill for the mistakes they made ! 
Also charged us 20% gratuity for 5 people..? I have never written a bad review on Yelp, but this time really upset me.
author: Hsu J.

description: I had to visit an alley in Tokyo, Japan to get the same quality of ramen here. The food, the company, the experience was OOTW - Out Of This World
author: Dmitri S.

description: Sake selection was really good. I'd rank the yakitori as follows: 1) Tsukune meat balls 2) wasabi chicken 3) Spicy chicken thigh 4) shiso plum chicken 5) beef belly. Karage wasn't bad but needed a mayo sauce. Gyoza wasn't bad but the wrapping was a bit thin... tasted like a loosely wrapped lumpia. Vibe/decor/service all good. Would come back
author: Breck O.

description: Soooo about 1-2yrs after my first experience here (which left me with a bit of food poisoning), I finally decided to try Halu again. Only to get food poisoning AGAIN immediately afterwards!!! And it wasn't just me - both my roommates experienced upset stomachs, so I think it's safe to say that I really won't be coming back here
author: Grace D.

description: It was good but not the best I've had. The food was at times salty and overall priced fairly high. They also were out of the sausage we came in specifically for. Service was not as fast with two different servers. We did not have to wait long for a seat. The Okonomiyaki was tasty and the Kara Age Ramen, though simple, was also satisfying. One of the better izakayas in the city.
author: Mikey J.

description: My first yakitori experience! So so good! I love grilled food, if you do, you'll like the grill taste! We ordered the chicken skewers, jap pancake, bacon wrapped enoki, chicken wings (get this-so good!), karaage ramen. There were three of us, we shared everything. They even brought out extra bowls for you to share the ramen. The server was great at recommending dishes and was so enthusiastic and engaging about it. Can't wait to go back!
author: Lisa H.

description:
I am very focused on the food in my reviews and my scoring typically is heavily biased on the food and nothing else.  This review is an exception as they had good food but everything else about the experience was abysmal and we didn't even get a single apology from them.

The crux of the matter is that we ordered 4 skewers and only one was delivered after about 20 minutes, and they totally forgot about rest of the meal.  30 minutes go by without any activity until we were asked if we were ready for the check.  When we said we hadn't gotten the bulk of our meal, they said the problem was that they needed to prep the food (i.e. put meat on skewers) and they obviously didn't want to so do so - so they just ignored the rest of the order.  

We were given the option of either waiting another 20 minutes for the food to order (i.e. they would start making it)  or we would be served different items that could be prepared more quickly.  We were starving and asked for the quicker option -- so we were served random food we didn't order and it took well over an hour twenty minutes to get served.  All the replacement options they brought were also more expensive than the items we originally ordered.

At this point, I would have expected a simple apology - but none was offered.  It was stated matter of factly that they just didn't bother making our food. 

The service was so bad that I left a $0.95 tip on a $40 order - and after walking out I felt like I had over-tipped.   This is a rare occasion where I think that a negative tip would have been warranted.

That's not how service should be.
author: reza n.

description:
I've been here 2 times and had a saliva inducing experience on both occasions. I would come here more often if it was a little cheaper. 

The beef belly and avacado beef had some of the best flavors I've had in a long time. I could eat those two dishes all night. I've also tried the okonamiyaki which was also done very well, having a nice crispy outside and a generous portion or seafood/meat inside.

The space is small, but has character. There is a beatles drum set on the balcony and a tiger head in the bathroom. 

I plan on coming back here again for sure. 4 stars and not 5 because of the poor service from my first visit where they forgot one of our orders and gave us the wrong bill twice. The second time the service was perfectly fine. The food is reason enough alone to try Halu, so don't let the possibility of bad service stop you from coming!
author: Sean W.

description:
I have to say I'm quite pleasantly surprised by this tiny/hidden izakaya place!

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
- Our server was pretty helpful in terms of suggesting us what food to order (which they came out to be really good too)
- The restaurant was tiny but the seatings were still pretty comfortable, not too cramped nor loud

Cons:
- The wait! (This is a big one) Halu does not take reservations, we arrived at 7 and were told there would be a 20 mins wait. But after 35 mins we still haven't got our table, so we went in and were told we would be the next party, then it took another 15 mins until we were finally seated... Granted we were asked to leave a phone number so they could call us when table's ready, but the extended waiting time was just too long compared with what we were quoted

* * * FOOD * * *
Spinach Salad: A-.
A tiny appetizer recommended by our server, the spinach was fresh but it was the sauce that made the difference. It was peanut + miso kind of taste, good start of our meal.

Tontoro Skewer: A.
Crunchy and tender, one of the best grilled pork belly I have ever had. Each piece of pork belly had an equal fat/meat ratio, the grilling time was just about right that the meat was still very juicy when it was served.

Chicken Skewer: A-.
Nothing surprising here but good quality of chicken meat and the addition of avocado was a nice match to the oily/greasy meat.

Gyutoro Skewer: A.
The beef belly was not as crunchy as pork belly, but definitely a lot more tender and juicy. Again the grilling time here was controlled very well. Some kind of sauce was put on the meat before it was served which made this dish even more delicious.

Chicken Katsu Skewer: A-.
Quite an interesting skewer. Grilling a fried stuff seems to be an extra step and I couldn't really taste the grilling part of it anyway. There was some onion inside the chicken katsu too.

Grilled Eggplant: B.
Quite disappointed. Very bland even with the addition of ginger. Should have come with soy sauce instead.

Okonomiyaki: A-.
Nice texture and very tasty, flavorful sauce. Not too thick. I was hoping there could be more green onion to enhance the taste even more though. Definitely a must-order dish.

Chicken Stuffed Mushroom: A-.
Another recommendation from our server. There was just a tiny bit of chicken meat in each piece of mushroom, but the combination of both was rather interesting.

Geso Age: A-.
The squid legs were deep fried in just about the right amount of time, not too crunchy while the squid was still very tender. The sauce was once again very flavorful.

Satisfied with almost all the dishes ordered! With beer and sake this little izakaya place is definitely a top choice for small group gathering!
author: Simon C.

description:
Absolutely the worst Izakaya I have been to and I will never come back again. Foods are bad and salty, and way overpriced. It's totally a rip off. The service is ok though. Can't believe this is so busy since the food is not worth the price at all. If you think the food is good I guess you never try any authentic and REAL Yakitori. This is just to fool people who don't have knowledge and experience about these types of Japanese food.

This is the first time that I have the motivation to write a comment on Yelp simply because it's so bad that I cannot tolerate.
author: Manling T.

description:
Halu has personality. It's a pre-gentificatin-type OG that brings izakaya fare back to basics in a cozy unpretentious hole-in-the-wall. 

Izakayas in SF are all too often posh and shiny, striving to emulate authenticity with dramatic head-to-toe wood everything that almost looks more like a temple than a restaurant. In contrast, Halu's vintage diner ambiance and whimsical decor of Beatles paraphernalia makes me feel as if I had walked straight into a local joint tucked into alleyways in Japan. (Ironic that the quintessentially American aspects of the diner are what make Halu so authentically Japanese)

The menu features ramen, yakitori, and okonomiyaki--staples including choices with a spin, such as kara age ramen, sirloin yakitori, and a more-green-than-usual okonomiyaki. There are several good alchy selections as well, such as potato sake (reminiscent of vodka, as expected).

(++) Kara-age ramen ($12): Personally I always find this to be an oxymoron since the kara-age would be good with anything besides sitting in a noodle soup and getting soggy. Although I still think the kara-age would be best on the side, I do commend the ramen here! The noodles are thin and bouncy, and unlike noodles typically found at ramen places (I suspect it's housemade or from Japan!) The broth is solid, a perfect balance of a nice robust flavor without being too thick and heavy.

(+) Hiyashi chaku ($14): Not terrible, but I would pass. First of all, the plate is oval which looks pretty but makes it very difficult to mix all the ingredients together. Secondly, the chashu portions are a bit skimpy because the slices are very very thin. Overall it didn't stand out too much.

(+++) Okonomiyaki ($17): My favorite dish here, and probably the best okonomiyaki I've had in SF so far! Usually I find it too saucy and carby, but Halu's version has a mild sauce drizzle, a slightly less starchy composition, and topped with a layer of nori flakes. Intriguing and tasty P:

Since the place is small, the wait on a Friday night around 7pm is approximately 30 minutes, but they call when your table is ready, and there are various Asian grocery stores to browse around.

It came out to ~$24 per person: a little pricey but fairly standard in SF terms, and worth it for a  memorable food adventure in a fun setting.

And yes, the food/decor do make good Instagrams, for those of you who take that into account :P
author: Edna C.

description: I am giving this place 4 stars based on the Karage ramen and the taste of the chicken hearts. We also ordered the chicken livers, but I was not used to the texture, so I didn't really like it. The karage ramen was so good and you do get a lot for the price. The chicken hearts and livers were a little pricey for what you get. I would only come back here to eat the ramen.
author: Allyson L.

description:
What an amazing Yelp find! We live near this place and had no idea they existed! 

Very small restaurant with loads of Beatles memorabilia on the walls. They play lots of 60's era music. 

My husband and I ordered gyoza and two bowls of ramen. Veggie and the fried chicken. Everything was delicious! The service was friendly and fast. I would have no clue how to improve this place. 

When we go back we agreed to be a little more adventurist since they have all kinds of Japanese dishes you won't find in anywhere else.
author: Alison C.

description: They close at 10, but kitchen closes at 9:30. Got there at 9:30 but gladly they still took us in. Happy with that. We ordered this set of skewers, really good and filling, also great service! The place is filled with The Beatles pictures and play their songs which is awesome! Would love to go back at an earlier time lol
author: Chey I.

description:
Been eyeing this place for a while and finally came around to try it! There was a little mishap with putting our name down. When we arrived saturday night around 8pm, the wait was said to be an hour. Our name was put down at the top behind the first sheet. Came back an hour later and it turned out they continued putting names in front of the 2nd sheet and we probably could have been sat earlier. They do take your name and number to text/call you when they're ready for you! We never got a text or call so we came back to check find out that happened, we were seated immediately though!

We got:

Drink
-ichigo yuzu liqueur ($15): We were upsold this item while ordering drinks. Half pint/8oz bottle. 8% alcohol. Was yummy and easy to drink, taste like juice! 

Skewers
-sausage: crispy exterior made it feel like it was bacon wrapped when it wasn't.. yum~
-beef belly: this was pretty fatty, but it a good way.
-chicken thigh: had a kick of jalapeno and citrus!
-meatball: this was my favorite! Juicy meatballs.
-chicken karaage: clean and simple, served with just a lemon wedge. Can't go wrong.

Skewers range from $6-10 for two skewers per serving. In my opinion that's kind of pricy. Other izakaya places I've been to cost $3-$7 per serving. Everything we got came out hot and was super delicious though! Service was friendly and food came out relatively quick. This place is pretty small and seats roughly 30 people! Best for parties between 1-4 people. A lot of people got ramen here which we didn't order, that's something I'll try next time! Our bill came out to be about $60 for all that. Wasn't exactly filling, but my tastebuds were definitely happy!
author: Tina N.

description: I can't comment on the food here since we obviously weren't welcomed to, but the service is unbelievable. We got here about 10min before 5 yesterday and saw a couple of employees setting up, so we waited outside until about 10min after their supposed opening time (5:10 or so), and the door was still locked. Then an employee came out and saw us, completely ignored us, and walked down the street. We went to Genki Ramen after, which is just a few blocks down the street. Amazing food and great service, highly recommended over this place anytime.
author: WeiWei H.

description: The Food at Halu was Quirky and very good! I'm particularly impressed with the Beef belly steak skewers and so were my table neighbors. The service was wonderful and the staff Very friendly!  In fact, the only issue on a Very busy Thursday night was the server forgot my salad and miso soup until After I asked for the check.  I'm not a Uber picky person and would have lived with it if it were not for the fact I asked for my check which they dropped off and then, after I dropped my credit card into the tray the soup and salad showed up and there was no apology. So four stars. Otherwise Grand place!
author: Sirdrewbrew ..

description: Great little hole in the wall and there is parking next door!!! I'll be a regular!! Interesting menu and drinks. You haven't had this before!
author: Heather W.

description:
Tiny place with maybe less than 20 seats. We got there shortly after 5pm when they opened, so we were able to snag a couple of seats before it filled up. What's funny is that we waited about 20 minutes for them to take our order, but we were [encouraged] to head out as soon as we finished our food. By the time we left, around 6:15pm, there were 5-6 people waiting outside in the rain (the space is so small there was nowhere for them to wait inside). 

The food was ok. I started with the chicken liver skewers. They were good, but a bit pricey ($5.75) for only two skewers. I also expected the liver to have a bit more of a richer flavor. Next, I got the Karaage Ramen. I didn't really understand the idea behind putting fried chicken in soup. As one would expect, the fried chicken was not that crispy after being soaked by the broth :/  The broth was flavorful, but lacking spice for my taste. Luckily, they had some red chili flakes for me to spice up my ramen. $12.50 was a bit more than I would like to pay for ramen, but it was a large bowl and the broth was flavorful. If you want a soft-boiled egg, it's extra. I forgot to ask for one and they never asked me if I wanted one. 

Halu has lots of character and is super cozy, but a little pricey. There are a couple other place in SF where I can get a better bowl of ramen for less money.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Great izakaya with a good menu. I highly recommend the beef tongue and gizzards! Yumm. I also enjoyed the ramen fairly well. That surprised me. The beer here is pretty good. I highly recommend the bacon wrapped mochi! Man, that was so good. I love the texture. The okonomiyaki is OK. Not the best I've had, but edible.
For my first izakaya experience out of Japan, it was really decent. And the service is so friendly too.
author: Jenn T.

description: The yakitoris was very good!   Except the waitress tried to overcharge me for $10 more.   Check your change after paying..
author: D F.

description:
I'm still on the hunt for okonomiyaki in the city.  The one at Halu is a combination of beef, seafood, and chicken.  I wish they stated that on their menu because I try not to eat beef, but I should've asked.  Besides, it was really good and filling!  It really should be shared with two people.

Because I ate the entire thing, I didn't have room for anything else.  I know I need to come back on the days they have their specials.

The restaurant is intimate (seriously, a lot of couples dined here), with awesome Beatles memorabilia, and even better music.  It's nice to see places like this in my neighborhood.
author: Vira P.

description:
food: 
- Yakitori omakase dinner good 4.5/5, you can substitute out things you don't eat. Chicken wings especially good, got an additional order of it. comes with your standard miso soup, rice, and side salad.
- Gyoza: 4/5, real crispy, comes on a sizzling plate. Filling was decent.
- Okonomiyaki pancake: 3/5, nothing special, not worth $17
- Erichan special: 3/5, nothing special, pretty salty, very simple
- Chashu ramen: 2/5, average, meat was tough
- Hiyayakko: 1.5/5, literally tofu out of the box with some green onions and soy sauce. Skip.

service: 2/5, this place is very understaffed. be prepared to receive your dishes out of order (appetizers came last).

just come here for the yakitori. nothing else is memorable.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Halu has great musical memorabilia. This is an eclectic hole in the wall with great offering of tasty food on a stick (Skewers) that are are perfectly done. Ramen broth is spicy and delightful, the portion was huge.  As first timers to Halu, our server, ERICA was DYNAMITE. She elevated our experience with her suggestions and upbeat spirit.  This is definitely off the beatin' path unique kind of Japanese joint.
author: Valerie I.

description:
Ramen is mediocre at best- if you dare, get the spicy kaarage. Don't get the chasumen.

I hear the yakitori is amazing though so I'll go back for that.
author: Mandi W.

description: Incredibly overrated. Waited over an hour for three yakitori plates and ramen. Charged my credit card twice. Go elsewhere.
author: Brian L.

description:
I never had the chance to try this place out mostly because the wait time here was always over an hour and I'm always too hungry to wait. I thought iit was because this place is popping (according to the Yelp reviews) but through my visit here, I learned it's also because the service here is suuupppeer slow. 

I came here on a weekday night, around 5:30pm (only about 30 mins after opening) and was seated immediately. Plus the restaurant was relatively empty, so I was happy that I finally get to try this place with little to no wait (yess!) My happiness was soon diminished as it took almost an hour for me to get my food. I honestly thought at one point that they were just trying to get me super hungry so that everything would taste good. The service here was also not that great. Took me forever to flag the waitress down to get the check, took a while to even get the check, and reached the point where we rather just pay in cash just so we don't have to wait to get our card back before leaving. 

However, I have to admit...this place is one of the better ramen joints in San Francisco. The ramen here tasted good. I got the karaage ramen and even though my karaage was semi soggy in the broth (make sure you request to have them separated!) it was nicely seasoned and fried. The egg was neither hard boiled or half boiled, probably just an overdone half boiled egg. The broth was flavorful and made the entire bowl pretty good in general. My bowl of ramen wasn't perfect but then again it's hard to find okay ramen in San Francisco.


TLDR; Probably one of the better ramen joints in San Francisco but for the wait you get here, I rather drive down to San Mateo.
author: Jenny N.

description:
Went to Halu on a rainy Friday right when it opened. It is a very small and dimly lit restaurant and feels like youre at an old fashioned bar and hole-in-the-wall style atmosphere. There are a row of bar stools in the front and small tables in the back. I chose to sit at the small table in the back with the lamp under it. The server (super friendly and nice!) told us it was the most popular table since it was brightest. There are a bunch of beatles posters everywhere and beatles music playing in the background which gives it a cozy old vibe.

For two people, we ordered and shared a five skewer saikyo chicken set, two beef steak skewers, a karaage ramen, and an okonomiyaki. More than enough food, and took home a fourth of the okonomiyaki. The saikyo set was a bit too exotic for our liking. The gizzard was interesting. Two of them were quite bony, and we did not like the chicken liver. The belly steak was yummy as well as the avocado and guacamole beef skewer. Both were a little too chewy..
I enjoyed the karaage ramen. It came with four big pieces of karaage, corn, red ginger, and onions. The okonomiyaki ($17) is the item to get here. It tasted authentic and reminded me of Japan. 

There are many unique items to try. Food is tasty and a bit on the pricier side but I would come back. It was about $75 bucks total after tips.
author: Christina G.

description:
Walking in to Halu you'll find a cozy, quaint, and friendly restaurant.  We went on a rainy Thursday evening so the crowd wasn't too bad.  We ordered the Kara age ramen with veggie lovers skewer set and grilled mochi w/ soy sauce and nori. Everything was delicious particularly the ramen w/ Broth full of spice and flavor.  The shiitake and trumpet mushroom skewers were my favorites on the veggie set. 

In addition the service was fast, friendly, and very helpful.
author: Dan O.

description: It's rare to find hole in the walls that are this unique! The food was delicious and there were a variety of Japanese dishes that aren't offered at most SF (fake) Japanese restaurants. It's a small restaurant so I wouldn't go with a big group.
author: Mako U.

description:
Had to see what the hype was about.  Got there and signed up for the 30 min wait.  Place is crazy small and they try to run a lean staff.  I see the effort, but I'm about the food.  Most of the food was just salty, saltier or down right crazy salty.   I had the chicken, wings and beef on skewers.  All were just lightly browned and season mainly with salt.  Decorations such as sliced green onion and sliced basil could not masquerade the sodium overdose.  I also got the chicken Karage ramen, which was ok, but with so many other places, that focus on stellar noodles, why come here for that?  

In the end, not worth the wait nor the $$.

-WC foodie
author: Jerry S.

description:
I've been here once before and thought the ramen was mediocre at best - you're better going to Iza Ramen in the Lower Haight.

Yesterday, I tried to go again with a few friends around 8:30. The hostess said it would be 20 minutes for a table, so we grabbed a beer at a bar nearby. We waited one hour for Halu to call us to tell us our table was ready, but they never called, so we stopped back in the restaurant to ask how much longer it would be. They were waiting for a table to clear up, so we waited until the table left. 

They cleared the table and then sat a party that was on the wait list AFTER us. When we went to question why we weren't sat even though we were next on the list, the hostess fumbled and said she didn't realize that we were waiting for our table EVEN THOUGH WE WERE WAITING AT THE RESTAURANT. At this point it had been an hour and 15 minutes since we first put our name on the list. They did nothing to accommodate us at that point, so we left. 

This place isn't worth the wait or the poor service. I won't ever come here again.
author: Gopi And Jake S.

description:
I REALLY REALLY enjoyed my meal here. It's a curbside hole in the wall set-up w/ a Beatles-laden decor scattered about the wall and ceilings.

While the ramen was on par w/ other spots in the city- which is to say above average, I really really did enjoy the Yaki-Tori selection.. For those of you that hail from NY, Halu is a smaller setup similar to Kenka in St. Mark's, replacing the old-scool erotic Japanese artwork w/ Beatles and 70's-80's music.
author: James L.

description:
A "hole in the wall" type restaurant, only seats approximately 30 people. The whole environment screamed BEATLES!!!! which was pretty cool, (:

-Okonomiyaki: Had bits of beef, seafood, and veggies inside! This is really reliant on the sauce and mayo, so ask for more! Tasted really good with the extra sauce but it wasn't fluffy enough for me if that makes sense. I would get this if you want something to fill you up, but other than that this was just mediocre.

:::Skewers:::
-Beef Belly Steak (*MUST GET!*): Very buttery and delicious. The flavors also popped and every bite was simply amazing.

-Beef Tongue: (*MUST GET!*): Tender and flavorful. Wasn't tough at all!

-Tontoro: (*MUST GET!*): if you love fat, I highly recommend this. The tontoro (fatty pork) skewer was juicy and delicious! 

-Chicken Cartilage: The texture was great, but this was slightly too salty for my liking. Also, after the umami from the beef/pork skewers, this was just a bit lacking. I'd say give it a try if you're a chicken cartilage lover like me.

-Chicken Liver: If you love chicken liver, I suggest you get it. The sauce complemented the liver really well.

:::Deep Fried Skewers:::
-Scallops: This was honestly pretty good, but I wouldn't get it again. It was fried perfectly; light and airy. However, there wasn't anything special about this. It was simply fried scallops, no distinct flavors or anything. I do suggest dipping this in mayo or their other sauces.

-Chicken Liver: Nope. I like my liver cooked WELL DONE because pasty consistency makes me cringe. This was cooked, but it was soft and the "melt in your mouth" kind of liver, so I was just not having it. Also, flavors weren't poppin. If you're a liver lover, I suggest you get the regular chicken liver skewer instead.
author: Jackie T.

description: A good restaurant to eat at, mediocre ramen at best not sure about the hipster vibe.
author: Tracy L.

description: WOW, what a great place!!food amazing , the decor, the music , a small bohemian Japanese restaurant with a twist!!!
author: Pamela R.

description: I've been to this place a couple times and love their food! However, I've tried to go there twice recently and both times they've been closed unexpectedly. A little frustrating and makes me not want to make another trip out there.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Sadly, I had the worst ramen ever here last night. The broth is thin, and I might as well have been eating mouthfuls of salt. I left most of the soup. The worst part is, when I told the host, she defended the dish and didn't take it off of the tab. Disappointing customer service. 

On the other hand, I enjoyed the skewers and, if not for the service, would return for those.
author: Paulina F.

description:
Came here on a Friday and got in pretty easily with a ~15 minute wait. 

Standard izakaya fare with wonderfully delicious skewers of various meats and veggies in a really unique and cozy setting. Highly recommend the takoyaki (fried balls of octopus). Price of food for 2 people + 2 beers was $38, which is a good steal for this fun, quirky joint. 

I loved the ambiance (the place is plastered in Beatles posters and funky sings) and the service was wonderful (the waitress kind of us sneaked us in). Will definitely be coming back to this hidden neighborhood spot. Great date spot if you're trying to impress but not spend too much $$
author: Ali F.

description:
The shop itself is really easy to miss because the location is so small and does not stand out in the most obvious way (unless you're a HUGE fan of the Beatles). When you step inside, you're greeted with a great vibe and welcoming atmosphere, from the staff to the music, and the hundreds of Beatles memorabilia gracing the walls of this shop. 

Halu is not a "typical" ramen shop in that it has a specific theme that really makes you remember your time there. The service is GREAT. Extremely polite, outgoing and always check on you from time to time. 

During my visit, I ordered Karaage Ramen (comes with 3 pieces) with extra chasu slices (2 pieces). The broth was very good, and the noodles were soft. While it does not have a lot of toppings like other ramen shops, the meat was plentiful and I still had a good fill after all was said and done. 

The shop is indeed small, so hard to move around with traffic. We had to sit at the bar right next to the entrance of the shop but it was not a problem since my party was not in anyone's way.

As for waiting time: Luckily, we arrived at 6:30pm and were the first names on the list they had. They give wait-listed people a phone call to let them know their seats a ready, so you can go walk around if you don't want to stand on the sidewalk waiting. 

Prices are fair for the food served. Street parking may be a problem for some of you unless you Uber/Lyft here or take other means of public transporation. 

I would definitely come back again to try the skewers. 

Overall, I would recommend this ramen shop. Feel free to check out the photos I've posted of the place!
author: Ryan B.

description:
This tiny shop is incredibly easy to miss! I had passed by it countless times while parking the car after dropping my mom off for grocery shopping, and finally entered it about a week ago with my friend. The shop is a little hole-in-the-wall Japanese restaurant that offers rock music and Beatles decor coupled with yakitori (traditional and fusion) and ramen. 

I entered around 5:15 PM and thankfully there was no wait. The shop began filling up afterwards however. As a note - they offer happy hour (take advantage of it!) but you will have to ask for the menu (seems like it's a secret of some sort). The prices are rather solid - $5 chicken karaage, a few skewer options, and several drink options as well.

My friend and I split a few orders:
Chicken karaage: I am a huge karaage fan, and this one definitely did not disappoint. For $5, you get a reasonable number of pieces and the chicken is tender, well-seasoned, and crispy! Definitely worth a try.
Chicken Stuffed mushrooms: these mushrooms are stuffed with bits of chicken, coated in batter, and deep fried then skewered to be served. Pretty interesting combo, worth getting if you are big on mushrooms.
Chicken skewer with avocado cilantro: The chicken on these skewers is really tender as well. The guac/avocado was underwhelming, having little avocado taste. This is worth getting for the chicken, but don't expect much from the guac.
Chashu ramen: Pretty typical ramen - not the best I've had but definitely still decent. It comes with a few slices of chashu pork and enough to split (they are happy to provide bowls to split) if you are also eating the yakitori.

Overall, the meal was pretty enjoyable. The service is good, the food is decent, and the ambiance is very unique. I would definitely come back for the happy hour, but I would probably not wait for a seat if it is full (you might end up waiting for quite some time).
author: Michael L.

description:
Hmm more of a 3.5 but I wouldn't personally bother to come out to this place again so rounding down to a 3. A friend and I were in the Clement St. area and decided to gave Halu a try. We arrived around 7pm on a Friday night and had about a 30 min wait. Good thing is that you can put your name down and give them your phone number so you can go and eat your heart out on Clement St. before coming back. They do have a small bench outside for sitting, but otherwise best to spend that time wandering the streets. 

Place is really, really small. I came from work so I had my laptop bag and I was bumping everything all over the place. When you walk in, there's a bar on the right and then tables on your immediate left--there's maybe enough traffic space for one person to go in and out. 

Service is friendly. I got the karaage ramen which was good and came out pretty quickly. It was one of those bowls of ramen that tastes really really good in the beginning but then you start to experience significant diminishing marginal utility pretty rapidly. Upon first bite, noodles were al dente and yummy, soup was rich and flavorful, karaage was decent but nothing spectacular. 

But then as I went through the bowl, I ended up really not liking the flavors... the soup ended up feeling extremely oily and not so desirable, the noodles were a little too thin for my liking (btw bowl is thin noodles) and in general it ended up being one of those bowls that's really hard to finish toward the end.


tldr; okay ramen... but nothing great. seems like they have a nice long list of other more izakaya style dishes that we should have tried. we didn't notice them since they're more noticeable on the wall
author: Jasmine X.

description:
First time here & small place (capacity est. 28 person). We ordered the following:

(Skewers)
-Chicken Liver Kushi Katsu (Just OK / $4 for Happy Hour) 
-Pasty Soft Liver (Just OK)
-Belly Steak (OK)
-Chewy Tongue (Good)
-Soft Cartilage Bones (Just OK)
-Juice Tontoro (Below Just OK)
-Deep Fried Scallop (Just OK)

-Okonomiyaki (Good if they can put more sauce & mayo on it) $17

*Servers were friendly
author: Wendy L.

description:
This has become my go to spot for izakaya in the city. Compared to other places, they give you bigger portions for a cheaper price. They also are on Eat24 and Postmates which is a good option if you don't want to deal with the long wait. Oh yes, if you get there late then you'll be waiting for a table for at least an hour. I suggest you get there close to when they open at 5pm. 

Anyway, back to the food. Everything here is flavorful so you can't go wrong with trying something new. That being said, my absolute favorites are the beef belly yakitori (you won't regret ordering this), beef tongue yakitori, chicken cartilage yakitori, mochi wrapped in seaweed with miso butter, chicken liver yakitori, and the bacon wrapped mochi. I haven't tried the ramen yet but I hear that it's delicious as well. 

Can't wait for my next visit!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Very small place. Filled w Beatles posters and Beatles music playing. Not great for groups. Thankfully we came before 6p and snagged a table for 6. My friends come frequently for the tapas. I would only come for Happy hour 5-7p as many of the skewers are discounted. 
Split various dishea of which some are listed below. Friends liked the Sake drinks.

Good:
Bacon wrapped mochi
Seaweed wrapped mochi
Yuzu chicken
Shiso plum chicken 

Just ok:
Avocado chicken- chicken was a bit dry but the avocado sauce was tasty
Chicken heart- didn't really care for the texture
author: Grace C.

description: Came here with girlfriend for dinner date and we generally enjoyed the food. It was decent and overly priced like most izakaya places which we expected. When i checked my card statement couple days later, the cleared amount was WAY HIGHER then what the bill+tip i had paid for at the time. This tells me they clearly rigged and adjusted the bill and or tip amount from what i had wrote down on their copy of reciept. This is very unethical and a terrible move as the food was not bad. But to stoop so low to do such a scammy move and cheat customers is just not right at all. and for this reason, this place deserves a fair 1 star. Hopefully this helps, do yourself a favor and don't come here. Don't take my word for it either as it looks like I'm not the only victim here. Other people have had their bills rigged as well in the past seeing from previous reviews. I mean you could always pay cash to avoid being scammed. But do you really wanna dine at such a shady place? Shame on you Halu.
author: Danny W.

description:
This place is small, but packs a pretty cute ambiance. Great for if you're looking for a hip environment to eat some yakitori and ramen.

I came here last night and it was already full. My friend and I didn't have to wait too long though as some tables cleared up and we got seated immediately. We were both craving ramen so we decided to get the chashu ramen (they have an option of spicy or non-spicy). It came at a decent time and we chowed down. I don't think I was a huge fan of the spicy broth, but the portion sizes were good and there were huge slices of chashu. Overall their ramen isn't anything to rant or rave about as I've had better elsewhere in the city, but isn't bad for if you live closeby and want a quick fix. Service was pretty good especially in such a tight space. I'll probably be back for the skewers!
author: Kathleen S.

description: The bestttttt. Great vibe. great food. The owners and staff are so welcoming- i wish they were open 7 days a week. Love the karaage ramen (chicken on the side) and okonomiyaki.
author: Ariane M.

description:
Wonderful! Terrific,  quirky atmosphere. Gracious, attentive staff. Delicious food! The izakaya dishes are the best.

My favorite was the beef belly. Om nom nom.
author: Miiiiiiiiike S.

description:
I have always wanted to try this place and saw the mixed reviews on ramen and pancake so only opted to order the yakitori and appetizers.

Food: 
(Food rating 3.5/5 = would have been okay not trying it)

Chicken Karaage -$10 standardly done well with crispy batter over 6 big pieces of chicken served with a lemon wedge but pricy 3.5/5

Beef belly steak- $10 for 2 pieces. So juicy, fat and meaty-flavored, very mouth-watering. Get it! 5/5

Shosu (plum) steak skewer- $7.5? For 2 pieces. They ran out of the Guacamole steak skewer. This was only okay in comparison to the beef belly steak. We peaked too soon 3.5/5

Potstickers- $6.5? Homemade and served on a sizzling hot plate so skin was crispy and meat stuffing was juicy and tender, a bit oily but tasty 4/5

Bacon wrapped scallop skewer- $9.5 For 2 skewers and 3 pieces on each skewer. Crisped oily bacon, makes for a sweet juicy, savory scallop. Good note to end on... 4/5

Total: $50 including tax

But then I ended up having a stomachache on the drive home and jumped on the toilet as soon as I got home (tmi lol). Granted, I do have a more sensitive stomach towards food cleanliness and expired/expiring food, and my dinner companion was okay.  

Overall, pricy and everything was decent, beef belly steak was surprisingly good, but the instantaneous stomachache was surprisingly bad... I'm torn. I do like that it's a decent yakitori place in the city (my go-to yakitori is in San Mateo) and a hole-in-the-wall, filled with Beatles memorabilia. But if this is really food poisoning like another reviewer says, straight to no stars cuz that is a no-no.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I had high hopes for this place. After getting to the Golden Gate Bridge around 7 and learning that parking was free after 8, we decided to grab a bite to eat to pass the time. I pulled up Yelp and Halu came up with great reviews. We headed over and a waitress put our name down. We waited around twenty to thirty minutes, which I was fine with. But then, after we were finally seated and had ordered, our food took FOREVER. Granted, the waitress had said that ramen was taking longer that day (also suggested we order some appetizers in the meantime), we didn't think that it would take over an hour. Well, it did. We enjoyed about an hour and ten minutes of twiddling our thumbs and listening to our stomachs growl. 

The waiter was nice though, and thanked us for waiting when we finally got our ramen. I was eager to forget about the whole waiting and enjoy this highly esteemed ramen. Unfortunately, it just wasn't amazing. The egg was very cold, and that's pretty much all I remember about the bowl. It wasn't bad, but it just wasn't worth the wait. I guess I just assumed the ridiculous wait was due to them making everything on the spot, and thus was expecting a piping hot bowl where everything was at least still warm. 

I'll probably stick to Orenchi from now on. The wait might be monstrous, but at least I know I'll get an amazing bowl of heaven within a reasonable amount of time (~15 mins tops in my experience) after being seated.
author: Rachel W.

description: Everything there is EXTREMELY salty. Would be a lot better if they didnt salt the food so much. I had to drink four cups of water. As the other reviews say, its kind of expensive for some meat on a skewer. The 4 potato slices on a stick was $3, which is the same price as an entire bag of potatoes in Guangzhou, China.
author: Kenny Saken W.

description: It says on yelp and on their door that they close at 11. It was 9:50pm and they say they're closed. Umm..okay. Not going to try them again.
author: Pamela P.

description:
Meat meat MEAT!! nice little whole in the wall serving up some major skewer action. 

We came before happy hour ended, so we took advantage of some beef tongue, taikyo set (skewers of heart, skin, gizzard and liver) some other beef with a green sauce that didn't add any flavor, belly, karage, enoki bacon, onomiyaki pancake , and some good ol sapporo 

Honestly, the experience was like Russian roulette, I don't really remember half the things I ate but overall, I would say the beef here is solid quality, but lacking flavor. Even that one skewer with the green sauce was meh, didn't taste like anything! And against the advice of fellow yelpers, we still ordered the onomiyaki pancake and yup, really doughy and probably wouldn't have ordered it had we known. 

The best skewer for me was probably the enoki bacon, really juicy. 

Overall, cute little joint, super hole in the wall as it was next to a Chinese 99 cent store type, and the happy hours snacks are not bad too!
author: Sandra L.

description: The chasu-men is legit here. Very comparable to Miki on Balboa. If you like chicken and their organs, you should get the saikyo set which includes skewers of chicken liver, skin, cartilage, and heart.
author: Edwin N.

description:
500sq.ft. Of home cooked style Japanese food. The wait is worth it.

Katsu just means "kabob": meat lovers Katsu is a good variety, scallops are fried, okras are delicious and fries and Ramen is decent (a bit salty for my taste, but good)
author: Mon F.

description:
Relatively convenient even on a Saturday night at 7pm.  First, there's a small parking lot literally right next door.  Second, there's a great bar with tons of beer on tap one block away (Richmond Republic Draught House), so you're not twiddling your thumbs while waiting for your table.  For our party of 2, it took less than 30 minutes to get seated.

We tried a ton of different things:
