- Beef belly (5/5) - Absolutely awesome.  Well-marinated, nicely marbled, and perfectly cooked.  This was the best dish of the night.
- Chicken heart (4/5) - Firm and crunchy - very tasty.
- Chicken gizzard (4/5)
- Chicken skin (4/5) 
- Chicken liver (3/5)
- Chicken tendon? (3/5)
- Okonomiyaki (4/5) - Nice and filling, with a good mix of different savory flavors.  A great dish to share.
- Pork Jowl (4/5) - Fatty and flavorful, served with a mustard dip.  Good, but not quite as good as at Sozai.
- Chicken stuffed mushroom (4/5) - Basically a chicken meatball inside of a mushroom.
- Seaweed-wrapped mochi (2/5) - Not a huge fan of this, as it was definitely on the salty side.

Overall, everything was really well seasoned, and it was a really enjoyable meal in a funky, cozy environment.  Would definitely come back!
author: Simon L.

description: We heard about this restaurant through an article in the Chronicle that highlighted the great food and  owner's love of The Beatles. We were so happy with the friendly service of his family who now runs the restaurant. Rock memorabilia is all over the walls. While it is a low-key, not fancy environment, it has lots of heart, character and reasonable pricing given the very high-quality food.  We would absolutely go back. Highly recommend. Thanks.
author: Larry M.

description:
Overall, below average Japanese restaurant, but with character.  I can see how some people absolutely love this place because of the atmosphere, however the food quality and preparation does not meet my standard.

We went to this place with high expectations of ramen after reading previous reviews.  Walked by it twice and couldn't find it, it is quite literally a hole-in-the-wall.  The music was great.  The server was very intense, in a traditional Japanese manner.  We were seated immediately and then she took our order right away.  
The ramen was decent, but the meat tasted over-boiled.  I got the lava-spicy while my friends got regular spicy.  They were disappointed and needed more chili to spicen it up.  Also, the egg is our favorite part and everyone's egg was hard-boiled instead of soft-boiled, .  
The restroom is very small and I hit my head and stumbled around trying to get in it, same on the way out.  Also it is lit in black light.
author: Josh L.

description: Tiny hole-in-the-wall with a lot of character (60's music and Beatles decor). Was able to snag a table for 4 (luck!). We tried the ramen, which had a nice basic broth and thin ramen noodles (the spicy is nice and spicy). The yakitori was delicious, we chose bacon wrapped scallops (how can you go wrong) and chicken with scallions (yum). We ordered the gyoza which came out on a sizzling platter, these were not frozen from a bag gyoza! They were delicious. I also wanted to try some of their katsu. We got the chicken thighs and the stuffed mushrooms, both were very yummy, but the mushrooms were very new to me, so they were a pleasant surprise. We had drinks too, overall the cost for 4 of us sampling and sharing was not bad for such delicious food. This is a tiny place, so prepare yourself for a wait if you are not there early (and don't leave a bad review just because of a wait, come on...).
author: Jaime G.

description: I love the beatles memorabilia everywhere. Not to mention their ramen and endless options for skewers. Vegetarian ramen is my go to here. Noodles are on the harder side which I enjoy.
author: Celine P.

description:
It is extremely rare that a place can do both yakitori and ramen so well!! 

Other than traditional yakitoris, they also have some Halu specials, such as a carne sada steak and yuzu chicken wings. The fried mochi wrapped in seaweed was so chewy (in a good way) but tad too salty. 

Ramen was perfectly cooked and the broth was super flavorful. When we asked the server about the broth, we were told that they never stop cooking it! 

Service was great too! And awesome place to go a Sake tasting! $10-$15 for 3 shots! 

Prob one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in SF!

Minus one star for the place is not the most clean as it is filled with memorabilia. I just try not to look at the dust :D
author: Katherine C.

description: I travel to Japan fairly often and love yakitori. Halu is legit. The sunagimo is excellent and the hatsu is just right. I'll be going back often!
author: Jon A.

description: Took a while to be seated because it was super busy which is understandable.  Got seated. After checking out menu I was ready to order. I told one of the waitresses I was ready. She said the other waitress will be with you. Ok, that's fine if she wasn't our waitress. It's a very small restaurant (seats about 25 people or so), therefore, you can see and hear everything. I find it annoying she walked by several times and did not notify or signal "my waitress". Waited for approx 5 mins. Nothing. I told her a second time I was ready to order. She whispered something to my waitress. But again, nothing. Now probably approx 15 mins my waitress looks over to me. I waved.  While walking the 5 steps over to my table she cleared another table's check and served another customer's drink. Is it me? Am I being too demanding? The fact that I asked 3 times and waited 15-20 mins to be served?
author: Jen L.

description: This is one of the best Japanese style tapas bar I have had the privilege to try! Not only do they play great, feel-good 60s' Beatles! But their fried squid is to die for! The service is great (the wait is completely worth it!) if you are visiting San Francisco and staying in the inner Richmond, this is definitely worth going to!
author: Gaelle F.

description: The food was incredible i'll give it that, but when i signed the check i left a small tip because that's was my spending amount. And before we left two workers came to my partner and i and started asking why we tipped so low and what they could do to improve and were over me just pushing me to make a bigger tip saying "where's my lunch. obey for tomorrow?". Her service was friendly up until that point and she completely ruined our date night. That is unacceptable, and i would know, i've been a server for a long time. Unacceptable and will not recommend to anyone who has a proffered spending amount unless you want to run into this issue.
author: Andrea M.

description:
Before Mission was infested by hipsters from Facebook and Google who rode the inconspicuous buses to and from work, it was the Mission frequented by real hipsters with real creative jobs who went to Burning Man before it became so cliche. That was before my awakening. 

Two years ago when I rediscovered the Mission, I went on a search for the hippest places and stumbled onto an article: 48 Hours in the Mission by New York Times. I had, of course, neglected to read the publication date, which, of course, ironically, was 5 years in the past. No wonder Weird Fish, Savannah Jazz and 500 Club had no wait time. I felt like a fool afterwards, though, ever since then, I've caught on. The Chapel, Mission Control (aka underground club), Viracocha, and obscure Argentinean beer and empanada places were among my discoveries.   I showed up at Lolinda when it just opened and was hip and I ordered Icelandic beer at Mission Chinese aka Lung Shan before it opened up its east village outpost in New York. 

You ask, wtf and why is it at all relevant to Halu? Well, it's very. very. relevant. For one, I needed to know that I have since risen from the ashes and I have since stayed ahead of the trend. Incoming Halu and GQ Nov 2013 issue. Halu was mentioned by a jet setter who frequented SF and recommended Halu. But that's not it.  I knew of Japanese bar food from my old stumbling ground in Toronto. I in fact had failed to get into a couple of those joints due to overcrowd. Incidentally, if you have not been to Toronto, you are not a real foodie. It has the best food scene in the East Coast. Ab Fab. But I digress. So we went for Chicken Skin, Chicken gizzard, Beef Tongue, Octopus, Fried Mochi, Steak, Pork, Yuzi Chicken, ramen, Peppers, chicken katsu, beer and sake. 

Ruben and Andrew were not so keen on trying gizzard or skin of the chicken. Though they seemed to be Ok with it. White boys, what can you say?  Scallop fried was delicious. In fact fried mochi took the crown for how good it was. Shannon and I were a bit more adventurous, we liked the skin, the gizzard, liked the tongue. 

Odd combo if you ask me, but it works. Sake was delicious, I had two bottles which perhaps was not a great idea considering I'm Asian and a lightweight, But I loved every drop of it. 

Seeing that the Mission was now overcrowded with hipsters who don't have great taste but pretend to have (see my review of Haven), I had been long waiting for something authentic, innovative and surprising, not to mention, a lesser hipsters infested neighborhood. I had suspected Richmond had it all. It did. As they say, the proof is in the pudding, or in this case, the proof is in the gizzard. 

GQ November 2013 was way better than New York Times 48 Hours in the Mission circa 2008. I have redeemed myself, at last. 

Note to those who are looking for a date restaurant, especially if you are a Caucasian man and you finally landed an Asian date.  Yoko Ono on the wall along with Beatles and endless British pub beer. You ought to be proud of yourself, for bringing hard-to-find Asian date to this restaurant. She'll be impressed, and you will feel like you actually managed to outdo yourself.
author: Victoria E.

description: Everything tastes really like Japanese style! So delicious! And in-n-out decorations and design are so typical and traditional like Izakayas in the corners of Japanese streets. Guessing the owner may be a fan of Beatles Cus the posts are pasted all over the wall. Waitresses are so attentive and considerate. Highly recommended!
author: Crystella FaFa Z.

description: Went to San Francisco and ended up my trip eating here . Although the place from the outside does not look very inviting, the ramen was great. Definitely will go back when I'm up there
author: Gabi V.

description: This quirky little spot is by far my favorite place to eat in the inner Richmond. Everything I have had on the menu is beyond delicious, and the staff are all lovely. Walking in the door just makes me smile.
author: Kaitlin S.

description:
Meat lover? Want to try ONE skewer of The best meats instead of ordering a set of 2?

Get the secret menu Jenny Set, 3 skewers of my absolute favorites, which include:
- KUROBUTA or kurobuta sausage with shichimi sprinkled Karashi mustard
- TONTORO or pork jowl
- HARAMI or beef flat steak

Hungry for more? I would also get another order of Tori-Gawa (chicken skin) and iichiko yuzu liqueur to go with this. 

Enjoy!
author: Jenny W.

description: I came here three times and I've always had the ramen, but that will be no more. Each time I've had it, it was salty, but not as bad as the last time. The ramen was too salty and the broth was not too creamy and I couldn't enjoy it. However, the skewers were good and well seasoned. The waitress was very nice though, but didn't know how to handle the situation when my friend and I told her that the ramen was salty. I wonder if many people ever let the chef know?
author: Mandy D.

description: They gave us the wrong order(too much food) but didn't charge us at the end. The pork ramen made my bf sick and felt weird on the stomach. We checked the yelp reviews after the meal and many have said they got food poisoning from their ramen! Definitely not going back there! Small place and very squished.
author: Potatoe Q.

description:
A hole-in-the-wall shop that's perfect for small parties of 2-4.  It could be hard to miss (on 8th Ave.), but the signage outside is very clear.  Upon entering all the walls decor scream Beatles; there is even a replica Beatles drum set above the main doorway!  Clearly, the owners and/or the workers enjoy the Beatles, and want to introduce or encourage their patrons to enjoy their passions with them. 

After I received my food, one of the waitresses noticed I had my phone on Instagram; instantly she tells me "#halusf".  I took my picture, like many other Asians, and posted on IG. Food: ordered a chashu ramen with pork broth.  Perfect food item for a chilly evening; portions were just right and it wasn't too oily.  Go again, yes, but be aware of the time of day: evenings are easier to find parking than afternoons.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I had a fantastic dinner at Halu last night, with plenty of grilled offal on a stick and beer.  As others have said, this is a very tiny restaurant with very little seating - we took the last available seats at 5:45pm and I'm pretty sure that the people who showed up right after us must have waited more than 40 minutes. 

The highlight of the dinner was definitely the outstanding yakitori. We had grilled tontoro (pork jowl) which was fatty and crunchy - much better than pork belly, chicken gizzards, chicken hearts, beef tongue, and beef belly (accurately described in the menu as "melts in your mouth"). We also split a bowl of chasiu ramen which which had excellent broth and noodles, and a seafood okonomiyaki (pancake) which was pretty good. Everything was accompanied with plenty of Sapporo beer. 

The decor is very interesting - everything is Beatles themed, and the soundtrack for the night was fun 60's music.  Good times, and I'll be sure to come back again!
author: Allen T.

description:
Like every restaurant, they have their good things and their not-so-good.

Good:

1. Friendly Service.
2. Tasty broth.
3. Price seems fair-ish on the ramen. 

Not-So-Good:

1. The chicken gets soggy almost immediately in the soup. And it's not the best chicken to begin with.
2. Small and crowded.
author: Cori N.

description:
It was absolutely delicious! especially, the boneless chicken noodle soup!
And the shrimp spring roll.
And it's right here in my neighborhood
author: adriana p.

description: Cool little place. Great atmosphere and service. Very personable staff, with grade-A recommendations. 8 out of 5 stars, we're definitely coming back.
author: Vincent P.

description: Katana-ya karage ramen is wayyy better. Small place but that didn't deter me to try it. It just lack tastes and for what we paid. $38 for 2 bowls of ramen is pricey
author: Tasha L.

description:
Small restaurant with Beatles galore. Service was friendly but a tad slow. The menu does warn that they operate in a very small kitchen so food may take a while. The music playing and the memorabilia covering the walls should keep you busy. I tried the: 

Beef & Veggie Okonomiyaki: The highlight of the night. It was crispy and soft with tasty bits of beef, topped with sauce, green onions and pickled ginger. I could have just eaten a whole one for dinner. 

Lava Ramen / Karaage Ramen: Huge bowls. I wasn't impressed with the ramen broth, although I thought the karaage broth was tastier than the lava. Also, the noodles and the toppings weren't very exciting. Both bowls were spicy and definitely packed the heat (the karaage can be ordered not spicy). 

Order the okonomiyaki and stick to the yakitori, which seems to be quite popular here.
author: Maya S.

description:
Halu is cool because they decorate the small little restaurant with an abundance of Beatles collectibles. They also play oldie music in the background, so i guess it really takes you back to the 60's/70's if you grew up jamming to those tunes. If you sit in the bar area, you'll see a row of Japanese Premium Beer lined up on the counter. Each of those beer can run you up from $8-$12, so be careful where you point to!

A couple of skewers are always fun, especially if you order things like the bacon-wrapped mochi or exotic things like those chicken/beef internal organ stuff (hope im not grossing anyone out!). I think most of the skewers just taste like oily crispy stuff, but they're fun to try. I think the $4 and up price tag would be more justified if I am able to distinguish the skewers by taste.

I come to Halu for their ramen though, so that's the most important part of the review. The Lava Ramen looks Red Hot Chili Peppers, but it's actually not too spicy. I don't like that their egg is not soft-boiled (the yolkiness is soooo important) and they put a lot of bean sprouts in the broth that it gets into my way of slurpping the ramen. So overall, i don't think it's the best bowl of ramen ever, but it's still decent.

I think this is a cool place to just enjoy the vibe with some beer/sake and snacks/skewers. I wouldn't stand in line just to wait and try their ramen.
author: Ringo M.

description:
Small, quaint Japanese restaurant that is Beatles themed.  There is limited seating but food comes out pretty quick! I tried their main ramen dish (okay noodles and okay broth), karage don buri (pretty good !!) and the best Japanese pancake with juicy octopus!!! Will definitely come back again for the pancake dish... 

Sake warmed up was a nice pairing on a chilly day too.
author: Sunny L.

description: First visit there two weeks ago was ok. I had ramen which was tasty and comforting but I had to wait about 40 minutes. They brought me a sample of karaage chicken to apologize which was a nice touch. I hadn't complained. Tonight my boyfriend and I stopped in and put our name in their list. They said they'd call us when the table was ready in about 20 minutes. They didn't call us for an hour. We had already decided to just go somewhere else. I like the Beatles decor and the black lit bathroom but don't know if I'll return a third time.
author: Debra M.

description: Best Japanese restaurant in SF in my humble opinion. Japanese is not just about sushi. It's yakitori, kushi katsu and small dishes and Halu has it all. It's a family owned and they are lovely. It also has a Beatles theme that makes it cozy and it just adds to the warm home cooked ambiance that is has.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Quirky and fun little Japanese izakaya! 

Beatles memorabilia line the walls, Beatles music liven up the space, and the aroma of freshly grilled meats fill the air.

That's what you don't wanna miss here, the excellent yakitori. The grilled shisito peppers, pork cheeks, and beef tongue are my favorites. At about $2-3 a skewer it's best to share a bunch of dishes for the table and explore something interesting from their sake/beer menu.  Through the night the place gets noticeably louder.   

The ramen isn't the greatest but definitely solid, I got the lavu chashu ramen ($12.5) which was like a spicy oil slick of generous and "tender enough" pork pieces. Hearty bowl! I heart ramen.

(I prematurely deleted all pics from this night!) Sucks! 

What didn't suck was the okonomiyaki. What makes this version so great is texture. I remember it like yesterday. Crisp on the outside while being soft and gooey on the inside. We ordered the seafood one ($15) but couldn't distinguish any of Nemo's friends in there so I'd recommend saving a few bucks by getting the veggie and beef ($10). (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/halu-san-francisco?select=57HhgYvmHiW__N0dEVcIjg#57HhgYvmHiW__N0dEVcIjg)

~ Notes ~ 
*Given the size of the resto, parties of 4 is about the max you want to do. For my group of 3 on a Thurs, it was a 30 minute wait. 

*They text you when your table is ready. At least they did for us. 

*My type of hole in the wall. Parking took about 10 minutes. 

Next up, Ippuko in Berkeley. 
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/halu-san-francisco?select=FiAiW7iIp1XVBaR6XOar8w#FiAiW7iIp1XVBaR6XOar8w)
author: Earl G.

description: Stopped in on the early side one night , place looked small warm and they had Ramen . First off the girl serving was nice and welcoming , the place had some great music playing Creedance Beatles etc.... ordered a spicy bowl of Ramen which was well SPICY! had a large happy hour beer $5 and some GYOZA ..... all was good. My only observation and its very common in SF , the prices are not on the sky side , except for the happy hour specials your paying prices that are 20% higher. Welcoming to the SAN FRANCISCO effect. I would go back and try other items the place was cozy clean and friendly .... sometimes those combinations are hard to find in the Clement corridor .
author: F J.

description:
Located on 8th Avenue rather than Clement or Geary Streets, Halu is a tiny, but cozy, Japanese restaurant tucked away in the Inner Richmond district. They offer a great selection of yakitori, ramen, donburi, and drinks. I've been here a couple times so far and haven't tried much, but I recommend the yakitori.

Salmon onigiri --
I was expecting a rice ball with a thick (or at least noticeable) layer of salmon in the middle. However, Halu's salmon onigiri only had small salmon bits dispersed throughout the ball. And it didn't hold together nicely either -- the rice ball quickly fell apart as soon as I took the first bite.

Yakitori --
There's a large selection of yakitori here -- beef, pork, chicken, seafood, and vegetable -- so you're bound to find a couple of options that are worth trying. I've had a small handful from the yakitori dinner special. The chicken meatball was flavorful and marinated nicely. Stuffed mushrooms were filled with ground chicken that was juicy, and the mushrooms were very meaty. Chicken wings were moist and fell off the bone so easily. Flat steak was a bit chewy, but good, and it was cooked medium, which is surprising because the meat was so thin to begin with. Okra was simple, but still tasted great and had a nice, non-rubbery texture. Bacon wrapped scallop was delicious (but bacon wrapped anything is delicious).

Karaage ramen --
This ramen had five pieces of deep fried white meat chicken that were very juicy and tender. The batter got soggy quickly, which is a no-brainer because the karaage sits in a bowl of soup. The broth was decent, not too salty, but very oily. The ramen noodles had a firm, chewy texture. A majority of the bowl consisted of the noodles too. Although they're very generous with the noodles, the overall proportions were off -- there was just too much noodles in the end.

Butter corn ramen --
This ramen comes with two slices of butter, which helped make the broth thicker and creamier, yet not too heavy. The spicy version definitely has a lot of heat! I had to drink a lot of water to subside the spiciness. This ramen came with two types of pork. The chasu was nice and tender, but not too fatty. The other pork was fork-tender, but it seemed a little cold, like it came out of the fridge and placed into the bowl shortly before serving.

As indicated on their menu, ALL ramen broths are meat-based, so Halu isn't a vegetarian friendly place for ramen. The service is very friendly, but wait time for food varies based on how busy the place is. First time we came here, the restaurant was packed and it took 30 minutes for food to arrive at the table. Second time we came here, it wasn't as busy and our food took less than 10 minutes. Halu probably holds no more than thirty customers, and they're nice enough to call you, letting you know your table is ready, if you don't want to stand outside waiting.
author: Priscilla W.

description: They forgot our food. We've waited over an hour to eat some ramen. At this point, I don't even care if the food is good because of the poor service. The food also isn't good though. The broth is super oily. I will not be coming back and I recommend you to skip this place.
author: Jade V.

description: Food is good, service so-so, venue is very small and cramped. I feel like I have had better ramen and could have gone somewhere that didn't have as long as a wait.
author: Monica L.

description: Wow, what a hidden gem!! This place is like a tiny time capsule back into the 70's with all things Beatles. Once you get over how old (and probably dusty) everything is, you'll find that the restaurant has a very unique and cool vibe. AND they serve delicious food! Definitely get the tako wasabi if you're drinking because they pair so well. Just... get... everything.
author: Thao T.

description:
In my book, Halu is the only Yakitori place in the city. Those other places are not yakitori. They are little piece of meat on stick for 10 bucks. I can put meat on stick too, but god damn it, it's not Yakitori. It's Yakitori-product.

Every time we come here, conversation stops to a minimal when the food comes. Because you cannot savor every bite unless you stop talking and concentrate. Every time we come, we ask ourselves why we don't come more often. 

It's probably good we don't, because one of the best things you'll ever eat, is the Beef Belly. oForget other cuts, beef belly is it. 

They also really know how to do their chicken parts. Get the Exotic chicken sampler for a sampling of heart, liver (amazingly done so that it just melts in your mouth), gizzards, soft bones, and chicken skin. My favorite? The liver and the soft bones. But also I like the heart. And the gizzard. I guess rather, I should say I like everything but the skin... it's just a little much for me. (Whatever you call a little much when you have a meal of chicken parts and beef belly).

Also a must get - Erichan's Special. Mochi wrapped in seaweed, with a little yakitori sauce on the mochi. Another, shuts-you-up dish.

The ramen, also must get. The broth is so incredibly porky, but it's not overly fatty / oily like many tonkatsumen.

I don't have to describe the greatness of the beatles decor and hole-in-wall''d ness and the general Japanese authentic-ness of this place, as others have mentioned very much.

Halu is a dying kind. Precious hole-in-the-walls, that is just about unpretentious good food. And that is all.
author: Bonnie H.

description: Pretty decent izakaya with a really great vibe/decor/soundtrack (beatles mostly). Their yakitori is excellent but sadly the okonomiyaki was too mushy without enough cabbage to give it some internal structure. We went pretty early and didn't really have to wait which I hear is a rarity.
author: Misha T.

description:
Good foods
Friendly staffs 
Beatles BGM 
Kids friendly 
No high chair and changing table
author: Mayu S.

description:
First time ramen eater here... I called to place an order for pick up and didn't know exactly what to order, I had read some reviews about the ramen with chicken and the potato pancake looking thing. The girl on the other end of the phone was HILARIOUS, she helped me decide. I got both :) 

THIS PLACE IS MY NEW FAVORITE FOOD OF ALL 

Hella small, EVERYTHING Beatles. Did I mention small?? 

5 star- flavor of combo pancake thingy, ramen with chicken and super funny staff.
author: Britt S.

description: A tiny neighborhood gem with heartfelt service and food.  We went on a weeknight at 6:45PM and the place was hopping!  A table opened up after a short wait and we were greeted warmly.  There are a number of menus posted on the walls with specials and combos that aren't on the printed menu, so take your time to take it all in.  The yakitori were excellent - flavors popped.  If you're in the area be sure to try it!
author: Mike O.

description:
Oishii!!! Hello Halu! It was a chilly evening and bf and I were in the mood for some type of soupy noodles...but not pho or anything Chinese. Halu to the rescue! It's a little place and there's easily a line but we were lucky enough to snag one of the last set of seats at the bar. The place is filled with The Beatles memorabilia as well as a huge poster of Hendrix playing a left-handed guitar right-handed.

We started off with two sets or yakitori - beef and chicken gizzards. Both were cooked perfectly. I think it's easy to over cook the gizzards bc I've had it at other places and they were too tough and inedible. Halu does yakitori well! We also had the wasabi octopus (raw). It far exceeded my expectations. It was amazing! Tons of wasabi flavor and so so delicious. Yes, the appearance and texture is slimy but once you get over that, it's so good! 

We came for the ramen so of course, we had to get that too. I had the pork ramen while bf had the beef with corn and butter ramen. Yes, it comes with 2 slabs of butter. Looked good but I was too afraid to try too much of that broth for the sake of my cholesterol shooting through the roof. First, the bowls are huge! The ramen was probably one of the best I've ever had. The perfect texture - chewy goodness. Second, the broth was flavorful and not filled with tons of MSG. There was a huge slab of pork in my bowl...score! I was so stuffed after finishing my bowl of ramen. Yes, I finished it...and almost regretted it 10 minutes afterwards. It's ok, I made it a point to work out extra hard the next day. 

I'd be giving 5 stars, but it took really long for us to get our ramen (30 minutes). Other than that, all was great. Bathroom was also tiny but very clean and had a lot of little posters and fun hello kitty knick knacks in there. The service was good too...the waitresses were super friendly and courteous.

We only heard 1 Beatles song during the whole hour and half we were there. I think more Beatles music would be more appropriate. Thank you for playing Led Zeppelin - Staircase to Heaven! Bf almost wanted to get up and jam the air guitar to the solo!
author: Liv A.

description:
Totally passed this place even though we were looking for it. It's a small mom and pop restaurant/hole in the wall (in the best way possible).

This place is filled with Beatles memorabilia and you have a whole bunch of cool stuff to look at while you're waiting for your food. And you can't miss the sign, they have cold beer here too.

I love places that speak the language of the type of food they make. I mean, it makes perfect sense. Japanese restaurant + Japanese speaking waitresses/cooks = LEGIT.

I shared the Yakitori Omakase Dinner special for $19.50 which included a variety of skewers including beef, chicken, okra, shrimp and stuffed mushrooms. The meal also includes, rice, salad and my favorite: miso soup. This was the perfect size to split amongst two people.

Oishii!!! ^_^ (Delicious!)
author: Sammie T.

description:
Holy balls is this place incredible! It's tiny though so don't plan on coming with a lot of ppl or be prepared for a long wait. The spicy karraage ramen is truly the best ramen I've had in my life! 

Accompanied with some great Japanese beer, grilled shishito peppers and grilled bacon-wrapped mochi and you have yourself the best damn meal money can buy. And yes, their prices are awesome and pretty damn inexpensive. Can't recommend enough!
author: Jeremy T.

description:
I would have given 5 stars, but because of the long wait, I had to deduct one. Firstly, the hostess said we could sit in about 15-20 mins, a table just paid and should be getting up shortly. 40 mins later, the same group was still sitting there. That's just plain rude for that group, considering the place is not that big and there are still people coming in to eat! The hostess/waitresses needed to be a bit more assertive to get these people up and moving. 

Anyhoo, by the time we sat to eat it was already 9:30pm (which in East coast terms is 12:30am). We ordered almost everything the menu since we were ravenous. I can't even remember everything at this point, but there was a spicy chicken ramen, the mochi thing, the breaded and fried scallops (one of my favorites), the yakitori sampler, among others. I don't even need to list everything out because it was all fantastic! I want to come back. I'm dreaming about it. 

The service was great during our time there, it just started out wonky.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Two friends and I arrived on a Wednesday night. We walked in, were told that the wait was 20 minutes, and gave them a name and phone number. We left, came about 20 minutes later, and were seated. The ramen selection seemed pretty limited. I did not see the typical flavors (eg: miso, tonkotsu.) Each of us ordered ramen: one chashu (pork and two karaage (deep-fried chicken). 

After being seated, we waited about 40 min for the food to arrive. The wait was NOT worth it. 

The broth was humble (read: plain). I usually have trouble finishing bowls of soup and usually take the rest home, but I did not this time because I didn't even enjoy the ramen enough to do so. Their Beatles memorabilia was more impressive than the ramen.

Also, as we started eating, the waitress was calling my friend's phone number. This means that if we did not come into the restaurant without being called first, we possibly would have had to wait an HOUR instead of 20 minutes. 

Maybe their other menu items are better, but I don't think I'll be coming back.

Sorry.
author: Quan T.

description:
The first time I went to this place, I loved it. The broth was perfect, there was a good amount of ramen, and even the appetizers were good. However, this second time around, I brought one of my friends because I was so excited to show him what a little gem I found. This was one of my worse experiences.

Even though there was no wait, the food took forever. It's like once they seat us, they forget about us until they see us just sitting there twirling our wooden chopsticks out of boredom, waiting to have our order taken. I ordered the pork ramen while my friend ordered the vegetarian one. We also asked for gyoza and agedashi tofu as soon as we sat down so it would come out first since we were so hungry. 

The ramen took 20 minutes to come out. They came out before the appetizers did. I was a little annoyed but then again I realized it was ramen and most of the ingredients were already cooked. But once we were done eating, we had to wait another 15-20 minutes for our appetizers! Really?! We had to ask the waitress twice to make sure they didn't forget about us. Turns out, they gave our appetizers to a table that came after we did. Our waitress wasn't even apologetic! She simply asked if we wanted to cancel and my friend really wanted the gyoza and tofu so we just waited. I was beyond irritated at this point. What horrible customer service that night. And they weren't even packed. I guess since they get so many customers every night, it doesn't hurt them if they lose one or two in the process of occasional crappy customer service.
author: Cathy N.

description:
Really good.
Get there early or prepare to wait in a queue.
We came in for their yakitori and we were not disappointed.
Favorite was the beef tongue and the chicken skin
author: Geordie E.

description: This place is dope. The theme is brilliant. A small cozy restaurant, not too many seats so you might have to wait but the food is amazing, small skewers, super well seasoned and cooked to perfection. Definitely need to come try this out.
author: Tan D.

description:
This place is tiny and small. 

I looked at the yelp reviews to decide what I should order...so I decided I'll get the lava ramen. So you know when some restaurants tell you it is "spicy," it just has a slight kick to it and you can add more and more spices to make it burn. Well, this one definitely is spicy in the first few sips! No doubt about it - this ramen is spicy! I do like the ramen overall. It is a large bowl and decent for its price. 

I had an awkward experience at this place with the tables. Since it's such a small location, we were asked to move over to the next table to create a new table for a party of two. No big deal. But getting out was awkward because there was no space in between our table. Overall, this place is TINY! 

I do like the skewers though. There's definitely some unique ones. 

Summary: Spicy, tasty ramen, in a tiny little restaurant.
author: Margaret L.

description: First time here, recommended by a server from Delfina's. It was a great introduction of Japanese food. Loved every bite!
author: Patricia S.

description:
Don't know why people here keep complaining about the wait.  If you want consistency and the best yakitori, you gonna have to wait.  Recommendation, come an hour early, put your name down, have some beers at Stein's.  They'll call you.

Whoever compares this place to Kitaro gots to get the F**K outta here.  Stick with your steak and potatoes and move to Boise, Idaho.  Or to the one that complains when the noise is too loud.  It's an IZAKAYA MUTHAF**KER! - Japanese drinking establishment, suppose to be LOUD!!!  Dipshits don't know what's up, better check yo self before you reck yo self, foo.

Eri chan and her fam do it right all the time.

Probably my favorite restaurant in SF.
author: Kevin L.

description:
This was definitely a little hole in the wall. We were there right before it opened and we were first.  about 15 minutes after it opened the place was packed. We ordered the chasu men and it was delicious. It came out quick and hit the spot on a cold SF day. The broth was creamy and the pork was soft. We also ordered the beef belly, in all it's fatty goodness. 
The only reason it's not a 5 was because our calamari came after our bill even though we ordered it at the same time as everything else. Overall it was pretty good.
author: Sheree C.

description:
Halu has to be one of my favorite ramen joints in SF hands down. It's a little hole in the wall right on 8th ave between Geary and Clement. Their spicy karaage ramen is top notch. I like to order the karaage on the side because i like it to retain the crispiness when I bite into the chicken. 

cute japanese owners, Beatles themed throughout the restaurant, delicious flavorful ramen - I don't care if I have to wait for a table or that the restaurant is dinky small. the only time Halu has disappointed me is when I come by and see that they're closed.
author: Ava F.

description: Huge fan! been there twice already within a week. My wife and I used to go to Ippuku a lot in Berkeley but since we discovered Halu, we no longer need to drive across the bay. Great selections of Yakitori and Ramen, also love their porridges. Everything tastes so good, gotta try them all! Place is very small so better get there early. Parking is easy to find. We will be back!
author: William C.

description:
Was hoping for much more from this place. Service was terrible. Ordered dinner and it too over an hour for my wife's dinner to arrive. Mine never came. After my wife finished mine had not even arrived.  

I didn't go out to dinner just to watch her eat.  We had a babysitter and had to leave. I asked for the check. No offer for a discount no apologies.  Just the check.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
The bomb diggity. 

This place is a go-to spot for me. Parking isn't toooo bad on clement so that's nice. Try the chashu ramen, try the karaage ramen, try the beef tongue, try the beef belly. Yuuusss! 

That is all.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Beatles paraphernalia, endless yakkatori, and great timing makes this place a hit!

First, love the decor and music. I couldn't help but stare at every bit of detail placed here. Now I enjoy minimalistic interiors but this place has the perfect balance of intrigue but not distraction (woops designerd rant).

We had:
- seafood pancake (okonomiyaki)
- erichan special (I believe this is the mochi)
- meat lovers special 
- cha shu ramen

I died with every bite starting with the mochi. I LOVE mochi and this just sparked my tastebuds because I've never had a savory version before. Try this is you're a mochi fan, you won't be disappointed! 

The seafood pancake was huge for two people and woo was it tasty.  Sounds strange but my favorite part was the corn haha!

If you've never tried the yakkatori and crave meat, I'd just go for meat lovers to try versions flavors. Juicy, savory, melt in your mouth glory. Do it.

Lastly, I really enjoyed the ramen! I know a lot of people can be picky about ramen but all I know is that this hit the spot and really, that's all that matters.

Go, and enjoy!
author: Leslie L.

description:
For yakitori, you're better off in Berkeley.

Prices are about the same here, but the food is not as good.

Some dishes are super heavily seasoned (think salt) and the sochu was super watered down..after being forgotten..

and when we finished about 5 skewers, bill for two came out to about $60-- not bad for light weighted plates right?

The waitress scuffed when I said I was super full.

Still, etiquette in me says dictates that I give at least 20% tip.

Even though the food was okay at BEST, and service (forgetting drinks, attitude, oh and the shoulder) bleh.

I'm just never coming back.

Don't be fooled by the cute decor and the hole in the wall vibe, totally not worth it.
author: Whitne Y.

description: Simply delicious. The atmosphere of The Beatles posters and other memorabilia from the 60s music scene make it a fantastic experience
author: Chloe P.

description:
Wonderful little izakaya that reminds me of the tucked away izakayas in Tokyo, particular one that I found underneath a big freeway overpass.

The tendon, tongue, wings, and okonomiyaki were delicious, leaving me wanting for more after finishing the one that I shared with my wife. The ramen was average so I would save your dollars there.

Service was friendly and helpful in choosing off the menu.
author: Stephen H.

description:
This spot is awesome. It's going to kick off my new quest for the best yakitori I can find in the bay area.

Service is great and they have this Yuzu Sake that tastes like a nice sweet summer nectar to sip on. Very dangerous.

Yuzu thighs, yuzu wings, basil tomatoes, shishito peppers and the spinach were my favorite dishes. It was so good we had to go there two nights in a row.
author: Jeff L.

description: Service was less than great but food was fantastic. My son devoured the skewers (picky kid) and I enjoyed the ramen. The atmosphere is fun and quirky for a little Japanese joint but somehow it worked.
author: Kristen K.

description: Love coming here for a quick izakaya fix. Great ochazuke and takoyaki. I generally don't order the ramen but have sampled quite a few of their yakitori. Place is tiny so there's usually a wait between 6:30-8:30pm. Friendly service!
author: Q C.

description: I'm giving this 2 stars because it's cozy and liked the decor. The service can use a major improvement, especially considering it wasn't crowded last night when we went. The food was severely overpriced even by SF standards. The ramen was bad with a weird funky taste to the meat and a salty bland broth. I ate about 20% of it then grabbed a slice of pizza afterwards. We should have waited 2 hours at Burma Superstar instead.
author: Not S.

description: The yakitori were a delight and the ambiance, if you come at a less crowded time, is quite enjoyable. I've definitely had better ramen and my hard boiled egg seemed like it had just come out of the refrigerator, but it was still satisfying.
author: Rae B.

description:
Super small and super cool!  

There's maybe 8 tables and then some bar seating.  You would totally feel like you're in Japan at a quaint local spot, except that the entire restaurant is covered in knick knacks and a lot of them being Beatles paraphanalia.

Our favorite yakitori picks: beef tongue, chicken skin, and the ramen.
author: Janel C.

description:
I remember when I first met Halu. A friend of mine was raving about Halu's ramen and invited me out. I joined him and thought Halu was nice but nothing special. I would visit weekly because it was what my friends did. But I was here for my friends, not for Halu. However, as time passed and I continued my weekly Halu sessions, Halu grew on me. The pictures and articles of the Beetles that graced its walls stopped bugging me so much and I began to appreciate it. The karaage ramen that I once deemed average began tasting amazing as I sampled different variations and really took the time to enjoy it. 

As time grew, I pursued Halu more heavily and took time to understand it. I would get its sake flights to taste all of what it had to offer and try different pieces of its succulent yakitori. Halu helped me understand myself too- I now know that I will absolutely devour any yakitori that has even an inkling of chicken in it. 

I knew me and Halu had something special going on when it closed its doors for several months, but for what seemed like an eternity. I missed the kaarage ramen. I missed drinking beer and sake there with my friends. I missed whetting my appetite with their expansive yakitori menu. When Halu returned to the Sunset, I ran there with open arms. You will still see me there- every Thursday sitting at a table with 3 or 4 other people merrily drinking beer and chowing down on ramen. If you see me, stop by and say hi!
author: Philip W.

description: I LOVE this place! Family owned, awesome food and Beatles everywhere! I've been coming for years and I'll never stop!
author: Chloe B.

description:
Amid the Outside Lands traffic horror, I wanted to stay away from going to the Sunset. I put my name down, luckily it was short and we got a table within 10 minutes.

First impression: Lots and lots of The Beatles collectibles and very, very small.

My friend and I got to ordering the chashu-men mild spicy. We had to have waited at least a good 30 minutes before our bowls were delivered to us. Needless to say, I was extremely hangry. The broth was really hot and pretty spicy, I'd say it was medium spicy. Not bad at all. We were also persuaded by the kind waitress to order the sparkling peach sake with jelly. I definitely recommend it! It's so refreshing and has an interesting texture.

I'm not a very patient person so I'll have to think twice before coming here again.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Excellent tako wasabi, squid, ramen, okonomiyaki! Service was a teeny bit slow because it's so busy and people order a lot, but it was worth it

It's soooo Japanese, cute, and cozy that it just reminded me of when I was studying abroad in Japan. My friends and I loved this place. Will be coming back again
author: Jenny W.

description:
Halu is a small little shop out in the Richmond. It's vibe is kinda like...old school cafe where there is live music (not that I know they actually do that). The main reason my friends and I came to Halu one night was because we were craving okonomiyaki, which is not really all too common around SF.

Halu is quite small inside; it seats maybe 20 people max (I think I'm giving a generous estimate). The kitchen is actually right by the front, diner-style. You can actually sit by the kitchen, along the bar. There is a tiny bit more seating along the opposite wall and in the back. I would definitely not recommend this place for larger groups. Even with a group of 5, I feel like we were pushing it.

Our waitress was very friendly and knowledgeable about the menu. She recommended that we could share the okonomiyaki (we ended up all getting our own though), and recommended some drinks as well. I think you should be prepared to be upsold on the alcohol though, so keep that in mind. We ended up getting the sparkling peach jelly drink without checking the price, and we had acute sticker shock. Service was very good nonetheless.

The food itself was good though. I mean, it wasn't extraordinary, but still satisfying. The okonomiyaki were very dense. I got seafood and wasn't quite satisfied with the amount of seafood in it, but my friends got the beef one and were happy with it. That being said, the okonomiyaki is better as a side, shared with a friend, rather than a full meal on its own. I also got the beef tongue yakitori, and it was quite tasty and tender (not tough). The drink I mentioned above was definitely a favorite at the table, everyone loved it.

Overall, our experience at Halu was good. If I found myself back in the area, I would come back and try some other things :)
author: Denise C.

description:
I have heard of the legend of Halu for ages. After years of years of yearning, I finally got a chance to try it out last weekend. We came early and were seated right away. To call the place a homage to the Beatles is a vast understatement. The walls are dripping with Beatles memorabilia and the speakers softly hum their tunes. There's even a Beatles drum set on the mezzanine. Well, you get the point, they love the Beatles. 

I'm not sure if it was intentional or not, but the restaurant is entirely staffed with women. Even the cook in the back is female. The vibe of the place reminded me of the venue in Kill Bill (the first one!) where our heroine went on a killing rampage in a Japanese restaurant/bar. Definitely very cool.

Now we talk abut the food. To start, we went a bit wild on yakitori -- beef tongue, short ribs, bacon wrapped scallops, bacon wrapped tomatoes, chicken wings, and okra. We also ordered the spicy raw octopus and seaweed salad. We got the spicy chashu ramen and seafood Okonomiyaki (Japanese "pizza") for the mains.

The skewers were good. I loved everything, especially the bacon wrapped scallops and the beef tongue. The seasoning were light so you can really taste the freshness of the ingredients. Definitely order a few skewers to share!!

The spicy raw octopus had a strong wasabi kick that cleared our sinuses. This was my first time eating raw octopus and it was good. The seaweed salad is pretty standard and compared to other places, the portion size was good.

Now, the main attraction, the ramen. I was amazed at how great the noodles were. The broth was top notch and the spiciness great for a cold night, but the noodles completely stole the show. It was so springy and the texture blew me away!! I asked the waitress and she told me that they air freight that stuff over from Japan. No wonder!!

I didn't like the japanese pizza all that much because of all the sauce on top. It made it too salty for my taste. I think if that didn't have all the topping, it would be good. I would order it again, but sans the mayo and sauce.

I will certainly be back to have more ramen and yakitori. A true SF gem!!
author: Alice W.

description:
Skewers are on point and most are between 5-9 dollars for two. Well flavored and perfectly cooked. 

I tried the chicken thigh katsu(probably my favorite thing ever. The breading was nice and crispy) citrus yuzu chicken wings (yummy but a little on a salty side for me at least. My bf loved it.) okra (nothing superbly special, but I love okra so much) beef tendon (I don't particularly like tendon but my bf loves it. From the one bite I took. It was very flavorful and soft) 

We also tried the okonomiyaki. It was a combination of pork beef and seafood. This was super good. Perfectly crisp on the outside and doughy and flavorful on the inside. My only complaint is that I didn't like the combo of all the protein. I'll probably just get pork next time. I wish they made a Hiroshima style one. But I guess I'll have to continue my search for that kind. 

Docked one star cuz of service. Just a little inefficient and takes 5 mins to get a hold of a server. But overall. Loved this place. Will definitely come back!
author: Joyce D.

description:
Overall it had some good ramen, but not worth the price / hassle.

If you read anything from my review, DO NOT ORDER THE FRIED SHRIMP SKEWER!  It costs $6.50, you get two little shrimps, and they taste like cheap frozen ones you get from grocery store.  Total rip off.

Pros:
1) their spicy ramen is good!  I was quite happy with it. 
2) the entire inside is decked out with Beatles stuff.  Where else can you eat ramen with Beatles in the background, besides your apartment?

Cons:
1) pricy!  Ramen starts at $12.5 for a bowl, and they charge for everything, even to make it spicy.  Seriously?
2) the wait.  We had to show up right as they were opening to ensure a table.  It's a small small place.  They also don't take reservations so if you don't want to get there early, you're gambling with your evening.
3) the skewers.  I don't know what the hype is about, these are WAY overpriced for what you get.  For $6, you get two little skewers.  See my photos to see what I mean.

The "meh"
1) the service.  The servers are spread thin, and you'll get nothing more than the bare minimum. 

However I will give our waitress props for promptly taking care of my girlfriends ramen when she asked for the chicken on the side, and they still put it in there.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Cute and charismatic hole-in-the wall Yakatori joint. Lots of atmosphere, tasty bites, and nice waitstaff. 

Just note that the grilled foods take a long time and the staff doesn't seem to track what's been served. When we went, we finished our ramen and left in about 1 hour but there were other tables still waiting for their skewers.
author: Steven W.

description:
************HALU HAS RE-OPENED!*********
As of October 14th, Halu returns! It is good to see our beloved neighborhood izakaya back in action! Spread the word!
author: Doug H.

description:
Back living in the 808, and still one of my favorite restaurants ever.
Too many great memories there to not be.
Rest in Power Komiyama Shigemi!
author: Barry A.

description:
I am the eggman, they are the eggmen. 
I am the walrus, goo goo g'joob g'goo goo g'joob. 

They're really into the Beatles here. When I was younger, so much younger than today, I never needed anybody's help in any way... until I discovered bacon-wrapped mochi. Me want more. It's a funky-retro closet of a place that beckons the hipster foodie like the sirens did when Ulysses passed by on the way between Scylla and Charybdis. Jamie W. and I got here fifteen minutes before they opened at 5PM last Saturday worried we would have to wait for a table. Not quite but it did start filling up relatively soon after that. 

So many temptations, but we knew we wanted the ballyhooed ramen. It wasn't disappointing and a far cry better than what we had at Asuka a couple of weeks before. Jamie went for the $12.50 bowl of Spicy Kara Age Ramen (Fried Chicken), while I ordered predictably as well, the $12.50 bowl of Lava Ramen (Spicy Roast Pork Ramen) (see photos). Speckled with hot peppers, the broth was smooth without being too salty, and the slices of pork were particularly plentiful. The noodles had the right al dente bite, and even the hard-boiled egg was satisfying. Seriously delicious stuff, but drink plenty of water. 

But even before the ramen, we dove into the $5.50 quartet of Mochi Bacon (see photo). So greasy, so chewy, so wrong. More skewers were needed. Jamie ordered the $4.50 Pork with Onion Kushikatsu, which was basically a pair of pork tonkatsu kebabs on a stick with sauce and mustard. I followed suit and got me some Chicken Liver Kushi-age, also for $4.50 ' cause I loves me some fried chicken innards (see photo). It looks like a Japanese-American couple runs the place with a hip-looking girl running around waiting on all the incoming diners. It's all good comfort food for the undiscriminating sansei with a pork fetish. That would be me. 

And in the end... 
The mochi bacon you take 
Is equal to the mochi bacon you make. 

FOOD - 4 stars...awesome Japanese bar food with one whip-snapping bowl of spicy ramen 
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...Penny Lane is in my ears and in my eyes 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...as fast as she could possibly serve 
TOTAL - 4 stars...a return visit to Liverpool is in the cards, love
author: Ed U.

description:
It was a toss up between choosing Kaiju Eats and Halu for dinner last night. Halu was the winner because they served yakitori (and chicken hearts were on the menu).

We ordered:

1.  Chasu-men (even though we ordered mild, they accidentally gave us spicy, but I loved it!)
2.  Karaage Ramen (chicken too salty)
3.  Chicken Hearts (yummy)
4.  Chicken Gizzards (a little rubbery)
5.  Crispy Chicken Wings (also yummy-must try)

Their portions of ramen noodles are HUGE, so make sure you come hungry, otherwise you will be a disappointment to the global movements to eliminate world hunger and poverty.

The venue is a very small "hole-in-the-wall" location.  On a cold night, which occurs often in San Francisco, you do not want to be seated at the bar section of the restaurant right in front of the door.  You will FREEZE because there really is no place for folks who are entering the restaurant to stand and wait to be seated.  Like, the place is for real tiny. 

However, it is awesomely decorated with lots of posters and photos of famous rock artists (Beatles, Jimi Hendrix, etc.)  

Even though it was a Tuesday night, it was pretty packed for dinner.  The servers were still friendly and worked their butts off, making sure we were happy.

The one CON I have about this place is that if you want to use your credit card, there is a $20 minimum.  It was only slightly annoying, but not the biggest deal in the world.  I recommend this place for people who have not tried it.  It's got good social energy.
author: Elisha Y.

description:
Small restaurant, quite a cute vibe with all the Beatle's memorabilia and music etc around. 

I remember the ambience more than food - which is saying that the food was good, but not particularly memorable. I had some skewers and my husband had the ramen, which was pretty average. 

For the long wait that we had in the cold, it was worth checking out but not worth coming back to.
author: Lisette P.

description:
I think its about time I broke my Yelp aversion to reviews. My Dukedom is at stake!!!

So here you go Yelp, this is review number 3. 

What can I say about Halu that hasn't been said by my check in total. I've been here 19 times (20 is coming soon!!!) over the last year. Nineteen. It's just that good. To put it in perspective, I come all the way from Nob Hill JUST to eat here. Those Lyft rides get expensive, but it's damn worth it. I just tell my wallet to man up and suck it up. 

Situated on a secluded corner of 8th and Clement, don't let its diminutive appearance fool you. Inside, the interior is jam packed with old school Beatles Memorabilia, old posters,and retro styled decor. They also play music from the old days (and not just the Beatles, I heard the Troggs too). It's a great third or fourth date spot, especially if your significant other likes the Beatles. I still get a kick out of all the cool stuff inside because it gives the place its own personality, something that many restaurants today lack. 

Because it's a small hole in the wall (and family owned and operated to boot), they are almost always busy and crowded to the brim. Be prepared for a wait on busy nights, but don't worry, the food is WORTH it. The servers are friendly (shout out to Erika and her family!) and do their best to accomodate you, but remember, there's only two of them servicing the entire restaurant, so be nice and patient!  

They are known for their yakitori, (skewers), and the meat quality for the price (7$ on average for 2 skewers at the time of writing this) is insane. 

Hands down the best beef belly I've ever hand. Period. 

Their chasu and karage ramen is also top notch. I wouldn't say it's the best Ramen in the Bay, but it's the best Ramen in the San Francisco area, imo, and I eat A LOT of ramen. (Sorry Ramen Underground, Ken-Ken, and Izakaya Kou). They close on Sundays and Mondays though, so I have to get my fix elsewhere on those days.

Note: they don't serve sushi here. Don't ask. Neither do they take reservations. You just got to show up, put your name on the list, and sit on that nice quaint bench outside. 

They have an extensive sake menu here too, so prepare to get your drink on too! 

STANDOUT DISHES YOU MUST TRY:
-Melts with every bite Belly steak (I order this every time without fail)
-Chicken Avocado Yakitori
-Okonomiyaki Japanese Pancake
-Karage Fried Chicken Appetizer (and the ramen).
-Chicken Heart skewers 

I love Halu and I'm going to miss it when I peace out from San Francisco in April. 

LONG LIVE HALU! :)
author: Jason L.

description: Pretty standard izakaya. I say "standard" meaning that it doesn't have all of the fancy local, organic, sustainable, [insert other SF food buzzword here] ethos that all of the trendy izakaya spots have. This is exactly what I'd expect out of a local izakaya, keeping in mind that izakaya translates to a "drinking shop". The yakitori, though not as complex with charcoal smoke flavors like other higher-end places, was still pretty good.
author: Kazu O.

description:
Likes: Halu combo okonomiyaki was like a chewy on the inside and crispy on the edges pancake. It had a little of very meat in it. 
Their combo was also great. Came with miso soup, rice, mini salad, and seven skewers of the chefs choice. The crispy chicken and beef steak were delicious. Two types of mushrooms were good. Another kind of chicken cut. I forget what the others were.  Friendly waitress. Parking not too bad on the street. 

Dislikes: chicken was good but a little salty. My tongue was tingling afterward. Lucky for them I like salt, but even this salt lover has limits!  Also our cups of water smelled like soap, which is great because that means they're clean! But I was worried there might be some residual soap leftover so I didn't touch my water :(
author: Karen M.

description:
The ultimate beatles-japanese house!

There are plenty of sushi houses in San Francisco, this place doesn't do any of that and for good reason. They focus their efforts on really really good Japanese food. 

There decor is probably like no other place in the city, beatles stuff everywhere. And the people are truly and honestly the nicest people.

Recommended: Yakitori Omakase Dinner (7 assorted Yakitori skewers)
author: Abraham A.

description:
Ok Halu, you're winning this!

Their yakitori is to die for. I actually don't care for their ambiance all that much but when you can indulge in such delicious and perfectly chargrilled skewers, who cares anymore. I somewhat wish that Halu had more selection drink-wise but honestly, their skewers are quite possibly the best I have ever tasted!

Go! Go now!

Enjoy!
author: Winè C.

description:
You don't come here for ramen. If you do, you are a fool.
Sure, you can have some ramen, but don't come here solely for that.

You go to Halu for yakitori/kushiyaki. 

Halu had thwarted me once before (on vacation in December) so I had to settle for something else. I was determined, I was on a mission to eat at Halu.
Why it has escaped me for all these years, I will never know but I admit I have been missing out for all of said years.  When I FINALLY made it...

Tiny joint. Seats about maybe 20, 25? Bar seating (in front of the grill) and a smattering of small tables. Try to go in a tiny group. The smaller the better. You will have to wait. Get your name on the list, give the nice waitress your phone # and you can either sit in your car or go grab a beer somewhere. Beatles posters EVERYWHERE. 

Order skewers. Order beer. Maybe share an order of ramen if you're exceptionally hungry. (buttered corn ramen! mmm)

My favorite skewers: 

beef tongue - so damn tender! 
okra - grilled and salted. crunchy. 
chicken stuffed mushroom - oh man I don't even like chicken but this ground chicken stuffed mushroom was DELICIOUS. the chicken was slightly sweet, ground up all nice so it was tender and juicy. 

appetizer: tako wasabi. I order this at every yakitori joint because it's probably my favorite thing ever. diced, raw octopus with fresh wasabi. MmMmMmM chewy, spicy, a little crunchy, slightly slimy. Not for those squeamish of raw foods by the way. 

Halu doesn't do the tare sauce on their skewers. They just lightly salt the meats/veggies as I feel good yakitori should be done. 

We ordered what I felt was a good amount and the three of us left content and happy. It wasn't until later that I found out from my girlfriend that it was her VERY FIRST TIME having yakitori. So glad that Halu popped that cherry! Halu also carries some good sake if beer isn't your thing. 

Be nice to the waitresses. They work hard. It's a small spot, but they're bustling about multitasking like pros. 

I've never been to Japan but let me tell you, upon finally seating (after a 25 minute wait, not too bad) I felt like I was transported into a Murakami (my one of my favorite authors of all time by the way, write that down) book in Japan. Norwegian Wood kept playing over and over in my mind (movie not nearly as good as the book but I still love both and yes I know it's a Beatles song I'm just saying).
author: Susy C.

description: Told us 20 minute wait. Waited over an hour then they gave our table away despite the fact that we were literally standing at the front door. Ramen here is mediocre at best anyway...
author: Tommy Z.

description: My son and his fiancé took me to Halu on one of my trips to visit. They said this was their "go to" ramen restaurant. I now see why. Awesome food and eclectic atmosphere ... loved all the Beatles paraphernalia ... floor to ceiling. Very small (probably only seats 15-20 max.). Looking forward to my next visit. Halu has set the standard for my future searches for ramen.
author: Britt W.

description:
The loooooong wait to get into this tiny hole-in-the-wall Japanese restaurant was agonizing!  

My friends and I, making it a party of ONLY 3, waited for 1.5 plus hours to get seated.  We were standing outside the entire time and even saw the fog gradually come in.  By the time we saw the fog, I was super antsy and super cold!

Their ramen, authentic Japanese dishes, selections of sake and ambiance of this place, is definitely worth checking out, but don't go for peak hours and never bring a huge party!  It's not made for big groups, but I would say a date for 2!

They gave us an order of complimentary sake for the wait.  I was not pleased still.  The time wasted waiting outside in the cold because the hole-in-the-wall restaurant is really small, does not balance out with 1 complimentary sake among 3 people!

Do order up their Fried Chicken (Karaage) Ramen, Japanese Pancakes (Okonomiyaki) and Bacon Wrapped Mochi if you do decide to go!  Those three dishes surely makes a great combo!

Just bring another person so you will be seated much faster and not become irritated by waiting!
author: Tiffany D.

description: this place is everything you expect when you hear "hole in the wall". it's so small. but it's so cozy and the staff is extremely welcoming. the walls are filled with Beatles posters and flyers, and they play Beatles music. the food is good - we tried chasumen and veggie ramen, and they were both good and we also got the dinner kabob set, which were also good!
author: Isabel K.

description: My new favorite shop in San Fransisco. Veggie lover is amazing, agedashi tofu is one of the best I have had in the city. Ochazuke with salmon I prefer better then the noodles.  Erichans special is awesome. Love the atmosphere and the Beatles theme. Great for vegetarians! Worth the wait.
author: Alina Z.

description: This place is serious! Seriously amazing !!!! Service is great! I don't care if I have to wait 45min! I'm getting my fix. Some highlights -chicken liver - chicken gizzard- hearts and of course beef with avocado! Plus I've been here a million times and the memorabilia never gets old! Yummmmmm
author: sofia r.

description: Had the Karage ramen while the BF had the Chasu ramen. Broth was flavorful and just the right amount of portion. After finishing the dish, I was not too full and just right amount of satisfied. :) the restaurant was entirely Beatles themed, which was a bonus since the BF was a Beatles fan. Ordered a couple of small yakatori dishes as appetizers: chicken liver, grilled shataki mushroom, chicken stuffed mushroom, and cold tofu. Each was perfectly seasoned and with just the right amount breaking on the chicken liver. :-) would definitely come back again when I'm in SF next.
author: Tina L.

description:
I finally got to try Halu last night and it was pretty good. If you like yakatori, this is your place. The boy and I ordered several beef skewers, (which sadly I do not know the names of because I let my boy do the ordering) the seafood pancake, soy-sauce mochi, stuffed chicken mushroom and the chicken skewer with an orange sauce on top. 

Everything was delicious! I really liked the chicken skewer with the orange sauce because the chicken was cooked to perfection. It was juicy, tender and the sauce went very well with the chicken. The beef skewers were great as well, I liked the one with the avocado spread on top but not the one with cilantro on top. I thought the soy sauce mochi was good to accompany my meat, but it was not amazing. There was no bacon on it or anything special. It was just mochi, seaweed and soy sauce. Also, it came with just two big pieces. We both felt like the pancake was very doughy and the batter made for it was the same as what you would use to make takoyaki balls. It was good but we wouldn't order it again. Another thing I really liked was the chicken stuffed mushroom. These were delicious and were filled with delicious tender chicken. Super yum! 

I would come back again if I'm craving yakatori.
author: Laura T.

description:
Halu is hidden away in Inner Sunset, but its Ramen really shines. Their noodles are cooked up amazingly al dente and are supposedly brought in from Japan. As a result, they have a springyness to them that few can match. Their regular ramen is coupled with a meaty and flavorful soup broth and generous portions of char-siu. This is one bowl of noodles that hits the spot on a cold day. 

A bowl of regular noodles will go for around $10 while a heaping serving of extra noodles is another $3.50. 

I can't wait to be back for a bowl of these noodles
author: Vince E.

description:
I haven't been here for a while, it seems like Halu has new menu.
Now, one of twin girl in the kitchen, I have heard that their dad past so she took her dad's position. It seems like they are really busy working here, keep their business going.
We were 4 of us here for Saturday night dinner having the Kushi-Yaki ( skewered bbq meat ) menu.
( reason why I say "Kushi-Yaki" only because Yaki-Tori means BBQ-Skewered-Chicken only. Skewered-Beef isn't called Yaki-Tori, period. Doh! )

We got:
Yakitori dinner, 7 skewers combo, plus:
Pork sausage was So Juicy!
Tontoro (pork Jowl) was melt in my mouth!
Beef steak fillet, Shiso Beef and Rib eye were So Tender!
Salt Chicken breast was So Good!
Also,
I really like the new Exotic Yaki-Tori menu:
Chicken hearts, liver, cartilage, gizzards, ummmm, so good!

All Kushi-Yaki are pretty big, 5 to 6 bucks for 2 skewers, is I think good deal.
4 bucks for one small Onigiri is not a really good deal, but WTF?
We had a wonderful time.

It was full house, and there was a line for 30 minutes wait. 
I am so glad to see Halu is busy.
That means, real people know what's really good authentic Japanese.

I think the twins and mom are doing good job, their dad is proud of them.
Hey old man, your Halu will be fine.
author: Nobu K.

description:
When it comes to good Japanese food in the city, steer clear of Japantown and head towards 8th and Clement. Halu is hands-down our go-to date place in the city. (you're welcome)

The atmosphere and the workers here are very friendly. With only a few small tables, the wait time can be astronomical. There is usually a wait, however you can leave your number and they will call you while you explore some other hidden gems in that area. (chinese markets, green apple bookstore) Parking is very difficult on Clement, but during Halu's hours of operation, it is not very difficult to find. 

We've been meaning to try their ramen noodles, but we always fail to leave room after stuffing our faces with skewers (yakitori).

H is imported from Japan & often complains to L about missing food from home. So, Halu is his home away from home. 
 
Our usual order:

Eri-chan special: (mochi marinated with sauce wrapped around with seaweed) This is a small appetizer & looks simple but taste delicious.

Tako-wasabi: octopus with a kick! It pairs well with beer.

Ton-toro (pork belly) L's favorite. It is melt in your mouth goodness. Definitely the toro of the land. 

Fried Stuffed Mushroom: we usually order this because the other skewers don't fill us up as much. Very hot! and be sure to use the hot mustard and tonkatsu sauce~ 

Nankotsu: (cartilage) interesting texture, has a soft crunch. H's favorite; because it pairs well with beer

Teba (chicken wings): Another favorite. Meat slides right off the bone! i've never seen wings like these, but another great skewer. 

Beer is best with their food, especially Orion. However, if you're looking for a cocktail, I would recommend their chu-hai drinks with calpico. And if you're a regular, we bought a bottle of chu-hai last time and kept it there for two months, which is a pretty good deal.

Overall Impression: Seasoned & grilled to perfection. Great place to kickback and enjoy your company and food.

Oh, and someone here likes the Beatles, sort of..


Arigatou~
h n l
author: H N L.

description: This is one of my favorite places in the city. Always a wonderful experience from the staff to the food. The music is amazing. When I first moved to SF I would come here several times a week. Never a bummer at Halu.
author: Patrick M.

description: Awesome little place that plays Beatles music and makes the best Yakatori beef belly I've ever had. Definitely recommend it for anyone looking for a delicious and eclectic spot in the Richmond. Also the servers are beautiful
author: Everybody S.

description:
Cozy izakaya place tucked away in the Inner Richmond.  There are only a handful of tables, not the best place for large parties, but definitely a great spot to grab a few beers and munch on some yummy skewers with a few friends.  The owners are huge Beatles fans...tons of Beatles memorabilia plaster their walls + their music fills the entire restaurant....definitely takes you back to the 60-70's.

I can't say their ramen is one my favorite, but their yakitori definitely hits the spot!  Amongst my favs are their chicken gizzards, stuffed mushrooms, beef tongue, tontoro (pork jowl), bacon mochi, and eggplant w/ cheese.

I'm a fan!
author: Janetto L.

description:
Excellent atmosphere.  

Very friendly staff.  Always smiling. 

Great ramen.  Nice price.  I've tried a number of items and enjoyed them all.
author: Cheese G.

description:
Kitschy Beatles-themed restaurant with delicious yakitori and other small bites. This tiny restaurant is hidden away - I must have walked by it 4 or 5 times before realizing it even existed. However, apparently not everyone was as oblivious as me, since this place gets really crowded and there is likely to be a wait!

I came here as a party of 3 and we waited for around 20 minutes for dinner on a Friday. Conveniently, they take your phone number down on the waitlist and will call you when a table is ready. There are plenty of bars in the area to get a drink at while you wait. 

We decided to try various yakitori dishes (nonkotsu karaage, chicken and scallion, tsukune), takoyaki, okonomiyaki, and cucumuber/seaweed salad. The yakitori skewers were all flavorful and quite filling. The takoyaki was piping hot and the okonomiyaki was very tasty as well.

Service was alright - it's definitely a crowded and busy restaurant so the waitstaff were running around all the time and it was a little difficult to catch one of them to order our food. Nonetheless, everyone was very friendly and it was overall a positive dining experience. 

Good for dinner with small groups or a fun date.
author: J L.

description:
I love this place.  The atmosphere with the Beatles stuff everywhere is just great.

The first time I was here I was searching for some really spicy ramen.  I asked for the spiciest ramen possible and so they served just that.  The lava ramen then was the spiciest ramen I had ever had.  Like 8/10 spicy!  I was in pain but it was so good!

The second time I was here I came with my boyfriend.  We got the lava ramen hoping for a similar spicyness but it wasn't really quite there.  Maybe 6/10 spicy.  The chicken katsu ramen was still very good even with the lower spicy level.  We also ordered yakitori and it was delicious.  My boyfriend ordered beef tongue and chicken hearts.  I tried some even though I usually don't like those dishes and to my surprise I actually liked them.

The service is friendly and the waitress will make many recommendations to you.  This is my new favorite place for ramen and I will be coming back again.
author: Audrey D.

description:
On 8th street, it's the third establishment from the corner, you can easily miss this place. Literally,  a hole-in-the-wall, there's barely any room to walk into the restaurant. The decor is Beatles everywhere, which I absolutely loved! Table reading was Chinglish and provided amusing entertainment.

Came here because was craving some yakitori and boy did they deliver! We ordered the following:

Combination Okonomiyaki ($15)

Skewers:
Chicken liver ($5)
Chicken hearts ($5)
Chicken gizzards ($5)
Beef tongue ($6)

The skewers weren't dry & had just the right amount of char. Beef tongue was nice and tender. Seasoning was a simple salt & pepper for the skewers except the liver (which the marinated was delicious).

Okonomiyaki is a Japanese pancake. The combination had veggies, seafood & beef. The toppings is just like what they have on a yakitori. So much flavor! 

Lucky we came early because it got super packed very quickly. Definitely coming back :)
author: Kitty K.

description:
I am giving halu 4.5 stars but our server was so friendly so I rounded up. Got here with my friend. Arrived around 6:20 and got us a table. By 6:30, there was already a wait. So glad we beat the crowd. This place is tiny. 

Yakitoris were good. I like the meats, the beef tongue, beef belly, yaki onigri, uni. That grill Mochi though. LOVE IT! We just got a bunch of skewers and it was really good. It's not anything special except a hole in the wall yakitori place that serves decent food. 

For me, this time was about good company. I would go back again. One thing, make sure they give you all that you ordered. I think they forgot my chicken wings and not sure if they charged me for it. =/ We did drop $100 for the food for 2. So it's definitely not cheap.
author: Hei Ming C.

description: Been here a few times since I used to really like it, but I'm kind of over it now. I usually get the fried chicken ramen which ends up being more oily tasting than anything. Plus the last time we went here we waited about an hour and a half for our ramen which really annoyed me since they kept insisting it was coming soon. Another couple came in the same time as us and left before we even got our food (they also had ramen). They offered that we order more while we wait (but why should we pay the price when your service is what's lacking?). On the other hand they play good music and have a cool Beatles thing going on.
author: Andrew D.

description: The veggies are delish, the gyoza is delish, the scallops are out of this world. This week I tried the ramen for the first time and oh boy have I been missing out! Hands down my favorite restaurant in the neighborhood!
author: Maya M.

description: I think this is the first ramen place I've been to that I didn't finish all of my ramen... wuttttt!  Maybe I just wasn't too impressed by the Chashu Lava Ramen... it was quite simple, with chashu, seaweed, green onions, bean sprouts, and some red veggie that I forget the name of... but nothing that makes me go oh-my-goodness I want more! I had a taste of the chicken karaage ramen, which I found was much, much more tastier.
