Super friendly service, but the food did take over half an hour to serve.  :c  Very limited seating and just waiting in general, kinda took forever.  :c  Waiting to get seated... waiting for the appetizers to come one at a time ... waiting for the ramen... :c  I don't think I could ever come here starving and expect to have a satisfied tummy within the next 30 minutes.  :c
author: Carena N.

description: Dayum! Beef belly yakitori on point! Ramen is solid as well. Excellent first experience at this joint. Doesn't hurt that it has a v impressive collection of Beatles memorabilia and killer tunes that kept my head bobbin between bites
author: Jeff M.

description:
Skewers are awesome, especially the beef tongue. We ordered 2 rounds of everything, love!

Ramen and okonomiyaki were just Ok. Okonomiyaki was heavy and doughy. Ramen was bland. 

Will definitely come back for more yakitori!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Previous to finally eating here, I've heard a lot of mixed reviews about Halu from the food to service. In a nutshell, I thought the izakaya / yakitori style food was amaze-balls, the ramen was bleh, and the service was slow.

Luckily I arrived early enough so I didn't have to wait for a seat (around 630pm). However, after ordering, the wait was probably about 15 minutes before the food arrived. And if you want to order something else, you have to flag down the server, even though the restaurant is only "so big." 

All of the yakitori dishes were very tasty with a good amount of sea salt on it. I especially enjoyed the short ribs & beef tongue. Other favorites include nori wrapped mochi, swiss cheese eggplant (special), & trumpet mushroom.

I have to warn that ALL of the decor/ambiance is Beatles, even the music! It didn't bother me, but just saying.

Def will be back again soon to try more things!
author: Alysha K.

description: Mediocre ramen. Long waiting time. Average service. Small and crowded restaurant. Noisy music in a traditional Japanese restaurant, I don't understand it. Skewers are costly, like $4/ skewer. Ramen is overpriced enormously, based on its taste. 4 stars Yelp rating? I don't get it.
author: Robert C.

description:
This place is totally a small hole in the wall and it makes me feel like I'm in Japan.. well I haven't been there butttttt yeahhhhhhh..... lol. I like the small yakitori concept and it's different than most Japanese restaurants in SF.

Yakitori - we didn't get this but I AM DEFINITELY going to try it next time I come here..
Kara age ramen- mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm. Period. In my opinion it's a tad overpriced but at least it's made well.. If you live near here, the ramen is definitely better than Santa Ramen (meh) in San Mateo.

I can't wait to come back again to try the yakitoriiiiii and other stuff. I was trying to be relatively healthy by just ordering one ramen :(

If you come with 2 people, you should order 1 ramen and share some yakitori. Me and my friend didn't think ahead!
author: Emily C.

description: We came in a half hour before closing and the servers so graciously welcomed us in; we ordered quickly, all got Chash-men Ramen and the broth was amazing. Everything tasted fresh and the service was quick and really welcoming. The Beatles decor also was a lot of fun and super interesting. Only complaint would be that the chashu pork was a little cold at first but the broth warmed it up quickly and it was super tender and tasteful. Definitely would come here again!
author: Andy T.

description:
We can work it out.

From the Beatles: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZNfuTDbdKoY

Celebrating the Beatles: Memorabilia adorn the walls of this small space with just enough room for a kitchen. But what might be small in size creates things big in taste:

- Refreshing cold tofu with a homemade dipping sauce

- Crisp and creative salmon onigiri

- Hot and hearty gyoza

- Bold chicken skewers topped with avocado

- Rich ramen finished with fried chicken and corn

- Subtle and superb green tea mochi 

Everything was really good and served in impressive time by a friendly staff. Opening refers to the challenge our selections. Such a compelling menu. We made it work.

No wait around 7 but there was a wait when we left at 8:30. Expect to pay a very reasonable $30/person before drinks.

Little food was left. We clearly worked it.
author: Jason B.

description:
A hole in the wall busy place tha t is best for small groups.  they adamantly advertise the NO SUSHI! idea

Seafood Okominoyaki
- best okominoyaki i have tried thusfar
- generous with the seafood
- savory goodness.   the taste of the shrimp was spread throughout the pancake
- lighlty topped with the perfect amount of sauces which provided the sweet, buttery flavor.
- a convienient metal spatula type utensil is provided for your convenience to cut and serve 
*the best dish of the night - i highly recommend

Soba Don
- cold noodle-salad dish in a broth 
- refreshing and flavorful, however it got quite salty by the end
- good variety of veggies and the soba was firm and chewy, the way i like it actually

my friend got the chashu ramen - he said it was watered down.  he gave me a slice of the pork - it tasted gamey and old to me.

service was very friendly, however extremely slow - our water was not even refilled halfway through our meal even though they were near empty.  also the food took forever to come out.  i'm talking like 25 minutes. but then again, this was saturday night.

the okominoyaki was worth 4 stars alone and i would come back to see what else they have to offer.  certainly will not be getting any ramen though.
author: Tina A.

description:
Love this place. 

It's a tiny family owned place with amazing character :) 
When you enter Halu, you notice the amazing collection of Beatles paraphernalia as well as other rock posters including late owner's band. (my his soul rest in peace) 

Then you meet two very personable waiters greets you and help you. 
Their menu is very traditional yakitori menu though lately they added some more contemporary dressings lately. 

If you like ramen and yakitori, this is a great hidden gem in the city to go =)
author: Mayumi Y.

description: Chicken hearts are just great. The Karage Ramen has great noodles and a solid broth but the Karage is meh. I would go with the pork Ramen.
author: Rohan D.

description:
It all started when I felt like having some okonomiyaki for dinner, and I was so eager to go to Japantown to order takeout.  However, my mother had different ideas.  She felt that Japantown is a little out of our way, despite the fact that I know the ins and outs of the area very well.  I didn't want to argue with her anymore about it, so we chose a place that was a little closer to home -- low and behold, we found Halu.

When we first walked in, I was actually a bit shocked of the decor for a Japanese restaurant.  It was a very rinky dinky place, with decor from the 1960s (i.e.: Beatlemania).  Although I'm not opposed to anything from the 50s and 60s, I found it redundant, considering that so many Beatles fans have vilified Yoko Ono as the woman who broke up the band.

To add more fuel to the fire, I felt that the food was nowhere near superb.  I've had okonomiyaki before, and for the price we paid for our meals, I tasted more "pancake" than anything else.  Although there was meat mixed into the dish just as I asked, I couldn't even taste it.  Even with the sauce, mayonnaise, and aonori flakes, it was practically tasteless.  Also, can somebody tell me what you have when you spell B-O-N-I-T-O followed by F-L-A-K-E-S?  That's what their dish DOESN'T have; that's one of the main toppings you put onto it.  Okonomiyaki is supposed to be a savory dish, and there was nothing appetizing about their version of it.

The reason why I gave this place a 2 is because despite the fact that the food wasn't to our liking, they definitely get points for their customer service; their waitresses were very kind and welcoming.  Originally when we walked in, the door was open, and where we were seated, we felt a really cold draft.  In an attempt to change seats with my mother, one of the waitresses noticed, and asked me if I wanted the door closed.  I said, "yes", and she did just that.  She was also very nice to allow us to take up one of their tables while we were waiting for our order to be boxed and bagged.

Other than the good customer service, I would suggest that if you really want a taste of some real okonomiyaki to take a trip to Japantown.  There's a couple of restaurants there that prepare a very traditional and savory okonomiyaki, as well as a Westernized version of it as well.
author: Claudine P.

description:
Found parking super easy on a Wednesday night here. There was no line, which was a huge excitement too. 

My bf and I arrived at 8:30, and ordered. We got our appetizers 15 minutes later.  Erichan's Special - mochi inside seaweed - was soooooo good. Definitely order that, because you can't really get it anywhere else.  We got the Karobuto Pork hot dogs, which was yummy too but slathered in oil (not sure if good or bad thing). 

We ended up eating our ramen at around 9:10. It was so ridiculous. We had some appetizers come periodically, but stil, our ramen took forever to come. I didn't really understand why it took so long, since it seemed like everyone had arrived before us and was already eating.  Perhaps there was only one cook, but the restaurant is tiny. I don't know why it took so long!  

But when it came, the ramen was delicious. I got the Chasu Ramen, which had good flavor. They also gave me 3 huge pieces of ramen, which was great. The amount of noodles was also impressive. We were both super full by the end of the night, something we weren't exactly expecting!

Also I love the atmosphere here.  Everything is Beatles themed - Beatles drumset, beatles-era music, beatles posters, all types of Beatles paraphernalia. Front of house service is sweet too. It's just those cooks that are so darn slow!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Going to a cruddy-ass izakaya in NYC, which is full of good izakayas, gave me the right context as to the great time I just had at Halu. Prior to moving to New York, I was an izakaya dilettante. How could I not be, given how few authentic izakayas are in San Francisco? Thus, I didn't appreciate what Halu had to offer. A cozy, divey, comfy environment with delicious food and a surprisingly awesome drink selection. I kind of got that sense the first time, but I did not appreciate it as much as I did after having run the gauntlet of NYC izakayas.

True, it's definitely not the cheapest at all. But the ambiance was great and with that, sometimes, less is more. I've come to an understanding that there is no "Kenka" in NYC, where you can eat and drink super cheaply in an izakaya style. So given that it's gonna be a bit pricier in SF, Halu totally hits the spot. (I compare it with Sun-Chan in NYC which is in my hood.)

If you need cheap izakaya, try Izakaya Mai in San Mateo. Had a great time there, furled my eyebrows at their sushi, but hey, everything was so good and so cheap all things considered.
author: Josh K.

description: Definitely my favorite neighborhood gem. Family owned and operated. Attentive, warm service with consistently full favored skewers. Did I mention an endless and ever expanding sake and soju selection? Wait, am I allowed to use the words "endless" and "ever expanding" in the same sentence? Well who cares, you are at Halu you are home!
author: Maxwell C.

description:
I've been to Halu about half dozen times in last four years.
If I lived near the inner Richmond district,  I bet I will be making Halu my weekly hang out.

Mimi is the owner and runs the kitchen.  She is a super woman whipping out all the food in her tiny kitchen. Mimi's daughters Eri and Sayaka runs the floor.  I am a big fan of family business and I am glad that these three women are carrying on Shigemi's legacy.

There are lot of stories to be told about this business but I think it is the love of family that created this restaurant and the bond of a family that helps carry it on...  

My recommendation is to start with yakitori appetizers first with your favorite sake or beer.
The root of this yakitoru dishes traces way back to Yoshidaya Japanese restaurant on Webster Street which is now occupied by Unami.  

Hope you will have a chance to get to know these beautiful people through the flavors of Halu.
author: Mark M.

description:
ADVICE: CHECK YOUR BILL!

The skewers are very much on the pricey side. Ordered 5 pairs of skewers in total and felt like we were very ripped off ($50 per person). 
The skewers were kinda on the salty side, nothing special.
Won't ever be returning.

*UPDATE*

Went back to the restaurant and asked the waitress for clarification, and it turns out she "accidentally" multiplied the orders in the bill twice.
So the total bill came up to $60 instead of $100!!!
So baffled at such incompetence, even when the restaurant wasn't busy yet. (We went in when it opened at 5pm and were the only customers.)
author: Jane W.

description:
This place is a destination, not just a local Japanese ramen house.  I mean, I Iive in the neighborhood and I walk only six blocks to get there, but when I do it's like I stepped into an episode of MASH and the service staff rocks.
My last visit was exceptional on the food and service.  Edamame, hand pocketed gyoza lightly fried in peanut oil, chicken thigh skewers, chicken ramen in medium spicy broth...Mmmmm.  Eat here!!
author: Sean M.

description:
A small little BEATLES themed ramen place in the richmond district that has very flavorful ramen and even greater skewers.

Our favorite skewer is the pork jow which is the pork cheek they always grill it to perfection. There is also a omakase skewer set for about $20 that really goes well with their ramen. 

As for their ramen, my favorite has always been their karaage chicken ramen. You can also get it spicy but it is a bit too spicy for my taste. The ramen offers a very flavorful broth and good ramen texture. I always leave feeling super full and spend about on average $15 a person.

Great place for cold SF nights and never too long of a wait. The staff is friendly and always welcoming.
author: Joanne K.

description: Yakitori heaven!!! My husband and I went here for dinner and loved the beef tongue and pork belly. Great price for food and friendly staff! I commend the dishwasher, waiters, and chef who have been continuously moving about to cater to the customers
author: Nikki Joyce A.

description:
My friend and I ordered the Chicken Karaage Ramen, the Chasu Ramen, the ground chicken yakitori, and the mushrooms (ie. two ramens and two skewers). The ramen were great. The broth was flavorful and the portion was filling. The appetizers were good. The taste of the food wasn't the problem..it's the SLOOOOW service.

When we arrived, we were seated at the counter right away (we showed up an hour after they first opened). We were given water,menus and ordered..all within  5 minutes of sitting down. That was the end of the fast service. We waited an hour for our food. They didn't even give us the two appetizers until AFTER they gave us our ramen.

Yes it's good food, but it's not worth the long wait. Next time, I'll come as soon as they open. Maybe the service will be better.

BTW, don't bother circling the block looking for parking when you come here;there's a metered parking lot right next door. BUT, note the meters run until MIDNIGHT not 6pm like most meters in the city....so feed the meter.
author: Zeia V.

description:
Phenomenal. I felt as though I took a trip back to the 60's in Japan (wasn't born then so I'm just imaging how it might have been...) and stepping into a quaint ramen restaurant (Halu) lead by a Beatles enthusiast. 

I had the chasyu ramen and gyu-tan (beef tongue). I was so full and happy after finishing my food. They put many slices of chasyu and the broth was so good, I'm sure our waitress caught my bf and I taking sips of it even after paying. They have Japanese waitresses working there, and speaking to them in Japanese made me feel even more like I was back in Japan. 

I do have one negative thing to say about the ramen's presentation. The toppings were scattered and and I was slightly disappointed. I can now see why fellow Yelpers feel upset after a long wait to see a ramen that looked like it was thrown together. But this is an easy fix! And unfortunately people judge based on first impression and I hope they put an effort into making their ramen look as good as it tastes. For this, if I could, I would dock half a star. 

The wait can be long, but I will definitely go again to experience their unique yet homie atmosphere!
author: Momoe K.

description:
I came here to fulfill a ramen craving and it definitely hit the spot! I had the butter corn ramen and it was delicious!! The noodles had a good consistency, the chasu it had was tender, the corn and butter in the broth made it tasty. The broth was flavorful yet light, I really enjoyed it.  It still doesn't compare to the ramen in Yokohama but it's decent!

We also tried the okonmiyaki with seafood it was made to perfection. It was a bit thin compared to other places but it was big. I definitely want to come back here in the future! :) I really enjoyed the cozy atmosphere inside as well it was interesting seeing all the Beatles memorabilia.
author: Stella J.

description:
This is one of my favorite izakaya restaurant in SF!  I come here practically every week. It is a really small restaurant so be prepared to be waiting for a long time. You can leave your name and number and they will give you a call when your table is ready. Table for 2s are usually quicker.. Anything above will probably be around 30mins + or just show up early on a weekday :) 

The decorations are awesome. The whole restaurant is dedicated to the Beatles. The music, the posters, the records.. It's really cool. 

The food is delicious. The kitchen is right there so you can smell all the yumminess. I usually get a few skewers.. Jowl, eggplant, chicken hearts, gizzards, chicken thigh, beef, scallops.. Ok fine you can't really go wrong with any of the skewers. The sake and beer selection is pretty big. We always order the drunken whale. It's a very suitable name!

The waitresses are very friendly and know everything about the menu. They are also very talkative which I love!  I will probably end up going back next week.. And the week after that.. And that!
author: Alister L.

description:
I have been going here for years and always forgot to are about them. Worried others will get there and take up all my seats, but this hole in the wall is my always to go location. I love the people there. Super friendly- feel like family. 
The ramen is super good and the yakitori is hands down. If your a sake drinker get the sake flights and you won't be disappointed. 

Great food and great service. Beatles fans!
author: David M.

description: Good ramen, great skewers. The ramen had springy noodles, which I really need. We had mild spicy chicken karaage. The broth had a real kick of ginger root. The chicken was well marinated, and crispy. Dem skewers doe. Great char and lightly smokey. We had the omakaze skewers. Got chicken wing, beef, mushroom, okra, chicken meatball. We got there close to opening at 5pm, and were seated right away, beating the crowds. This was a kind of an unexpected date night with the wifey, and turned into a memorable night of enjoyable new place and tastes. We had a secluded seat and took in the Beatles and sixties music decor. I was surprised the music playing wasn't strictly Beatles only. They even played some (gasp) Monkees!
author: E. W.

description:
I work in the Financial District and live in Russian Hill. There is no good reason to frequent Halu except its awesomeness.

I load up 3 friends in a cramped Mini Cooper and we make the run out to The Richmond specifically for Halu as often as possible. The standout favorites are skewers of stuffed mushrooms and the seafood pancake, which gets better every time we have it. Lots of incredible grilled items and above-average ramen to finish off a perfect meal of small plates and Japanese beer.

It's super small, so be prepared to wander down the street for a cocktail while you wait for a table. They'll call you. Oh, and "No sushi today..."
author: Dallas B.

description:
Wow, their hours are like...non existent. Bright side, the hours they ARE open have prime parking outside. Clement is like, no bueno for the parking.

Came here a few weeks ago with a couple of friends. It was FREEZING outside, but they were nice enough to take down our phone number so we could huddle in the warmth of the car. Halu isn't big enough for people to wait inside...its barely big enough to eat. Group of no more than 4 people please! Bring a group of 10 and you've basically got the entire restaurant (I exaggerate, its really like 20...). 

They serve the food Japanese-style, with the skewers and small plates first, and the soups later. Unfortunately for me, my group wanted skewers and I wanted noodles. Guess who had to wait a long time until we finally asked them to change the delivery of the food??  Winning? Nah, failing. 

The food itself was really good. My friends had the gizzard, mushrooms, rice balls, scallop bacon, and a couple of the ground meat ones. They offered me a few bites during the long wait...and everything was good. =)

I had a basic chasu ramen and it was pretty good! Evidence of good ramen is a decent broth, but delicious noodes that has a slight bite to it. Learned it at Ikemen in LA, when the owner/chef explained it all to me (feelin' like a Ramen expert now...make way!!). 

Service was decent. They had about 2 waitresses for the small space that was there, so it made sense that service would be good.  Seated in the back against a wall, I did notice there were a lot of dates happening. One couple, whom we were sure was on a first date, split the bill...guess no second date?? Ehh??

For the short wait, and decent food, I'd give it a 4. I'm not sure if I would wait in a super long line for this...
author: Lily W.

description:
With its kitschy decor, showcasing a vast collection of Beatles memorabilia and a giant poster of The Who, Halu feels more like a college dorm room than the restaurant that it purports to be. Not that this is necessarily a bad thing, as the Beatles-theme of this hole in the wall definitely offers a certain uniqueness that one would be hard-pressed to find elsewhere. 

However, this was sadly the most memorable aspect of our meal. While the food certainly wasn't poor, it remained largely unremarkable and if it weren't for its funky Beatles-theme, I may have forgotten about Halu altogether. 

For starters, the wait time between arrival and actual food consumption is incredibly long. The restaurant is tiny, so it's almost guaranteed a table won't be readily available when you come. Combined with the snail's pace the kitchen maintains, a trip to Halu can be a pretty arduous one. 

Wait time aside, the food was only middle of the line for me. I came to Halu for three reasons: (1) Bacon Wrapped Mochi (2) Okonomiyaki (3) Ramen. Unfortunately, none of these dishes excelled. 

Bacon Wrapped Mochi - After months of fantasizing about it , I was super excited to finally sink my teeth into some. However, I was pretty disappointed with the real deal. While the texture of crispy bacon paired nicely with the the soft chewiness of mochi, Halu's was super greasy and on the bland side. 

Seafood Okonomiyaki - It took close to 1.5 hours to make; however, the final product didn't quite justify the long preparation time. It was tasty enough and the amount of seafood in it was generous, but the pancake itself was a little burnt. After sitting on the table for a while, it hardened to a cracker-like texture. So, try to eat it immediately, while it's still warm and kind of soft!

Ramen - This was the biggest disappointment. I opted for the Corn Butter one while my friends got the Lava and Spicy Karage Ramen. The annoying thing was that they staggered the timing of our ramen. The first two bowls came out together, but the third bowl didn't come out until 30 minutes later. As for the ramen itself, the noodles tasted like the instant kind and didn't have the springy texture that I prefer. The broth was nothing special. Too salty in my opinion. Also, if you have an aversion to spicy foods like I do, stay clear of the Lava and Spicy Karage Ramen. Even my friends who love spicy foods had a hard time getting these down. 

Overall, I might be willing to come here again. But, it definitely wouldn't be at the top of my list...especially not if I'm craving ramen. THREE STARS.
author: Natasha H.

description:
I spent more time waiting than I did eating + wait time to pay the bill. 
There are 24 seats + 5 bar seats. 
Keep in mind that there is only one table of 6 in the very back. 

As you enter the restaurant, the entire kitchen is to your right. 
The interior is decorated with music bands, mostly the Beatles. 

I had the char siew ramen (regular spice). The meat is very generous, thicker than other places (imagine 3 quarters on top of teach other) as well as the portion size. I am not a huge fan of the ramen noodle. They're a bit more rubbery when compared to other ramen houses. The broth was yummy, but pretty salty. 

My friend had the spicy char siew ramen and they said it was "really" spicy. 

As stated before, this place is a hole in the wall, to accommodate the very generous 29-30 seats, you will be pretty close to other foodies. Thus, this place is LOUD. 

The waitstaff is super friendly and quick. 
The waitlist is usually with one of the waitstaff.
author: Jess W.

description: I am such a fan of Halu! Great service, cool ambiance. I can't wait to go back, have sake at the bar and try different ramen. That was my first time trying fried chicken in ramen, you would think it would be soggy but it was packed full of favor and spices!
author: Skye J.

description:
Easily the best ramen place in all of San Francisco. There's a reason it has people lining up outside an hour before it even opens. 
If I had 4 stomaches I would order 4 bowls of ramen here and still take more to-go. 
Also has a nice environment, chill music, space for maybe less than 20 people, really has a cozy and almost romantic setting. Great place for a date.
author: Yevgeniy V.

description: This place loves the Beatles!!!  Found this place via a review on Facebook.  They serve ramen and have several must try's. We ordered the nori with mochi. Along with salmon and bonito rice ball along with their char shui ramen.  Small kitchen so dishes came out one dish at a time.  Waitress forgot one dish - we were so full we didn't need it. Neat experience must go and try their other items on the menu.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This is the best ramen I've ever had in the Bay Area, and maybe the best I've ever had in my life. The ramen is just out of this world. I've also tried a range of their skewers and loved them all. I just can't say enough nice things about this place. The place also has a really awesome atmosphere, with tons of cool Beatles stuff on the wall, a good vibe, and good beer. What more do you want!

Ok, maybe the one downside is the size of the place. If you come at a busy time, I guess you'll have to wait. But... the food is amazing! So much heart in this little gem, I can't wait till my next visit!
author: Sam S.

description:
Cute little place and was packed on a tuesday evening when my party of four came in. Waited approximately 20 min until we were seated right away when the bar opened up. Saw that they had echigo red so we had to try that and it was delicious (sort of like IPA). Service was prompt and efficient; our server Erica was very nice, attentive, and patient with all our questions (which we had a lot). She also knew what each of us ordered and seperated everything for us so we did not accidentally eat each other's order, because we did order a lottt of food. 
Food I had (all vegetarian) : 
Veggie pizza- very unique and interesting, not what I expected due to the tonkatsu sauce but not bad 
Soy sauce mochi app- not my favorite; thought it was a little too bland, but that's just mochi 
Cold tofu app-very flavorful and appetizing 
Ume onigiri- loved it! Perfect combination of sour and salty 
Mustard green onigiri- not my thing but my companions liked it; the combination was a little too salty 
Mushroom steak app- very unique and had a strong taste to it, pieces of tofu inside 
Eringi yakotori- really good and grilled perfectly; tasted even better with sauce 

My companions ordered many of the meat items and the ones they enjoyed the most were the chicken wings (rock salt), chicken thighs (shiso/ume),  beef belly,  and gyozas. 

Overall, 5 stars to the cute ambiance, good food, good alcohol, and good service.
author: Lydia H.

description:
One of the best kept secrets in San Francisco.

Nojo - you should be ashamed for charging so much.
author: Koalie W.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night and got a table right away. Really a hole in the wall but they managed to fit my party of 7. I love the Beatles so the music and decor was awesome. Waitresses were super friendly and bubbly. Service was attentive. 
Food: they didn't have bacon that night :(
* fried mochi was savory and really yummy 
* combo okonomiyaki was flavorful 
* stuffed mushrooms were okay 
* spicy chashu ramen was pretty good, loved the egg and big portion. They don't skimp on the meat! I'd say it's medium spicy

Got a bottle of this sweet and spicy sake which was interesting and some asahi to finish the night. Overall, great service and extensive menu-- would come back to try their yakitori
author: Reggie L.

description:
It twas a cold, wet, windy San Francisco night.  Perfect for a warm bowl of ramen in a small cozy Japanese restaurant.

...well until the waitress came over and told us yakitori was their specialty.  doh!  yakitori was indeed pretty good.  I thought the ramen was average but maybe I'm a bit influenced by the fact we waited a good half hour after the yakitori came out for the ramen to be served and it was only 3/4 bowls that came out.  Had to wait another 10-15mins for the 4th bowl to come out.  The spicy pork broth from the chashu lava ramen was indeed very very spicy so watch out.  The karaage chicken part of the karaage chicken ramen was deep fried well so make sure not to get it wet or you'll lose the crispy fried goodness!

and then it was back out to the cold, wet, windy San Francisco night.  Oh until the waitress came out and chased us for a tip because even though it says on the menu gratuity of 20% for parties of more than 6 they don't actually automatically include this on the bill.
author: Angela Y.

description:
Ordered ramen and the yakitori dinner. Ramen was ok, pretty salty. The yakitori dinner had a variety of different yakitori and i loved all of them. The stuffed mushroom, meatballs, and salad it came with as all sooooo good. All for a reasonable price too.

Service was great. Everyone was so nice. It had a nice ambiance. I'd come here again to chill with a couple of friends and drink beers and eat. The place is really small and probably only seats about 20 all together, so I wouldn't come here with a large group.
author: Christina L.

description:
6:20 PM - Walked in and were seated immediately at the counter (hooray party of 2)!

6:40 PM - Someone came around to take our order: two of the Pacific Blue Shrimp yakitori ($11), one steak fillet skewer ($12), the erichan special, which was seaweed-wrapped mochi ($6.50), gyoza ($6) and two orders of the chashu-men - ramen with chashu, and BF got his spicy (+$1)

7:10 PM - Mochi arrived.  DELICIOUS.  Buttery, savory mochi and seaweed.  

7:30 PM - Shrimp skewers arrived.  Sizable shrimp, but roasted to a crisp and it was hard to get the shell off.  No flavor otherwise.  Not worth $11/shrimp.  Owner asked if we were waiting for anything else.  Ummm, yes, MOST OF OUR FOOD.

7:45 PM - Gyoza arrived.  Completely flavorless.  But at least it looked like it was freshly made and not over-fried.  Owner said, "this should be your last dish!"  to which we were like, UH NO.

8:00 PM - Owner came and gave us an order of calimari on the house and apologized for the wait.  This was pretty good, and I liked the dipping sauce.

8:05 PM - Steak fillet skewer came.  Probably the second best thing I had here.  Juicy, tender steak with three spoonfuls of daikon on top.  I could've eaten a whole meal of these, but at $12/pop, it's dang expensive.

8:20 PM - Ramen FINALLY came.  Pork was incredibly tender and there were three large pieces, portion size larger than any place I've ever had.  Amazingly chewy and delicious noodles.  Unfortunately, the broth was so salty it was bitter, and I couldn't eat more than a few spoonfuls and had to give the rest to BF.

I seriously cannot believe the turnover is so slow here.  I understand the kitchen is super tiny, but there needs to be a way to streamline things so they aren't asking what else we're missing, and seriously, 2 hours to get all of our food?  Ridiculous.  Either limit your menu so you can just make a couple things and speed it up, or have a better system to take care of your customers so they aren't sitting there, feeling abandoned.  The few times that one of the two girls came to take care of us, they were really nice and sweet, but those moments were really rare.

Probably won't be returning.  But thanks, now I can cross off another ramen place on my to-do list.
author: Tori S.

description:
I wanted to take the bf out to dinner and I had Halu on my bookmarks for a while. We came on a Friday evening at around 745 expecting to wait. Fortunately, there were two available tables upon our arrival.  The space was very small.

The place wasn't extremely busy but the waitress was all over the place. It took us a while to flag her down and place our orders. Then, it took forever to get our tea (we had to ask twice) and it took at least 35 minutes to receive our orders. That's a LOT of waiting.  However, I was hopeful that the food would make up for the long wait. The seizure-inducing anime on the television set wasn't helping either.

And then the food came.. It was excellent. Definitely worth the wait.  We ordered (in pairs of 2 skewers each): 

Yakitori:
bacon wrapped mochi, chicken wings, chicken thigh, bacon wrapped scallops, shrimp, pork and onion

Karage:
Basil chicken, scallops, shrimp

Ramen:
Lava

The yakitori and karage average $5 for 2 skewers.  Portions are on the small side.  Skip the karage - order more yakitori.  My favorite are the chicken wings and bacon wrapped scallop.  The mochi was very interesting with a crunchy exterior.  The basil chicken karage was good too.  The lava ramen was indeed very spicy!  It is the spiciest ramen I have ever had so far, before adding the chili pepper.

Unfortunately, they didn't have chicken skin.  Minimum charge for credit cards is $20.

Two thumbs up!
author: Vivian H.

description:
Wish I had found this place a year ago when I was craving for yakitori. Great things can be found on a stick at Halu. The service was ultra friendly. A family of four run the small charming and ecletic joint in the heart of the Richmond district. Although we didn't drink this evening, they offer a wide assortment of Asian alcoholic beverages - beer, sake, soju, and plum wine. 

Went there initially to try the ramen, which I would give 2.75 stars for a borderline ok, but the yakitori is amazingly delicious hence the 4-star overall rating. 

Decor is charming with an affixiation to the Beatles. Small but charming. Not recommended for groups over 8.... just so happen there was a party of 8 when we left. This is what I imagine Japan to be like with their myriad of tiny shops in alley ways! Can't wait to visit!
author: Stephen Y.

description: Excellent skewers, and the ramen was definitely big enough to share with another! Great little hole in the wall.
author: Casey H.

description:
First the good news. The food is not bad. Not authentic, but I do not believe they claim to be nor is it necessary, just worth mentioning. If you are looking for traditional donburi in a bowl, for example, this is not your place. Most items executed well.

Now the bad news: facilities and service. The place is tiny and can get loud. Even when you get a seat (may god help you if you get a seat at the bar by the drafty and busy door) you will be forever jostled by patrons and staff coming and going. And with SF's cool weather, a blast happens with every door opening. 

No reservations are taken. In a Friday night my party arrived at 6 and was told we would wait 40 minutes. We agreed to wait, but this means outdoors. 75 minutes later we were shown a table.

The drink orders were so rushed I never got to order before the server left. I asked our food server to send the drink server back but she never did. The food arrived on a staggered basis over 15 to 20 minutes and one member of the party did not get her meal until the rest of us were done (and we had delayed starting out of deference).

On top of that I found servers rather disinterested, never apologizing or at least explaining why service was so bad (for example, anyone would be somewhat sympathetic to "I am so sorry but it is swamped tonight and we are down one person",etc).

Too many restaurants in the city for me to put this one on my "must return" list.
author: E F.

description: Got there at 5 when they opened and had a short wait. Staff were super friendly and the food was great. Had ramen and would highly recommend. Skewers were delicious but fairly small.
author: Mitch C.

description:
Very good place! It is not a good place but will bring you Japanese old school style, the store theme is Beatles! 
Food is delicious, make you feel like you are in Japan. Recommend try everything on the menu, you will find surprise, that is not much, because Japanese plates are very small.
author: Yiwei Z.

description:
I love the atmosphere, cozy and friendly. 
I haven't try their ramen yet, but grilled stuffs were so good, especially grilled veggie set. This is my new favorite spot to get some sake and I wish they open late night.
author: Gin C.

description:
One of the best robatayaki places in the city IMO.
Had the Koumi don which was great and healthy (brown rice, side of salad, and marinated fried chik teriyaki).
And then for the satays, had the Beef tounge, ground chicken, bacon mochi (1st time!), and chicken wings. They were all great and highly recommended.

Also, the restaurant is decorated with Beetles and Jomi Hendrix memoribilia which i thought was pretty cool.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I have to say this, this place has been one of my favorite place in the city for almost 5 years, I went there regularly (like 3 + time a month for 5 years) for great food and awesome atmosphere even though they have a long wait sometimes, and I always brought other people and recommended this place to friends.   
However, I will not be coming here anymore after tonight to be honest, because they recommended a beer to a loyal, regular customer without notifying that the beer is $25 per bottle. 

I'm sure I'll miss the food, but this is good enough reason for me to stop going there.

I'd say,you might wanna check before you order how much the beer is, cause they wouldn't voluntarily tell you if it is $25 per bottle.
author: KyuHee K.

description:
I went here with a couple friends for dinner. I ordered the chashu ramen lava spicy. It wasn't too spicy when I first started eating but then it slowly got more spicy. I liked the ramen noodles. They were not over cooked and had a good firmness to them. There were several large pieces of chashu in the bowl. The meat had good flavor. There was also half an egg in the bowl. My friends ordered the yakitori and it looked very good.  

The service was pretty good. The restaurant is really small inside. They play beetles music and have beetles artwork covering the walls. They don't serve any sushi. Come here for the great ramen and yakitori. I Wish they would open for lunch.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Stopped by this weekend for a good dinner.  I had the fried chicke donburi and my GF had the ramen.  Both were good.  The gyoza was very good.  

A few things I wanted to note.  1)  It's a small place, so you'll get familiar with your neighbors conversation. 2)  They'll take your name and phone number so you can grab a beer at Steins while you wait.  3)  The menu (printed and whiteboard) has a lot of stuff on it that might not be familiar to you, but that shouldn't dissuade you from asking questions and trying something different.
author: Larry L.

description:
this hole in the wall is heaven in a sock! Completely intimate there is barely any room to shift around. But we're not here to be comfortable it's all about the food! 

This place can surely get crowded and a line out the door, i would suggest you only go with a party of 2 or 3 at most. 

I love all the skewers, we tried beef tongue, pork cheek, bacon wrapped quail eggs, rib eye, shiso pepper, everything was delectable! 

I love takowasabi and not many places offer it, so its was another pleasant treat. But the service, the tiny atmosphere was awesome, this will be my new go to spot in SF.
author: Zane T.

description:
five years later, this place is still one of my favorite places to go. 

theres just something to this place that cant be replicated. 

amazing family run place. still damn good food. i just wish i still lived close by!
author: Euge L.

description: We stumbled upon this restaurant on a dark and gloomy day, and were pleasantly surprised. We arrived at 5, which is the same time it opened but we had to wait a few minutes to be seated. The Beatles theme in the resultant made for good table conversation while we waited for our meal. The service was efficient and prompt. I ordered the chasu-men with roasted pork, and added spice for an extra dollar (which was a little annoying but still worth it). The ramen noodles cooked to perfection, and I throughly enjoyed my meal. Overall, a great dining experience at a great restaurant. I definitely would return if in the the area.
author: Roberto V.

description:
I really loved eating at Halu. It felt like a page torn out of a Murakami novel, all of that eccentric Beatles paraphernalia packed into a tiny whole in the wall of a restaurant.

I had been snacking at the many dim sum shops down the corner, so I only ordered the stuffed mushrooms, chicken wings (skewered), and an Asahi. But oh my gosh, everything was just delicious and so satisfying. The fact that we didn't have to endure a really long wait made it extra special too. Will definitely come back.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
This little gem is a quite hidden and is very small! My boyfriend and I went on a Saturday night and there was a 25 minute wait, not too shabby. The service isn't amazing but that's only because it is always full inside and there's only a couple of waitresses. 

My boyfriend and I both had the Chasu ramen, and it was delicious! I did not expect it to be so yummy. We both ate the entire bowl and left very satisfied. If you like ramen, then you should definitely give Halu a try.
author: Serina W.

description:
i'd say that this place totes has the potential to be quite hard to miss, but luckily, the HALU sign in size 1500 font makes it quite findable. you can see the sign from Clement street, even though the restaurant is off to the side on 8th Ave!

the place is tiny! it's crammed with Beatles paraphernalia and other knickknacks. there's a counter that squeezes about 6 stools, and a handful of tables for 2. i would recommend not coming with more than a party of 2, otherwise you'll be waiting for years.

luckily, we were able to squeeze the two of us into the counter seating area. unluckily, i was seated next to a ... full grown bulky (buff?) dude. both of us are wearing fleeces, so we are essentially elbow to elbow. we laugh awkwardly at how cozy we are and remove our fleeces, so now there is about a 1 inch gap between our elbows. awkwardness slightly resolved, until i drop my  chopstick wrapper and it conveniently falls into his lap due to our close proximity to each other. and back to awkward we go...

bathroom was cute, had one of those squishy toilet seats that you really get to sink your behind into. not enough room to open the (outswinging) door so i nearly hit the man in line for the bathroom outside.

both of us ordered the chashumen ramen (~10-11 bucks), which came with noodles, ginger, bean sprouts, onions, corn, and an egg in a pretty large sized bowl. noodles were bomb and plentiful and cooked to al dente perfection. broth was flavorful. meat was PLENTIFUL! i wasn't expecting that many pieces of meat floating around but hey, the more the merrier! pleasantly surprised.

we also ordered 3 types of yakitori - pork and onion, flat steak, and bacon wrapped scallops. delish! pork was tender and went perfectly well with the onion. the flat steak was seared . bacon wrapped scallops are self explanatory, aka oily heaven in my mouth.

overall halu is in my top 5 for ramen, but it doesn't quite hit the top spot for me. however, i would be willing to come back here again to try the karaage ramen and the other yakitori!
author: Caitlin C.

description:
While the ramen was not as good as some of the south bay ramen places, it's the best we've yet tried in the city and was the highlight of our meal. After the ramen, we had several skewers - katsu shrimp, shiso beef, chicken skin, bacon wrapped scallop, chicken thigh, and enoki mushroom. Overall the skewers were excellent - favorites were the shiso beef and the enoki mushroom.

They have a good selection of reasonably priced sake and we really enjoyed one of the unfiltered ones.

Contrary to prior reports, we found the waiting system to be quite fair. They took everyone's name and number and called when their table was ready (even though most groups were just waiting outside). We appreciated the ability to wander through Green Apple books while waiting the 45-60 minutes for our table.
author: Amy D.

description: After a failed hunt for cheap dim sum in the neighborhood, we found Halu unassumingly tucked away next to a store that sells arguably the most hilarious cat-themed spandex I've ever seen (not relevant to Halu, just a bonus for your eyes). From other reviews it looks like there is usually a huge line, but the 3 of us walked in and were immediately seated. AMAZING Ramen--definitely the best I've had in a long time. Fried chicken in ramen = my happy place. Also loved the Beatles/psychedelic decor and the tiger staring at you in the bathroom (definitely go to the bathroom while you're here). Great find!
author: Limor F.

description: I don't know why this restaurant has 4 stars. Sunomono is totally nasty. I have never had that like fucking taste.Ramen is also disgusting. The taste reminds me of Katnaya terrible ramen. I think they add a lot of MSG because my tongue felt numb.  Never return.
author: Sea F.

description: The yakitori was pretty good but the ramen was mediocre. They charge $13 per bowl so I expected something amazing but was pretty let down with the quality of what I got (I ordered karaage ramen). That being said I have high standards for ramen and this place just didn't do it for me...
author: Jamie T.

description: Very few seats and slow service, so avoid the typical dinner hours. The Beatles memorabilia was cool, the waitresses were nice, but I gotta say the ramen is nothing special. It's definitely westernized and not authentic Japanese ramen. However, the grilled beef skewers were MINDBLOWING! It's grilled crack. It's crack man, because like 3 skewers are $8 and you'll go broke trying to get full. They're so good though. I don't know how they make it so good. It's just steak with chili powder on it...you got some more of them skewers mang??
author: Abel W.

description:
I guess, to start, I haven't been to a whole lot of yakitori joints. 
I mean, I get a skewer here and there and it's usually pretty good and all.
Grilled meat or what-have-you on a stick. Big whoop right?
But dang, this place... It was my wake up call that I've been missing out.
For the most part, everything's just seasoned with salt, maybe. 
But that's all it really needs. Everything's cooked perfectly. 
My skewers weren't all burnt to a crisp, and nothing was dry. 
I can't remember what I ordered; probably most of the stuff on the menu and on the specials list. 
What I do remember is... Beef tongue. 
All I can think about now is making out with that tender juicy tongue and drinking beer. 
Other than the yakitori stuff, I didn't try anything else. 
So, for now, this baby's getting 5 stars (just for the yakitori) 

This joint is pretty small and has limited seating. 
There's like this Beatles theme going on. 
Restroom's are a tad troublesome to get into.

Oh, btw, get the butter fried mochi wrapped in seaweed. You'll thank yourself later. 

Laaaaate.
author: Garland W.

description:
Not quite sure why this place is so popular.  The filet skewers were quite plain and at 12 bucks, it's a bit pricey for 2 little pieces of beef.  The chashu ramen was a bit salty and somewhat plain.  Fried salmon skewer was good, but also on the plain side.  The best item of the evening was the grilled Mochi, which was soft, chewy, and sandwiched between two pieces of Nori.

Though they were under staffed, our service was quite good. 

The verdict?  I would go to Chotto or Sozai for Ramen or Izakaya....
author: Paul K.

description:
I'll preface this review with the fact that I realize that some of these things are going to be one-time events, and will probably not happen to anything else. That being said, my review:

It was pretty cold outside so getting some ramen sounded like a good idea. I've heard some good things about Halu, so I decided to give it a try.

The place is small, but they gave me a seat at the counter right next to the door. Probably the worst seat in the house, constantly being blasted by wind when the door opens and bumped by other people entering and exiting. I was able to be moved a little further in later on in the meal.

I sat down and put my arms down on the counter, and felt something metallic. I looked down and there was a 2" RAZOR BLADE under my arm. I flagged a waitress gave it to them and I just got a 'oops' as she took it away. 

10 mins after that, she asked me if I wanted any water. I said yes and got it 10 mins after that when she came to take my order. 

I ordered karage ramen and beef yakitori. I got my yakitori in 15 mins, but still had no napkin and utensils. Yakitori was really good though, some of the best I've had in the city.

I finished the skewers and continued to wait an additional 60 MINUTES for the ramen. The guy next to me had his ramen delivered to the wrong table, and waited an additional 30-40 mins. Be prepared to wait even if you're already at a table.

The ramen itself was pretty tasty. Noodles were solid, karage in it was nice and tender, and a good mix of toppings. The egg was a little disappointing because it was refrigerated, instead of a nice soft boiled egg. The broth was a little salty for my taste as well, but I know this is more of a regional thing. It was a good bowl of ramen, definitely not worth waiting over 60 mins for though. I would rather go to Izakaya Sozai or Chotto.

My total dinner time was a little over 90 minutes.

Not sure how this place has such great reviews. Food is above average, but the wait and terrible service ends up making it just ok.
author: George T.

description:
Originally clicked on 5-stars, but I think it's a touch on the pricey side for what you get, so dropping to 4.

Halu is one of those restaurants that really belongs in a more hipster part of town than the Inner Richmond.  Amazing vibe, its a weird combination of Japanese/Beatles mashup - hard to explain.  The service and staff are very friendly and very helpful at explaining the huge array of items.  I've been there on numerous dates/double-dates, and can't say I've explored even half the menu yet.

Specifically wanted to touch on the ramen here, for my list-making purposes :)

Broth: great - light, yet perfectly balanced and flavorful. Its surprisingly good in fact, considering it doesn't even seem like ramen is the focus of their menu.  

Noodles: also great - thin and soft and just the way I like them.  

Meat & veggies: just right - nothing mindblowing, but nothing distracting either.

Overall its a strong bowl, and definitely should be on your list of things to try.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Too expensive for a little less than mediocre food...

Venue: Very small and cramped restaurant. my party of 11 filled more than half of the restaurant. Semi busy.

Service: Good.

Food:
- Heart $2.50, Scallop bacon $3 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/j7ZO28rAdTVlQdE2zJSSTA?select=oONDFoNpkKzG6Z4N7LbGnA) - Scallop bacon was good! But $3 for two small pieces?... it wasn't THAT good... Heart was ok but not for the price.

- Chicken ramen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/j7ZO28rAdTVlQdE2zJSSTA?select=zJF6_NkYG6tdSOnbkfVy9g) -$11.50 Broth wasnt really that flavorful and noodles were okay... 

- Chasui ramen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/j7ZO28rAdTVlQdE2zJSSTA?select=GxDhk11lAQM7YlAdjDJIzA) - $10.50 same as the chicken... had better someone else for cheaper...

Price: WAAAAAaay too over priced for food that isn't that good. I've had ramen elsewhere for a lot better and cheaper. Skewers weren't bad but the price is too expensive...

Overall: I do not recommend...
author: Jannifer H.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night because the boyfriend wanted ramen while I wanted pho but we settled on ramen because we just had pho - the requirement was that we must try a new ramen place because we have been going to the same one for the past 3 or 4 times. And here we are, writing a review about Halu..

Had the chasu-men, scalloped wrapped bacon, and stuffed mushrooms.

Stuffed mushroom: delicious, I loved the sauce, and I would definitely go back to have more of these little babies or I need to find a recipe close enough to imitate at home. 

Scalloped wrapped bacon: also delicious but compared to the stuffed mushrooms they were just okay, I probably would not get this again but it was cooked perfectly, the scallop was taste and the bacon was delicious.

Chasu-men: I wouldn't say this is my favorite ramen and I don't think I would purposely come back here for the ramen. The broth was not flavorful, I would say that it definitely lacked in flavor which made it just "meh" but it does come with lots of noodles and big pieces of chasu. 

If I were to come back my main goal would be order from the yakitori side of the menu!
author: Mona L.

description:
Long before the izakaya scene in the Bay Area, there was always Halu. Walking in, the sign on the front door is hilarious, "No Sushi served here." The walls are decorated full of Beatles memorabilia and they have oldies jammin on the speakers. 

-okonomiyaki. AWESOME and flavorful...would order each and every time
-chashu ramen was just alright. it was ordinary compared to what other places are doing now, which I'm slightly biased towards.
-short rib skewers were cooked well but I've had korean probably too often to understand the lack of korean marinade.
-bacon wrapped mochi was pretty good
-bacon wrapped cherry tomoatoes were GREAT. the crispy salty bacon is complimented so well with moist juicy tomato

It's a small place, but we got there early so we didn't have a problem getting seated at a table. Later when the place packed, they asked us to split the tables to accomodate other diners. And when we left, there was a line.
author: Dennis L.

description:
Halu represents something special.  One of the last bastions of restaurants in San Francisco with character and an amazing menu and staff.  I love the servers although recently we had some misorders. The entire restaurant is Beatles themed with really special memorabilia. I keep finding new items every time I go in. 
We live 5 blocks away and find any opportunity we can to go there.  
Not a good place for more than four people.  It's tiny and a little loud. But fun. Good date spot. 
The yakatori is well composed and relies on perfect cooking time and the flavor of the meat or veggie. Get the chicken wings, chicken heart or avo beef. 
And the ramen. Oh my. Although not the best ramen I have had its solid and one of the top 5 in the city.  It is unique like all ramen so don't compare it. To an Ozakaya sozai.  I do recommend getting the chashu ramen spicy. The karage is too dense and takes away from the broth. The corn butter ramen is excellent but not an every visit sort of recipe. 
The Erichans special is an orgasmic mocha wrapped in nori. Its a little hard to eat but well done. 
Also don't forget the okonomyaki.  It is filling but prepared light.  The flavors are distinct and traditional making it feel authentic. The price has skyrocketed in the last year but the mixed seafood is awesome.
author: Darius D.

description: Quirky yet fun space filled with Beatles paraphernalia. The restaurant is extremely small. I felt a bit claustrophobic being seated by the doorway but heard great things about Halu and stayed. Props to the one young server trying to manage all these tables in a the tiny place. I skipped ordering any yakitori to leave room for sake and ramen. Took longer than expected for our dishes to come out. I had the chashu-men which came with all the usual fixings: corn, ginger, egg, & slices of pork. I did not like the addition of bean sprouts and green onion. The bean sprouts were raw and distracting with every bite! Although a bit disappointed with the flavors, i get the cozy neighborhood vibe. They're welcoming and the staff is obviously a hard working bunch.
author: Samantha L.

description: Halu is amazing. They have some of my favorite Ramen in the city and they definitely have my favorite yakitori. The wait can be a while occasionally but they'll take your number and call you when your table is ready. Richmond Republic is around the corner so you can grab a drink while you wait.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Checked in at around 7pm, and waited 30 minutes to get seated. It's a "hole-in-the-wall," so it can get a bit crowded inside. The service was good and our waitress was very friendly. 

My friend and I ordered the marinated octopus/sashimi/squid sampler, the pork jowl skewers, gizzard skewers, pot stickers, and the chasu-men ramen. 

I was quite disappointed with the ramen, it was mediocre at best. The broth was quite bland and overall very salty. The appetizers were delicious, especially the pork jowl skewers and the pot stickers. I would come back again, but just for the appetizers. I would not recommend the ramen.
author: Cass Y.

description:
Sushi free zone. 

This is like a good 'ol american diner but written in Japanese.

Order the Bacon Wrapped Mochi.

The service was perfect. The waitress was really nice and took the time to explain to me items on the menu I did not understand. I've only been once but will soon be a regular.
author: Justin S.

description:
Favorite ramen place in sf! I also love their chicken skewers, veggie heaven salad, and Mochi. Don't worry if you can't finish the spicy charsu ramen, it's just as good the next day. 

The service is slow, but the waitresses are super friendly. It's just a really busy small restaurant.
author: annie n.

description:
Quite simply one of the best restaurants in SF.  Food is great.  Space is great.  Owners/servers are great.  The prices are a little high for the skewers, but overall, the prices are better than most every other good restaurant in SF.  I love it here.

It's tiny and there is often a wait, but there are bars around you can go and they will call when your table is ready.

Everything on the menu is worth trying.

Go here.  it rocks
author: Michael S.

description:
Halu is good. I've been here one too many times to remember exactly what I've had... but everything was good. Some memorable items:

Ramen (any kind) - The ramen was always cooked perfectly, not too soft, not too chewy. The broth is delicious as well.

Stuffed Mushroom Kushi Katsu(?) - I always get this when I come here! The stuffing is just so refreshing, and then you get into the battered mushroom and they just melt together deliciously.

Bacon wrapped mochi - Not the biggest fan, but it's worth trying just to know what it's like.

Basically I recommend any of the skewer items (that's what they're known for!). The price is not the cheapest, but it's also not super expensive.
author: Munnie T.

description:
this is strictly for ramen and service.

came in on a Thursday night and place was packed. it's already a pretty small place so my group of 4 was willing to wait. you can put your name and number down and they will call you.

waited about 45 minutes and finally got a table.  everyone was craving ramen so we got two cha siu and two chicken karage ramens.

waited probably another 45-1 hour for my ramen.... yes 45 minutes for a ramen?!!! as I starved myself some more, I sat and finally after the 30 minutes a waitress tells us it's going to be another 15-20 minutes and it's coming soon.  

ramens finally came.  and let me just say we were jus happy to finally eat. however, my friends order of corn on the side didn't coome and also one of the ramens were missing an egg. cmon!!! we waited and the least would have been the correct order. we were too hungry and didn't want to bother them since it was already super packed.

cha Siu was basic and I don't understand why it even took so long. nothing special but they did give a nice amount of meat. the chicken karage was probably the best. big pieces and nicely fried. ramen and broth was nothing special and I would have not waited for 45 mins for it......

I will still want to come back to try the yakitori since it's known for this, but not for the ramen.
author: Josie L.

description:
Still my favorite place for yakitori!

New must orders:
- chicken thigh (momo) w/ yuzukosho
- katsu trumpet mushrooms
- erichan special: buttermochi
- gyutoro - beef belly steak
- gyoza - homemade!!

Tip: the workers at this spot are the best :)
author: Kristen C.

description:
The signage said it all: "A Different Japanese Restaurant". It was different alright. I have driven by a zillion times and never noticed the place until I read the reviews. I arrived @ 5.15pm and from the outside, it looked dark and dingy like there were some construction works going on inside. The sign at the front door still said "closed" and the frontage looked uninviting. The inside though was quite cute. The walls were adorned with Beatles paraphernalia, posters of the Grateful Dead, The Who and Jimi Hendrix. Signs of a bygone era like "Love", "Peace" and "End of War" were posted in the restaurant. The inside had a funky vibe and the ambience was like an old English pub. it also looked somewhat like my old college dorm! The atmosphere was incompatible with the kind of food they served though I don't mean it in a bad way. I found out that the reason for the upbeat hippie look. The yakitori chef (owner?) was a musician before and obviously a big Beatles fan.

The decor did bring back some fond memories of the 60s and 70s but the food didn't quite measure up. My biggest disappointment was the chashu ramen. The chashu smelled obnoxious and was a big turnoff. It smelled of pig's urine. Damn! This was the second time in three months that I was served with stinky chashu. My other experience was in Great Eastern in Chinatown. The bad pork spoiled the broth as well and my complaint to the server just fell on deaf ears. I can understand once in a while the shipment of pork they buy might be bad but I can't condone or understand how the chef could have failed to detect this and continue serving it to their customers. A big thumbs down on this one.  

I always order skewer/yakitori items whenever i dined in an izakaya place. I am not sure why I picked the basic yakitori fare like chicken liver, chicken gizzard, shitake, stuffed mushroom and salmon yaki onigiri for the evening. They were not bad but were not great either. In addition, I tried the tako wasabi which had good flavor and did give my jaw a good work out. On hindsight, I am sure what I ordered were not their best. There were other stuffs in the menu yelpers raved about. Included in my next to try list - bacon wrapped mochi, rib eye skewer, agedashi tofu and the seafood okonomiyaki (pancake).

The restaurant does have a unique atmosphere that I like and has potential for improvement. On the ramen, they need to pay more attention to meat quality, go easier on the salt and allow the pork bones to simmer longer for better broth flavor.
author: Geoff G.

description:
This place is bomb.....

Great service. ....  small place but good environment.
Food is best yakitori in the bay area.  Highly  recommended.  

The only the wait too long. And little bit high priced.
author: sean c.

description:
Do not come here if you're in a hurry or really hungry already. Only bring people you love to spend time standing in line and waiting for food with. Basically, everything just takes forever to happen. 

All of the yakitoris are delicious but you would have to wait and wait and wait for the next dish to come out.
author: LeTran B.

description: Food was great. Service was a little slow. When we arrived at 7pm there was only 1 waitress working. She was very attentive but she definitely could have used some extra help. About 30 minutes later a second waitress showed up and the service was a little better.
author: Kelly B.

description: Like most small ramen places there was a wait list. They said 30-45 mins but it actually took a little more than an hour. I wanted the chicken kaarage ramen but they ran out. I ended up getting the chasu ramen. It was too spicy for me. The broth was light, I was hoping for more flavor. The pork belly skewer was delicious. The stuffed mushroom was pretty good too. The Japanese pizza I didn't really care for. I'm giving this place a 2 because of the wait, they ran out of chicken karaage and because it was cramped inside.
author: Lae H.

description:
HALU gets a HELL NO from me. 

I went there on 4/27 with a friend and I had no idea that were going to eat in something a little bigger that a walk-in closet. Ok, not that bad, but you get the idea.

The chashumen ramen was pretty good. Great soup and noodles. However, the chashu pork was chewy, gamey, grey colored and cold as it was floating in the hot broth. You could tell it was refrigerated. Same for the hard boiled egg and corn. The only saving grace for this ramen was the delicious, thick broth and noodles. 

We were told our yakitori order would come AFTER our ramen. It was not-so-good. We had the beef tongue - too chewy. Beef tongue should be tender.  Beef with shiso and ume paste. Traditionally ume(boshi) and flesh-meat are not eaten together. I wanted to try something different. It was OK, but wouldn't do it again. Chicken livers - tasted "dirty" and "muddy."  Even my friend who's a fan of offal noticed the off taste. Oyster chicken - couldn't  really figure out where the oyster came in. The shishito peppers were spot on, but how can you f-that up? 

The worst part is the service. Friendly wait staff, but 45 minutes for the ramen and the yakitori served AFTER our ramen?  For real?

The killer is the tiny space. Waitstaff constantly kicking my chair... Squeezing in between tables and patrons... F-ing distracting.  

For me, this is a Neverland (as in never to return) place. I think this place is OK for your hipsters and cosplay crowd, but not for two 40-some odd year olds. 

My favorite ramen and japanese comfort food joint is HISAGO on Geary. Great food, place and space. The chashumen ramen is incredible!
author: Suburban Shi-Shi J.

description:
Hello, Halu.. 

You walk into this rock of a gem and you are welcomed with friendly service and hit with a musical wave of every single beatles song. What a compilation of everythings beatles by the way, from wall to wall, are plasters of beatles posters, peace signs and more beatles related signage... And then, of course you have the special menu!

WOW their japanese pancake, amazingly crispy outside but soft and doughlike texture with beef. mmm 

Best Ramen I had so far. Usually I don't really care for Ramen because it always ends up just tasting like packets of instant ramen I can eat at home except 4x more expensive. But at Halu, I got the veggie Ramen and it actually had it's own different flavor rather than just tasting like noodles and soup. I can taste the mushrooms and the thinly sliced veggies and their soup had it's original taste. 

Most definitely will come here again!
author: Tiffany N.

description: This place is a hidden gem in the Richmond and well worth the trip. Their robatayaki was really delicious. In particular the beef belly yakitori was one of the best meat dishes I have had in 2015. Their ramen was delicious and original---I got the red miso spicy w chicken cutlet. (I think that makes it Hokkaido style.) Extra points for the very random Beatles theme used in the decor and sound system. Definitely going back.
author: Rob B.

description: Great food. Beatles memorabilia all over the place. I could probably live there for the rest of my life. Thank you Halu team!
author: Kelly T.

description:
Coming here was a mishap. We intended to go to Kukje, but people were on CPT so we instead took the opportunity to cross this restaurant off the to-eat list. Even before entering, you know this place has spunk. The canopy says "A Different Japanese Restaurant" and the door has "no sushi today (or tomorrow)" and "sushi free zone" signs on it. The format is sign up and wait, but rather than a communal clipboard for soon-to-be diners, the list seemed to be managed mentally by the servers.

On a Tuesday evening, we were lucky enough to catch a table upon arrival due to the people before us on the list being neither present nor reachable by phone. Seating was quite limited, with 6 or 7 bar seats and about that many tables. We sat immediately by the door. If you're at the door table with a large(ish) person, I recommend seating them on the side of the table away from the door. As it was, the back of my chair was sometimes getting hit by the door, and a few times my elbow brushed passersby. The many people waiting mostly left and checked back later or waited outside.

Beatles, Beatles, this place is absolutely crawling with Beatles. I hope you like them and I hope you've brushed up on your Beatles edition Rock Band. Beatles music plays from the psychedelic Beatles movie on the screen above the door. Posters are all over the walls and memorabilia crowds the bar top.

All this eye candy kept us busy during the long, drawn-out time it took for our order to be fulfilled in bits and pieces. The place was packed and something like two people were working the stove, so expect to be patient between ordering and getting your food. We ordered 5 kinds of skewers (chicken heart, beef tongue, pork jowl, bacon-wrapped asparagus x 2, and okra), veggie okonomiyaki (similar to pajeon), veggie don, some beverages, and later red bean ice cream. The skewers arrived in several waves. As described in the menu, it indeed took a while for the okonomiyaki to be prepared. Somehow, it was this wait plus even more time before the veggie don (which I see as a much simpler dish) appeared. Keep in mind that the tiny kitchen was cranking out dishes for everyone in the packed restaurant.

The food was, in a word, good. Picture in your mind - and mouth - much savory tastiness, and very slowly reread the food items I listed in our order. Imagine. Concentrate. Whatever feelings you had while doing that, that's how good the dishes were. The okonomiyaki included a faint scent x taste that I couldn't name, and I think it was from the combination of the herbs and fixin's on it. I liked the crisp blackened areas on the top and bottom. We took only three "issues" with the food. Some of the salted skewers were a bit too salty for my friend, but my friend did appreciate the distinctiveness of the specially prepared house salt. Also, the menu listed the veggie don as being over brown rice, but our rice was white. The third thing I noted was that everything seemed oily: the meats, the vegetables, by association the rice - everything. I realize it all had been made on the same greasy stove. Just be ready for it is what I'm saying.

From the time we arrived to the time we departed (and afterward), the workers were more than nice. Friendly, patient, recommending, suggesting, describing... you know, the qualities and actions you want in people who are creating your meal experience. It was a pair of waitresses serving us, but the one who showed up more than the other was animated in her lively talk of the dishes. For example, the don bowl came and its recipient wondered how they'd eat it, as they only had chopsticks. My friend took this somewhat literally and asked our server how to eat the dish. Our server took this to another level and, along with hand gestures, told us her personal process of scooping a bit from one side, scooping some from the other, digging further to get the rice, etc.. This was after a showy recommendation of ways our table could mix up or split the dish to share it. Also, props to our servers and cooks for their flexibility when, about 20 minutes after ordering, we remembered we'd wanted the okonomiyaki sans mayo.

I say the people were still nice after we left because, on our way to our car, we passed by one of the cooks who was hanging out on the sidewalk drinking a hot beverage. They had a friendly conversation with us, friendly even to the point of bowing way too many times. You know how it is. Maybe I'll have to return a few of those bows when friends and I go back to try some of the other dishes that we totally need to eat.
author: Dan B.

description: I love everything in this restaurant! The atmosphere, the music, the waitress was very interesting. She was so enthusiastic. They have the coolest bathroom! the toilet seat was comfy, haha. And of course, the most important thing is THE FOOD! One of the best ramen in town. I ordered Karaage ramen, the taste of the broth was perfect for my taste! We also ordered the Crispy Wings yakitori and I forgot the other one (it's something "melt in your mouth?" beef yakitori), that the waitress recommended and it was delicious! I wish I had known about this restaurant before, because I'm definitely coming back for more. I'm sorry I spilled the yuzu sake!
author: Melinnie A.

description:
H alf Japanese izakaya, half Beatles shrine is the best way to describe Halu
A mbiance is not the most common you'll experience:
L ots of music memorabilia on the walls; "Help" blaring on the sound system 
U ltimately, the food is great and consistently delicious

R ight off Clement, this little gem seats about 20 max
E asily can fill up, but the wait isn't long on most nights I've been here
S mall space makes it feel homely and comforting even if you feel squished in
T he menu is stacked with awesome options like these:
A ppetizer favorites like Asparagus and Agedashi Tofu
U nique treats like Chicken Basil Kushi Katsu and Bacon-wrapped Mochi
R eally delicious yakitori options like Beef Tongue and Kurobuta Sausage
A nd the Beef Veggie Okonimiyaki and Pork Tonkotsu Ramen are superb!
N o, Halu doesn't serve up sushi, so don't embarrass yourself asking for it
T his place is all about the good stuff:  the grilled meats, treats, and Beats.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Very cute place that is Beatles themed - all Beatles music playing and tons of Beatles memorabilia all over the walls.
We tried a bunch of stuff there and it was all very good.
Combo Onkonomiyaki, a bunch of yakitori: pork jowl, chicken with mayo and scallions, stuffed mushrooms, bacon wrapped mochi and chicken skin - all delish!

We came here on a Thursday night around 7:30pm and were seated right away.
author: Michele S.

description:
I'm on a neverending quest to find some of the best ramen in the city, and I have to say that I have found what I can consider some delicious ramen. I wish I did my research more, as I didn't know they had bacon wrapped mochi. I'll have to touch on that later. 

In any case, I loved the ramen. I had the fried chicken ramen and each piece of chicken was super delicious. My friend ordered the corn butter ramen that has the pork, and I gotta say, I wish I ordered that too. Those extra pats of butter really do something. I was sippin on gold or something. 

Definitely coming back here because I haven't been able to stop talking about it to anybody. The decor is super cool, I dig the Beatles stuff and the guitar bathroom. Also, I want to try out this yakitori, I hear it's worth having.
author: Caroline L.

description:
NOTE: A regular bowl of ramen is the listed price. For the spicy option, you need to add an extra dollar. I've never seen this pricing anywhere else... I might as well have brought my own sriracha sauce with me.

A small and cozy Japanese restaurant with about 10 tables and a bar, however, posters of The Beatles albums and other 60s rock bands on the wall plus the loud rock music throw off the traditional Japanese vibe.

We arrived at about 7:30 and left a name plus phone number so they would call us when a table would be available. The manager (?) said it would be about half an hour wait but she did not want to give us "a bullshit estimate".

We were finally seated at 8:30 and ordered by 8:45. Our three bowls of ramen finally arrived at 9:30. While waiting, we noticed that the manager and waitresses especially favored one table of customers. They were obviously friends and received many appetizers "on the house" along with an exchange of casual conversations with swear words. Adding to the long wait, this attitude we observed by the staff really degraded the overall experience of the night.

The ramen wasn't especially fantastic and the noodles itself was hard to chew. I was disappointed when I was served only half an egg with my ramen. Most ramen restaurants serve a delicious soft-boiled egg.

Overall I was quite disappointed and will not be coming back here anytime in the near future. Three bowls of ramen and one small appetizer cost us $50 not including tip. I would recommend you to find someplace else if you are craving ramen as it is not worth the time nor money.
author: Brian C.

description:
Best yakitori I've ever had. So good I wrote a blog post about it on our food website with photos of everything we ate, so you can check it out if you're interested.
 
http://eatsporkjew.com/restaurants/food_and_travel_blog_make_you_fat/

Halu is a tiny little shoe box where large parties either don't get in, or have to wait a really long time. Go in a small group or sit at the counter by your lonesome. The prices and quality of the skewered meats and vegetables can't be beat and they have a wonderful selection of sakes. 

The staff is quick on their feet and do a really good job of serving everyone in such a crowded space. The decor is also a sight to see, with Beatles memorabilia from the 60's and 70's covering every inch of the restaurant.
