If you find yourself in the Inner Richmond, you have to put your name down and check this place out. It's delicious!
author: Philip H.

description:
Their menu lists grilled (yakitori) and deep fried (kushi-katsu) skewers (2 sticks per order), regular or chasu ramen (you get a huge bowl), donburi (don-don), salads, and a nice selection of appetizers and sake/drinks. They also have both white ($1.50) and brown rice ($2). But note that not all items are available every day. For example, they didn't have hijiki (seaweed) or beef tongue on the days I visited.

The house salad is delicious, with avocado and cherry tomatoes. In my opinion, the highlight of my meal was the remarkable chicken karaage, nicely seasoned and very moist. The capelin or shisamo (pregnant fish) appetizer was very nice too. You get 4 small grilled whole fish for $4. The ramen is not the best as others have claimed, just good enough (I could make a better bowl at home). And one time they forgot to put the hard boiled egg in my bowl, no big deal.

The skewers are about $4-5.50 for the meats, and if I remember correctly $2.50-3.00 for the vegetable items. They also have 2 combos that include 7 assorted skewers, with rice and salad ($13.50-16.50). My favorites are the grilled chicken hearts (gizzards are okay too), the stuffed mushrooms, the asparagus wrapped in bacon, and the deep-fried okura (okra).

This small place has 5 or 6 tables, and 5 seats at the counter. When the place is packed they have trouble keeping up with orders (I had to wait +30 minutes before I got any food). They make most items to order, from chopping and assembling the simple salads, to boiling the water for tea (regular size electric kettle), so that system gets bogged down very easily when the place is full. The food portions are moderate, not overly generous, but still okay. And I think that the prices are reasonable (not cheap), considering the quality you get. The husband & wife work in the kitchen behind the counter, while 2 girls (maybe their daughters?) work as the waiter/servers. One of the girls appears more calm when it gets busy, while the other seems to get flustered.

This place was formerly Mama-san. I think that this is the 3rd time this location has changed ownership. The first owners were also a mom-pop & daughter setup, that served teriyaki, donburi, katsu, and later expanded into sushi/sashimi. For many years when I lived in this area, it was one of my favorite dinner spots. Many years later they decided to move and sold the business. The second owners kept the name, and changed the menu towards ramen and other items. But were not able to keep the quality of the original. So they quickly went out of business.
I hope that this new family can manage to keep this business running.

Note: CASH only!!  No credit cards accepted.
author: Luis C.

description:
Hole in the wall. Very limited seating. Not good for parties larger than 4. If you don't want to wait don't come during rush hour. 

Otherwise, food is good. Now that I have experienced ramen from the motherland of all ramens, I don't think it can ever be the same. Everyone loves the chicken karaage ramen. If you like spicy, this is the only spot in town that actually brings the heat! My favorite is the yasai (veggie) spicy ramen. 

Decently priced, good ramen and appetizers, order some beers and call it a night.
author: Stine H.

description:
Meh.  

Sigh.  I so wanted this to be as good as another ramen place I recently visited: it's nice to have choices.  The service was good.  My server was very pleasant, knowledgeable, and friendly (5 stars there).  The ramen though, was not good.  The broth was simple, not at all complex, and very greasy tasting.  The noodles were stuck together, which was very disappointing.  The pork was tasty, and tender.  The ramen gets one star.

The hours posted state that they open at 5PM, but at 5:45PM, the doors were locked and the sign posted said "closed".  I walked around for a little bit on Clement and by the time I came back, they were open -around 6:00 PM.  If you change your hours, you should change your signage too.

Like I said, "meh".  Not so great.  I won't be back.  The search for another ramen place continues...
author: Kristin R.

description: Yum! I loved the ramen at this place.  I got the Lava Ramen and it was nice and spicy and the broth had great flavor.  Will definitely think of Halu next time my ramen craving hits!
author: Elena N.

description:
I can't make it over to Halu every week like I proposed in my initial review, but I did find my way back tonight and I sort of pigged out because everything I ordered was so delicious.

Accepting the advice of Jen D, I ordered the Koumi Don (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/j7ZO28rAdTVlQdE2zJSSTA?select=3NIJPzPE04p8L6ve6iYdlA).  The Koumi Don is a battered and fried piece of boneless chicken thigh meat served over a bed of toasty brown rice.  The layer of batter is super thin so you can easily overlook it, but it adds a nice bit of crunch to the chicken.  A spring mix of assorted greens combined with a vinegar-based dressing comes on the side along with some thin slices of grilled zucchini that had a wonderful sweetness to them.  

In addition I had an order each of the Rib Eye Yakitori and the Scallop Bacon Yakitori (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/j7ZO28rAdTVlQdE2zJSSTA?select=7IhdX5l9cpEvdaB1I1VA8w).  The rib eye steak cut into bite size pieces then skewered and grilled were very tender and perfectly seasoned.  The scallops wrapped in bacon were just dripping with bacon fat.  Mmmm, bacon fat.  Yes, it was excellent.

I didn't stop there though.  I also had an order each of the Asparagus Bacon Yakitori and the Salmon Yakitori (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/j7ZO28rAdTVlQdE2zJSSTA?select=BC6SlJPsIVyuNMHD05mkFQ).  The bacon rolled asparagus pieces were also dripping in bacon fat.  Yum ... bacon fat!  It was the perfect unification of delicious bacon and crunchy asparagus.  The salmon was very good too basted in a sweet teriyaki sauce and topped with granules of black pepper.

I washed everything down with an ice-cold Sapporo (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/j7ZO28rAdTVlQdE2zJSSTA?select=Ak2lgCTnp9Z7msFqxkuG-Q).  I left the restaurant happy and full, and I shall return again!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I frequent Halu a lot and it's one of, if not my favorite, izakayas to go to in SF.

I'll start off with the service. On a busy day, it is pretty hard to get a servers attention at time, but it's not because of negligence. Erika and co. are constantly moving around and when they do get to me, they're nothing but friendly. On a slow day, service is perfect. No complaints.

Next is wait time. On a busy day, it can take awhile for certain things to come out, BUT there always seems to be a steady stream coming to keep me satisfied. I normally spend at least $100 and don't remember a time where we were just waiting with nothing to eat/drink.

As for food quality, it's amazing. I don't think I've had anything I've disliked at Halu. There are somethings that are better than others (in my opinion), but overall no complaints. Yes, the food is a little salty, but I like salty foods so it's not an issue (may be for others). Beef tongue, pork cheek, chicken liver, cilantro/avocado chicken, shiso/ume beef, okra, eringi and shiitake mushrooms, etc are all things I normally order on skewer. Gyoza, soba salad, and kara age is always good too for appetizers. On occasion they carry green tea tiramisu which is my favorite dessert there.

I don't switch it up on drinks too much but they do have my 2 favorite Japanese alcohol beverages: Orion beer and Iichiko shochu. They do have normal sake, flavored sake, chu hai, etc as well, but I normally don't go for those so can't comment on quality.

Lastly, the atmosphere is great. It is a small place, but it reminds me of izakaya in Japan. The Beatles' memorabilia around the place is cool and they always play great tunes. If you don't mind getting cozy around other tables/people, check it out.
author: Steven I.

description:
Halu is the best.  I can say without hesitation that Halu is the most authentic Japanese comfort food spot in the city.  I lived in Japan for 5 years and had been looking for a friendly, relaxed and delicious spot for yakitori and other Japanese standards.  
The food here is perfect.  They have wonderful grilled dishes, specialties like tako-wasa and their own creations like Eri-chan's special.
The  staff here is friendly, hardworking, and accommodating. 
 I wish I could eat here every week. It is that good!
author: Kevin S.

description:
02.12.11

This is a small, hole-in-the-wall feeling neighborhood restaurant.  Wouldn't recommend it for a large group (we had a group of 11), since the restaurant seats about 25.  We were forewarned that our dishes will come out in waves since the kitchen doesn't handle that kind of capacity at the same time.

I ordered off the menu - spicy corn butter ramen [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/j7ZO28rAdTVlQdE2zJSSTA?select=-QJGCudp3NJ9pSvMItSTwg].  Boy, they do spicy right.

I wasn't that hungry so stayed away from the yakitoris, but the others went to town and ordered a bunch.  The overall theme was "too salty", which I didn't feel with my ramen.

Total damage for our table of seven: $120.
author: Jenny L.

description: Service was incredibly slow.  My husband's dinner didn't even arrive before I was done.  Seating was very tight!  Food that was served was very good.  They need more help on a weekend.
author: Kelly M.

description: If you are coming here just for a bowl of ramen - you are doing it all wrong!! I haven't had their ramen but their Yakitori and Kushiyaki selection is really really good and you are totally missing out. I came here with 4 other Japanese people and we had a few salads and Yakitori all night. Absolutely delicious and authentic Yakitori. Cute, cozy space with friendly service!
author: Food E.

description:
It was really hard trying to find yakitori places in the Bay but I managed to find Halu.

This place was kinda hard to find because it was at night and raining but we eventually found it. When we walked in the place it was packed and it was super small.  We sat at the semi/bar!? When we sat down, we had to stop and admire all of the BEATLES memorabilia :) Anyway, looked at the menu and the mister and I were so excited to try everything.. really. Haha.

We ordered the flat steak and short rib. BOMB. We also ordered the usual bacon asparagus and chicken heart. We enjoyed both.

Also ordered 2 specials. I forgot what the first one was called. I just know it was some sort of beef and we got the bacon wrapped mochi. The beef one was good but the bacon wrapped mochi tasted exactly what it was. Weird and meh. Not such a good idea mixing the two.. yea.

Had to wait a while for our food to come out but it was well worth it and the waitresses were super friendly. 

Anyway, we were hella full and very satisfied with our meal. I think we'll be coming back here to eat when we're back in the city.
author: Criselle O.

description: I got so much food when I was here. I tried the chicken katsu ramen which was so good, chicken was nice and crispy and soaked up in broth. also got the Japanese pizza sort of all very good and crispy a lot of good flavors. Order the chicken and beef yakitori which had like a guacamole sauce on top of the meat that was a very good side dish. I would definitely go back here and get some more Ramen. a very tight place on the inside but the food is cooked fresh and with love, very authentic
author: Alvin Y.

description: By far greatest place in San Francisco. I recommend to all friends and visitors for a real hole in the wall experience. Located in what seems like a normal Richmond District apartment with the most amazing Beatles memorabilia. Not to mention the food is amazing! The mochi appetizer will blow you away, and ramen have a high place in my heart. Love love
author: Brigitte C.

description:
We came here tonight after my night class.  I've been wanting to eat at Halu for almost a year but never had an opportunity to go.  This place is GREAT!  

Right when I walked in I can hear "meeeshelllll my bell" with the cute beatles themed interior.

It's a small mom and pop restaurant.  It probably can seat 20 on the tables and there's a bar seating area as well.  We arrived around 9pm so there wasn't a line to be seated, but the restaurant was a full house.

We ordered:

chicken ka raage - A.  The batter was very light and served straight from the fryer.  Crispy on the outside, hot and juicy on the inside.  Cooked to perfection!  Some japanese restaurants serve the mayonnaise with the ka raage but. this place doesn't.  still a great appetizer full of flavor and juicy yummyness!

miso soup - i don't think i've ever had miso soup with enoki mushrooms and it was a nice complement to the tofu rather than just green onions.  i love how everything they serve is HOT, like they prepared it specifically for you.  it actually took me almost 5 minutes for me to drink the soup without being worried about burning my tongue!  the flavor was perfect.  salty, but not too salty. tofu was soft, but not so much that it was falling apart.  and i'm still loving the enoki mushroom!

beef and veggie okonomiyaki - BEWARE, there is some dried shrimp for those with seafood allergies!  i wasn't a huge fan of this plate.  there was too much sauce, too many flavors.  but, i actually think this may be what authentic okonomiyaki is supposed to be like, so it's probably just my personal taste in food.

stuffed mushroom yakitori - my favorite of the night!  marinated to perfection.  again, served HOT.  you bite into the mushroom and it's a burst of delicious teriyaki, meat, mushroom all in one bite.  really really amazing.

short rib yakitori - very delicious!  i only had a small bite because i was getting full but definitely worth getting again the next time we go!

bacon wrapped asparagus yakitori - who doesn't love bacon wrapped ANYTHING.  it was really delicious.  the asparagus was still crunchy and the bacon was cooked just the right amount to bring out all the toasty bacon flavor but soft enough to wrap like a blanket around the asparagus.  DROOL.  

def will come back again in the near future!  i want to try their ramen =)
author: Sandy L.

description:
I came here four or five years ago when it was Mama-san's and it was terrible:  mediocre food, awkward atmosphere, and strange service.  Halu is a refreshing change.  The location is small and intimate, which for some reason makes it feel more Japanese and is covered with old music memorabilia, mostly Beatles stuff with sprinkles of Jimi Hendricks and the Doors.  They serve yakitori, but I came for the ramen.

We wanted to split a tall Asahi, but our waitress suggested the quart-sized cans of Asahi for just $3 more imported direct from Japan.  I've never been to Japan, but I feel like it's the sort of thing sold in vending machines next to panty hose and condoms.  Anyway, I ordered the Chasu, and I got two thick pieces of pork belly, half a hard-boiled egg, and ginger.  It was delicious.  My boyfriend ordered the chicken karaage.  He liked mine more.  :)  I'm afraid, though, that I was a little surprised by the $10.50 price tag on my bowl of ramen ($11.50 for the karaage).  It wasn't as outrageous as a $14 bowl at Ippudo in the East Village but still pretty shocking this being the Inner Richmond.  I think I'll come back, but I won't be able to get rid of the feeling that I'm being cheated a little.  I also want to try the yakitori next time.
author: Daniel F.

description:
This place is a cute hole in the wall. I've actually passed by Halu quite a number of times and hadn't noticed it before, even when I was eating across the street from there. A coworker suggested I try here. The decor inside was quirky and fun. Big Beatles fans there.

We got the chef's pick of skewers and there were some that I liked and some that weren't all that special. We also got some type of tofu and stuffed mushrooms. I didn't really like the mushrooms, but I did enjoy the tofu. We split a ramen since we heard it was good, but the ramen wasn't anything special. 

The service here is friendly enough, but there is a wait time for food when it gets busy.
author: Jay L.

description:
Was in my old hood, so we decided to try Halu.  Once we walked in, we felt like we were in a restaurant i the Haight, or Berkeley!  The Beatles were playing in the background, and the entire decor was old school 60's posters of the Beatles, Jimi Hendrix, the Who, the Monkees, etc.  We were seated right away, and were kind of expecting slow service (from reading all the other Yelp reviews).  Most other Yelp reviews were on the money; however, we read about this place being authentic homey Japanese food.  That was what attracted us to try this place out.  

Had the wasabi marinated octopus salad (nice kick, and healthy chunks of tako).  Chicken gizzard and Bacon Wrapped Scallops Yakitori were both grilled up right, and Chashu Ramen was pretty good, noodles were pretty good, but the broth was a bit salty for my taste...  My wife had the Hiyashi Chuka which was the most unique dish of the night (cold noodles, roasted pork, and lots of veggies arranged nicely on top, with a great tasting broth - waitress was nice enough to explain how to mix it all up before eating it - loved it).

All-in-all, I would come back and try all the other yakitori choices.  Definitely recommend this little gem.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Soba Don $10.00

Soba noodle served with cucumber, thin sliced egg, spring mix green with wasabi soy avocado sprinkled with daikon sprouts and kizami nori

Don't miss this salad!  Ramen & Yakitori are delish too

Chill atmosphere esp when it's not crowded so come early in the week, early in the evening or you'll just have to wait. In that case Bring a Parka.
author: raven n.

description: This is a three to four star place in my mind. The ramen's are too strong for my taste. They are overwhelming. I liked the Gyozas. The place is very cute with beatles memorabilia. Service was excellent at 5:30pm. The place has a very good feel to it. The ramen should be world class in a place like this (given that it is their main dish) and it wasn't.
author: bora o.

description:
Affordable, great service, and most of all: DELICIOUS! 
Halu is like that hip but unassuming kid on the playground that knows all the cool things to do and fun places to go. The Beatlemania decor inside is absolutely charming, and they played Beatles all night, so much love!! A fun, casual place to grab a bite with friends, everything is very share-able.
It's small inside, but the wait was only 10 minutes when we came for dinner at 6pm on a Saturday. 
Okinomayaki was the highlight, all the sauces and textures blended together very nicely in a symphony of flavor. Everything else we ordered was great too. Would love to be a regular at a place like this!
author: Tuwie N.

description: My favorite Japanese ramen in Inner Richmond. You should come for the ambience alone. It feels like you've just stepped into a Tokyo ramen shop. It's quaint and has a little bar that's perfect for single seating. No need to be on your phone, there's enough Beatles memorabilia on the walls to entertain you. Besides, you come for the ramen. It's an in-and-out deal. Get the Cashu-men ramen spicy! The pork is so tender, it falls to pieces. Yakitori apps are great too!
author: Michelle B.

description:
A close friend of mine took me here and I was like, "Um why didn't I know about this place already?  I live like 5 blocks from here!"

I love finding neighborhood gems.  I know I don't live in SF anymore but I'll always be a Richmond district girl, and having lived in the area for more than 20+ years, the hood's become quite a treasure chest of restaurants.

Halu is one of them.  I love all the Yakitori I tried and will go back for the ramen.
author: Susan C.

description:
Went with my boyfriend. It's our first try there and it's nice. We had okonomiyaki and some skewers. They are tasty. I am skewers fan and I love them! However the tea is unbelievably expensive- $5.75 for a pot of tea made of a tea bag. We expected it to be free since most Asian restaurant offer free hot teas. For six dollars we would expect real tea leafs rather than tea bag.

After all we thought it was a nice restaurant to try.
author: Amie Z.

description:
My friend recommended this place and was i super excited. The food was good. And that's the end of any positive things I have to say, what follows is one of the worst experiences I ever had eating out.

The wait for food was offensive. I was willing to wait for the table for 40 mins but waiting 2 hours to eat was painful. Had I known that my meal would take so long I would have gone somewhere else and no, a free shot of sake is not going to make up for waiting for my order and seeing someone else who came long after me get served before me. I guess that's what I get for being a first time customer and not your chummy best friend.

Maybe that's why there is so many knickknacks around, to distract you from the abysmal service. They should be embarrassed. 

Wait, is this a hipster hangout? That might explain it.
author: Joh W.

description:
HALU. HALU. HALU. HALU.

I'm a Japanese bar food snob. Katana-Ya? Pshhh puhlease. You call that good?

Halu's food is worth a heart attack. Their spicy karage ramen was the best decision I made on Friday. Like Nike says, just do it. Just order it and savor it. 

Their skewers are tasty as well. Bacon wrapped bay scallops, shrimp katsu mmmm. Skewers are around $3/per and their main dishes are ~$13. Appetizers range from $6-$10ish so if you end up ordering quite a few things, your bill will add up. Food takes some time to come out (it's worth the wait.) Small restaurant so I imagine there can be a bit of a wait if you go during peak hours. 

I plan on going next weekend and stuffing my stomach with their Karage ramen. Did I say next weekend? I mean I plan on going tonight.
author: Rosa L.

description: The ramen is decent, though the starters were better. The service, though very friendly, was wildly inconsistent, with our three ramens coming at such different times that almost no two people ate at the same time. Also, no way this place justifies wait times similar to Ramen Dojo in San Mateo.
author: Varun B.

description: (See pics) Updated review. Still on top of my list with great izakaya, especially with only a couple people, that you get to sample lots of dishes. As always, service was very sweet. Yes, there could be a line so walk around to work up an appetite.
author: T L.

description:
This place was great.

I went to the Richmond, fully expecting my friend would suggest Burma Superstar or some other tried-and-true place with a ridiculously long wait. Instead she said, "there's this Japanese place around the corner, I've never been, do you want to check it out?" I am game to try new spots, so we skipped on over to 8th and Clement to discover a small restaurant (I think hole-in-the-wall is an exaggeration unless you're talking Yamo-sized) which seemed packed but happened to have a table for two, and bar space as well for the people who came in after us.

The servers were very friendly, and seated us right away. Immediately I noticed the decor--this place was packed with Beatles memorabilia, and other bands as well--a Jimi Hendrix poster hung on the high wall over the front-of-house kitchen, a couple of Who posters--but mostly the Beatles. There was even a drum kit on a tiny balcony over the entrance, which looked possibly only just large enough to host a three-piece band, should one ever want to perform a rock concert in the tiny space. Despite the obvious theme, there was nothing precious or kitschy-seeming about the place--it felt like you were in someone's home, albeit someone who had a thing for classic rock posters. The vibe was totally friendly too... the servers seemed like they were down-to-earth, but there was no slacking when it came to attentiveness. 

We were presented with an enormous menu, which, along with the specials list(s) and many handwritten labels for items on the wall, contained such wonders as "Avochick" or chicken thigh skewers with spicy guac, a savory fried butter mochi wrapped in nori, an array of yakitori items, several ramen options, ochazuke, okonomiyaki, and other intriguing specialties. I was pretty excited.

Once we finally made up our minds, we ordered yakitori, kara age "don don," and the butter mochi appetizer. Everything came out pretty quickly, even though the restaurant was full, and my friend and I enjoyed catching up and checking out the scenery in the meantime. The rad server even offered an suggestion for how my friend could eat her meat ("like a popsicle") when she noticed my friend having trouble getting everything off the bone. The food runner (who maybe also was the chef?) presented everything formally and gave us the Japanese names. 

Oh and the food? Super delicious... homey in presentation but served on super cute plates (apparently bought from the restaurant supply place around the corner) and succulent. Butter mochi? Buttery. Kara age? Light and with a small flavorful salad and scoop of rice for a totally satisfying meal. I didn't try my friend's yakitori but she practically licked her plate clean so I'm thinking that it was bomb. 

Our total bill, including tip, was $40, not bad for a fully satisfying, unpretentious, fun izakaya experience in SF, and with leftovers to boot. The servers were totally cool with us sitting and chatting, even for a while after we had paid (which I usually feel guilty about doing at most good and small SF restaurants). I totally would go back here again.
author: CJ L.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night and it was not packed at all. I really do like to eat without the commotion of hearing others conversations. The ambiance is chill. You've got tables for parties and a counter like a bar.

Service was good and food came out pretty quickly. I can only comment on the Chashu-men and the Kara Age Ramen. 

Chashu-men - Noodles were kinda chewy at first bite, but quickly softened up to a nice texture. I was just really hungry! The soup was slightly ginger-y for my tastes, but I hardly noticed it after. Good amount of spices in it. The chashu was excellent!

Kara Age - tender pieces of chicken. Soup and noodles the same. If you want your kara-age crunchy, I guess you can just order it on the side.

The only problem I had was the price. $10.50 for the chashu-men and $11.50 for the kara-age ramen is a little steep. A buck-fitty less for each would seal the deal for me coming back.

I'm not big on eating things on sticks, but they looked good. I'm a stickler for price, so I probably would never order those haha

Nice place, but I probably won't be back. Good food, kinda steep prices. Minus 1 star for that.
author: Timothy L.

description: Worst service. Waited 20 minutes to get my order taken. 1 hour to get my food. We had the Karaage Ramen and Veggie Okonomiyaki. The ramen came first. The broth had a weird after taste. I've had lots of ramen places, both modernized and authentic and this broth just left a weird after taste. By the time my boyfriend finished his ramen, I waited 30 more minutes to get my pancake which tasted as if it wasn't cooked throughly and rushed. Overall, the food was less than mediocre and definitely not worth $40 and over an hour of wait. Oh, I almost forgot. The reason they're getting only 1 star is I was served water with a bug in it. I also want to add that as I'm writing this on my way home, both my boyfriend and I have a stomach ache and I'm starting to get a headache. I wish I didn't waste my time and money.
author: Katrina L.

description:
Another great recommendation from my friend JMAK! WHOO!

So, of course, my BF and I ordered ramen because we're still on a quest to find the best ramen in the bay area.  Before that, we ordered an appetizer...bacon wrapped scallops!  (see pictures)  SUPER JUICY.  

It was the moment of truth ... our LARGE bowls of hot, savory ramen were placed in front of us and the first few things I noticed were:

- SCALLIONS!!  (Makes everything taste better)
- thinner, old school, negi ramen noodles (like the instant noodle kind...)
- darker colored broth

This is old school ramen.  (I say old school because I grew up eating Ichiban :P INSTA NOODLES!))  I had a Ratatouille moment when I took my first bite (put the ramen on the spoon and dip some soup in it ... and then pack on the toppings...thats how to savor everything!!!) ... it brought me back to a time of simplicity and childhood.  It was so soothing and MUCH lighter tasting than Santa Ramen.  The broth was SO good that I ordered an extra bowl of rice and mixed it in to finish it off!  

The difference between Santa Ramen and Halu is definately the type of noodles and the two completely different flavors.  If you want something heavier and richer in flavor, I recommend Santa...(they also have kimchi!!).  If you want something more classic, I recommend Halu.  

The only thing is this place is TINY!  I can imagine how busy/packed it gets on the weekends.  We went on a Wednesday evening around 7.  Service was EXCELLENT!  Will deeefinaately be coming back.
author: Kat C.

description:
Bacon Wrapped Mochi...need I say more?!?!?

On Saturday, 7.3.10, my friend and I came to Halu at around 6:30 PM and there was about a 5-7 minute wait for a table. 

FOOD:
*Miso Soup ($2.50): YUM! The miso broth was rich, savory, and not too salty. There was tender pieces of enoki mushrooms and tofu. The scallions added a great freshness to the soup.

*Agedashi  Tofu ($6): YUM! The silken tofu was lightly fried to a light golden brown. The outer layer was slightly gelatinous w/ a light crunch and the tofu was velvety smooth. The tentsuyu broth married well w/ the tofu adding a salty and sweet savoryness.

*Yaki Nasu (Baked eggplant - $6.50): Meh. Although the eggplant was soft and tender, it was very bland b/c it was lacking the miso paste. 

*Bacon Mochi ($5): YUM! The smoky, savory, and fatty bacon was a nice contrast to the soft and chewy glutinous mochi which had a hint of sweetness. 

*Pork Jowl ($5.50): YUM! The pork jowl which is like a lean pork belly was grilled to perfection. It was juicy, moist, well-seasoned w/ hint of smokiness from the char marks. 

*Kushikatsu Scallop ($5.50): OMG--SO GOOD! The scallop was battered w/ panko breadcrumbs and lightly fried to a golden brown. The crust was light and crispy and the scallop was incredibly succulent, sweet, and tender. The accompanying tonkatsu sauce complemented the scallops well as it added a tangy sweet flavor.

*Short Rib Skewer ($5 for 2): YUM! The short rib was perfectly grilled; the beef was tender, moist, and well-seasoned.

*Chasu Ramen ($9.95): It was just ok and I don't understand what the hype is all about. Although the chasu was tender, the broth was salty as opposed to being "flavorful". The noodles were overcooked almost to the point it was borderline mushy. And, the egg was a hard boiled egg and not a brown egg which is more flavorful. Overall, the ramen was missing the depth of flavor from the broth which results from simmering pork/beef bones for a long period of time. 

SERVICE: 
The service was ok, but aloof at times. Upon arrival, we stood there for several minutes before being acknowledged. When the waitress (owner's daughter?) finally noticed us, she ask us to sit at the counter, but we politely requested a table instead. She then walked off w/o saying anything and came back 2 minutes later and placed menus at the counter. I had to repeat myself again until she complied which made for a slightly uncomfortable situation.

Service is typical of any Asian restaurant where they don't check in w/ you and you have to ask if you need/want anything. The food did take a while to come out so it took about 2 hours for dinner.

AMBIANCE/DÉCOR:
A hippie's haven; Beatles memorabilia and other décor reminiscent of the 70s. Halu is TINY; there's about seating for 20-24 and for 5 at the counter. 

I have to note that being in the bathroom is a bit unnerving. First, you have to put your hand into a wooden box outside the bathroom to turn on the lights and there is a huge water heater in the bathroom which is a safety hazard. 

PARKING:
Metered street parking which can be difficult in the Inner Richmond. There is a metered parking lot at the corner on 8th Ave, but it's metered until 12 midnight. 

I highly doubt I would return for the ramen since there has been a proliferation of ramen shops that serve superior ramen. However, I would return for their Izakaya and low-key funky vibe.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
This place is such a hole-in-the-wall that I never noticed it until I yelped for ramen in San Francisco. The inside is as small as it looks on the outside but the unique thing about this place is that everything is about The Beatles and the 60s.  It's just way too funny.  It's just not very expected when you walk into a ramen place.  Oh, and NO sushi.  Halu makes it very clear before you walk into the door that it's not a sushi place.  They only serve yakitori and ramen.  

Let me say that I think Halu serves the best spicy karage ramen.  It comes with freshly fried chicken, bean sprouts, corn and a bit of ginger.  I love it.  It's great on a nice cold day.  I'm not sure how else to describe it.  The broth is spicy but not so spicy that it'll make you cry.  It's at the perfect level of spiciness.  However, the spicy ramen here is spicier than most other ramen places that I've tried.  It's a great kick if you love spicy food that won't kill you.
author: Shirley T.

description:
I've been dreaming about this place for months. MONTHS!

Ever since my friend told me about it and we looked at pictures of bacon wrapped scallops and ramen on Yelp, I've been craving it!! Due to different schedules, we had to wait til winter break and here we are! :) We were lucky that it was rainy because that made hot steaming ramen sound even more appealing!

So we arrived at 5 pm (right when they opened) and it was pretty empty except for one guy at the bar. That was definitely a good thing, especially since we didn't want to be stuck waiting around!
The servers are SUPER DUPER nice and so friendly and helpful! Our waitress accidentally missed my order, but she was so genuinely sorry and kept apologizing that I started to feel bad for even mentioning it. She even took a picture of my friend and I! :)

Anyway, the most important part was the food, so lets get to that! My friend ordered the chashu (roast pork) ramen and I got the yasai (veggie) ramen. It was OH-SO-DELICIOUS, but I have to admit, it's a HUGE portion!! Not that I'm complaining..I ate it the next day for lunch! 
We also shared 3 different kinds of yakitori: salmon, bacon wrapped scallop, and bacon wrapped MOCHI!! Highly recommend the bacon wrapped mochi! :D I didn't see the special menu until later, but I'm itching to try the beef tongue yakitori next time I stop in!
Guess we were feeling pretty hungry, so we also got a beef & veggie okonomiyake! That was good as well. Nice crispy edges :)

Inside, there is a bunch of Beatles memorabilia, as well as some other awesome rock legends, like Jimi Hendrix and the Shitones. It's fun to look at everything and a great way to kill time while waiting for the food to come out! My friend and I got to sit next to the holographic yellow submarine poster! :D

Overall, it's a great little ramen place with a unique atmosphere, friendly staff, and FANTASTIC food!! :D You can bet your bottom dollar that I'll be coming back! I was actually thinking of taking my mom because she's a huge Beatles fan!
author: Kei H.

description: Small place , great food! We ordered different skewers - each one very juicy and perfectly grilled! Okonimiyaki was good too - though not as impressive as skewers!
author: Suparna J.

description:
Yakitori is their main feat in a tiny somewhat hole in a wall Beatles tripped out place. Almost as if you're in some quirky restaurant in Japan where the space is small but very much lively. Their yakitori selection is fun. Some of them were more flavorful than others (specifically the beef ones). Their ramen was pretty good and simple with a hint of ginger. I would definitely come back for the experience. 

Quick tip: get the yakitori chef selection if you want to try several ones but can't seem to choose.
author: Johanna P.

description:
AHHHHHHHHHHH AFTER DISCOVERING THIS PLACE ON YELP DURING THE SUMMER AND WAITING FINALLY FOR IT TO GET COLD AND SCHOOL TO BE OVER I GOT TO EAT HERE TODAY! yay! COLD RAINY SF DAY MEANS YAKITORI WITH MY FRIEND

so we came right when it opened at 5PM BEST TIME TO COME!  you get to sit wherever you want =). and you get to look at all the great Beatles stuff on the walls. OH they have a unisex bathroom, but it has toilet seat covers! yay!

we ordered the:
bacon wrapped mochi from their special menu DELISH
bacon wrapped scallop yummy
and salmon also really good not dry

I ordered the chashu ramen and my friend ordered the veggie ramen
it's a pretty tasty ramen on a cold day they gave lots of chashu aka pork and lots of noodles, I got really full

but we also ordered the beef and veggie okanomiyaki! lol that was tasty

People say things take a while to come out but if you come at 5pm when it opens food comes out pretty quickly

SERVICE: GREAT SERVICE, after we ordered all our food they asked us if it was okay if our food came out at different times like ramen first and yakitori and then okinomiyaki or if we had a preference for the order lol We were like oh it doesn't matter any thing can come out first , we just want to eat.
when i almost finished my ramen the okanomiyaki came out and my friend asked the waitress if her veggie ramen was coming out yet. apparently they didn't hear her order it, but they were soo apologetic that it made us feel guilty! such sweet waitresses she bowed in apology soo many time soo nice so cute.  well they made her veggie ramen pretty quick and she loved it soo that was awesome. and they were constantly refilling our waters. they also saw us taking a lot of pictures so they asked us if we wanted them to help us take a picture, the picture turned out nice! lol no shaky hands.

I really like this place and can't wait to come back! it is small and cozy.

oh while we were there there was a family that came in with 2 kids but they were well behaved and also a couple on a date, so it's a pretty good place to just go eat, but don't bring babies or children that cry a lot a small space like that can easily be ruined by too much crying

ps my 1st review awesome time!
author: Jennie P.

description:
Mmm, Halu.  I do have to say that the service is super friendly (5 stars) and the food's pretty good (4 stars)... But the wait time is so long (0 stars).

All the yakitori comes out with the personal touch of the chef, who you can sort of see over the high counter (the kitchen is open to the tiny restaurant), delicious and fresh as soon as it comes.  I love the eri-chan special, and the bacon wrapped mochi is definitely quite good.  Generally, everything is really quite delicious!  

So guys, Yakitori == noms.

The ramen is prepared bowl by bowl, and also pretty good, so I'm a fan.  And the Beatles paraphernalia everywhere!  How can you go wrong?

Well... you can wait to be seated... And wait for the food... And Wait.

The Wait... So. Long.
author: Emilynne A.

description:
It's a unique Japanese Restaurant. They serve different but yet authentic Japanese food and tasty too.. 

The place is decorated with memorabilia , services are friendly, but a little small if you have a group more than 6. 

The price is reasonable not cheap, but consider the location is in the bay area.
author: Mimi M.

description:
It was cold that night and we were hungry. We waited longer than the lady promised, grumbling about how if she had told us a more accurate estimate, we could have stayed warm in the book store until they called. 

We walk in and it's like going back in time; the music, the decor- it all adds to the experience. Hands down the best ramen I have ever had. Though I have to admit, I am no ramen connoisseur, my taste buds usually don't lie.

I had leftovers and they made it home, but they didn't survive the night.
author: Norma ..

description: Expensive. However, this place really has the feel of an izakaya you might find in Tokyo and it really brings me back--except unfortunately you can't see the chefs grilling. Recommended: bacon wrapped scallops, whatever prime steak they have, and the fried squid. Best yakitori I've had stateside. Cool American twist on the decor with the Beatles memorabilia everywhere. The wait list is a good excuse to grab a cheeky beer around the corner, and they'll call you when you're up.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Great service. Food was amazing. I dream about the broth, and the noodles are perfect. Not too tough or overdone. Family run wth a great Beatles theme. Kinda cramped but well worth it.

I always get the same thing : Spicy chicken Karaage. EXTRA SPICY. 
Japanese people aren't big on spicy food, so whenever I go to a ramen house ( i've been to a lot), and I tell them EXTRA EXTRA spicy it always comes out mild. Halu always doesssss it perfectly without detracting from the flavor. SO if you're a fan of really spicy foods ask them to do it extra spicy and they will definitely make it happen.
ALSO their appetizers are on point. Try the bacon or seaweed wrapped mochi, or the chicken karaage side. OMNOMNOM.
author: Dandara D.

description:
Amazing, tiny, and popular.

In other words, you gonna wait in line, sucka.

But, and I rarely say this:  it's worth it.

The ramen is good, and if you want to try something delicious and different, try the cold noodles.

The grilled meats are excellent and the specials board always has something intriguing to offer.  

And beer?  Natch.  I like the red one.  

It's got the warmth of a family run place, and an eclectic vibe due to the mostly-Beatles 60's and 70's music memorabilia platered on every available surface.  

I like it.  I like it a lot.
author: Liz S.

description:
There are days where I want nothing but a nice hot bowl of noodles, whether it be Ramen, Pho, Udon, Soba or Mein. One thing to noe about me is  I am always down for soup and noodles. Today was one of those days, it was cold and rainy and nothing would make me feel better than sipping hot broth and slurping down some yummy noodles!  

I have been to Halu a few times now and have tried their Ramen and Okonomiyaki. The Chasu Ramen has tender Chasu with bean sprouts, corn and a porky flavor broth. While on teh other hand the Karaage Ramen contains very flavorful Chiken Kaarage that is fried to perfection, not too oily and not overly fried. The broth is a bit richer than the Chasu Ramen broth but it is equally as good. 

http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/LE4E4-KNbSrZnIfXGs7hMw/

While I was finishing up my Ramen the waitress popped up over the menu's which were right next to me since we were seated at the bar and nearly scared the crap outta me. In a kawaii koe she said "Ramen no Aji wa doudesu ka " wit a big smile. I replied Oishii since i was hella caught off guard :X. She then replied "ii desu ne" and went back to doing her work. Couldn't figure out if she was being nice or flirty! Shurgs

I finally tried their Okonomiyaki, My friend and I got the Beef and Veggie Oknonomiyaki. http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Bo2Eg8oc8zLFcM9HgyApZQ/l

it was a work of art! Amazing, it was crisp and had a small crunch with every bite and I felt that the flavor was the best i have had. it had a homestyle taste to it and it was not masked by salt of richness. I will have to come back to check out their specialties which are grilled food! 

The decor is pretty awesome i might add, they have alot of old skool vintage items, and they have Beatles memorabilia everywhere. This place looks like its a part of someones home but thats what makes it cool. It does however have limited seating and a bar area in the front. I feel right at home eating here.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Easy to miss this place tucked away on a Clement side street...well, except the usual mass of waiting patrons is a dead giveaway.

I've been here a couple of times. Specializing in yakitori, and also unexpectedly catering to die-hard Beatles fans, the uniqueness alone keeps me coming back. 

The waitresses are sweet and friendly and do their best amidst the raucous, cramped interior.

As plainly stated on the menu, the food really is best enjoyed with a couple of beers. The yakitori comes out piecemeal and it's one of those rare places you can take your time to share a meal and good company.

Now as far as the food...No sushi ;) !! 
I've loved all the skewers I've tried, especially the stuffed mushroom and chicken liver (go figure). One of the few places offering okonomiyaki, I found them to be a little thinner than expected, but sublime nonetheless (go for the combination one). Ramen was salty and not recommended, but you're going there for the yakitori anyway.
author: Cassie C.

description: Yakitori - arguably the most tender meat in San Francisco. Great spot for a party of 2.
author: Micaela H.

description:
I love this sake bar, it reminded me of my favorite sake bar in NYC called Hagi.

The grilled tapas are simple and tasty, seasoned with just a bit of salt and fresh lemon juice. Nice collection of sake, too. 

It's a Beatles-themed sake bar with a sign on the door that reads "no sushi today or tomorrow".
author: C J.

description:
Halu is my favorite place to go for dinner. I could visit every day and never get sick of it. Things on skewers, ramen (some incredibly spicy!), Beatles decor, anti-sushi kitch, music, specials board, beers, sake, bacon... what else could you ever want for a favorite local?

Visit Sutro Baths first, come cold and ready to be warmed up! We like to split lots of skewers then share one bowl of ramen. Yum!
author: Megan G.

description: Hole in the wall with delicious food, charm and friendly staff. Chicken wings, bacon mochi, spicy lava ramen are all great choices. They also had a special of fried mochi wrapped in nori, which was heavenly! It's a small joint so it fills up fast, but no problem getting a table at 6pm on a Saturday night.
author: Kiri I.

description: So amazing! Visiting from VA and spent about an hour deciding on where to go for Yakitori. This place was everything I wanted and more. Fantastic variety and all perfectly executed in the tiniest of kitchens. Had damn near one of everything. Highlights were chicken hearts that were shocking tender and perfectly seasoned, chicken gizzards that where the perfect textural contrast to the achingly tender hearts, beef belly that was essentially beef butter somehow holding itself together with a few strands of muscle, and the wasabi octopus appetizer served raw that was super weird in the best possible ways (crunchy, tender, slimy, spicy and salty all at once). On top off all that, the walls were covered in Beatles memorabilia and they were playing some great music to go along with it. Do yourself a favor and eat here.
author: E C.

description: Quaint little (emphasis on little) Japanese restaurant. Family owned and run by the nicest and most pleasant people. The team service is awesome, but it's the ramen that keeps me coming back, time and time again. The broth is rich, savory and oh sooooo delicious. The noodles are always fresh and firm, and it is always served piping hot. It's a small place, but the food is worth the wait. Please don't ever go away Halu!
author: Monica W.

description:
Finally some nice ramen! This place is definitely not 'TOP RAMEN' noodle place especially when your avg ramen here is about $10.  Service was nice - waitress asked me how did i hear of this place etc. I can tell that this place screams BEATLES...hahaha

Space is small but they make up on the food. Soup in the ramen was delicious could not feel any msg. That's a good thing! Will definitely come back and try other tasty stuff.
author: Thomas C.

description:
I really enjoyed our meal at Halu. Sure, it's a hole in the wall and it is very small. But that is all part of it's charm.

Plus, can you beat a small Japanese restaurant sporting bunches of Beatles and rock memorabilia?

The service was friendly and fast. Our server was also helpful in making menu suggestions. After we ordered, there was a steady stream of food. Plus, we ordered a ton of food and some beers but the total was only about $87.

We mix up how we order and, for Halu, she did most of the ordering. I picked one dish. She picked the rest. I do not know the correct name for each dish we but I do know what the dishes basically were.

She selected:
Sausage Yakitori (4 stars)
Pork Yakitori (3 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/3qcjble

Fried Chicken (3 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/3ndlsnr

Bacon Stuffed Zucchini Skewers (5 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/3b7uk2y

Chicken Skin Yakitori (3 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/44n8pmk

Fried Scallops Skewers (3 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/45yagmg

Chicken Liver Skewers (I will not score it. I do not like chicken liver I tried it. I still do not like chicken liver.)

http://tinyurl.com/3p5mmn6

Salad with strawberries (5 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/3f9shhh

Edamame (3 stars

http://tinyurl.com/3myrtow

Seafood Pancake (2 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/3ktclg5

Stuffed Mushrooms (5 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/3lvhfvk

I selected:
Shiso Beef Yakitori (4 stars)

http://tinyurl.com/3ha42as

The stuffed mushrooms were taste explosions. I could eat a dozen of them. Oh what is the best thing you can do with zucchini?  Yep you got it.  Wrap it in bacon. The salad was super fresh. The sweetness of the strawberries was a nice contrast to the slight bitterness of the greens.
I did not really like the seafood pancake. It was a little soggy. Plus, the seafood flavor was just one big overpowering note.

Cool hole in the wall ambiance + fast. friendly. helpful service + great food = no-brainer to return or recommend.
author: Mark D.

description: My kind of place. Intimate, clean, good food, nice atmosphere and friendly staff. A real gem in the city.
author: Ronald B.

description:
Stumbled upon this place while yelping for some Ramen on a cold night. Once we walked, we noticed the place was super small - bumps, bruises, and spills...oh my!  We couldn't even really open the door to enter because it was pushing on a seated customer in the way. I felt so bad.  It's even a challenge to get into the bathroom because it was so tight lol!  

You'll also notice the rock & roll decor that goes well with music they were playing. They had a bunch of Beatles memorabilia as well - i guess they're big fans.  I must say, a very unique place!  Our waitress was friendly and knew how to get along with customers very well. 

Halu is a "sushi free" zone!  They have a good assortment of Yakatori and also a "Halu's Special Menu" which you'll find on the wall.  Our small dishes came out pretty quick but it felt like the Ramen took awhile to come out.  Didn't thnk it would take THAT long - good thing "Spirited Away" playing on the the tv kept us busy.  

I'll definately come back here to try more Yakitori and Kushikatsu.  I'm new to this Yakatoriness and think that its a little pricey for such such small, simple dishes (i.e., cherry tomatoes wrapped with bacon) - I guess you pay for the experience, which I don't mind...sometimes.  I probably won't come back for the Ramen though.  I came here with my boyfriend and a friend and we all got Ramen - each one of us complained that it started to get waaayy too salty!  Talk about risk for heart attack and dehydration!!

OUR ORDERS...

Yaki Onigiri - grilled rice ball mixed w/ salmon & bonito flake with light soy sauce $5 (smelt burnt; tasty but not my fav)

Kushikatsu Stuffed Mushrooms - covered with crispy panko breaded w/ minced scallionson on top; came with Tonkatsu Sauce and Hot Mustard; 2 skewers for $4.75 (omg so good - best part of the night for me; mouth watering, w/ a surprising lemony juice flavor; don't really knew what it's stuffed with but I'd get it again)

Yakitori - scallop bacon 2sk/$5 (2 pieces on ea skewer;salty but hey...it's bacon!; scallops were good)

Corn Butter Ramen - chasu, veggie, extra corn $10.5 and $0.50 extra for fresh grated garlic (lots to mix so mix well; broth was a great taste at first then the garlic flavor started overpowering the soup and it also started to get too salty)

Chasu-Ramen - roast pork with corn, Ginger, egg, bean sprouts, and green onion $9.5 (didn't really like the broth; salty as well)
author: jesiree b.

description:
A Beatles-themed ramen shop with bacon-wrapped treats??

HALU-LUJAH!

5-Star worthy because:
1. Super cool Beatles decor with lots of cool knick knacks and trinkets
2. Bacon wrapped EVERYTHING.  Mochi was the flavor of the day when I went...it was DELICIOUS!
3. Spicy ramen - good noodle texture & rich flavor!  Yummy pork!
4. Friendly service
5. Cool rotating menu
6. Veggie ramen - packed with a variety of veggies!  (but still in a meat broth)
7. Good tuneskis accompanying your meal, but not too loud so you have to scream to talk with someone

I'll be back without a doubt!!

**Just a heads up though - the space isn't that big, so I don't think it's a great place for large groups.  However, for a place like this, I think it's better for a small group anyway so you can take in all the scenery (and less people to fight with over bacon-wrapped skewers :-P).
author: Alice C.

description:
We waited nearly 2 hours from start to finish -- finish being when the ramen arrived at our table bc we ate it up so quick. The place has about 10-15 seats and is run by 2 amazing women who probably have to listen to impatient patrons yell and complain often. 
Now I certainly wouldn't recommend going here while you're starving bc the wait can be atrocious but just know the ramen you're waiting for is bomb and worth it. We  were annoyed up until the first bite and we still can't believe how positive we left halu considering we waited 2 hrs.
we have plans to come back in a few weeks, but we're going to grab snacks after putting our name on the list.
author: Melissa N.

description:
Three of us came here for dinner. The service was horrible! Why write a list of names if you are NOT going to abide by it?!?!

We came here around 7pm, walked in and I told the lady "Erica for 3" and she placed me on the list. This hole in the wall restaurant was soo TINY that we decided to sit outside in the freezing cold till they called my name.

30 mins later, I was like what is going on?! People were going in the restaurant, but not coming out! No one called my name and the three of us were freezing our butts off! I ended up going in and said, "hey, we have been waiting for 45 mins and you are seating people that came in AFTER us." They lady wasn't even using her damn list! What a waste! WHAT WAS THE POINT OF THE LIST TO BEGIN WITH?!?!

We finally get seated and ordered some yakitori (nothing worth remembering), Seafood Okominoyaki, and each of us ordered ramen.

All of the dishes we ordered was MEH, not worth the wait, not worth the crappy service and not worth my time again.

The ramen broth was not good, the pork was dry and the experience was horrible. 

Ramen and Yakitori places are emerging all over the place, I am sure I will find some place better than this place!
author: Erica T.

description:
My mouth waters when I think of Halu's Spicy Lava Ramen... but be warned, it is pretty damn spicy! I can eat a jalapeno raw, but I couldn't down Halu's Spicy Lava Ramen without taking multiple water breaks. It was freezing and raining outside, but I was almost sweating, and my mouth was on fire from beginning to end. 

The ramen came with typical toppings, like chashu and egg. The noodle is probably not homemade, and is on the thin side, but it matches the soup very well. I've just had a bowl of ramen at Ippudo in NY and I thought I'll never find ramen as good as there's in San Francisco, but Halu's lava ramen proved to be just as good.... maybe because I'm a fanatic for spicy food... We also ordered few yakitoris, including teba (wings), beef tongue, scallop-bacon, and also their tofu steak with mushroom sauce. They were all sososooo good =) Yakitoris had a nice smoky flavor, and the beef tongue was so soft and fatty, it's seasoned perfectly with just a dash of salt. 

So why not give this place a 5 star? Because, I had to get up 3 times at night to drink water, most likely due to the excessive MSG in the ramen broth. Is it worth it though? Probably, and most likely I'll come back here sooner than later, despite the awaiting thirst and dizziness.
author: tiannaaah J.

description:
Two stars for the food -but three overall because they were so damn friendly! 
 
I heard this place had great ramen, so my friends and I thought we would give it a shot. It doesn't open until 5pm so we roamed around and sampled food at several bakeries that line Clement St. There was a group of people waiting 15 min before it opened, so we thought - must be worth the wait! 

Well, bad first impression- they opened ten minutes late and we were in a serious mood for food. 

They quickly sat us and thanked us for waiting. I was kind of shocked at how cozy (tiny) their space is. It's definitely really quirky - something I'd imagine I'd find in Haight Ashbury and not run by Asians (just sayin!). 

I had the Chicken Kaarage Ramen and some yakitori. I'm sad to say that I wasn't impressed. You know that feeling you have sometimes when you're soooo hungry that anything tastes good? Well I was soooo hungry and this didn't blow me away. 

The search for good ramen continues!
author: Shannon A.

description:
A beatle-themed hole in a wall. Cute but it lacks ventilation so don't be surprised leaving the place with your hair and clothes smelling like grease. 

Nevertheless, great yakatori! I love skewered chicken wings that are salted, peppered or marinated and grilled. Bacon wrapped mochi, their mushroom something something. 

Their ramen menu is rather small and I found it to be mediocre. Soup was nothing special and my noodles were a little more on the soggy side. I'd go back for more yakatori though.
author: Jenny K.

description: Went here tonight and I'm obsessed with the   Chicken Kaarage ramen! I got it spicy and yes it was! I love things spicy and this doesn't disappoint plus I love ginger gave it a greater kick. Besides the great food, the decor is amazing! I love the beatles and all things classic rock.   They even play it which goes well with food and casual atmosphere, and even gives the feeling of a pub.
author: Nadia N.

description:
SMALLEST ramen place ive ever been to! i thought dojo was small but Halu takes the cake of being the smallest. 

but the ramen was good, i order the chicken karaage ramen and the pieces of chicken karaage were really good and a big size!!! 

the servers were really nice and were attentive as they could be with the restaurant always being full. 

i wouldnt recommend this place for a larger group. because honestly i dont feel that this restaurant was meant to be a restaurant. i couldnt even see the restaurant from the outside and i was parked on the corner of 7th going towards 8th  but still none the less the food is good and the service is good.
author: Matt F.

description:
No Sushi. This is the real deal if you want to experience Japanese food besides ramen, sushi, and sashimi. Family owned and crazily decorated with Beatles memorabilia (the father was in a band before), this place has good, authentic food. Yes, service is super slow and the place is tiny, but usually after a few beers/shots of sake, you won't notice.

My friends knew the owners since they are regulars so they ordered massive amounts of food. Can't remember all the names, but I took pictures!

Highlights:
- Bacon Wrapped Mochi: yummmmm...doughy goodness
- Oyster Chicken: covered in onions and good
- Spareribs: tender and flavorful
- Okra: light and good
- Yakitori: yummm - must try!
- Erichan Special: pan-fried mochi w/ seaweed! light soy saucey flavor and mochi is just awesome in general!

Ramen:
- Spicy Ramen: super spicy! other than that, I don't see anything special about it, just average
author: Linda C.

description:
The ramen and food here is pretty good. What set me off about this place is the service was horrid. We came here on a random Wednesday night. I was feeling a little sick and wanted something to warm me up a little and thought ramen would be the perfect solution! 

Arrived here at around 8:15, no line, got seated right away and ordered promptly. We got the Eichan's special and 2 ramen bowls. It took about 10 minutes for the butter-basted mochi to arrive, which is a bit long considered the level of difficulty to cook mochi in a pan of butter. It was still good though. After that, we waited (no kidding) 30 MINUTES for our ramen, we didn't start eating our ramen till about 9:00, we were annoyed and hungry. and kept looking for our meal to come. I mean come on, it seriously doesn't take 30 whole minutes to boil some noodles, warm the broth, throw in an egg and heat up some pork. We do admit, it was good ramen and the wait staff was very nice and friendly. They did notice we were getting a little restless, but didn't offer anything to compensate our lackluster food service. 

Not sure if I'll be quick to return here, we've been here before and recall that service wasn't that bad. I'll have to give it some time, but for now Izakaya Sozai is my new go-to ramen spot.
author: Justin L.

description: Need more ramen in my belly! Totally owe an apology to the kind staff  at the Saratoga lovation!
author: Michael R.

description:
We were shopping in the area and decided we wanted ramen so we yelped this place. It was pretty early on xmas eve so the place was empty... in fact it was super hard to find, from the front, you'd think it was a clothing store because it shares it's front entrance with one. We saw that the menu didn't have many choices for ramen and almost walked away but decided to just give it a try since we were there...

SO glad we did!

I didn't know I'd like yakatori so much!! I mean I've always loved eating meat off a stick but never thought I'd sit down in a restuarant just to order that. We did try the ramen which I didn't think was anything impressive BUT I loved all the skewers we had.

My favorite was the chicken stuffed mushrooms, then the bacon wrapped tomatoes - well - I love anything bacon wrapped. The chicken skewers were a bit boring and wasn't as flavorful as the rest. We also had the bacon wrapped zuchinni.

The fried chicken skin deserved a paragraph on its own! Did I think I'd ever order just fried chicken skin? okay yeah maybe I would..but this was So good! lotsa tasty fat pouring into your palate as you chew this crispy yet soft chicken skin!

We orderd 6  different skewers and ramen .... I wanted another stomach that day so that I can try more items on the menu! will definitely be back to try the rest.. SOON!
author: Anna T.

description: We've been through your doors many times per the past couple of years for a good reason. Love the divy ambiance and really enjoy the daughters who runs the floor, both are very cute and full of personality of a family-run business, I really like the atmosphere. The walls covered with old Beatles paraphernalia and Beatles songs playing in the background. It's very good wholesome Japanese food all around. As one put it "If you like ramen and yakitori, this is a great hidden gem in the city..." I agree, a hidden gem. :)
author: Patrick W.

description:
My favorite ramen joint in SF. Has to be included in the best ramen in SF contenders. 

AND the Yakitori is perfect: favorites included trumpet mushrooms, chicken wings, melts belly steak is to die for.

Besides the food, this small establishment is what I love about San Francisco. Unassuming, quirky, with tons of personality. It's family owned and operated and seats ~20 people. Waits can be long, but put your name on the list and grab a drink on Clement.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Came to this place after the Nightlife at Cal Academy of Science with 6 people. Seating was surprisingly easy, half of the place was empty (Thursday night). Parking lot is also convenient. 

Came to the place because of the yakitori. It was pretty good, but I found it nothin different from the other yakitori places. However, the ramen here was pretty amazing. The noodles and broth were both on point. 

Also, excellent service. I know larger groups are harder to serve (especially in a smaller place with only one or two waitresses). Will definitely come back again!
author: Daniel K.

description:
So I am back to the restaurant just now and I had ordered Fried chicken ramen. It was AMAZING!!! Best in the area! I ordered Green tea Tiramisu too and it is as delicious as it could be!!!! It has become my favorite japanese restaurant in the bay area and I definitely going to be back for more. 

Free street parking at 8pm and be prepare to wait though:) I do think that the food is going to worths the wait.
author: Ana F.

description:
anything with a 3 star rating means it's unlikely that I'd go back, but I would make an exception for Halu and give it one more try.

We got ramen and yakitori which were good, but not knock my socks off. next time i want to try their okonomiyaki.

decor is eclectic-- you can tell the owner is a music fanatic, especially of the beatles.
author: Kimberly F.

description: Best ramen I've had in the city - perfect broth (and spicy!) and the most tender pork I've had in a ramen dish to date.  Tiny establishment with Beatles memorabilia on every wall, which only adds to the charm.  I'm definitely coming back.
author: John S.

description: Best Ramen I've had in SF! Moved here from Orange County and it's been my mission to find a place that competes with Shin Sen Gumi. The Gyoza was very good and the pork ramen was amazing. They give you three big pieces of the most tender delicious pork. We ordered one regular and one spicy. Both perfect! I highly recommend this place if you love Ramen.
author: Robby H.

description:
I love this place. Ramen was so good and all of the skewers were too. (yes, i got them alll! i loveee yakitori! :)

minus one star cuz they're so darn small! what the hell! its like a joke. only can feed like 10 people at a time?! -__-
author: Lisa N.

description:
Friendly service!

Came here on a Saturday evening with 2 friends. Got the spicy karaage ramen. Karaage was delicious. Broth and noodles were ok. Also got bacon wrapped mochi and grilled mochi. I feel like the mochi should have been cooked more in the bacon.

The ramen took a while to come out though and I was wondering where it was for a while.

The shop is covered in Beatles memorabilia and plays Beatles music, which is kind of amusing. The bathroom is super small! Kind of like being on a submarine :P
author: Michael W.

description:
Quite possibly the worst dining experience i've had in the city. 

We waited about 40 min to sit down, even though there were plenty of open seats. I can understand that though because it's a small place so they probably didn't want to overload the kitchen. We finally get our names called right after 2 people who signed in before us. 

By the time the waittress even approached us, the party of 2 right next to us at the bar had already received drinks and food. We hadn't even ordered a single thing (and I had to actually walk up to the wait stand to get her attention - god knows how long it would have taken if I hadn't). 

By the time we received our ramen, we had been sitting for over an HOUR. That's crazy! There was another gentleman who walked in when we were in the middle of our meal and he was able to receive his ramen, pay and leave before we got ours. 

The yakitori was pretty good but as others have said, it's on the greasy side. The ramen was just OK. The pork broth wasn't rich enough and the meat was overcooked and mushy. 

I definitely will not be coming back here.
author: Alli J.

description:
Usually I find it a shame that often people only feel inclined to write bad reviews and not praise those rare and precious businesses that do things right. Unfortunately this place is not one of them. 

I've actually been to Halu around ten or so times now over the course of a couple years; friends and family who have never been insist that we go, as it's an SF novelty and in my neighborhood. I'd say about seven of those ten occasions were unenjoyable due to service issues - I suppose my most recent effort was the final straw.

We put our name on the list and waited outside. Two people leave, then the one couple before us came back to be seated, then two people leave, three people enter, two more enter...we begin to wonder to ourselves why so many are going in and none of them are coming back out...

So we check. The waitress was just seating people because they walked in at the right moment. She hadn't forgotten about us outside, but had no regard for the "waiting list". Over the course of 30 minutes she had seated 5 people, none of which were before us on the list. We asked why; she was completely unapologetic. The three that she sat down at a four-seat table first because we were only two? Understandable. But how many times was she going to do that while we waited for half an hour. Needless to say, after ten generous times, I'm done trying. And you know what? The ramen isn't really that good. There. I said it.

But it's not all bad! After walking straight out the door we made our way to Thai Time directly across the street, another little hole-in-the-wall place that admittedly we had been too afraid to try. We were immediately seated to find an extensive menu of excellent thai food, and without us even asking, our waitress moved us from our two-seat table to a four-seat table once it was available simply because we had ordered so many dishes. A wonderful silver-lining and now a new tradition that doesn't require listening to "I Wanna Hold Your Hand" on repeat.
author: Leslie F.

description: Best Ramen in the Bay! They were fine with my "no noodle, veggie ramen with a side of pork and egg" request. Freaking delicious with some very interesting specialties. Looks like an old american dinner with all Beatles memorabilia. It kind of made me laugh and go "Wow!" at the same time.
author: Trish W.

description: This is one of my favorite place to eat. This is a small, cute family owned restuarants and everyone is very friendly here.  Some of my favorite skewers are the fried stuffed mushrooms, beef tongue, chicken mayo and pork jowl, All of them are nicely seasoned.  I also love their ramen and okonomiyaki. Thier Okonomiyaki is tasty and crispy on the outside. Food & service is always perfect here. I always wish I can order everything on the menu here, but I can only eat so much. :)
author: Jennifer K.

description:
It's a really cozy and lovely place to eat - very interesting restaurant decor, I liked the retro-Beatles-music theme they had going on. 

I tried some of their skewers and the ramen, both of which were very good. I got the karaage ramen. Good ramen, good broth! I'm usually disappointed by ramen in the city, but this was surprisingly good! The skewers were very good too - we only got chicken hearts, but I wish we got more! Will have to try more when we visit again. 

The service was sweet, although slow. The food took a long while to come out, and they took forever to refill our tea. But I do get it is a busy restaurant and not many waitstaff. 

One star off for the extremely long wait for food. If you come, be prepared to sit and have a nice long chat with your friend because you'll be waiting a long long time. I wouldn't have minded the wait, but I was already pretty hungry when I got there so the long wait didn't help. I might be slightly exaggerating about the wait - I honestly don't remember exactly how long it took for the food to come out, all I remember is getting a little grouchy when our food wouldn't come out so I could stuff my face!
author: Lena Y.

description: Great divey joint. Cool memorabilia on the wall. Delicious food.
author: Kyle K.

description: It's open again! I went on the first day of the re-opening but they didn't have the any skewers. So I plan to go back next week. Everything should be back and running as normal by then. Can't wait!
author: Karen L.

description:
I LOVE this place. From the Beatles decor, to the amazing staff that run this place. I used to live in Japan, and miss the food there often. Most places in the US serve sushi and that's kind of their highlight. That's great, but to be honest I didn't eat all that much sushi. There are a myriad of other Japanese dishes that exist that I thought I would never be able to eat again.
Then I found Halu after moving to the bay area. I come all the way from East Bay to eat here.
My personal favorite dishes are their Ramen, the Eri-chan special (mochi that is grilled and wrapped with nori) and the Okonomiyaki (another amazing dish that you have to try, originally from Okinawa).
It gets busy, so if it's a cold night bring a warm coat. This place is cosy and intimate, and everything you order is made right there on the spot. I wouldn't have it any other way. Do yourself a favor and give Halu a try.
author: Milhouse B.

description:
7.22.11
9:00 PM
$35 pp

I couldn't help the nostalgia rushing over me as I walked into this tiny izakaya off of Clement.  Halu is the best representation of unpretentious Japanese pub-food as I know it in San Francisco....maybe even in California.  The space is cozy and a bit run down but is nonetheless charming and welcoming.  The interior is slathered with 60's rock memorabilia and posters (think The Beatles, The Who, etc).

The food was delicious:

Halu salad: A-
Kara-age: A+
Grilled Eggplant: B (classic)
An assortment of skewers (grilled and fried): B+/A-

The servers are quirky but pure intentioned and extremely friendly.  I'm unsure whether reservations are accepted but we showed up at around 8:20, and were seated by 9:00 (we were able to wander around the area and the hostess called us when our seat was ready).  If you find they do take reservations, ask for the tables away from the entrance as it can get quite cold by the door.

I can't wait to go back.
author: William R.

description:
One of my favorite Japanese go to places.  Everything on their yakitori menu
is good.  I especially love their okonomiyaki (Japanese style savory pancake).  It's crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside. yummmm. 

I would highly suggest getting the chicken oysters, mochi bacon, and beef tongue.

Although their ramen is not the best ramen ever, there's just something about the beefy broth and their chewy noodles that always makes me want more.  

Something that stands out about this tiny restaurant is their 60's decor and the Beatles music always playing in the background.  I know it gets busy and people complain about the wait, but it's totally worth it.  Plus the people there are so nice!  You can't really get frustrated with them.  If you don't like waiting just get there earlier. 
And if you need to wait, put down your number and go to the bars.  They'll call you.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
It was a cold Winter night and ramen seemed like a good choice to warm us up. Bunny and I did some research and found Halu. Finding the restaurant took some time. We had parked a few blocks down.  After locating the place, we walked inside and put down our name. Since it was a bit small, the hostess suggested that we give a number and when the table was ready, we would get a call. 

We walked around for a little bit, but a lot of places were closed and we ended up just sitting on the bench right outside the restaurant. Whenever two people came outside the exit, we would get anxious, wondering if our table was ready. Finally we received a call and were seated.

As soon as we are seated, we are delivered with the bad news that ramen was not being served!. We were a bit disappointed and even contemplated leaving. However since it was already late and we had waited so long, Bunny and I decided to give yakitori, the only other item on the menu, a try. 

Looking at the menu, it was difficult to decide which ones to order so we decided on the Yakitori dinner, which came with soup, salad and 7 chef's yakitori, and the Kushi Katsu Yakitori, which also included soup, salad and 6 chef's yakitori. It wasn't our first choice, bt there was nothing that could be done. Our server apologized and said that ithey ran out of ramen about 30 minutes ago. Had we had known, we might not waited for the table.

We were also talked into ordering lychee sake and apple sake. The miso soup comes out first. Our hot soup tastes good on a cold night. Shortly the Yakitori Dinner and Kushi Katsu Yakitori Dinner plate arrives. The servers explain all the different skewers. The presentation of the dishes are nice.

The meat was tasty and the salad was pretty good. There as a lot of variety and different types of yakitori. However, since I'm not a big skewer fan, it was just okay. The servers were nice and kept checking up on us. They would apologize about the inconvenience.

I would like to come back to try ramen, since that was the main reason why we had gone in the first place.
author: Doris W.

description: Delicious! Cozy atmosphere and super friendly staff/owners. Love this place.
author: Connie B.

description:
Came here for the first time last Friday night about 7pm and we were surprised there was no line and a few tables open. But, about 1/2 an hour later, all tables were full including the counter. I guess we got there the right time. 

Since they specialized in yakatori, I ordered the gizzard to taste and chashu ramen. My friend ordered the yakatori dinner which had the panko breading - chef's choice. 

The gizzard was very flavorful - I love the texture to it and I believe it had alittle sea salt on it which brought out the flavor. I would order it again. 

The ramen was good and my friend said his panko yakatori was good too. To me, the ramen was just okay. We were actually still hungry after our dinner which is kinda disappointing, I guess. 

The service was nice and friendly but it was definitely slow. Had to wave the waitress a couple of times to get their attention. 

I will be back if I am ever craving yakatori, which is not too often. For ramen, I would go to J-town.
author: James L.

description:
A whole in the wall ramen and yakitori shop, Halu is easily missed if you don't specifically look for it. Every surface is plastered with the Beatles memorabilia, which strangely feels very Japanese (the pop-culture-leaning half). Perhaps the Yakitori's cook's side gig as a drummer has something to do with the kitsch. With all the decorations, the place is still tidy and clean.

I can't speak for the yakitori, but Halu makes fantastic shoyu ramen. The broth has depth and every slurp is full of flavors. The curly noodles are just chewy enough and  great to bite into. I love the spicy chicken karaage ramen, but be forewarned it's not for the faint hearted as its spiciness will quickly put beads of sweat on your forehead. They plunk the crispy chicken karaage into the broth, which struck me as strange initially but I've come to enjoy.
