Although service is friendly and food delicious, I'm always nervous about making the trek out to Halu. Once I came when they decided to be closed during normal hours and another time they didn't open half an hour later than scheduled. I've been back recently and was reminded of how good the ramen is. I'll slowly give them the benefit of the doubt and hope they won't disappoint. Until I feel safe about this relationship, it's just a 4 stars commitment from me.
author: Rina W.

description: Yakitori Chef special and pancake. The service was great and the food was good but too expensive for what it is (skewers) Unique spot, fun atmosphere but price is too high to make it a regular visit.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Waitress 1: Hi, how many?
Us: 2
Waitress 1: Is the bar area okay?
Us: Can we get a table?
Waitress 1: Umm... (walks away)
.....standing there for a couple of minutes.....
Waitress 2: Hi, how many?
Us: 2
Waitress 2: Is the bar okay?
Us: We'll wait for a table
Waitress 2: Ok (walks away and comes back a minute later)
Waitress 2: Did you want to sit at the bar?
Us: We'll wait for a table

My friend and I came to Halu on Saturday, July 3 after the Jazz Festival.  We had the above conversation with two different waitresses.  We were seated after a table left, which was about 10 min or so later.

FOOD:
*Miso Soup - Yum, this is one of the tastiest and best miso soups I've ever had.  The soup wasn't too salty and contained pieces of tofu, seaweed, green onions, and even enoki mushrooms.  

*Agedashi Tofu - Mmmmm, everywhere Japanese restaurant I go to, agedashi tofu is a must.  The tofu was lightly battered with a gel like outer layer and soaked in the delicious broth.

*Yaki Nasu (Baked Eggplant) - Pass.  We ordered it because we thought it was the one with miso sauce, however, it was baked and was quite bland.  The waitress told us to make a sauce with the soy sauce and provided ginger, it didn't taste great.

*Pork Jowl - Delicious, it tasted similar to pork belly but a little more on the saltier side.

*Bacon Mochi - This was okay.  As a bacon lover, I had higher expectations.  Oddly, I thought this dish tasted similar to popcorn.

*Scallop Kushikatsu - DELICIOUS!  My friend thinks I have a "scallop addiction" and sure enough, I sat down and had to order the scallops.  The scallops were tender and lightly breaded and deep fried and came with a tonkatsu dipping sauce.

*Short Rib Skewer - Yum, the meat was tender and tasty

*Chasu Ramen - Pass, I think my expectations for the ramen was high.  The broth was a bit salty and the noodles were overcooked.  The kernel corn in it was delicious though. 

SERVICE:
Although this is a small, hole in the wall sized restaurant, Halu seemed to be lacking service.  The waitresses failed at coming around to check on us as well as failed in greeting customers who came in in a timely manner.

There is one unisex restroom.  The light switch is on the wall outside of the bathroom.  In order to switch it on, you have to stick your hand in a cutout of the wall...odd.  There is also a HUGH water heater in the bathroom.

PARKING:
Street metered parking - since you're in the Richmond, it can be quite difficult looking for a space.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Just read about this in SF weekly and realized I never raved about how awesome this place is (probably regretting that decision now because this place is as small as my kitchen, so I don't want it to flood with foodies hehe)

The yakatori, ramen, and beer is basically the trifecta of japanese bombness here. The pork jowel was my favorite and was some uber fatty yet totally worth it taste of heaven. If you are ever consiering going vegetarian or vegan and need a reminder of why thats a bad idea, try the pork jowl...

The bacon wrapped mochi is another big win here. They make similar yakatoris as this at Izakaya Sozai (which are also delish) but this place wins on the lower prices, shorter waits, and cheaper beer.


There is a LONG list of yakatoris for everyone to sample on the wall right next to the seemingly misplaced gaggle of Beatles memorabilia, so don't worry about finding something everyone will like. Lastly, the ramen and beer. Both wins. I tried the fried chicken ramen and the lava ramen which were excellent, and well...beer is beer, and they have it at prices I like to pay :)

Check out this shack if you are in the area, I think you'll find this little gem has more to offer than meets the eye at first glance.
author: Samantha R.

description:
A very fun, slightly quirky izakaya with yummy yakitori and other small bites. 

Yes, the bites are very small..so order a lot! Each plate is ridiculously cheap but the plates do add up.

Not to miss -
- shiso beef
- bacon wrapped scallops
- fried chicken with basil
- okonomiyaki (I prefer the veggie one)
- not much of a ramen person myself, but friends rave about the chashu

I have had to wait just once out of five or so visits, but that's just my good luck I guess. Service is slightly slow but friendly. 

One of my top SF picks!
author: Amrita M.

description:
"Hole in the wall place".Lately I have been craving ramen noodles and I yelped which restaurants served good ramen. Yelp lead me to this place. Looking at it from the outside looked pretty sketchy. Going inside everything the restaurant seemed to be the Beatles #1 fan. It was really small, packed, and cramped. I was seated quickly and the smell of the food made me more hungry and excited to eat. 
I had the Kara Age Ramen and I have to say, it definitely satisfied my craving. The noodles were not too salty it was just right. I also had the chicken skewers which I thought was a rip off. it was $4.50 for 2 itty bitty skewers. Don't get me wrong, they tasted delicious but the portion was too small. I am glad I was able to try this place out. The main courses are definitely worth paying for, not so much the appetizers or the salads.
author: Katrina T.

description: The ambience is rad, tiny little shop with Beatles memorabilia and music. We were fortunate enough to not have to wait for a table, but once we were seated we were not helped for 15 min. Potstickers were good. Ramen, which took an additional half hour, was below expectations. The noodles and meat were ok, but the broth looked and tasted like a toilet. Disappointing ramen experience, although it looked like the other dishes were popular.
author: Rudy R.

description:
Walked into Halu from recommendation from a friend the weekend I was in San Francisco. Great decor, cozy joint, also great restaurant ambiance! Waitresses were extremely friendly, and despite having to wait 45 minutes to be seated it was worth it.

Waiting for the food was a little long though, we were seated at around 9pm and food didn't come until nearly 10pm. I was ready to just stuff myself on yakitori, so I ordered bacon-wrapped quail egg, chicken hearts, gizzards, bacon-wrapped enoki, and some grilled mountain boar sausage. My friend ordered shiso steak, bacon-wrapped zucchini, and the same chicken innards. The food came out in segments rather than all at once, which kind of made me restless when I finished the portion and had to wait another 10-15 minutes for the second.

Yakitori isn't filling, but I didn't want to order anything else. Definitely didn't leave full, but I'd love to come back again to have a few drinks + yakitori. Something that bothered me was that the waitress said the kitchen closed at 10:45 so we couldn't order past that point, but there were people who came out as we left (10:30) so I'm guessing they know the owners or something. 

I was told that the yakitori + okonomiyaki here was good, and everything else on the menu sort of lacked--so I played it safe. I definitely recommend coming here if you're in a small party and want to sit at the bar and have drinks with friends (their selection seems generous) and yakitori.
author: Ling C.

description: Awesome! you dont need the extra noodles. Portion looks small but pack a punch. ..just a  tad pricey for ramen.
author: Pablo K.

description: Awesome decor; the place is literally a homage to the Beatles. Paul McCartney needs to stop by and just check it out. They have awesome yakitoris; everybody needs to order the oyster chicken and pork jowl. Like many izakaya joints, the place is pretty small so you need to be patient about waiting in line. Unfortunately, the only bad thing I have to say is about their grilled rice ball; it was grilled perfectly but was wayyyy too salty.
author: Theresa M.

description: Great ramen, chicken yakitori, and koumi don, but the service was incredibly slow.
author: Amin S.

description: The soup hit the spot...not only did the temperature of the soup but the intensity of the flavors and the spiciness warmed you up. They don't mess around with their spicy..it is spicy. Even as I was grossly sweating, I couldn't stop drinking the soup. The fried chicken still had some crisp to it and it was so tender and there was a good amount of them that came with the ramen. The ramen were cooked to perfection. 12.50 for a bowl..not the cheapest but worth trying it. PS: Get the pork jowls...so tender and delicious.
author: Eve C.

description:
Cute Japanese place with literally 8 square-shaped tables cramped in a hole-in-the-wall. I love it.

It was my first time eating ramen made in a restaurant, so I was very excited. I went with a group of friends, and seeing how small it was, I was surprised by how quickly we got seated. We ordered a few yakitori's and ordered our respective ramens.

It was a Thursday night, and yes, there were several other people at the restaurant, so business was really slow. It took 10 minutes to finally be able to order... another 30 to get our food. They messed up on someone's ramen, so it was another 15 before they got their food. But oh man, their ramen is soooooooo good!!

It's not like at a Korean restaurant where they charge you $4 to cook a pre-packaged ramen and put extra veggies (or cheese) in it. Oh, no. They have their special miso (or soy, whichever one you choose) broth with their awesome noodles. I opted to go for the vegetarian ramen, which I thought I'd regret, but their variety of 10(!) vegetables kept my tongue satisfied and tummy full!

If you don't mind waiting a while, I'd say come here and enjoy a nice, large bowl of Japanese ramen! Yum yum!
author: Becky K.

description:
I had wanted to try a Yakitori type Japanese Restaurant and Halu was my first experience. Loved it!  We concentrated on the skewers with chicken wing, heart, stuffed mushrooms etc. Our favorite was the chicken gizzards they were delicious.
The restaurant is small and family run, its quite cozy. The restaurant is decorated with Beatles memorabilia which gives you a lot to look at while your eating. Overall I say check it out !
author: Ron C.

description:
The fact that it took me, ME, almost 3 years to try a restaurant that specializes in Yakitori and Beatles memorabilia is a tragedy.  Really.  I'm ashamed.

This Saturday night, we donned our wool coats and braved the fog to try out Halu.  Again, I'm embarrassed to say that although we always think the Richmond is "so far away," it took us like, 12 minutes to drive here from the Mission.  And we parked like, 12 feet away from the restaurant.  So really, we need to stop bitching about such things.

There was a 20 minute wait so we walked over to the 540 Club on Clement for a quick $2 PBR.  Halu called us in almost exactly 20-25 min. and we were immediately seated upon our re-arrival.  

Service was a little spotty-- I think one of the servers was new.  But they were both super cute and nice so I'll give them a pass.

But the food was spot on.  We basically ate everything that most people wouldn't on the menu, including:

-Dark pork sausage: LOVED
-Chicken hearts: Liked
-Katsu liver: LOVED
-Chicken skin: LOVED (eat it while its hot!)
-Chicken oysters: LOVED
-Okra: LOVED
-Bacon-wrapped quail egg: Recommended by our waitress, probably a favorite of most white people but it was kind of too chewy for us
-Shishito peppers: Liked
-Seafood okinomiyaki: LOVED

All that and a large beer cost us about $75.  It was probably too much food but we wanted to try lots of things.  Lots of people were eating ramen, so maybe we'll try that next time, although its difficult to turn down grilled animal parts :)

GREAT Yakitori place.  Oh, and did I mention they play Beatles music on a loop and their decor looks like my bedroom from 1996-1999?  There's that too :)
author: Kristin P.

description:
A small place. Somewhat hidden. Great place. 
I like their Spicy Chasiu Ramen. Their Yakitori is ok too. 
Come try. 
Nice waitresses are nice too.
author: Albert W.

description:
Yum! Somehow I'd decided on the way over that I didn't feel like going here, didn't know why I was going, etc. So I was ready not to like it. But Halu excelled despite my negative attitude! At 7:30 on a Thurs night we actually didn't have to wait for a table for 5, which seemed lucky.

We went fairly all out on the food, focusing on the yakitori. Favorites: ground chicken (nice and loose, rather than having the hockey puck texture of so many meatball-type items), short ribs (a little chewy but very flavorful), fried tofu appetizer (delicious!!). Good: chicken wings, chicken thighs, kara age (fried chicken) Wouldn't get next time: bacon-wrapped asparagus. Good idea, but I found that some of the bacon wasn't very crisp and was more limp. I would try to get more vegetables overall if I were the one ordering next time. Surprisingly good: whichever salad we had, which had unusually sweet and tasty strawberries and nice chunks of creamy avocado.

I really liked the overall saltiness of a lot of the items - I know it'll apparently kill you faster than you thought and everything, but it was a nice touch on crispy exteriors.

And don't worry, fellow Beatles haters, they only played Beatles music for like half the time we were there.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Small place that can get super busy on a Sat night during Thanksgiving holiday which is good but at the same time, took a while to get a seat and even longer for our food. But that's pretty much the only gripe. 

Their menu is extensive but not overwhelming and can satisfying all your taste desires in one sitting. Ramen? The yasai was chock full of different veggies and while the broth isn't as rich or porky as say, santouka/orenchi, but it was still fulfilling and the noodles were up to par. Yakitori? Beef tongue was done well! Donburi? Our koumi don (lightly breaded and fried chicken) was done really well, atop a bed of brown rice with salad and grilled eggplants on the side. And kushikatsu? You don't see much kushikatsu in other restaurants--breaded and lightly fried. Our pork and onion was yum. 

Basically, there's a little something to satiate every Japanese culinary desire in you. I still have yet to try the okonomiyaki but I'm sure it doesn't disappoint. A great neighborhood joint that I'd patron often if I lived in the city!
author: Annie W.

description: Great service. The yakitoi is really good; I like the beef tongue and chicken ones. I also tried karrage ramen. It's worth a try, and the portion is huge (5 big pieces of chicken karaage and a full bowl of ramen). I will definitely go back to try out more yakitori.
author: Pui L.

description: This place is slow!  I always make sure to eat a small snack before I come, because there is always a wait.  The one good thing about this place is that you can wait in the car and they will give you a phone call when your table is ready.  But the waiting isn't even over yet when you get your table.  It takes another 30-40 minutes for the food to come out.  Be sure to come early though or they will sell out of a lot of the skewers.
author: Tina L.

description: I have been here twice in the last three months now. First, this small restaurant is the type that reminded of actual small neighborhood restaurants when I visited in Japan. Second, I really like the fact that the parents and children and a few family friends work here. Third-very reasonable prices including entrees, appetizers and beverages. Fourth-no sushi means you can find all the harder to find items such as my favorite, Okonomoyaki. I had the vegetable one on my first visit since it is hard to find in SF, and I was amazed at how large it was. It was the best one I've had outside of Japan. Soba noodles, salads, and all of the skewered and grilled appetizers you can't go wrong with, esp. bacon wrapped Mochi!
author: Aaron R.

description:
This place is nothing like any other Japanese place I've been to.
Not because this mom and pop eatery only seats about 20 people max, but because of all the Beatles decor and the 70's music in the background.
It was unusual but fun.

The ramen I ordered was good.  The shoyu broth was a little on the light side but nothing a little cayenne pepper couldn't fix.
The katsu the wife ordered was better, but the skewer sample we split really impressed. 

The alluring smells of deep fried goodness from the kitchen wafted throughout the restaurant and even drifted its way outside.  It was very pleasing aroma before we walked in and as we were leaving.
Unfortunately, it also permeates your clothes and won't dissipate for at least a couple of days.

Overall, the authenticity and family feel will have me back for more.
author: Dan B.

description:
Very Japanese place + Happy servers
The food was great as well!
I like gyusuji for isakaya~ 
There karaage was good too
author: Dalu Q.

description:
Hole in the wall...super small.  I got the spicy chashu-men and was super-satisfied. My fellow diner ordered a shredded potato/veggie pancake thing with dual sauces on top that was phenomenal.  We got there right when they opened and felt the restaurant come to life on a weekday evening. Service was quick and friendly.  Pork jowl yakatori...delicious!  Fun decor; quaint. Good place to take a low-key date. One more time...praise be to the spicy pork ramen!

No sushi.  Not today or tomorrow.

I will be back.
author: Edward F.

description: Beatles memorabilia everywhere! Finally got a chance to get a table [even tho we sat at the bar]. Everytime you drive by this place you see tons of people waiting outside. The food was great. Had some ramen and ordered this mini skewers, mochi  [forgot what exactly].  Also ordered the potatoe pancakes. The service was a bit slow but they were packed on a Sunday night. Just remember when you come here, NO SUSHI.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Tried this place last night and wasn't super impressed.  The place is a hole in the wall (very small). 

Ramen was average and the yakitori was good but overpriced.  They portions were small. 

I think I'll stick to Saiwaii Ramen on Irving since it is closer by to my place.  

The service was really nice though.
author: Cin T.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said about Halu...

I found the small space charming, the Beatles memorabilia funny, the service friendly and helpful, and the food delicious.  Oh, and their "no sushi" poster on the front door made me laugh.  The television show they were playing was something with cute girls and baby animals.  It was very odd, but it made everyone in the place laugh.

As to the food...
Bacon wrapped mochi?  Yes please!
Bacon wrapped enoki?  Yum!
Yakitori chicken skins?  Mmmm!
Yakitori shitake mushroom?  Of course!

They were out of the Daikon salad, so we went with the Gomae (spinach) and it was delicious.  Probably the best I've had.  The spinach was cooked and cooled perfectly, and there was just enough sauce, not too sweet.  I sound like Goldilocks, but seriously, it was delicious.

My only complaint was that I would have liked the bacon to be cooked about a minute longer, but that's personal preference.  The bf thought it was cooked perfectly.  Guess I just like my bacon extra crispy.

Next time I'll have to try the ramen, as the waitress told us the noodles don't have egg (I'm allergic) - yay!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I came here with my friends on a friday night and the wait was not long at all.  We got the counter seating and got the full view of all the liquor lined up on the counter.

We had the lemon flavored sake which didn't taste like sake at all.  This was followed by a drier milky-white sake.  We ordered the japanese pancake that usually comes with tonkatsu and mayo-like sauce, but my friend wanted the sauce on the side because it sogs up the pancake.  When we tried the pancake, it was still crunchy, crispy and flavorful.  The agedashi tofu was much better than the ones I had at tekka.  Their batter was much more lighter and the tofu was very soft.  My favorite was the shisu? beef yakitori which had tender chunks of beef with mint leaf and a tangy orange sauce.  The warm mochi wrapped in nori was also awesome- chewy and salty.  My friends ordered the ramen and they loved it.  

One of my fave yakitori places, better than o taisho or village yokocho because it had great food and a homey comfy feeling.
author: Nancy H.

description: This is my and my husband's 2nd time eating at Halu. The first time was right before the Holidays; they were so busy they sold out of Ramen. We were definitely disappointed but the super spunky, friendly staff (think they are part of the family who owns the place 'cause they seem so invested) were very accommodating. There was a long wait so they offered to take our name/number and call when the table was ready. This is common practice here, which is nice if you want to walk around or get a drink instead of standing around. The place is also pretty tiny so out of respect for their customers they have folks wait outside. The wonderful ladies who run show did whatever they could, with sincerity, to recommended some other non-Ramen dishes that were excellent - curry beef stew, pan seared mochi, sea food pancake, skewers with peppers and sausage. This time we were able to try the Ramen, which was the best I've had - chicken karaage and roast pork for the husband, Oh, and this little gem of a restaurant is decorated from head to toe with Beatles memorabilia, including an actual drum set tucked high up on a loft for all to see. Finally, they play the best oldies, songs not heard on the radio throughout the night (e.g., The Crystals "Then He Kissed Me" (yay, Adventures in Babysitting for those who remember!). So much fun and great food. If you're in the Richmond you really outta check this place out!
author: Cara G.

description: I still like this place, but I am SOOOOOOOOOOO disappointed that they took bacon mochi off their menu.
author: James T.

description:
This diminutive spot adorned with Beatles paraphernalia really wowed me. The space is so small our waitress kept bumping into us, charming, but not for anyone who is the least bit claustrophobic. Despite being so small with an open kitchen, we couldn't smell frying food while dining, nor did we smell like fried food upon leaving. Major bonus. 

Because it's izakaya style, we decided to go for it and order a mountain of small bites. 

Stuffed mushrooms 
Onigiri 
Ramen 
Pork jowl skewers 
Bacon-wrapped mochi 
Daikon salad 
Cold tofu

Arrive early, although it's off the beaten path of the main drag of Clement Street, the six tables fill up quickly.
author: Lee H.

description: I love this restaurant! It's tiny, very cozy, and the waitresses are very nice and attentive. Everything we tried had lots of flavor. The chashu ramen's broth wasn't too greasy, and the noodles were a perfect al dente. We also tried the chicken wings, beef tongue, the special they had that night of liver/cartilage/heart/skin/gizzard, and the okonomiyaki. Everything was bursting with flavor and good textures, my only disappointment about this place was the amount of food you get for what you're paying (e.g. four small chicken wings for $6.50). I will definitely be back though!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Easily one of my favorite places in the city. Everyone I've dragged in has loved it, staff are always friendly and patient, and we've yet to have a bad dish.  

Lots of tasty veggie options (no veggie ramen, but there is an awesome veggie okonomiyaki), and it's been easy to accommodate gluten-free friends too.
author: Brigitte B.

description:
Mmmmm, I could totally eat ramen 8 days a week... though, I might get sick of hearing the Beatles all day long if I came to Halu THAT often (they play them 24/7 and, as all the other reviews have mentioned, the place is decked out in memorabilia). But it is quite nice having this quirky ramen/yakitori joint in the 'hood--if I ever need my noodle and/or Fab British 4 fix, I know exactly where to go.

The first time I came here, service was pretty spotty--the seating arrangement was awkward, food was good but came out slow, and not enough teacups were given. Granted, they were extremely busy that night, and Halu redeemed itself this past Friday when me and 3 friends risked the wait and walked here after DYL at Buckshot--it turned out there were actually a few empty tables and our food was super fast (and yummy)! Hopefully this is a sign that the service has improved (and not just that we're in an awful recession :-/ ). 

I think there's 3 choices for the hot ramen (I always go for the miso flavor), as well as cold ramen and soba dishes. The chashu is always nice and fatty. Nom nom nom noodles.

I'm new to the yakitori concept, but I gather that it pretty much means that if a part of a chicken has a name, it CAN be eaten--on a stick, no less! There is also kushiyaki available, or non-chicken/vegetarian skewer options.

You're asking me, will my love [for Halu] grow? I don't knoowwww, IIIIII don't knoow...
author: Kate V.

description:
Very cramped:  I couldn't lean back without getting hit by the door when it opened.
Poor service:  We were there for 2 hours because they took forever to make our food, forgot items and got confused on what was what (they didn't know what food they were handing us)
Food was nothing special:  Full disclosure, I'm not big into yakitori.  Even so, I've had better.
author: Ronan L.

description:
After playing basketball with a North Korean defector and brother (his volte-face act of political shift came first before I ultimately embraced him into the circle of trust), we left the gym completely exhausted, cold and ready to gormandize on burritos.  However, our minds changed upon walking out and being greeted by the rain.  Usually when its a cold day, social norm calls for a variation of soup, pho usually.  However, having recently tapped into the dish called ramen, I opted for that.  We drove to Izakaya Sozai, our initial choice, however, were crestfallen to learn that it was closed on that particular day.  Changing my search parameters on my yelp application, Halu had the next best rating.

This place is tiny and cozy, a true hole in the wall.  However, imagine this hole in the wall completely adorned with Beatles memorabilia.  Posters are hung and there are many books and booblehead variants of the Liverpool quartet; Beatles music softly serves as the soundtrack for your impending meal.   From reading previous yelp reviews, it seemed that wait would be a while, however, we came around 9:30 pm, and while the restaurant was jam packed, the waitress quickly had us seated at the makeshift bar.  Service was very slow as the waitresses took forever to give us water and even longer to take our order.  This seemed to be a reoccurring theme as I saw many patrons tap their nails impatiently on the table.  However, the waitresses were neither standoffish nor pretentious, offering a kind word of patience or chatting us up.  I ordered the chasu-men and a side of agadashi tofu while hahnjob ordered the special spicy ramen.

My tofu took about 20 minutes to get to us while our ramen took abou 40.  The tofu was good, fried just right and served in a bowl of some sauce.  I don't know exactly what it is...a variation of soy/ponzu....but it was delicious.  I prefer a little crispier tofu but all in all, this was a solid dish.  My ramen, however, was very average.  After eating Himiwari's ramen with pork belly, I can't go back to eating the pieces of chasu.  They are good pieces of pork, however, not as flavorful as the pork belly.  The noodles did not stand out at all.  They tasted eerily similar to the instant ramen noodles.  They were a bit too hard.  Himiwari also ruined my egg experience; I can no longer eat tea eggs with my ramen.  I prefer the boiled ones where the insides are still goeey and mix with the soup base once broken.  Scooping up corn pieces were scarce and I was amazed when my spoon finally ensnared one.  There was also no seaweed; i thought seaweed was a staple however the bean sprouts were a welcome addition.  However, the broth was good, savory and not too salty.  The food was average and the wait long, however, the waitresses were very outgoing.  In addition, this cramped hole deserves a visit; the ambiance is unique and one of a kind and I will be back to try their specialty, the yakitori.  Maybe ramen just isn't their forte.

Ob-la-di, ob-la-da, life goes on, brah!...
Lala how the life goes on.
author: Brian V.

description:
Food: 3.75 stars
Service: 4 stars
Value: 4 stars

I wasn't planned on having dinner here, but it happened that it was right next to a park lot and we didn't have to wait in line. This place is tiny and busy. You'll definitely have to wait outside if you come after 7pm. 

Yakitori (skewers) is what they are specialized in. So we ordered chicken gizzards, beef short ribs, pork with onion, scallop with bacon, beef tongue, tontoro pork, and oyster chicken. All of them were small in portion, ranged from $4.5 to $5.5 for 2 skewers. The most delicious ones were beef tongue and scallop with bacon, very juicy and tender.

We also tried the seaweed salad $4.5, but it was nothing compared to the seaweed salad at Sumiya in Santa Clara. For something more filling, we also had a chashu ramen $9.5. It didn't taste good, and not authentic at all. We had a small bottle of sake called "drunken whale" $15. It wasn't too mild nor too strong, just right and went well with the skewers. 

The waitresses were nice and friendly. I could have given them a little higher score for the service. Unfortunately, the food was very slow! May be they were short in hand, so we had to wait for long time to get each dish.

The most funny thing is that I read the reviews later, and found out one yelper, Adelina W., wrote about the yaki origiri; it happened to us also except we were the one who didn't order it. I guess the waitress still confuses with the table number!
author: F T.

description: If you like waiting 2 hours for ramen then this is your place!! One of the worst dining experiences I've had. Table of 4 sat around 9pm, did not get our ramen till 10:30pm. Absolutely terrible. Avoid at all cost
author: Rene A.

description:
Is it weird to get a yakitori craving if you aren't Japanese?

Well it happened to me and I had to search Yelp to satisfy my urge. Surprisingly there aren't that many dedicated yakitori joints in SF. Last time I was in NYC I went to a bad ass one (http://www.yelp.com/biz/yakitori-totto-new-york).

We tried a number of different skewers. The best by far was the pork and green onion. The various steak skewers were pretty tough and heavily salted. Other highlights included the chicken wing and chicken hearts. 

The space itself is pretty neat, a small dining room and some bar seating. It's very Mom and Pop run, which means you can expect friendly service but watch out, it's cash only! The decor is Beatles-heavy and the music was good (but not too loud) it reminded me vaguely of a little classic rock bar I found myself in one time in Tokyo. 

If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd stop in again. However, my search for the ultimate in yakitori continues...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Their Twitter feed says they'll open on the 15th!  Cannot wait, as Halu is our favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  Their yakitori (meat and/or veggies grilled on skewers) are awesome, so many choices and all of them great.  But they also have great sake and beer, and the waitress is great at recommendations if you tell her what you like.  Their ramen is great to share, okonomiyaki is delicious (also a great item to share), salads are unique and fantastic.  Also don't miss the yaki onigiri (grilled rice balls with salmon).  Oh, and I almost forgot the kushikatsu; they take the yakitori and bread it and fry it, just wonderful.  

Honestly, it's fantastic, and anyone and everyone should go check it out to get an idea of an awesome culinary offering from Japan.
author: Mason N.

description:
This review is based only on the ramen which was not bad. but not great.  Small intimate place.  People were nice enough.  Service was confusingly slow given that we ordered ramen and there were only 3 occupied tables including ours.  It took about 30 minutes to get our food which again, was pretty mediocre.  

With so may options out there, I'm not unhappy I tried it, but have no plans to return.
author: Mystery V.

description: Hidden gem tucked away off Clement. I enjoy the rock n roll posters and the great comfort food.
author: Eric M.

description:
Man I really wanted to like Halu, but let's be honest...if I have to wait an hour for my food there is a problem. Being seated for 20 minutes before even having someone stop by to get our order was criminal too.

But really, we're here to rate the food aren't we.

Halu seems like a rip off.

Honestly, if I order a donburi, or the soba, I do NOT want half the friggin plate to be a salad. And there's nothing under the salad, so it isn't like it's hiding more rice, or more soba noodles.

And the soba, really, it comes with avocado. That's fine, I love avocado, I just don't love it when the dish is put in front of me and it's already turning brown and grey. Talk about a major turn off.

The seafood okonomiyaki was the star of the show here, really good, and a nice crust. Would come back to order that, but I don't think it's worth an hour wait just to get food when it seems like every other table around you is getting what they ordered.
author: David H.

description: This is the kind of place young hipsters love. The Beatles decor is totally random but gives this place personality. I had the ramen which was so so. I liked the al dente noodles and the chasu pork is flavorful. But it was missing the rich and creamy tonkotsu broth I was hoping for on a cold day. And for 12 bucks, it's not cheap. The service was fast and very friendly though. Will have to try the yakitori next time. Although the lack of charcoal smell in the air makes me wonder how it's cooked.
author: William B.

description:
This place has all the fixings to be an awesome hole-in-the wall find but they really need to improve their service and hospitality to find their way into my heart. 

 First of all, I LOVE the beatles (like, had a framed picture of Sir Paul McCartney on my bedside table in 7th grade, love) so you really have to push my buttons to get me to take stars away from a beatles-themed restaurant.  It was a really cold night in SF and the place doesn't have glass in the windows (?!?) so it was FREEZING in there.  It kind of detracted from the food because you really want your ramen piping hot, don't you?  Next, they completely screwed up our order and were bringing out the most random dishes.  What I assumed was my vegetarian dish turned out to have tiny bits of beef hidden within it and I didn't find out until they brought my actual veg dish, when the other one was already half way gone.  For someone who has been a vegetarian for 16 years, finding out that I had just nommed a half plate of cow was just a little bit devastating to my psyche and my tummy.  

Despite the very poor service the food was phenom (yes, carnivores, even the mysterious beefy one tasted deliciuos).  Asparagus Yakitori was delicious if of tne small side, and my buddy loved the ramen.  Points also redeemed for the music and the classic rock decor.  

I would probably go back here but next time I will be sure to double check what everything is before digging in.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
The ambiance is 5 star - elvis themed place in the middle of chinese restaurant zones of clement. 

Everything else is zero to one star unfortunately...
The izakaya type of dish is pretty dull and the okonomiyaki is skinny and tasteless. During my three visits, the only thing worth eating is the minced chicken on the skewers. Being an okonomiyaki snob, I would opt for those at Genki Ramen - which is only 2 blocks away.
The servers were not attentive and seemed to be busy in their own little bubble zone. 

Save your $ and run as far as you can from Halu.
author: Fred F.

description:
Decided to try this place with the hubby on New Years Eve and didn't even realize it had been there for a while considering all the good reviews. 

The place is very small and I think they were either not very customer oriented or severely under staffed that night, but I swear that even though I knew the waitress as we had gone to HS together, it took like almost 20min for us just have our order taken and then another 15 before we even got any tea even though others who came in after got it right away. 

Aside from having to wait nearly an hour just for the ramen (which by the way we ordered the karaage ramen as they were out of the Chashu) it was probably the best ramen I've tried aside from the one we had in LA. 
We did order two appetizers but those actually took even longer so we spent a total of an hour and half there out of which we only spend 30min actually getting to eat.  

So although we didn't think too highly of the service, I'll give them another chance being that they seemed under staffed and I knew the waitress and don't think she would purposely forget about us. Anyway, that's why I'm knocking down a star but ONLY for service. 

Overall...
-GREAT ramen and not too expensive, had enough flavor without tasting like MSG.
-Best Karaage around, though not the kind with the teryaki sauce.
-Will definitely be back for the ramen and karaage.

The bad..
-Service seemed extremely slow and without offering any apologies
-not a good place for a larger group
-decor is lacking any Japanese influence whatsoever and instead made you feel like you were throw back in the 60's hippies era dinners with all those Beatles memorabilia covering the walls.
author: Petra S.

description: The ramen was delicious.  The Beatles decorations are fun.  The yakitori was very good.   Great place to go out with friends and enjoy some comfort food and snacks.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Okonomiyaki, Yakitori and Ramen!

It's a small hole-in-wall, with 4-people counter space and 6 tables. Very divey. It's such a great place for catching up with friends over beer and yakitori.... However, I dont think you want to bring a big group of friends due to the space constraint. Oh, they also charge automatic 20% gratuity for party of 5 or bigger.

I love the Lava Ramen. Its quite flavorful with two huge pieces of pork, corn, and half of a hard-boiled egg.
As for the yakitori, Chicken Liver and Beef Tongue are must-try! 

Service is very prompt and friendly and they accept credit cards.
author: July N.

description:
Ok for reals?  4-5 stars?  This place is cute but seriously over rated.

Skewers were tasty, seasoned very nicely with the perfect amount of charring.  We had the hearts, gizzards, ginko nuts.  All were good.  We also had the pan fried mochi in seaweed.  Yum.

But the ramen, which is what we came for, was so disappointing!  Why does everyone go on about the ramen?  Suzu & Katanaya are so much better.  The broth had no flavor, not enough veggies (where's the bamboo shoots?) and the noodles were not the right texture, not al dente or chewy enough.

Chicken kaarage was above average, really big juicy pieces.   There was a ginger taste to it, so if you don't like ginger, not a good choice for you.

Decent, but underwhelming.  Search continues for best ramen in SF....
author: Josie M.

description:
The ramen is good but the yakitori could've been better. We ordered the stuffed mushrooms, bacon wrapped scallops, bacon wrapped rice balls, and fried chicken. Was a little disappointed to see only 3 bite sized pieces of each considering the price of each dish. Everything turned out to be pretty mediocre. 

I loved the "hole in the wall" location of Halu, and was pleasantly surprised to see how clean and tidy the interior is. I would return for the ramen but will probably pass on their small plates.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Been here a handful of times and they still serve the spiciest ramen in the Bay Area. Hotter than Katana-Ya, Kahoo, Ramen Dojo and all the other ramen places that have spicy on their menu. If you like it super RED, the kind where your lips are quivering from the mini fires after each slurp of broth and mouthful of noodles, you've found your spot. 

LAVA Ramen - not always on the menu, but ask for it. I love love love the karaage (fried chicken) lava ramen and so does the SO. Noodles are good, may not be as great as others, but the broth is unparalleled. 

Yakitori is kick butt too. Beef tongue is TEEEEEEddddddEFFFFF!  Scallops wrapped with bacon **nom nom nom**. 

Few bar stools, 4 tables that can hold up to 4-6, and 2 that can hold a couple. It's small, but worth the wait. Service is stupendous. Everything is made to order, so sit back, sip some sake, and wait for a piping bowl of ramen.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I came across Halu on "Hot on Yelp" and it sounded like the perfect casual dinner choice my fellow ramen-addicted friend and myself.

Tiny place that looks family run and decorated with Beatles memorabilia all over the walls.  

We shared:

*Chicken stuffed mushrooms yakatori (one order = 2 skewers)
*Agedashi tofu
*Two bowls of shoyu chashu ramen
*1 bottle of sake

I think the best part of the meal was the stuffed mushrooms covered in their house sauce.  Either that or the sake, which came highly recommended by our nice server, who said it was her favorite.  And she was right- it was really smooth.  

The tofu was good, though the fried outer skin was more sticky than it should've been.  It sort of fell apart in the broth.  The very tasty broth that I probably shouldn't have been slurping up on it's own.

The bowls of ramen were huge and for the most part decent, but not great.  The broth was slightly lacking in flavor and I prefer Katana-Ya's version over Halu. 

I sort of wanted to order more yakatori (especially the ginko nuts, or bacon wrapped anything!) but after two huge bowls of noodles, we were both stuffed beyond belief.  I think next time we'll focus more on the other dishes and less on ramen.  

The most expensive thing we ordered was the sake, at $9.50.  Ramen was $7.50, mushrooms were $3.50 or $4.50.  About $20/pp.  Not bad at all.

Don't forget- cash only!
author: Joanne G.

description:
A nice, simple menu. I had their ramen - nothing extraordinary but just plain good. I need to check out the other stuff.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Great Izakaya, tiny space with good eats and great service.

We decided to try a little sampler covering most of the menu- yakitori of beef with shiso leaf, pork jowel, bacon wrapped mochi...all had great grilled flavor. Onigiri with pickled mustard greens, daikon salad with a nice sauce, cold tofu over ice, and fried stuffed mushrooms were all hitting the right spot.

Top it off with the fried chicken ramen with a super tasty broth that had strong hints of ginger and we were satisfied.
author: Henry H.

description:
Craving Ramen one night, I found Halu on Yelp and decided to try it out. I went with a friend around 930pm, and there were customers, but not too packed, and no wait = yay!

I ordered the Chasu Ramen, and thought it was just okay. I did notice that they give you a lot of toppings here, more so than other ramen places. However, I think the quality of the ingredients was just okay - chasu was okay and not too tasty. Also, the ramen noodles here didn't taste the freshest.

Overall, Halu was okay and I've definitely had better elsewhere. (I know more about Ramen places in the South Bay [ORENCHI!!], and actually had no idea where to go in SF..)
author: Tiffany K.

description:
dined here last night. Every now and then, I find a place that reminds me why I am so fortunate to live in San Francisco. Halu is such a place. 

great yakitori, great ochazuke. i had the seafood okonomiyaki which reminded me of being back in Osaka. I love the hole in the wall, kansai atmosphere. only complaint I have is that they do not have draft beer. love this place
author: John D.

description:
First time here. First time eating ramen. Was ok, a little pricey. Table of 7 people and it was $30 a person. I thought that was a bit steep for food I can grill on the BBQ and ramen I can make out of the package.

We got the fried chicken ramen which was good, although I don't know if i seem myself eating much ramen in the coming days. I don't know anything about ramen, I ate it. It didn't have much flavor. I guess that's what happens when you eat ramen with no MSG.

We got several skewers. I like the ground chicken - which was like meatballs, the flank steak (just ok), the asparagus (good but it was $2 for ONE stem of asparagus, pricey).

Overall I though it was OK. The place was packed when we left - around 830 on a Wednesday night.
author: sierra s.

description:
I've been here one time and I loved it!

Bacon wrapped mochi, chicken meatballs, and other skewered goods. My boyfriend lived in Japan for 5 years and he really digs this place as well. I really like that Halu is family operated. Do yourself a flavor-flav and check it out.
author: Grace C.

description:
This was all our fault.

We really, really wanted to like this place. It's a cozy hole-in-the-wall with Beatles & Hendrix memorabilia adorning the walls. Just a handful of tables, a fair number of regulars (judging by the other Yelp reviews & labeled saki bottles), and a high rating on Yelp. Must be good, right?

That's what we expected when we walked in. I should add that we were starving for ramen also. I did a search on the Yelp iPhone app and this was the second search result. We glanced at the high-level reviews and decided to go for it.

Our experience:

+ Got there at 9:00pm on a Friday night. The place was packed. That's a good sign.

+ Got a seat right away. Score!

+ 30min wait before being able to order. That's okay, it's fairly crowded. There's only one waitress on staff, so she's probably swamped.

+ 15min wait for edamame. Cool enough. The crowds are disappearing now and there are a few empty tables. Hopefully since the rush is subsiding, we'll get our food soon.

+ 45min wait for the rest of our food. Okay, not cool. It's 10:30pm now and we're starving. So much for getting our food soon.

+ 10min to scarf down our food because we were so hungry. I burned my tongue slurping down the scalding ramen. :-P

+ 20min wait to get the check. It's 11:00pm now. Fan-f'ing-tastic.

While we were waiting for the food, we looked back at the Yelp reviews. That's when we began to see all the 1-2 star ratings. They mostly complained about a long wait and poor ramen. Uh oh. That's what we came here for: ramen. We also came here starving and expecting to get the food in a reasonable amount of time.

The 4-5 star ratings raved about their yakitori and fried dishes. Damn. One reviewer wrote that the waitress told him, "We're not a ramen shop," as an explanation for why the ramen was taking so long. Double damn.

And the ramen itself? Average. It wasn't bad, to be honest. A little salty for my taste, but not stellar. I've had better ramen. I'm a bit of a ramen snob too, so I may have unrealistic expectations for a place that's not a ramen shop. :-P

Also, after we finished the ramen, the surface of the broth congealed, showing how much fat was in it. That's not too unusual, but well-made ramen doesn't congeal like that. You see drops of fat on the surface instead.

What really killed Halu for us was the wait. It took us an hour and a half to get our main meals. Thank goodness we ordered edamame, otherwise we would have just gotten up and left. (We were seriously debating that too.)

But really, this was all our fault.

Why? We should have read the Yelp reviews more closely. Just because Halu was the second search result for "ramen in san francisco" doesn't mean it's the second-based place for ramen in San Francisco. (So maybe it's Yelp's fault? ;-)

If we had read through some of the negative reviews, perhaps we would have adjusted our expectations accordingly. Or gone somewhere else.

My recommendations:

+ Come here when you're not starving.

+ Come here for some drinks & snacks.

+ Order the fried foods. Stay away from the ramen.

+ Be prepared for a long wait.

With those expectations, I'm sure you'll have a better experience than we did.
author: Mike L.

description:
Small hippy japanese ramen and yakatori joint. Extremely small place, but so cozy and so friendly. They don't have a waiting area because space is so tight, so you leave your name and number. I love it because after putting down your name, you can walk off and window shop on Clement Street. 

The order was:

* Chashu-men Lava (spicy) $12.50 (4 of 5) Very spicy and noodle was quite al dente. The noodle texture reminds me of real good egg noodle. But the pork slices are very soft. Melt in your mouth type of pork. Also, I really like the lava, so it will be hard to try the non-spicy flavor when I drop by next time. Great portion. This ramen portion is actually shareable. 
Note regular is $10.50 
* Kara Age Ramen $12 (3.5 of 5) Very good broth and you get 5 nicely fried pieces of chicken. But in comparison, the chashu-men is a lot tastier. Great portion. This ramen portion is also shareable. 
Note spicy is $12.50
* Bacon Mochi 2 for $6 (5 of 5) Yummy. Like eating marshmellows wrapped in bacon. It was fluffy and crispy at the same time. Delicious. 
* Oyster Chicken $3/each (3.5 of 5) Twist on chicken skewers. Topped with white mayo type sauce and scallions. It was juicy white chicken breast meat. 
* Stuffed Mushrooms $3 (3 of 5) Mushroom was juicy. But I saw the other table had a fried version of the stuffed mushroom and that looked a lot more amazing. I think their tempura skewer is probably a better item to order. I will skip stuffed mushrooms and go for their katsu mushroom next time.
* Beef Tongue $3 (5 of 5) Fresh and bbqed perfectly. It was delicious. Juicy and crunchy. I highly recommend this skewer.

Fun place, but not recommended for large groups. Can't wait to go back and try more yakatori from their menu. So many choices.
author: Janice T.

description:
i am not someone who thinks they are above waiting.  i'll happily wait for a table at an awesome restaurant.  i'll gladly sit there in conversation while waiting for badass food.  however, all the wait was not worth the while.  tonight for dinner around 8:30 was not too bad a wait.  it was around half an hour for us to get a table for two.  what i really appreciated was that they'll call you on the phone when your table is ready so we could take a stroll or go shopping around to kill time.

i absolutely love the decor and the vibe of the restaurant.  i am a big beatles fan so i totally appreciated the memorabilia and was really groovin to the music.  so the two of us got seated at a table for four in a corner.  a few minutes later, the waitress asks us to move to a smaller table for two because, and i quote, "we have a company of three coming in."  okay whatever.  i mean, the table for two is squished between these other tables but i totally understand.  this is a small restaurant.  i'll give up my cushy seat and seat for my handbag to help them out.  didn't even think about it.  

so we get seated at our new table and order ramen and yakitori skewers.  man, the yakitori was pretty bomb.  we only had the chicken skin, chicken gizzard, bacon wrapped enoki, and bacon wrapped scallops but they were all amazing!  i love chicken gizzard and my favorite was the bacon wrapped scallops.  how can anything wrapped in bacon not be good!?!??!  the answer is NOTHING!  

so i'm totally getting into this food until i see the couple that gets seated next to us, in our old seats.  yes....COUPLE.  so i thought, whatever, their friend is probably running late or maybe the company of three cancelled.  i tried not to be bitter about it but it turns out it was just two people and they just happened to know the people who worked there.  the only thing that pisses me off about this is that they lied to us to get us to move.  

so then, we keep talking and talking and our stomachs keep growling and growling.  they took forever and a day to get us the ramen.  i think we sat there for an hour.  and keep in mind, this is a small restaurant and tons of people have already been served, they are paying their checks all around us.  we did not order a five course meal.  even five course meals come out faster.  it was two bowls of ramen.  broth, noodles.  so FINALLY, our ramen comes out.  we got the spicy chicken karage ramen and the butter and corn ramen.  the spicy broth cost an extra $2.  really?????  $2 more to make it spicy?  wtf. 

the spicy broth was super spicy.  like get caught in your throat and start coughing spicy.  the butter corn broth was super salty.  it didn't have any special or distinctive taste.  just salty miso.  the noodles were a good chewy consistency, the corn was good, and the hard boiled egg was good.  the chasiu was not very delicious either.  so in the end, i was super disappointed with the end result of what i was waiting for.  

also, one of the two waitresses that served us was super passive aggressive.  she was the kind who would make eye contact and continue talking to the other waitress.  right, cause it is so smart to ignore your customers.  then, after the bf asked for a refill of water and said thank you, she said OK.  i might come back late night for a couple of yakitori snacks.  but i'd never wait or have their ramen again.
author: Irene W.

description: I went to Halu last week for the first time.  I love this place.  Yes, it is small. Yes, you have to wait.  This place is fun and the food is fantastic.  Nothing average or typical.  Come here if you want really good ramen and yakatori.  The people who run this place are the real deal - super nice, super fun.     Cannot wait to go back for more!!
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Went to Halu with a girlfriend to catch up. I'd never been to a ramen place before and this place is adorable! It's tiny so if it's crowded be expected to wait outside! Fortunately we got a table within 10 minutes. The decor is really quirky with all this Beatles stuff and they play Beatles music the whole time! I should totally take my dad here...

Anyways, my girlfriend and I split a vegetable ramen bowl and it ended up being the perfect amount. We also both got a Sapparo which was a great pairing! haha The prices are definitely reasonable so I will be coming back! Not a big ramen fan, but if i were to go to a place it would be here :)
author: An-Nhien L.

description: Got there at about 6pm. Big Mistake.  The place was packed to the gills.  Luckily, we got seated fairly quickly.  Unfortunately, that was the only thing fast about the evening.  I felt badly for the server there (she was the only one) who had to wait tables and answer the phone for takeout orders.  It took quite awhile before she came to take our order.  She was sincerely apologetic and clear overworked.  Had the Yaki-onigiri and the Chashu Ramen.  And a side salad- which was super tiny.  It took about 40 minutes for us to get our food, so about an hour after we first sat down.  Thankfully, the food was delicious and we weren't in a rush.   Broth was flavorful and not too salty.  Lots of noodles, can't imagine what the "extra noodles" would be like.  Very loud and funky place.  Definitely give it a try, but be prepared to wait a long time.
author: Curt Y.

description: Delicious Japanese food served w a smile in a very unique environment. A cave of a place dedicated to the Beatles.  Get the Otokoyama saki. Some of the best. Smooth. Ramen here is next level.
author: Lucy P.

description:
This place sucks. 

I came here a while ago, and here's what annoyed me.

-It took forever to get a table
-It took 45 minutes for a few skewers of yakitori to come
-It took another hour for the ramen to come out.
-The service sucked.
-The food sucked.

Not worth the wait or $$$.
author: Christina X.

description:
I'm not usually at a restaurant for service, I'm there for delicious food. I don't even care if i have to serve myself if the food is awesome. The trouble comes when service, or lack of service, gets in the way of me getting/eating said delicious food.  

That is my beef with Halu. Block me from my food and we have a problem. 

I really enjoyed the yakitori that we got, (the ramen is fine, but not amazing), but our meal took over 2 hours due to slow service. We also never received a few of the items we ordered and were still sitting around waiting for them when I was handed the check.

I'll be back because as I noted I'm there for the food and the yakitori were really good, but seriously Halu step up your service game.
author: Stephanie W.

description: What a strange place.. Who would have thought of a Beatles-themed ramen and yakitori place out in the Richmond. Although I'm not a Beatles fan, I'm a big fan of their food. The yakitori is great (be adventurous, you will be rewarded). The cold noodles and ramen is pretty good (good, but not at the ramen dojo level). The sake selection is great. The waitresses are really good, lots of fun, and pretty hot. I recommend coming early so that you can get a good table and not have to wait for your food. This place is solid.
author: Da Wei S.

description:
order: lava ramen, yakitori
veg: veg yakitori, ramen is not veg friendly (meat broth)
spice level: average

noodles not made fresh onsite but supposedly flown in from japan. about 10 tables, beatles theme and feels like a small japanese hole-in-the-wall spot. wait was about 10m at 8pm on a weekday, service was prompt. butter corn is creamier and still have some kick to it, but not as good as their tonutsu. good little spot if you're willing to get over to sunset
author: Niket B.

description:
No sushi here! The skewers are excellent
and affordable, so get a variety. We got chicken hearts, okra, and all the ones that mentioned bacon. 

Also try the sweet mountain potato!
author: dj z.

description:
Yummy!  Was trying to go to Izakaya Sozai initially but the wait was so long we opted for Halu instead (thanks Yelp!)

The yakitori we got were pretty tasty, the ochazuke really good, and the kara-age perfectly fried.  The okonomiyaki was really tasty too.  In fact, everything was really good.  Just rely on your fellow Yelpers to guide you as to what to order.  Can't go wrong with anything on their menu!

Definitely a place to check out if you're looking for izakaya!  Not a full 5/5 because it's kind of small, crowded, and a little uncomfortable inside.  Definitely better for small parties.

And yes, the decor is Beatles head to toe, makes for a kind of cool vibe and environment :)
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Wow. I'll say that I usually have certain opinions of places like this. Usually it's small, expensive, and overrated. Trendiness and a lack of local clientele usually make up the bulk of the reviews of places like this.

However Halu is different. They totally blew me away. Food was good. 
Service is impeccable. The place isn't exactly small, but I wouldn't recommend groups larger than six to come in and eat here.

The only negative is that parking can be troublesome around here. But that's just the nature of the area. Come here and be pleasantly surprised. I know I was.
author: Clinton L.

description:
I'm a bit on the fence here. If I could, I would put 3.5 stars, mostly because I feel like a ramen place should have great quality ramen noodles. Halu's broth was pretty amazing, very pork-based with a shoyu complement, but of the spoonful of noodles I sampled (since I can't eat too much wheat anymore), they seemed soggy.

Other than that, the fried buttered shoyu (or tamari? I forget) mochi was super super amazing. Warm, salty, crispy chewiness. And if you love mushrooms and avocado, you will love the Veggie Donburi, which comes with a side salad of nothing but greens and the buttered mushrooms/avocado are over a bed of seasoned brown rice. Three kinds of mushrooms, too.

Great service, though, and a sweet atmosphere. It's like a cubby corner filled with Beatles paraphernalia.
author: Helen I.

description:
How I wish this place rocked.  I live a block away.  On every occasion I've visited, we been seated right away, with the restaurant half empty.  Eventually it fills up.  But by that time our orders are already in, right?

The food is tasty, although I've not tried the ramen.  Its mostly been the appetizers and yakitori.  How much time does it take to grill some items that have already been prepped in skewers?  Apparently about an hour.

Arrive at 6:40.  Order at 6:50.  Drink arrives at 7:10.  Edamame arrives at 7:20.  First dish arrives at 7:30, nearly an hour later.  Last dish arrives at 7:45.  This for some simple grilled items.

I should have told the could that came in with a four year old and was told their table would be ready "soon" to go elsewhere.  I can't imagine their suffering while their kid goes hungry waiting for the kitchen.

The front room staff are great and they do have a tiny kitchen, but as things are, they are not working.
author: E L.

description:
Bacon. Wrapped. Mochi.

And their ramen is pretty tasty too.
author: S C.

description:
If you didn't know about this place, you probably would have never noticed it even if you walked by it everyday.  The exterior of this Japanese joint is very plain, while the small interior is saturated with The Beatles memorabilia.  Pretty cool to me because I'm a fan of them.

The staff is super friendly and the food is good.  Unfortunately, I had to knock off an entire Yelp star due to the fact that it took over 40 minutes to bring out the food (not good when you're starvin' like Marvin) and there was some cold breeze going towards the direction of our table (I recommend bringing a jacket since the inside is pretty damn cold to begin with).

When the food FINALLY came out, I was not disappointed.

Spicy Chashu - Men ramen:  The hot broth stimulated my hungry taste buds.  Lots of good flavor with the right amount of spice.  The pork was tender, just the way I like it.

Enoki bacon yakitori:  Everything is good with bacon!  The bacon kinda overpowered the taste of the enoki.  The only part of the enoki that I tasted was the texture of it but I didn't mind at all.  I heart bacon.   

Bacon wrapped mochi yakitori:  A very interesting combination in terms of texture.  The mochi is really soft while the bacon is a tad crispy.  I liked it because it was different and I never had anything like it before.

I would definitely like to come back again and let this place redeem themselves so that I can give them back a star that I'm sure they deserve.
author: Suzi K.

description:
This place is a pretty cool and unique Japanese restaurant. As everyone states, yes it's filled with Beatles memorabilia... and has pretty 
relaxed/divey feel to it. 

I tried the chicken karaage ramen and it was very delicious, also. They give you huge portions, and the chicken is tender and savory. Overall, very pleased with my experience at Halu.
author: Lucinda W.

description:
oh my god.

best ramen i have EVER had.

super small place with large crowds of people continuously flowing through. make sure you are not starving when you come here because chances are you will have to wait for a table and it takes about 30 minutes to wait for your food. but once your ramen comes, it's like you forget all the curse words that were going through your head because the ramen is DELICIOUS!!!!

me & my boyfriend both ordered the spicy fried chicken ramen (i forgot the real name for it) and it was to die for. i am usually not a fan of spicy broth and will definitely come back to try the regular broth - but i didn't care that my entire mouth was on fire because it was soooo delicious.

the waiters/owners are super sweet girls and the decor is awesome. totally a divey ramen place!

i can't wait to come back! i am craving it again right now as i type!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
FRIDAY NIGHTTTTT! I love going to SF on a Friday with my close friends and trying a new place.

What we ordered:

To drink:
-UME cocktail ( I actually ended up with plum wine cause there was a miscommunication)
-Rasume cocktail

To Eat:
-Beef steak skewer (too salty)
-Tomato basil ( I liked this one a lot)
-chicken wing (too salty)
-bacon wrapped mochi ( It's honestly just meh, nothing amazing)
-Tashu ramen (YUM!)
-Combo onomiyaki (This was really good! I could eat this all by itself!)

The service was really friendly and the atmosphere was really nice. I think that night the chef was just a lil too salt happy and tossed a lil too much salt on the skewers or maybe I just didn't know what to order. Overall it was a really nice experience. I would go back again. Hopefully the next time the food won't be so salty!

Parking: Fairly easy to find considering the area it's in.
author: Albert K.

description:
If you're into the Beatles, good for you.  You found a nice little dive for yourself where you can enjoy their memorabilia and tunes over the speakers.  

However, as for their food and service (which is the most important aspect of going to a restaurant) is...to be nice, very overrated.  I've been here about 3 times and each time, the food does not come to table until I've basically lost my patience to wait any longer.  There is absolutely nothing worse than waiting too long to get your food, especially when the ramen here isn't even that good!  To be fair, the yakitori is okay and I could give them 2 stars because of it. But the server - the one who handles the waitlist - didn't even apologize to me when I asked her how much longer I have to wait to get my food.  I understand the restaurant was packed and there were people on the waitlist.  But all I ordered was just ramen.  That was it, and I waited over 50 minutes for it.  While being thoroughly agitated, I realized why there is such a long waitlist.  It's because the cooks take so damn long to cook the food.  Again, I like to stress that this is based on all 3 times that I've eaten here.  And each and every time that I've been here, the food comes out at a glacial pace.  To top it off, when one of the parties on the waitlist came in to ask the server how much longer he would have to wait, the server disingenuously said that it would take about 10 more minutes.  The patron then replied that she already told him that he would be waiting for about 15 minutes but he's waited for over 50 minutes.  Instead of being apologetic, she gets defensive and tells him that she cannot control the patrons that are inside the restaurant.  I was basically fuming at this point and wanted to chew her out.  Instead, I got my check and went on my way, deciding that I would never come back.  The excessive wait for the food is just not worth what you receive in return on your plate or in service.  As a I was leaving, I almost recommended the same guy who was still waiting with his girlfriend to go somewhere else instead.  I hope he had a much more pleasant experience.

Hey Jude, your restaurant should strive to do better.
author: Evan H.

description:
If any of these apply to you, don't eat here.
- You don't like your food in small pieces, skewered with bamboo, grilled and served in small portions
- You don't like your food salty
- You don't like odd parts of meat like tongue, gizzard
- You don't like small places
- You don't like The Beatles (!! what's wrong with you!?)
- You don't believe good things come to those who wait
- You're on a first date

Halu is quaint. I love how it makes me feel like I could've stepped into a hole in the wall in Shinjuku when I walk in. The Beatles blares over the sound system, and you get tucked in a small corner with a menu and specials on the wall.

We ordered a few skewers, and a yakitori dinner (a good variety of skewers including totally cute little okras to chicken wings, minced chicken balls and stuffed mushroom), and ochazuke.

Everything is a little on the salty side, just so you know. But yakitori usually is.

My personal favourites are the stuffed mushrooms - I love mushrooms, but grilled mushrooms? It's more than love. These fellas are grilled with a little minced meat, and the sauce tastes like coca cola. What can possibly go wrong in that combination?

I also liked the shiso beef, and beef tongue. Pork jowl was not too bad too. Can give the kuro buta sausage a miss. 

The ochazuke was such a comforting dish, especially since it was so foggy in the Richmond that evening. A reasonable piece of salmon floating in rice and broth with mustard seeds. 

But meal though, was topped off by a seemingly awkward, deceptively tasty combination: mochi wrapped bacon. Soft, warm, toasty and chewy mochi wrapped with the crowd pleaser that is bacon. Ah. It was happiness.

Go with a group of your pals, stuff yourselves silly, you'll have a good time. I wouldn't recommend it for a first date - it's hard to chat, and the food isn't for everyone.
author: v w.

description:
This was my first time trying ramen (other than the kind you get for under a dollar at the super market) and it really did hit the spot on a cool San Francisco evening.  It wasn't particularly anything special for the price but I'd recommend trying it.

I particularly loved the decor of band posters like Beatles and The Who. Likewise the music playlist of Beatles music was very enjoyable. 

We were told the skewers were what the place is known for (by the waitress) but we didn't try them this time. We did try the stuffed mushrooms which were very tasty.
author: Lynda O.

description: Seated for thirty minutes and did not get served, while passed by the waitress multiple times avoiding eye contact with us. We just walked out. Ain't got no time for this.
author: Anthony W.

description:
Small small place. Everything is decorated with Beatles memorabilia, including the bathroom. Beatles playing on the radio, guitars all over the walls - Halu definitely has it's own peculiar charm. 

Both the chicken heart and chicken gizzard yakitori was great, next time i'll try the chicken skin too.

The ramen was so-so. I had the chicken karage ramen. The chicken was amazing, but the ramen was a bit underwhelming. The noodles are a bit thicker than I like, and the broth was a little flat. I should've ordered the mild lava karage ramen. The spicy soup has a kick that the regular version is missing.

I'll come back for some late night yakitori, but for ramen i'll go somewhere else.
author: Colin H.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet. 

I.Love.Halu.
This small, hole-in-the-wall spot in a random neighborhood has great izakaya food and REAL japanese beer. Not the kind that is "imported" from Canada, but actually from Japan. Great grilled and fried skewer foods, daikon salad, yaki onigiri, and more. And the people who work here are always super nice and give great, honest suggestions. This is a great local spot to come w/a group of friends or even a casual date.
author: Emy s.

description: Hmm. Let's start w/ the positive - we were provided water. That's about it. On to everything else that went wrong. Establishment is tiny. You'll literally step through the entrance and into someone on a stool. When other yelpers cautioned that it would take awhile, I really should've taken their warning. Waited 20 minutes feeling it may be due to a small staff. Then 30 minutes passed with only a grin from the waitress. After 50 minutes, a waitress asked "how is everything?" seeing clearly that we had not a single item before us. This is all while we sat at what they called "the bar" which is really a counter they will constantly bang and slam things upon. I dislike giving negative reviews, but this series of event really pinched a nerve - maybe even a few nerves. What topped it off was that when we decided to get our dinner elsewhere, they didn't really care.
author: Myra K.

description:
We were stoked about trying the ramen here and were a little disappointed with the experience & not blown away by the food...

On a scale of 1-5 (5 being great):

Service = 1 
They were super busy so it's almost understandable, but you would think they'd want to turn the tables around faster. It took forever for us to order and they got it wrong. Getting in and out of that place took 2 hours - it should have been less than 1.

Food = 3
- Ramen: good but not fantastic. Pork broth was good but not super rich, and the noodles were good but not as chewy as I like them (totally a preference thing). 
- Chicken karage was decent but not outstanding
- Mochi with seaweed was good 
- Overall, everything we had was just ok.

Ambiance = 4 
The interior of this place is really unique. They have Beatles memorabilia  covering the walls and a cute/weird drum set on a ledge above the door.

I probably won't go back unless I'm starving, happen to be in the area, and there are less than 3 tables occupied in the place.
author: Ali L.

description:
I wouldn't usually order beef tongue... But I'd order beef tongue every time I'd set foot into halu! Halu is a cute little restaurant in the heart of the Richmond district where having a restaurant is extremely competitive. It's a hole in the wall ran by a family; one sister cooks in the kitchen, the other waitresses. 

I came here with a friend at 7:30 on a weeknight and took the last available table.  I let her do all the ordering.  She ended up ordering beef tongue, a really fatty pork, stuffed mushrooms, butter corn ramen, and bacon wrapped asparagus.  Sounds like an unreasonable amount of food between 2 people, but everything except the ramen comes in small portions, yakitori style.

Beef tongue was extremely tasty.  It was seasoned perfectly and had a really good flavor.  If I didn't know it was tongue, I would've thought it was small pieces of steak.
Fatty pork (can't remember the proper name on the menu), was memorable.  It was grilled so the fat catches the off the grill taste while being crispy on the outside and around the edges.
Stuffed mushrooms were my fave!  They're stuffed with some meat and covered in panko, then deep fried.  When you bite into them, they're juicy and crispy. SO GOOD.  Theyre also served with some sauce.  Honestly, the mushrooms on their own are tasty enough.
Bacon wrapped asparagus, can't go wrong with that.  I thought the price was a little expensive for a total of maybe 1 spear and 2 strips of bacon.
Ramen was average.  I don't know if I'd say Halu's specialty is ramen so if you're looking for ramen, go somewhere else.  The noodles weren't overcooked and the broth was light with a mild flavor.

If you're looking for a fun place to go to, try Halu.  It's not your typical sit-down restaurant where you order your own big plate to yourself.  Go with some friends and share foods that are served on sticks while looking at posters of the Beatle's accompanied with shots of sake!
author: Cheryl Q.

description: Service was really annoying the other night.  Everything from seating to " wow ur not drinking" screwed up order.   Food is good though.
author: Demanding T.

description:
Great eats!  Tiny spot though, but delicious food.

Lava ramen was decent (spicy pork ramen), but my faves were the small dishes.  Chicken karage was yum, the butter grilled mochi wrapped in seaweed was THE BEST, bacon wrapped enoki was perfect, and stuffed mushrooms were super tasty.

We also had the chicken meatball, pork sausage, and short rib yaiktori, but they were just ok to me.  The grilled eggplant was good because I love eggplant, but very lacking in flavor.

Def will come back soon, but not looking forward to the long wait for a table!
author: Cheryl L.

description:
2 chicken wings
1 chicken gizzard
1 okra
1 bacon wrapped asparagus
1 grilled eggplant, skinned and topped with bonito and grated ginger
1 seafood okonomiyaki
1 bowl of kara age ramen, miso broth
1 glass of chardonnay (please don't make fun of me)
_____________

$47 and some change

This place is fun-tastic. Beatles memorabilia and tunes play while you sit in a tiny dining room waiting in anticipation for your yakitori skewers and ramen. 

The ramen broth was delicious; so rich, deep, creamy and porky. The yakitori were good too, but the eggplant was insane. They grill an entire small japanese eggplant to perfection, not to much that it turns to a pulp, but with enough texture and softness and the slightest hint of smokiness. Then, you add the grated ginger and dip in the tiniest spot of soy sauce. It was heaven in a bite, I tell you.

The okonomiyaki was pretty good, but honestly, I think the ones I make at home are better.

I allocated my 10% of meat consumption and cooked foods this week right at this restaurant. Totally worth it, and I will be back next time to properly chow the goods with some Japanese beer instead of chardonnay.
author: May T.

description:
I'm a big fan of ramen, so I visited Halu on a Friday night to check it out. We arrived around 8pm, but had to wait an hour to get a table for two. We ordered the chasu ramen, the spicy karage ramen, chicken oyster skewers, & pork & onion kushikatsu. 

The food took quite a while to arrive, but the waitress did let us know beforehand that the karage ramen would take longer to prepare. What annoyed me though was that she was very, very apologetic to another table for the long wait on the same karage ramen dish & comped them some edamame, but completely ignored us! 

When the food did arrive, the ramen was not what I was expecting. It was incredibly greasy & way too heavy. The meat was super fatty & falling apart. & that was just the chasu dish -- the karage ramen was even more greasy. The kushikatsu skewers were underwhelming as well, too much batter & seemed undercooked. The one star of the night was the chicken oyster skewer, which was very fresh & tasty. 

On top of all this, the service was incredibly crappy, as I mentioned earlier. We had to remind the waitress to bring a diet coke 3 times (!!!). They completely forgot about our kushikatsu skewers until we asked for it. They blatantly babied certain tables & completely ignored others. It's just really ridiculous & taking into consideration that the ramen was really not great at all & even made me feel a little sick, it's unlikely that I'll be back. I'm always a little skeptical when I read about bad service on Yelp, but this place is legit for crappy service.
author: Ruby H.

description:
Great izakaya - delicious seaweed-wrapped mochi and bacon-wrapped everything!  Wonderful choice if you're looking for a place to get drinks and nibble on wonderful goodies on sticks.  :)
