I was initially directed to Halu for its ramen - I think other places are better for ramen.  Nonetheless, it doesn't take away from the fact that it's a great izakaya place.  According to the husband, Halu's better than Izakaya Sozai in the Sunset...for those who want a point of reference.
author: Fontane L.

description:
You say goodbye, and I say Halu.  Halu Halu. 

Fun little restaurant off of Clement.  Walls were covered with Beatles memorabilia and they played a lot of sixties music while we were there. Felt like being in a little cafe in Japan (or Abbey Road).   Music was a little too high in volume.  Impressed with the interesting menu. Has a tremendous variety of yakitori and you can make a meal out of the yakitori alone. I had a salmon skewer which was great. The rice balls were a little too greasy and salty, though. Also, serves things like okonomiyaki.  Slightly different style than the okonomiyaki I've had before.  A lot of mayonnaise and they would not make it with ramen. 

Service is a little on the slow side.  They're trying to be izakaya style but I think they should actually concentrate more on serving their food than serving drinks.   Wish that they were open for lunch.

The main thing we came for was the ramen. The noodles were good and the broth was outstanding, perfectly balanced. Was so good that I emptied the bowl.  I have had the butter corn ramen and the karaage and both were very tasty.   The ramen is some of the best in San Francisco and competitive with Suzu and Genki, and you know that can't be bad.   Yeah yeah yeah!
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
Been here a couple times now, the food has always been very good.

See Halu is one of the few yakitori places in the city, with a good variety of items to choose from. I've always enjoyed the chicken kaarage and their okonomiyaki is very delicious. Okonomiyaki is fairly thin compared to others I've had, a bit of crunch but nice and moist too. One time I tried this mountain potato thing, kind had a slimy texture like okra..it was different, it was good but i can't say it would be my favorite thing on the menu haha. Grilled items, very tasty. I did one time get a very salty skewer..i think it was beef tongue..but everything else was fine so i guess i was unlucky that day haha

I've never had the ramen here but one of these days I will definitely go check it out.

Also one of the major things I like about this place..well other than the food. Is the decor and music. Lots of vintage items and a lot of Beatles stuff. Its really great and makes me feel really comfortable eating here.
author: phillip w.

description:
Loved the food but service was slow since they were packed.  This is not a complaint, just informing the readers.

I'm a huge fan of the chicken hearts and chicken skin.  Who doesn't love meat on a stick!

Our waitress was really nice.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
This is my first time and will be my last. My sister & I visited there just last Thursday for dinner and was hoping to experience a four star rating meal from this restaurant that was ranked by Yelp members. However, we were a bit shocked, disappointed and wasn't our cup of tea. 

This place is small, which shows a good sign called "HOLE IN THE WALL", that also presents this place been here for a long time. I recall seeing this when I was still in High school, but not sure what they are really known for. 

From reading the reviews, I just went with the basics, a bowl of cha-su ramen. The bowl of ramen contained only  a couple pieces of cha-su and less than 10 pieces of each - bean sports, corn and even green onions. My sister asked to have her vegetables to be set on the side and that's how we have noticed that a $10.50 bowl of cha-su ramen has so LITTLE vegetables. These were not high grade or the most expensive type of vegetables too. The cha-su was just terrible in texture, I felt like I had some Chinese hard boiled pork from the soup base and it was just not satisfying. 

I would say that Ramen is not their "best" at this location. If you were considering having lots of sake, wine, or beer, maybe this is just the type of place to be - to have BAR food with your alcohol, but not a $$ worth 4 star rating restaurant. 

The reason I gave one star is because at the end of my unfinished bowl of ramen, the waitress showed courtesy to ask how was the food.
author: M W.

description: I had the vegetarian noodles.  I wish there were more variety of vegies in my bowl.  Also had a few kabobs of gizzards and beef.  They tasted too buttery but my friends said it's natural oil.
author: Byron L.

description: Great food very unique, small space so expect to wait a loooong time. Great yakitori, good ramen broth tho the noodles were a little lacking imo
author: Dang L.

description:
The meal itself was tasty, but the service left a bad taste in my mouth. I came with 3 friends and we waited for 30 minutes before the waitress asked us to go to a local bar for drinks and then come back. 

We waited a pretty long time until we were seated - probably close to an hour. Once we were seated, we waited almost 20 minutes before I had to walk to the front of the restaurant and request a menu. I might come back here for the food, but there are more options around that I would rather go to.
author: D C.

description:
I was in the mood for ramen and went here looking forward to my favorite ramen in the city. I expected slow service as always, but my recent visit was so downright bad that I can't justify coming back.

When we arrived the server seated us in the shittiest seats right next to the door on a windy evening, even though the place was only half full. I requested if we could sit in one of the back empty tables, but she told us we couldn't. It took the server 30 minutes before she came around to take our order after flagging her down. My biggest peeve was that 8-10 people arrived long after us and she took their orders before ours even though we were clearly ready and waiting. 

45-60 minutes after taking our orders, no food had yet to come out. All the folks who arrived later than us were already halfway finished with their meals. By that point I was PISSED and about to ditch this place. Just as I was ready to dash, my food came out after asking the server about my food. It seemed like she seriously forgot about us altogether. 

The ramen was good as always, but not worth waiting 1.5 hours. What kind of place takes 90 minutes to serve ramen? If it was up to me I would have left her zero tip, which is a big deal because I've never left zero tip at a restaurant. But my companion took care of the bill and left a tip. 

I usually have high tolerance for bad service, but the customer neglect here is unreasonable even for the lowest maintenance customers.
author: Victoria N.

description: after two previous attempts at eating here I finally made it and it was all that it lived up to be.  cute and kitchy with music straight out of a Quentin Tarantino movie. I ate the spicy karage ramen and when they say spicy, they're not kidding. I was sweating in two sips of the broth, but really tasty. not too salty and the spice didn't impede the flavor of the broth. I didn't care too much for the skinny egg noodle and prefer the noodles at genki, but still gold star for my ramen.  my friend had the chicken don with special sauce, and special it was. perfectly cooked chicken and vegetables over brown rice and mixed greens.  a pleasant healthy surprise.  the service was good and everything tasty.  a must try and a definite go back.  the place is tiny so groups of 2-4 is perfect.
author: Susan Z.

description:
Upon walking up to the door you are greeted with a sign that reads "No sushi today (or tomorrow)". What? A Japanese restaurant that doesn't serve sushi? 

Halu is tiny and really easy to miss. The door also looks like it is a side entrance which can throw first-time visitors off. they have a counter/bar set up with hooks for purses and a big stand for umbrellas on wet days. Oh and hooks by the door for big jackets. I just wish the first available table wasn't so close to those jackets. I would say this place isn't good for groups larger than 4.

The bacon-wrapped scallop skewers were really good but at $5 for two it's a bit much. I do like how they offer three types of ramen (pork, chicken and veggie) but vegetarians beware the broth is meat based!

I got the kara age ramen and i liked how the pieces of chicken were really large and managed to keep its crispiness even after being in the broth for a while. I didn't like how the broth tasted pretty salty but that's probably because of the chicken. 

According to Yelp they take credit cards, however last night they were only accepting cash (which was known from a sign where the register is). Luckily my friend and I had cash but this should have been communicated early on. I think I'll keep looking for that perfect ramen spot in the city, but they were really nice.
author: Liz S.

description:
Damn good Yakitori place !! 2 of my favorites and i guess alot of peoples favorites :: 

1) Stuffed Mushroom Kushikatsu
2) Pork with Onion Skewer

Ofcourse try the others, you will not be disappointed.  

Came in here looking for ramen, left happy with yakitori and ramen :-D .. what I had to have it all...
author: Ajay P.

description: Yakitori is awesome here!! Lots of choices!! The people are very friendly and place is authentic japanese pub spot!  Make sure you try their special yakitori menu! So many sake and shochu choices as well!!!
author: Jane R.

description:
This place is VERY GOOD! Although the place is tiny and they do not serve sushi, the food they do serve is amazing. 

Food: Grilled Meat and Veggies Skewer sampler and Fried Meat and Veggies skewer sampler are delicious! The meat is very tender and fried food in panko breadcrumbs, you cant go wrong. 

I would recommend coming here early because the wait can be long!
author: Elliot T.

description:
Daaamn... that flavor really smacks yo face man.... the food is so packed with zest that I could've sworn they bombed it with MSG! but no (this place doesn't do that at all, nor would any other japanese place)) the flavor is so vibrant that it's kind of hard to imagine how they do this without cheating...  

It's a hole in the wall with a pretty cozy vibe... lot's of 60's memorabilia and tasty yakitori, ramen and a good selection of sake, shochu and beer... to sum it all up I would say this place is AWESOME! I left full and satisfied... as it should always be....totally recommend this place.
author: John R.

description:
We finished a great movie today, Avatar, and decided to go get Ramen for dinner.  
I've passed this place multiple times as it's right next to the public parking lot in the Richmond, but never paid much attention to it until I read a recent Yelp review.
We arrived at 6 PM and they had no more tables which could fit 3 and we sat at the counter (right by the door) until a table opened up.  They have approx 4 tables in the back which can hold 4 skinny people and the rest were 2s.  This is a tiny place like Katana-ya in Downtown.  
If you like yakatori in small portions, they have a large selection but you will go away hungry unless you supplement with some of their other dishes.  Most of the yakatori items were $4-$5 for 2 skewers but the items on the skewers were probably only 4 in long.  

We started off with a very peppery and over-salted beef and onion yakatori that was so-so.  The panko breaded basil chicken was much better.  The okonomiyaki (pancake) was $10 and resembled an Asian small personal pizza but was soggy and had way too much mayonnaise.  We ordered the beef but I think we got the seafood because it tasted and looked like it had a lot of white fish in it.  Heavily topped with green onions.  Doubt that we'd try this again. 

Jr. Yelper liked his karage-chicken with a large serving of rice and green salad.  Hubby had the karage-chicken ramen which was good.  I had the roasted pork ramen.  The meat was tender and good but hands down, the best pork ramen to be had would still be at Santa Ramen in San Mateo.  The noodles were good and I had 1/2 slice of hard-boiled egg in it but it was pretty salty.  I think the egg was marinated as the whites of the egg was tinted brownish, probably in soy sauce. 

They were busy for dinner.  One primary waitress took the orders and the other 2 women in back were cooking and the owner would help out.  The primary cook was the male.  They really could benefit from having another staff work the tables or at least a busboy.  Service was exceedingly slow, even 'tho the staff was very nice.  If you're in a hurry, this is not the place to come eat.
author: Ry T.

description:
A secret gem with great Japanese street / communal style foods. 
This place represents many types of food you will find at Japanese amusement parks and festivals. 

Must eats here:
-Okonomiyaki
-Yakitori's: bacon wrapped scallops, bacon wrapped asparagus, beef yakitori's, chicken thigh meat 
- Nori wrapped mochi

I'm not an okonomiyaki expert; I only had it 3 times a week for like 3 years of my life growing up in Japan. It was my favorite food from the time I was 8 years old to 11 years old, so it definitely brought me back to that homey feeling of flavors from my childhood. I will be back here often. 

For those that don't know what Japanese pizza is check it out ....http://www.justhungry.com/okonomiyaki-osaka-style
author: Kristina A.

description:
What hidden treasure in the Richmond.

I stumbled upon this place while yelping for a good yakitori. Halu is a really tiny restaurant hidden in richmond neighborhood. The inside is decked out with Beatles memorabilia and you will be listening to nothing but non stop Beatles tracks. So be warned if you for some reason hate the Beatles then maybe this isn't the place for you. 

On to the food. The yakitori here is simply amazing. I never knew grilled okra could be so tasty. All the grilled skewered meat and veggies were cooked to perfection. My favorite were the chicken wings and beef. All the ingredients tasted very fresh. I saw bacon wrapped mochi on the menu and I just had to try it because it sounded so ridiculous. Wow was it good. That dish just proves that everything is better with bacon.

They also had a very nice selection of sake and beer. If you are looking for a nice place to chill and have a few beers and yakitori then Halu is the definitly a place for you to check out.
author: David W.

description:
Halu. A different kind of Japanese restaurant. 

That's what the sign outside says. And, for the most part, that's exactly what it is. It's really refreshing to find a place that doesn't fit the typical mold, decor, feel, design, jeux-ne-se-qouis, etc. of 98% of Japanese restaurants in the US. When you walk into the closet-sized restaurant, you realize two things. First, it's tiny. Since we're talking about Japan, tiny is authentic. Second, it's all about the Beatles. Everywhere, floor to ceiling, the decorations are all Beatles, all the time. Of course, the soundtrack is too. It's a different kind of Japanese restaurant.

We came here for the ramen. Yelp let myself and my Japanese friend down when it suggested we have the ramen at Izikaya Sozai. That ramen was pretty weak and we felt betrayed. Nonetheless, given that Sozai didn't clear the bar and Nombe is no longer even offering ramen, Halu became our last ray of hope. The ramen here is very typical, and very delicious. All of the tastes are understated. The pork is even and not too fatty. The addition of a little bit of ginger is a simple, nice touch. The noodles were dead-on great. Best ramen in SF? Possibly.

We also had the chicken kara age and chicken kushikatsu. The kara age was definitely fried well and the portion is pretty good for $7. The kushikatsu was pretty unique in that there were basil leaves intermixed with the chicken under the panko breading. I loved how the basil and chicken worked with the mustard dipping sauce.

Anyways, Halu overall was a great food experience. The only thing holding it back was the service. Their 15-minute waiting estimate would have been about 45 had we not decided to sit at the bar. A couple came in later with a reservation and were told to wait another 20 minutes (always unacceptable). And most egregious was that they charged for "green" tea. It's bad enough to charge money. It's inexcusable to not know what kind of tea it actually was once I asked them to specify. That's not ok.

So, overall you're left with some great food, some terrible service and a different kind of Japanese restaurant.

Fair enough.
author: Tolga E.

description:
Halu is a tiny place with a nice beatles theme going on. They play the music over and over and the whole place is decorated with beatles stuff.

Yakitori is is grilled stuff on a stick. There is quite a lot of different yakitori here. Each order comes with 2 sticks and usually 3 pieces of what you ordered on that stick. Yakitori seems well priced, but eating and drinking your fill is expensive. Bacon mochi is definitely a must try here. It's additively good and tasty, but bad for your health.

Nice place for yakitori and drinking, but definitely not a place for ramen unless you're a fan of salty ramen. The ramen is are very salty compared to your usual ramen, I'm guess drunk people crave salty things?
author: Steven B.

description:
Last summer I went to Halu 3 weeks in a row and each time with a different guest...I really hope that the proprietors didn't think I was some sorta call girl (cue Pretty Woman song here).

Nevertheless, I've fallen for the Beatles ambiance, and just had to share it with my family and friends immediately.  I'm no yakitori expert but I found them a little salty for my taste, but it's nothing that a cold glass of Asahi won't balance out.  I tried different items at every visit, but my favorite order is the soba noodle plate.  Small little place, I prefer to sit in the middle of the restaurant.  It gets drafty and cramped towards the door and at towards the back of the restaurant is where all the bouquet of yakitori smells  reside and stuck to my clothes.  Good hearty eats +  the musicality of John, Paul, George & Ringo  in your ear  + super friendly waitstaff = strawberry fields forever!
author: Laurel S.

description:
This place rocks for their yakitori skewers!  At first i thought this was the same place as the ramen Halu over in San Jose, which has one of the most dinstinctive and yummy ramen broth I ever had...but nope, different type of resturant completely.  Been here a couple times..not close to where i live..but i would go out of my way if i have the Yakitori craving.

I love my beer and yakitori, this place delivers.  I don't like just your typical yakitori, like chicken and beef...but vaerity.  This place delivers.  You can get the typical but you also get the ginko nuts and organs.   Got to have the organs and beer.  They grill it just perfectly...   

They also got other small plates and also ramen.  I would not say that their ramen is in the class of Katanaya... but it's pretty good.. ...  The broth is flavorful and lots of stuff in there.  I can taste the pork bone in the broth, the noodle is chewy which is good, but can't say more from there.  I go more for the skewers, but finish up with the ramen. 

Place is kinda small but atmosphere is unique with all the beatles posters going on.  

Fun place and recommended.
author: Vien C.

description:
We've only been here a few times buy absolutely love it here. 

If you love, and I mean LOVE LOVE LOVE! the Beatles... Go here. Trust me... (all I'm saying... You have to be here to understand.)

We usually order a great deal of yakitori here and absolutely adore their echigo salad dressing! What is it! Why am I screaming!

Order one of everything, and try something new. They always have new specials and the place is family owned. Mom, dad, two daughters and what seems to be maybe their son.

Y(^_^)Y

Two peace signs!
author: Christopher L.

description:
In my quest to find good Ramen in the city, I decided to try this place out based on the Yelp Reviews.

I had the spicy Karaage Ramen special.  The Karaage was good, but I didn't like how it was plopped in the soup.  I should have asked for it to be on the side.  What's the point of frying something to be crispy and then dunking it in broth which then kills any crispness?  I thought the broth was OK, but I found that it was overpowered by the spiciness /sourness (my bad for going with this option, I should have chosen non-spicy broth as this was my first bowl of Ramen at this place).  The noodles were the thin style egg noodles.  I liked how the bowl/broth were super hot, but the noodles couldn't stand up to the heat and became soft/mushy.  I didn't really want to finish my bowl at that point.  

My wife had the shoyu Ramen and it was definitely better than my bowl, but the broth lacked depth and really didn't shine at all.  In addition, the Chasu didn't have much flavor at all.

In addition to the Ramen, we tried the bacon wrapped scallops and thought they were pretty good.  This is a definite must try.  

In the end, I rank the ramen at this place at 2.5 stars.  It is MUCH better than the other Ramen Halu in San Jose but not as good as Himawari in San Mateo.  I'd go back for the other things on the menu but not the Ramen.  Not even for a quick fix.
author: ray r.

description: Cool, interesting divey spot, just wasn't for me though.  If you like this style of food, then definitely go.  Other than ramen, i'm realizing this isn't my type of food.
author: Dilly M.

description:
I'm not usually a fan of yakitori, and I did not know this restaurant does not have any sushi until i got there but i'm definitely a fan! I came here around 10pm on a friday night and was told there'd be about a 30 minute wait. The restaurant is TINY, you could probably only fit about 25 people in there max. After we had ordered, we literally had to wait ANOTHER 30 minutes for the food to come out. The waitress had told us it would be awhile, but i didn't think awhile literally meant a half hour. I'm not sure if the food is worth an hour wait, especially since i was STARVING but it was the best cold soba don i've ever had. Then again, there aren't many japanese restaurants i've been to that had cold soba. The noodles were cooked just right and the sauce combined with the cucumbers and avocado and egg topped it off perfectly. The portions could of been a bit bigger considering it was an entree, but i definitely recommend giving it a try! I also tried a bit of the kara age ramen, and it was SPICY!! so for those of you who are fans of spicy soups, that is definitely a must try as well. 
Even though i'm not a fan of yakitori as i mentioned above, i felt that i needed to try something at least since that is what they are known for, so i got the eggplant stuffed cheese thing. i love love LOVEE eggplants and pretty much anything that has eggplants in it, so i did enjoy it. However, i don't think it is anything spectacular so i probably wouldn't recommend getting it.
author: Heidi T.

description:
When I called Euge for dinner, he asked: "Can you eat gizzards, hearts, that kind of thing?"  Can I ever!

Halu is perfect for overeating offal because it all looks so cute on the skewers.  Crispy chicken skin, tender beef tongue, mochi wrapped in bacon (what a great idea...I've been eating mochi with bacon since), fried chicken pieces, pork belly, Japanese pizza, roasted gingko, tiny whole fish, octopus in tongue-tingling wasabi sauce.

Offal fan or not, you can't go wrong here.  But do go with a sense of adventure because there are so many things to try here.
author: Sooj O.

description: I've heard great things about this place. I was very disappointed to find out that they do not have any vegetarian broth. I had the veggie pancake pizza instead, which was okay but did not hit the spot when I was hoping for ramen. The rest of my party seemed happy with the ramen. There are better ramen places in the city if you know where to find them.
author: Lucy C.

description:
It's alright, cool little place. Decor very neat but food is just okay. I had the seaweed mochi. Nothing special its basically pan fried glutinous rice flour w/ butter, soy and some nori..... $6 for 2 small pieces??? so not worth it. 

Chicken karaage ramen was alright. First few bites were good and then it got saltier and boring.

there really arent that many places in sf for good ramen
author: A L.

description:
I went to Halu Restaurant last night only to find a crowded little room and what looked to be very satisfied patrons.

I came in at the tail end of my social gathering, so I ended up just having luke-warm ramen.  As useless as this may sound, I don't know what was ordered, so my opinion on this place is based entirely on the mysterious bowl of ramen I had with large pieces of crispy chicken floating inside.

I tried a little bit of the butter and corn ramen broth and was very impressed.  Since that's the indicator of good ramen for me, I'm definitely going to try that the next time I return.

With hours as restricted as they are, I'm sure my next dining experience will be amazing.  To top it off, the wait staff was helpful, fast paced, and nice.  

Till next time, Halu!  4 Stars for now!
author: Johnson N.

description:
Another reviewer commented that this is a non-sushi Japanese restaurant. Having lived in Japan, we're always on the hunt for "real" Japanese food. We definitely found it at Halu! 

We visited this restaurant around 7:45pm on Saturday night. We were seated right away at the bar. 

We shared the Agedashi Tofu, which was just perfect, and an assortment of skewers as follows:

Bacon-wrapped asparagus - very tasty.
Asparagus - good, not amazing.
Gyuu-shiso - delicious, with mild shiso flavor.
Pork jowl - good, a bit rubbery
Bacon-wrapped enoki mushrooms - amazing - our favorite dish!
Trumpet mushroom kushikatsu - good, not amazing.
Chicken gizzards - he loves 'em (me = not so much).

The only drawback, and frankly why the restaurant gets three stars instead of four, is that it took more than an hour to get our skewers. The appetizer came in about 20 minutes, which is okay. But then, it was maybe another 45 minutes (or longer) till the skewers came. The restaurant is small, but it really shouldn't have been a two-hour meal since we weren't drinking (much) or planning a drawn-out experience.

We will definitely be back and I'll upgrade this review if we don't experience the same issues with speed. Either way, the food is great so check it out the next time you don't have anything else planned!
author: Karen C.

description: Closed Sundays, i found out last weekend driving over only to frown at the front door. :(
author: B H.

description:
It's more like 3.5 stars only because of the crazy cool decorations and ambiance of the joint. It's a small space with an area with a few tables and a counter where 5 people can sit to eat. We sat at the counter and it was totally fine - except it was pretty cold that night so everytime someone opened the door I froze a little. But I didn't mind that much - just keep your jacket on!

When you finally sit down and settle in, you start to look around and realize every single item/accessory the restaurant has put up, is some kind of Beatles memorabilia. If you really settle down, you'll also notice that the music played while you dine is some Beatles song or some rendition of it (acoustic, live recorded performance, etc). Pretty cool!

Anyway, here's what was ordered:

*bacon wrapped mochi - you get two skewers with two wrapped mochi on each. SO GOOD - eat while hot.
*okonomiyaki - definitely the most authentic I've had since visiting Japan. Although I don't prefer the amount of sauce put on it.
*chicken karaage ramen - it was ok. the chicken was super flavorful, almost a little too salty and also remember to take out the chicken RIGHT AWAY unless you like soggy breaded chicken. The noodles and broth could've been better, but it passed.
*grilled onigiri - this is definitely the best thing I had here. It's simple. A rice ball with some salmon flakes mixed in, GRILLED. The rice is nice and crunchy - seriously perfection.

I was pretty satisfied with my dining experience here. Just didn't like the 45 minute wait (we went at 8:30pm too!) when it was freezing cold outside. Ample amount of parking, which was good because we waited in the car with the heater on until we got seated. It was slightly pricey for some items, but they do specialize in yakitori, so definitely get those that are a little more novel and rare.
author: Julia K.

description:
Great service and fantastic food. I love the hole-in-the-wall feel. I only went with one other friend, so it was a great intimate setting. The walls are really nicely decorated with music posters, featuring the Beatles and other bands. It was really difficult finding Halu, and we had to wait 20 minutes but it was SO worth it! The broth was delicious and I ordered the Chicken Karaage Ramen. 

Will definitely come again.
author: Sharon T.

description: Best izakaya joint in SF. Hands down. Service is always friendly here no matter how busy they are.  Things you MUST TRY here are: stuffed mushroom kushikatsu, short rib skewers, salmon skewers, bacon wrapped mochi, and their RAMEN. Grub hard.
author: Hyuk L.

description:
Solid food, good service, and sweet (Beatles) atmosphere. The yakitori was nicely seasoned and delicious, though you should expect to extra-order since the skewers are small. I had the chicken kara-age rice plate -  the chicken was perfectly plankoed - and it came with a great salad with shoyu dressing. Bf had the chicken kara-age ramen - nice, flavorful soup (the kind that tastes like they cooked the broth with bones) with good ramen. Portions perfect.

The place is small so likely to get packed - we went on a Monday at 6 pm and was one of 3 tables, but it quickly filled up at 7.
author: C L.

description:
My worst dining experience ever. Sincerely, I will never return to this place.

The service was insultingly bad: waited 30 minutes to order, our food got mixed up with others, waited over an hour for our correct entrée (which never arrived) so, we walked out leaving $4 on the table for the lamb kabob appetizer (which came out 30 minutes after ordering). 

Appalling.
author: Drew D.

description:
There's a waiter here that tells people to kindly go outside and that she will take your name there. But then she never does, and you end up waiting 20 minutes and then you find out that there is in fact 3-4 parties ahead of you. 

THIS PLACE OBVIOUSLY CANNOT HANDLE ITS OWN CROWD AND ONLY SHOWS A POSITIVE ATTITUDE TO PEOPLE WHO ARE SEATED.
author: Connie N.

description:
I was introduced to this place by a friend. Even since moving back from Japan, I have been craving some good ramen and was told to go here. 

This place is a total hole in the wall. If you're walking by it you wouldn't even know that it existed, since the windows are all covered up. This place was tiny! Is it really wheelchair accessible?! That aside, when we entered we were immediately greeted with a warm "irrashaimase." Not all cold and monotoned like at those Japanese themed Chinese ran restaurants. 

We came in at around 7pm, it wasn't full and it wasn't completely empty.  As we ate however it began to fill up.

I looked over the menu and decided I didn't want to order any ramen. They put corn in their ramen which I am not a fan of. I have never had corn in my ramen in Japan and I don't think I want to start having any in it. Maybe I will try the ramen another time possibly ask them to not put in corn. 

We decided and ordered the dinner plate of yakitori and kushi katsu, in addition we got the grilled bacon wrapped mochi and a bottle of apple flavored belgium beer. 

The beer was excellent. I usually hate beer but the fruity taste was what drew me to it. 

The edamame and miso soup came out first. What can i say about the edamame? It was edamame, unsalted and to my liking. The miso soup was a bit too salty for my taste. I quite enjoyed the grilled bacon wrapped mochi. It wasn't too salty and not to sticky that it would get stuck in the grooves of your teeth. Was perfect!

The yakitori and kushi katsu came out beautifully plated. The first thing I tried was the yaki stuffed mushroom. It was so good, not all mushy and rubbery and the taste wasn't overwhelming. So far so good I thought. I then tried the katsu onion. Bleh, it was a thick slice of onion battered and fried. Needed a kick to it. After trying all the items on the yakitori plate and katsu plate, I can say for sure the katsu was bland and only seasoned wit a bit of salt and pepper. The yakitori was inconsistent some were good and some were overly seasoned with salt. Maybe if I had some more beer it would have helped. 

The decor of this place, I am sure a lot of people think its a bit weird with an overkill of Beatles memorabilia. A lot of bars in Japan are randomly decorated usually with whatever the owner has an interest in. If you go to a bar which catered to foreigners it is mostly decorated with foreign music memorabilia,  foreign license plates and knick knacks. The decor was very much like the random shady hole in the wall bars in the backstreets of Japan where the businessmen come to drink and let off some steam after work. So happened a customer was speaking non-stop Japanese to the owner the whole time I was there. I felt very much like I was back in Japan. I loved the feeling!

This place is definitely an izakaya a place you come for drinking and snacking. Or on a cold night you feel like having some warm ramen in you. 

For a first visit, I mostly enjoyed the atmosphere, great getting to listen to Japanese being spoken and it's great if you want to knock back a couple drinks and snack a bit.
author: C L.

description:
YAY! I am a fan! Yakitori is my favorite! 

I can't believe I haven't wrote a review on this place. I've passed by this place a million times but haven't tried it until last year... and it takes me another year to write the review =) Their yakitori is very good! their ramen is good also!!! I want to go back and try their Okonomi-yaki! Gotta make plans to go back... gotta make plans to go back... mmmm yakitori... i heart yakitori!

this place is really small and cozy.  if you are looking for some place nice or fine dining, this is not the place. cute place to bring a date!
author: Kapo T.

description:
I took a chance and took granny goose to a much talked about restaurant in her neighborhood that's had rave reviews for their ramen.  She likes the Chinese version of ramen so I thought she'd dig the Japanese.  

I ordered for us - 
Bacon wrapped mochi - pretty tasty, bacon was fatty so it felt bad
Yaki onigiri - very tasty and I liked the bits of salmon in there
Chicken Karaage Ramen - super delish, especially the chx - good flavor and perfect breading
Okonomiyaki (seafood) - a little salty & saucy but good

The ambiance is interesting - Beatles photos on the wall and that genre of music playing but in a Japanese mom & pop restaurant.  Cool & interesting.  It wasn't busy around 6ish on a Wednesday evening.  It was a little disappointing because service was kinda slow.  But a great authentic Japanese restaurant in granny's neighborhood.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I am a Halu back girl, I am a Halu back girl!

I don't think I'll ever get sick of this place.  When I'm in the mood for some really good yakatori or ramen, I come to Halu.  I order whatever yakatori sounds good (anything with bacon is great!), a large beer, maybe some ramen and they never disappoint.  And their side salad has that ginger dressing that I can drink.

It is a very very small place, run by a 4-person family and has only 1 waitress.  So if you come here, be patient.  The wait to be seated might be long, you might have to wait 15 or so minutes before ordering or your food might not arrive very fast.  This is not the place to go if you only have 30 minutes to eat.  Its the place to go when time doesn't matter.  Just sit and enjoy your beer, the Beatles deco and the smells of your food being prepared.  Its all worth it.
author: Bianca R.

description:
I expected to be blown away since this tiny place is always packed with people freezing outside waiting to get in, and bumping Beatles tunes.
But the service was painfully slow even though it's the size of an Altoids tin and the yakitori was lackluster. The ramen is good but it was akward when a couple got up and chewed out the waitress saying that they had been waiting for someone to take their order for 45 min. and they helped our table first and we had only been waiting a half an hour. I felt more at ease after a lot of sake and decided that I should only come back with the same group for sake downing whilst enjoying Beatles tracks and gazing at classic rock memorabilia - a nice ambiance for a good buzz.
author: Bettie N.

description:
TASTEY!! 

I'm a big fan of izakaya and have had my share of it over time - everything we had was delicious.  This place is super cute and funky with its Beatles theme and the overall crowd was awesome.

Food - everything you want in izakaya. Here are some recommendations:

1. Beef Tongue
2. Shiso Beef
3. Lava Ramen
4. Karage Ramen (the person next to us ordered it and it looked amazing)
5. Black Sausage
6. Fried Rice ball
7. Peppers

There is a lot more on the menu, but this is a good start for anyone wanting to give Halu a try. 

The service was excellent.

Thanks!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Expect the following:
- Beatles mania
- possibly the best ramen in SF city limits with a super thick and rich porky broth and perfect, toothsome noodles (sorry Katana-ya, but you're no longer #1)
- excellent okonomiyaki (Japanese pancake)
- awesome yakitori of all types: we had shishito, chicken skin, and mochi wrapped with bacon..yessss....precioussss
author: Angi C.

description:
Came back last night for a quick dinner with an old friend.  I got there a little before 6pm on a Thursday night and there was only one table filled.  I was supposed to meet my friend here, but it was chilly peppers and I didn't want to wait outside, so I went in.  Of course, 8 minutes later I get a phone call from him asking where I was.  He was outside while I was inside.  Luckily, that situation was fixed lickety split.

I was thinking about getting some yakitori, but decided instead to order the Veggie Don.  He ordered the Chashu Ramen and a big bottle of Sapporo.  My Veggie Don was actually really good!  It came with salad, a variety of mushrooms, avocado, and brown rice.  It was a pretty big serving size, but I managed to finish almost the entire thing.  I left a couple leaves from my lettuce and a couple scoops of rice, but it was really good.  I ordered it initially because it sounded healthy, but SCORE because it was also really good.  I'd definitely order it again if I were at Halu.

The service was great.  The waitress was really attentive, but probably because there weren't very many people there.  The bill (before tip) came out to about $28.
author: Kris L.

description: Went here for the first time this thursday with my good friend. I had no idea there was such a gem of a restaurant here! I had lived near the area before and never stumbled in. Such regrets! Anyway, it is a tiny place, but the atmosphere feels very cozy and well established. The cluttered and aging decor added much to its mom+pop charm, Beatles themed, with coordinating music in the background. The food was wonderful! we ordered a chicken karage dish that came with veggies and salad, and a bowl of chashu ramen. everything was served for sharing, which was nice. The veggies were fresh and the ramen was stellar. The best i've had yet. We encountered a small problem with a dish we ordered being forgotten and coming out late, but as we were just on a casual outing and had no where to be, it was not really an issue. The wait staff was super nice about it. My friend and i tried a sake called Drunken Whale, which was super. i can't wait to go back.
author: Iliea S.

description:
We've been snacking at little things all day so decided to try this place from a friends recommendation since we didnt want a full on meal.  We got there about 8ish on a Saturday.  The five of us had to sit at the bar but I think we were lucky since a bunch of other people came in right after us.  They were super busy so service wasnt quick because it took some time for us to order.  They do acknowledge you right away when you get in the door to let you know how long the wait would be.  Its tiny and packed in there.  They have a lot of Beatles memorabilia.  Didnt get to try the ramen or the okonomiyaki at this visit but will try next time.

We just got a bunch of yakitori:  all very yummy but they do all add up $$$

butter fried mochi wrapped in seaweed - sooo good 
bacon wrapped scallops 
bacon wrapped mochi
oyster chicken 
rib eye steak 
short ribs
okra
trumpet mushroom

chicken karaage - nice since it wasnt heavily battered
author: she q.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars except i'm subtracting one star because of the cramped quarters and long wait for food. we went on tuesday night 7:30ish

We went there specifically because of the great reviews for the yakitori ( skewers). most were $4-5 for two skewers, no doubt, they were amazing. definitely have the chicken thighs, short rib, pork &onion. we really liked the chicken & basil katzu skewer served with katzu sauce and hot mustard sauce. 

the service was great and apologetic for our wait. we only had the skewers because we weren't starving, so perhaps it would have been faster if we had something else to eat as well.

I'd come back if it was only for a quick snack or if they had a taco truck with only the skewers!
author: jessica c.

description: We really enjoyed this unusual and friendly place. The ramen was the best I'd had in recent memory. We had a grilled shrimp skewer which we dippped in a matcha/salt mixture... Loved it! Only knock was a way-too-salty chicken & brown rice dish - our strategy next time will be share 1 ramen & order lots of skewered fun stuff. I thoroughly enjoyed the food, atmosphere, and service and look forward to my next visit.
author: Michael P.

description:
However good this place may be, yakitori, ramen, tofu, whatevers, it's definitely not worth waiting for 45+ mins only to have the table you've been waiting for to be snatched by another party who just arrived claiming they had reservations.  For some place that does not allow reservations, that's most convenient.  Therefore, if I were to eat there, would the item I ordered be taken away and given to another table as well?  This is food service and you're running a business, not a club where if you tip the bouncer or waitress, you get an advance in the line. 

No thank you, there are plenty of other places in the city with good ramen as well.
author: Vincent K.

description:
I have the chance to revisit Halu tonight. I swear, this place is better every single time you come! At first I thought the first time I was here tasted good because I was kind of hungry and was afraid that it won't be as good anymore... but I found out how wrong I was to doubt this place! Halu, I will never doubt you again! You are the best! (I seriously mean it!)

Came back this time and tried many things we didn't got last time.

- The seafood okonomiyaki is a MUST! Big, beautifully made, and delicious!
- Chicken skin was good like last time!
- the Oyster chicken is YUMMY!
- bacon scallop is awesome... I still craved for more!
- enoki bacon is amazing like the last time I ordered it.
- the chicken karaage ramen was so-so, but still better than a lot of ramen I tried around SF.

There were more food we ordered, but I was so hungry that I didn't bother to remember their names... I'll get them next time! 

Also!!! GREAT SERVICE! Our waitress was very attentive, smart, and knew what we wanted before we even ask! She rocks!
author: Gordon L.

description:
the food was mediocre

-- Spicy chasu ramen didn't have enough other ingredients than pork and half an egg. Meager amounts of bean sprouts. feeling like I am just having starch and protein.
-- all of the skewers are probably not grilled under high enough heat. I love it when the bacon wrapping the asparagus becomes almost a crispy layer of the asparagus. Here the bacon is chewy and fatty around the bacon. 

Service was horrible

-- they first told us that chicken skin and shishito pepper were sold out. This is saturday night around 8.30pm -- height of dinner time during the weekend and completely sold out
-- the food came quite late.
-- they brought 4 out of 7 skewers that we ordered. When finishing, I asked one waitress to check on the other skewers.
-- Few minutes later, the other waitress came with the bill, without mentioning anything. When i ask her if everything was served, she went back to check. Then she brought the check with everything we ordered, and I told her that we are still missing 3 skewers, she went back to the kitchen and informed us that gingo nuts and chicken gizzards are out as well, and crossed out the items on the bill. This is done after 3 times of prompting them that something needs to be adjusted.
-- the waitresses were running around in this small space, knocking my elbow twice on the table, one spilled a whole stack of dishes. what a disaster.

This restaurant needs to have a process to keep better track of things ordered, served, available to be served, rather than running around aimlessly like chicken with heads cut off!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Great place for ramen on a cold SF night.

Charshiu Ramen:  $8.75
Spicy Kara Age Ramen:  $10  *** Deliciously hot chili spicy ***
Okonomiyaki:  $9  *** Huge enough for 4 to share ***

Wednesday nights:  NOT CROWDED!

Good place to go by yourself too.

Not a good place if you can't stand The Beatles while you're eating.
author: Kayan W.

description:
Yes, sometimes it takes a while to get your food here. But this isn't In-N-Out folks. 

Take your time and enjoy the company of your eating companions. Alone? Enjoy being out with your bad-self!

I've had the miso and shoyu ramen and I have to say miso kicks shoyu's bootie. The noodles are nice and chewy. The pork is very tender. The corn is a nice addition. 

The chicken wings are sooo good! The squirt of lemon really brings out the flavor of the meat and the salt. 

The stuffed mushrooms! So much flavor packed into a tiny package. 

The flank steak is BBQ good. 

The pregnant little fish was the adventure that we took and it was fun! However, I hesitate to say that I will travel that road again. 

The chicken karaage is A-mazing. It comes out so crispy and hot. Little bits of dark meat fried with the skin partially on so that there is MORE crispy surface area.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
I love their menu because I feel like I totally forgot I am eating YAKITORI skewers in the USA. Very authentic. The prices are very reasonable.
The restaurant ,even small space that reminds me of Japanese size Izakaya restaurant in Japan.
author: N M.

description:
I'm so glad there's a place in the neighborhood like Halu.  It's a tiny joint with a few small tables and a bar.  Excellent yakitori and ramen.  Friendly service.  And the walls are littered with vintage Beatles memorabilia, to go along with the classic rock playing on the radio.

My girlfriend and I come here on special occasions.  It's like punctuating a good day with a great meal--hot food served fast with a tall glass of cold beer.

Long story short, Halu makes me happy.
author: Tony L.

description: It was good!  Yakitori selection was not as broad as I'd expected, but this place is cute and good.  Great service and tasty.  Would come back with friends for a late night snack and some beer.
author: Alex T.

description:
Came here with Euge I to shoot the breeze and to grab a couple of beers and some snacks. It still amazes me how many friends I have met through Yelp and I can tell Euge and I will be good friends for life. 

This place is a mix between a bar/restaurant/tapas/hangout spot in the Richmond district. Yes.........this is how a yaki tori bar looks like 20+ years ago. It's really not done up like the newer yaki tori restaurants which I like. It's just a very cool place. The owner is a huge Beatles fans and that was evident with the music being played and the memorabilia throughout the restaurant. 

Everything is just very fresh. It's the kinda place where you have a couple of beers and then order some food........talk.............then order some more beers in which they have a huge selection of...............then order some more food.............then just talk. It's like going to Europe and enjoying a three hour lunch. This can last a few hours which I didn't really minded. The staff was friendly and it helps when the Euge is there. 

Overall, a great little yaki tori restaurants hidden in the inner Richmond district. Thanks for the beers and snacks Euge. My turn next time.
author: jason g.

description: Wow. This place is amazing. We went here with a few friends last night, and the food and service were great.
author: Berkeley A.

description:
This was probably the best Izakaya I have had to date. I have been to Oyaji, Ju-ku, Sozai and Nombe and Halu was by far the best. It doesn't have the variety that Sozai and Nombe does but it has what counts. We ordered only skewers. The tsukune was juicy, the shishito peppers were crispy, the shiso beef was de-licious. To top it off when we were ordering shochu the waitress offered this barley shochu that tasted like whiskey which was amazing! 
The place is tiny so get there early. The service was a little slow when we ordered our second round but I think it was cause it got busy. Overall, I can't wait to go back.
author: Shari W.

description:
This place is great. Tiny, tiny place and reminded me of tokyo. Good selection of yakitori. Had stuffed mushrooms, beef tongue, chicken heart, Spicy pork ramen and onkonomiyaki. Everything was delicious, I could have 4 or 5 of that beef tongue skewer it was so tasty! The spicy pork ramen was just the right amount of spicy ness with a robust broth and good ingrediants. I would recommend not to share this as its not an extra large ramen, so to share for two is not really enough. The okonomiyaki says it was osaka style, but Ive HAD the one in osaka and it was nothing like this. This was more like a think pancake, it was beef okonomiyaki and it tasted good but we just wanted more for $10!

Spent $40 sometihng and we werent stuffed but it was good. I think to be really full here you probably could spend easily $30 a head. Will come back for skewers and ramen for sure!
author: Petri Y.

description:
I came here on the recommendation of a coworker who raved about the ramen and since the weather in SF is usually chilly-leaning, ramen sounded pretty darn good to me. The place is popular. Expect a wait. It's nice that they have a "will call" option so you can wander around, but don't wander too far because they will give your table away if you aren't within sprinting distance. 

I tried the fabled ramen and it wasn't good. Straight up. BUT the yakitori and grilled meat stick options were VERY good. Skip the ramen, go for the grilled options. I would say that Halu is a good izakaya, but not a good ramen place. And they play the Beatles so good taste in music, though I'm sure the staff must hate the Beatles with a fiery passion.
author: Meghan R.

description:
Who knew Beatle-mania swept thru the land of the rising sun?  An eclectic ambiance of Japanese manga and Beatles memorabilia makes for a strange union.  

Service was an absolute disaster.  Was part of a party of 6 - we each ordered our own meals.  4 of us got our food relatively quickly, but the other 2 had to wait 45 minutes.  We were told that the food took a long time to cook - but isn't yakitori just meat on sticks?  How long does that take to grill?  The most annoying part of the service - When the owner came out and gave us a conditional-apology for the service, admonishing us with a statement about how people patronized their establishment by drinking sake while waiting for food...but all I saw was families drinking water...WTF?!  Does that excuse a 45 minute delay between serving half the table?
author: Sy K.

description:
This is a nice and small restaurant in the Richmond and they specialize in yakitori. Honestly I don't see what the appeal was. The service was pretty slow. We sat around for 30 minutes and they didn't come by to take our order. The ramen wasn't very memorable. Broth was ok and the noodles were ok. But it didn't stand out against any of the other ramen-yas. They also didn't the half cooked egg that I look for at ramen places. Boo.

I did like the flavor of the yakitori though. Yummy teriyaki...

Maybe it was an off night for them... I'd come back again to give them another try.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Excellent ramen stock with good depth (plenty of pork bone flavor), toppings (okay) included tender thick slices of pork, half hard cooked boiled egg, bamboo shoot, and sprouts. Noodles were on the soft side. I had the spicy lava ramen and i'll be back to try the other ramen offerings. 

Tha yakitori was only okay, mostly because the put a teriyaki-ish glaze on everything, making everything taste the same. Also, they use a gas grill here, no charcoal. I liked the chicken hearts and bacon scallop the best.
author: Derrick V.

description: Hands down the best izakaya in the Bay Area!!  Stick to the grill items and you will not go wrong.
author: Crystal S.

description:
OK this place is a little hidden treasure.  It's cute, it's quaint and the people who run the place are interesting and likable.  It's very small over all and is crammed full of Beatles stuff and 60's rock in general... a wonderful odd mixture.  The food is pretty good too.  I've had ramen the couple of times we've gone and it's been better than good.  My husband has had the various yakatori offerings and loves it, loves it, loves it.  Whenever Halu is mentioned, his eyes literally light up.  
The food is good, the atmosphere is totally entertaining and the prices are average.  It's a great little place and everyone should take a little visit when in the neighborhood.
author: Nix B.

description:
I really like this place and I wanna love it but I don't. The space is way too small for the amount of traffic they get. I've been here multiple times and the only great experience I had was the first time.  The most recent time we went with a party of 3 and was told a wait time of about 20 mins, we ended up waiting over an hour and just decided to eat across the street at Thai time.

I do recommend to try this place but just go early.  Also, good service and very nice people.  

My dish: Spicy butter corn ramen with extra corn

His Yakitori recommendations:
Gizzards
Chicken wings
Bacon wrapped enoki mushrooms
author: Anna C.

description:
I'm always trying to find a ramen shop to out-do Katanaya.  Halu didn't quite do it but it was still a yummy dinner.  Their ramen is thin and soft (kinda like the packaged stuff but better), and their broth is very savory.  I prefer thicker ramen with more of a chew.  Average of $10 a bowl. 

Okonomiyaki was also much thinner than previous pancakes I've had and also more crispy which I liked.  Too much sauce on top and not enough seafood. ~ $10 again.  

Kushikatsu beef was really soft and tender, great panko crust, and good variety of seafood and meats to choose from ~$5

Overall, not bad but since it's not in my neighborhood and not cheap or amazing enough to justify the commute, I think I'll keep searching..
author: Beatrice T.

description:
I can't even write this without laughing to myself a little.  Dinner here was random, hilarious, crazy, and entertaining all rolled into one.  Actually the whole night was like that.  I'll try to break it down as much as i can without divulging too much information of what said night consisted of.  

Liver yakitori - i wasnt feeling it.  
Tongue yakitori(i think thats what it was) - was good at first but was so chewy it was like bubble gum.  
Fried okra - good. 
Chicken karaage - really good.
Ramen - mmmm really good too.  
Sake - who doesnt love sake.  before i could finish my glass, it was already being refilled.  

Dinner conversation was entertaining as usual with great stories.  Due to all the sake i cant remember verbatim what was said.  Something about getting my ass kicked and being defriended if i dont take Euge's advice, F*** the Oakland As, wacked losers, car bombs, future ex-girlfriend, and being so much cuter in person.  There was also something about a watermelon being crushed by someones head.  Like i said, random.

Halu is a small place but the food is really good.  What i like most is the Beatles theme.  Im a huge Beatles fan.  Our waitress was great and incredibly patient - im sure shes use to it.  Definitely wouldnt mind coming back here again soon.
author: Juv C.

description:
When I am in the mood to celebrate and indulge, this is the only spot I always hope is open.

I have had quite a bit of Yakitori. 

There is no place that even comes close to how good Halu is. The atmosphere is wonderful. The family who runs the place are very genuine and highly talented individuals. Normally I eat as many skewers as I can afford and then follow it up with Ramen or a Rice Bowl. They have an excellent selection of Beer and Sake. Plum wine if you are into that sort of thing. As for price...

You can choose to have a lighter meal and feel satisfied if you don't have a lot of money. I however tend to save my pennies for an all out epic feast to balance the alcohol intake. No matter what route you take, I guarantee you won't be disappointed with the quality and flavor of the food.

Definitely one to put on your list as a hole in the wall secret of the Richmond.
author: Joel V.

description:
We're still on the hunt to find really good ramen in the city. Since this place do serve up this yummy noodle dish, we had to try it. My fiance ordered the Chasu Ramen and I had to have the Spicy Ramen. Ummmm ... spicy ramen was perfect! The amount of spiciness was on point ... not too spicy where it ruins your meal but spicy enough to kick it up a notch! We also had the yakitori and chicken karage. 

Very cute neighborhood joint. We will definitely come back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Mrs L.

description:
Small but mighty gem of a place. Ramen noodles and The Beatles? Um, hell yes! 
Here's the breakdown:
1.) Beatles music and Beatles paraphernalia EVERYWHERE. A feast for the eyes and ears. 
2.) Friendly staff.
3.) Small, intimate, casual vibe. 
4.) Spicy, hot, tasty Ramen WITH Pork. yum for me.
5.) Spicy, hot, tasty Ramen WITHOUT Pork. yum for hubs.
6.) Small, but tasty yakitori menu (we tried the beef and the shrimp, and we give thumbs up). 
7.) They wrap BACON around everything. I didn't order pork products, as Hubs doesn't eat it, but when I go back, I will GO.TO.TOWN.  Because, well, I DO eat pork. Can you really really not be intrigued with a place that wraps everything in pork?! 

So in summary: Yummy ramen, meat on a stick, John, Paul, George and Ringo smiling at you benevolently from all corners of the room. Bacon-hugs around everything in niblet form. 

Yeah. It's good stuff.
author: Kimberly N.

description:
Seriously, I wish I had a larger stomach so I could try more stuff during my visit.

First of all, the ramen is pretty tasty.  I will come back just for that.   But items like the butter fried mochi is what sparks as a reason to return.  Their menu list is pretty expansive and daily specials deserve extra attention.  It can get pretty packed, as the place only has a few 4 tables in addition to a small bar.  Expect to spend some cash if you want one of everything like I did.
author: Simon Y.

description:
This place definitely is able to pull of their American/Japanese theme.

All that aside, the Ramen at this place is a 3 - 3.5 STARS. I give credit for all the different ingredients they put into it, definitely on the hearty side with a wide variety in vegies/meats/etc...When you taste the broth you can tell it's NOT authentic Japanese Ramen Broth. This broth has one thing going for it, and one thing only, it is RICH in the pork bone flavor. But as you begin to eat more and more you start to realize how salty this broth is. 

As for the noodles, 3 STARS. Skinny noodles that are chewy.  But they are not top of the line Ramen noodles. I've had better at Himawari.

As for their chicken gizards, 2 STARS. I eat them all the time at home and at Japanese restaurants (Oyaji and Himawari). The flavor is that of salty chicken blood...not appetizing at all. 

This review is based on my experience with eating Ramen at Himawari, Suzu, Tanpopo, Katana-Ya, Oyaji, Genki
author: Nick C.

description:
Weird little Japanese diner.  Lots of Rock and roll paraphernalia.  The karaage here is excellent and so is the skewer sticks.  Lots of ramen and hot food options to go with the alcohol.  

This place is a tight squeeze.  It's quick to fill up and hard to get out.  Service can be slow and painful.  With the wait, the decor gets old and overwhelming.  It's a wanna-be Hard Rock.

So, if you want to spend as little time as possible inside, get here early or really late.  Otherwise, you'll spend hours eating your trickle of a meal.
author: MTBer I.

description:
I am forever on the hunt for the best ramen in the Bay Area and I have yet to find one that tops Tenkaippin in Honolulu. In my years of searching, I've found Halu to be one of the better ramen spots in San Francisco. Decorated in Beatles paraphernalia and cycling through every Beatles album ever made on the speakers, the family-owned business hit a jackpot with the Beatlemania-themed restaurant.

When I recommend this restaurant (with a seating capacity of about 20 people) to other ramen connoisseurs, I always tell them to go when you're not hungry because you will wait for your food. It took 25 minutes to get our 2 orders of the Kara Age (fried chicken) ramen ($10 each) and an order of the buttered mochi wrapped in nori (seaweed) ($6.50).

The mochi was seasoned with a buttery soy sauce, grilled until it's warm and chewy, then wrapped in seaweed before serving. The appetizer is definitely my favorite of the night. The ramen, which consists of corn, ginger, bean sprouts, green onions and uber tender fried chicken, was so thick and rich, a slight film would form on top if you let it sit too long. Kind of gross, but it tasted good. I have an appreciation for hand-made noodles, and I'm almost positive Halu uses packaged noodles, which is disappointing.

On my next venture to Halu, I'll try the yakatori (skewers). It's supposedly their specialty, but I can't bring myself to pay $5 for 3 tiny little skewers. In the meantime, Halu will remain my close substitute for ramen until my next trip to Hawaii.
author: Sam L.

description:
I've been there two times and have very different experiences. 

The first time we came with my roomate at 8 and didn't have any difficulty to find seats. We were served quite quickly and the food tasted really good. We both had Koumi Dons which were fabulous.

The second time I wanted to bring my French friends to this restaurant and we arrived at 9. I know it's unusual in the US to have dinner after 9 (in France we usually eat around 8h30-9h00) so this was a good point that the restaurant close 11pm. 

The bad news was the wait, due to the lack of space (the room is really tinny). I let my phone number to the waitress who told us that she would call me 20min after. 30min later I finally called the restaurant. They apologized, saying that, at this moment no more seats were available and we would have to wait 15 more minutes. Which we did, but again, we didn't hear about them so we call the restaurant and, after showing our beginning of irritation, they told us that a table was available (available = being cleaned). After all these incidents we finally had a great dinner.
author: Virginie D.

description:
The first thing I thought when I walked in was woah! Decor was all Beatles. I guess the owner is a huge Beatles fan. The restaurant itself is very small so I would recommend trying to go at an off meal time rather than just popping up. 

We had the Yakitori meal, which consisted of a couple of grilled skewers (chicken, steak, and okra). I've always been a fan of okra, so for them to have it was awesome. 

Next we had the ramen. I thought it was just ok. Definitely had better elsewhere. 

Finally, the Okonomiyaki came out. I guess this takes longer than usual to make. I hate onions and didn't realize it was going to be cooked with them. So if any of you don't like onions, make sure to let the server know.
author: Andrew C.

description: Great vibe and music to accompany very tasty ramen and skewers...pretty small setting.
author: Eric C.

description:
I want to say I love this place like everyone else. Really I do, but I can't. Sorry Halu. 

I'll give you props for the cute 60's decor. For you Beatles fans - it is pure Beatles heaven for ya all. The service crew were really friendly and attentive. However, we are talking food here. I don't know if I ordered the right thing or not. Fellow yelpers raved about the ramen here and how good it is. So - me being me, I had to try it out. 

My friend and I ordered the Karaage ramen and char-sui ramen. We also ordered a side of butter fried mochi wrapped in seaweed. The mochi was very good. It was pan fried and then wrapped in nori. There was also a drizzle of soy sauce. Never thought of doing that combination but hey it works. 

Now onto the ramen. I know Halu is mostly known for it's yakitori but I swear yelpers were writing their ramen was good. Was it you ask? I had better unfortunately. The broth was bland. It didn't taste like anything. Seriously. If you were to ask me was the broth beef, chicken, pork, or veggie based - I wouldn't be able to tell you. The broth was just brown. Can brown be a flavor? 

The Karaage chicken was good - crispy and full of garlic. The pork was bland unfortunately. I wasn't keen on the portion size. After eating my ramen and the mochi I was STILL hungry. Seriously - do not go to this place unless you either have a very small appetite or had a huge meal prior to eating here. 

Sorry Halu - really wanted to love ya ....but I just can't.
author: Cris H.

description:
I wanted to like Halu, especially after a handful of my friends on Yelp and in real life raved about it. I won't go into too much detail about how small the restaurant itself is or into the Beatles' decor because you can read that in the over 250 reviews written before mine. 

Here's the breakdown of the three star rating: 
Food - four stars 
Service - three stars 
Decor - three stars 

If this was my sister writing this review, it maybe have gotten lower marks. 

I would go again for the spicy chicken karage ramen alone! The broth is legit! Perfect heat, nicely breaded and cooked pieces of chicken, and plentiful not so thick noodles makes this a hit!! I'm glad we ordered a variety of yakatori skewers. The bacon mochi definitely was my favorite, and would have loved to try the short rib skewer, but it never came (part of why service got a three stars...that and the one server didn't bus our table when we were clearly done w/ our entrees, and as we waited awhile for our remaining yakatoris).  Also, have to mention, there was something slimey/wet by my feet which I tried not to think about the entire meal.  Quick turnaround, and small quarters make it hard to clean thouroughly between patrons.

I'll keep an open mind, and go again. Won't take my finicky mother or sister next time, and hope they have the lychee sake.
author: Marie B.

description:
HOLY CRAP i waited +30 minutes for my food!!! I only ordered ramen and 3 types of yakitori!  WTH? 

THis aside, the food was uneventful. The tebasaki were TINY, the ramen was, well my ex GF made better, and the chuhai was watered down. 

Yes it is authentic but for 1 chuhai, 3 orders of yakitori, and  a bowl of ramen for $40 with tax and tip is OUTRAGEOUS.  

add the 30+ minute wait.  Did i mention i waited forever to place my order.

This isthe second time i have been here. The first time i didnt like the ramen and thought it was a fluke.  Nope it is confirmed it is bad, Katana ya is better.   
But if you are into kitchy neat looking cramped spaces, you will love this place.  

The owners are nice though, I so want to open up a place and blow people away with the price/glav ratio
author: Spanky M.

description:
Scene 1: Watching Ponyo eating ramen with Sosuke.

Me: Ooohhhh! Where can we eat?
Cousin: Ramen! I know a ramen place!
Me: Ramen it is!

Scene 2: Waiting outside Halu.

Me: Brrr! So cold!
Cousin: Now I really want that ramen!
Family: We're hungry!

Scene 3: Finally seated.

Server: What can I get to start you off?
The Mister: Can we get a bottle of sake? 
Server: Sure thing!
(Comes back with sake for four. And a pot of hot tea, upon request.)
Server: You have to try our Yakitori because that's our specialty. People think we're a ramen place but we're actually not.  We cook good skewers.
Us: Really? Wow.
Server: So what have you decided?
Us: Can we get 2 chicken ramens and the pork loin ramen?    

Scene 4: Three empty bowls, 10 skewer sticks, 1 empty sake bottle and an empty Kirin bottle later.

Us: *Burp* 
       That was good. 
        Yum.
Beatles: Help! I need somebody! Help! Not just anybody! He-eelp!
Kids: Hey, we have that song!
author: Mimi S.

description: Yakitori were good, especially the chicken hearts.  If you like spending money on appetizers this is your place.  Because you order a few of those skewers, they all add up.  You probably want to drink it with beer.  I had the miso ramen with 10 different vegetables. It was too salty for me.  The bowl was huge and lots of noodles with tiny little mushrooms.  Atmosphere was friendly and family-ish.   Skip the rice wrapped with the flicks (sorry can't remember the name).  Didn't have to wait on a Sat night.
author: Helen L.

description:
Yum yum yum. I didn't know this place existed until my friends took me here for dinner. The place has a really, really small store front, so it's really easy to miss. I thought it was cool that the inside of the restaurant was Beatles themed.

I would highly recommend the skewers; of everything we had, they were my favorite hands down. We had the chicken heart, chicken gizzard and the fried stuffed mushrooms. We also had the rice balls and some ramen. It takes a while for the food to come, so be prepared to wait.

The people working were all nice and funny, so that and the food totally made the kinda long wait totally worth it.
author: Maple C.

description: Great ramen, cool atmosphere, crowded as hell.
author: Michael E.

description:
Meat on a stick.  I want my nickname to be Meat-on-a-stick.  It just tastes better if it's cooked on a stick and served slightly charred.  Mm.  I'm having a flashback just thinking about this.

It was Friday night, I had been running around doing errands and trying to do research for this very important thing I'm suppose to write this weekend.  I waited for the 33 bus that took nearly as much time as it would have taken me to walk, but not really so I just stood in the sun and ruined my porcelain complexion.  After the bus deposited me ungracefully in Geary and Arguello, I walked the 8 Richmond blocks (i.e. 1/3 the size of standard city blocks) to Halu with a small detour to the bank.  No credit cards.  CASH ONLY.  

Lou and I sat at the counter and he ordered this ridiculously large bottle of distilled barley shochu.  So much for not drinking this weekend.  

Ordering was fun and easy, the choices were exciting and came out quickly.  We tried the bacon scallops, bacon enoki, tontoro (pork belly), shiso beef (best flavor combo ever), salmon (eh, it had some yucky sauce on it), age dashi tofu, and spicy kara age ramen.  I was really really full.  

The yakitori was good.  I think the salmon could have done without the sauce, and just a sprinkle of salt.  I like shioyaki more than teriyaki.  Bacon enoki was great.  There was this bottle of red powder sprinkle thing.  While the yakitori was already flavorful, the magic red powder made it better somehow.  With magic.  

The ramen was good but by the time we got to that, my taste buds had been saturated.  I could no longer taste anything.  Woof.  I surrender peacefully. 

It's a little expensive to just drop in for a snack, but that makes it more realistically Japo because the standard of living is really high in Japan and food is really expensive.  The price of a pair of skewers was similar to the price of nigiri at $$ - $$$ places.  The most expensive was tontoro and shiso beef at a whooping $10 for a pair.  But that's no more unreasonable than toro nigiri or mirugai nigiri or awebi nigiri.
author: Christina C.

description: Just get the pork jowl, tongue, wings, scallops and beer - and bring a friend to shoot this shit
author: B H.

description:
There may not be anything to say about Halu that hasn't been said.  I would wait in the freezing mists of Inner Richmond all night to fill my belly with their delicious yakitori organ meat's and bomb ramen's.

You want to eat at Halu?  Be prepared to wait.  But the good thing about the wait is it's not overflowing with scenesters like at Burma Superstar.

I holla for Halu.  Yea, I just wrote that.
author: Pouria Y.

description: Authentic izakaya joint, decently priced, and fun atmosphere. Service sucks sometimes because it can take forever to get your orders in, or heaven forbid, you want to order more of something. My favorites here include shishito peppers, liver, gizzards, hearts, beef tongue, and bacon-wrapped mochi. The ramen is decent but not something I'd get again.
author: Rich L.

description: The chicken karaage ramen. amen. thanks.
author: Kitty K.

description:
3 stars NOT because of the food. The yakotori is great! Tony and I had the chicken gizzards, the beef tongue, and the enoki bakon yakitori last night. The flavors were great. We topped it off with some chashu ramen, because it was a cool and foggy night in the City, and we needed some noodle soupd to warm us up. The ramen is a-ok, not fantabulous. But, people venture to Halu for their yakitori.

The service is the reason why it doesn't get higher marks. Sadly, we were neglected. It's a tough call. I think it's family run, and the space is small, so you really cannot hire a lot more people. But it took 10 minutes before we could order, after we seated at the counter. Another 5 before we got our green tea. When our chashu ramen came, we asked for napkins. She said "yes" and then forgot. Tony busted out his own napkins. When I finally caught her eye again, she did get the napkins, and that was when she realized she never got napkins for us. She apologized for that.  Our yakitori finally came mid-way through our ramen.. I make a note of this BECAUSE sitting next to me at the counter was a regular. I could tell because he kept telling Shige-san how great the yakitoris were - they kept asking him if he wanted more- and his yakitoris came immediately! He ordered some of the same yakitoris we did, after we did, and he finished his before we even got ours. They even got him extra napkins when he asked.  It took another 10 minutes to get our check. I watched her hug several friends, take several orders. I asked her twice of the check. And the topper? She was doing the math so quickly, that our final bill came to 14.75. But the ramen orders alone should have come to 17.50. We paid the correct amount. If they note the mis-calculation, we gave very little tip. If they dont note the miscalculation, we gave at least a 15 dollar tip.

But, the food is good. And we live really close by. So we did the honest thing. And we'll probably be back some day, when we are looking to eat some yakitori. But we can't come when wer're starving. The wait is too long.
author: Annie Y.

description:
Forgive me, but I don't see the hype about this place.  After reading about this in SFWeekly and reading the Yelp reviews, my bf and I were excited to have dinner here.  Maybe the idea of having yakitori, drinking beers, and listening to the Beatles is better than actually being here.  We were both disappointed with how small the portions are.  We got the yakitori platter thinking we could pick our own 7 different yakitoris but nope, it was prixe fixed so to speak with 3 different kinds of chicken, okra, and something else boring.  So we subsituted.  The skewers were tiny, maybe with enough food on there for 1 normal bite.  I also got the chashu ramen; but didn't see any chashu in it!  

it's getting 3 stars because it is a cute little place, but it's not getting more stars because the food was just a-ok, we were still hungry when we left and the bill was $60, and it got really greasy smokey in there. :( 

i wanted to like this place...but I don't.  That was my first time and my last time.  Good Luck!
author: Sally T.

description:
Total fan, can you say LUB,LUB, LUB them!!! What is LUB?? It's LOVE!!! Yummy Yakitori, and I don't care what people day, but the Beatles theme rocks! But of course that's just me!! The waitress was totally sweet and it's a family owned and runned business. Delicous, bacon wrapped anything! Order it. Ramen hit the spot for me, but I missed the star because I wanted to add egg to my ramen. 
Hidden GEM!
author: Judi K.

description: So far, one of my all time favorite ramen places in the bay area. Truly a hole in the wall. Their ramen, bacon wrapped mochi and bacon wrapped scallops are delicious.  Great find!  OH and they play ALL BEATLES music. The icing on the cake! With Beatles memorabilia covering nearly every inch of wall space.
author: Rob L.

description:
I've lived in the Richmond district for over 13 years & believed I knew every Asian restaurant in it, Japanese and otherwise.  I am still confounded that I never noticed this Nihongo hole in the wall joint on my bike route to GGPark.  Amazing!  Its door has been openfor at least a year, by the accounting of other Yelpers, at it's spot just off of little Chinatown Clement Street not six blocks from my front door.  One night as I pedalled toward the Park, I peeped its twinkly lights and read the name above the door:  Halu, a different kind of Japanese restaurant.  My first thought was that Halu ramen house in San Jose had just opened a sister shop in SF.  So I rolled up and engaged the first person I spotted waiting in line to get a table.  He informed me, with a slight air of early twenties know it all cendescention that did nothing but betray his beggardly ignorance, that it was neither ramen house nor isakaya, which I had guessed at.  It was yakitori.  San.  
Needless to say, excitement instantly welled up in my being, and the image of the yakitori that I had eaten at when I walked out of the train station in Kyoto on my very first trip to Japan popp into my head.  Nostalgic feeling clouded my eyes.  I felt so happy to be smiling at this stranger and his friend, whoever they were.  They must have thought I was a mochi marshmallow.  I hope so.
Ever since that first encounter with Halu, the desire to eat it's provenance and drink it's large hot sake has hovered closely above and beside my belly.
