I wanted to stuff its hibacki grilled kabobs into my gaping pie hole yesterday, today, and tomorrow.  Nothing was going to come between me and Halu, a "different kind of Japanese restaurant."  Beatlemania be damned!
At last, it happened.  I have Bill Belichek to thank, in point of fact.  My girlfriend Julie and I had a wager on the Patriots v. Colts game, with the prize a meal at Halu.  If Mr. Bill did not opt to go for it on fourth down with 2 minutes left in the game, perhaps Julie's home state Patriots would have held on to their six point lead.  Lo, it was not meant to be.  Halu here I come!
And thankfully, the different kind of hole in the wall did not disappoint this little padawan.  Halu & it's fab five friends greeted me at the door warmly, sending one of two twin sisters to Arishay us and guide us to an open table.
The spot is tiny by SF restaurant standards, but quite roomy by hole in the wall standards.  Compared to Tekka Sushi down by the park, it's cavernous.  The color warm yellow comes to mind when one enters.  You see, as noted here, Beatles gear in all corners.  There is also a prominent Jimi Hendrix picture up, as wells a the obiquitous happy cat and cartoony godzilla figurine.  The place is candy for the eyes, true indeed.  I particularly found the wooden branch "fencing" along the back wall very pleasing to look at.  Australia came to mind.  
Julie and I ordered it up O for sure!   Large hot sake, large sapporo for drinks.  For eating, we were all about the pig!   Bacon wrapped enoki, bacon wrapped scallop, bacon wrapped mochi, oyster pork yakitori, as well as shrimp on a stick, and whatnot.  It was all very fattening!  But very good for your soul, too.  Every few years, one must go ape shit on the other white meet, don't you think?  
We tried the pizza pancake that yelpers seemed to craze on, but I personally thought it way sub par.  The very best eat of the evening:  butter fried mochi wrapped in seaweed.  Now if you like mochi, seaweed, & butter,  with sauce served up Japanese style, you're gonna absolutely jizz over this one.  Your eyes will roll back in your head , no doubt! 
I'm glad I finally got to eat Halu.  The bill was not exactly a bargain, it was still worth every dollah dollah bill yo!  The service was polite and familial.  After all, this is a spot run by a single family.  If you arrive at dinner time, plan to wait.  One piece of advice:   if it's busy, order everything at oned.  That said, this place is good and true.  You'll love it.  Believe.
author: Roland C.

description:
Been trying the different places along Clement since its my neighborhood. Stumbled on this one right when they opened.

Damn, it is good.

The skewers are so juicy and full of flavor. The panko batter has a perfect crisp while the meat or vegetable is very tender.

I will definitely be going back here to try some of the other skewers that I did not try this time. Order the Echigo beer, awesome.
author: Seth H.

description:
I'm not a big fan of ordering ramen at restaurants, but I decided to embrace this whole "no sushi allowed" japanese thing and order it anyway.  Given the scant selection of main courses, I didn't have much choice.

The two stars are for their flavorful shrimp yakitori--one per yakitori.  But the praise pretty much ends there.

My friend and I were one of two parties to arrive right when the place was opening for the night.  Yet, it took them about twenty minutes to come out with our appetizers, and then probably an additional fifteen to twenty to come out with our ramen.  I mean, it's just ramen.  Although, I suppose we were lucky, as the groups that arrived later suffered a longer wait.

And when our ramen finally did arrive (it apparently did not matter which one you ordered), HOLY COW it was salty!  Well, not salty, but sodium-ie in that Asian sort of way.  And, I'm Korean, too. That's saying a lot.

The waitress brought us hot water to take with our sake.  We were please to find that said hot water, when generously added to our ramen broth, produced a palatable dilution.  At that point, though, we were giddy drunk and just playing with our food.
author: Anna L.

description: O Halu!  you and I have a love/hate relationship.  Sometimes you treat me bad, and sometimes you treat me great.  Well, tonight, you did good.  Ramen was delicious.  The extra piece of pork on the bottom of bowl, when I least expected it, made my night.  The extra staff person you hired that spoke little english, made service a bit speedier.  I love it.  No monotheistic converstions about the ramen gods, and their powers to satisfy.  Just take my order, get it right, and bring it to me hot and tasty.
author: Jeff H.

description:
BACON. WRAPPED. MOCHI.

nuff said. i think they forgot about our order at points, but they were super apologetic. no matter. i will wait a thousand years for roasted seaweed wrapped soy and butter crusty chewy mochi, sweet and salty trumpet mushrooms... mmm.
author: Sita B.

description:
holy crap i don't remember the lava ramen to be that spicy.

solidly destroyed me (in a good way)
author: Jeff N.

description:
Stumbled onto Halu as I was trying to find a good izakaya-ish place, and Oyaji is closed on Tuesdays. I'd read that the place wasn't really set up for groups, but of course, I brought in a party of 8. It was the best thing ever.

Long story short, the staff was very accommodating and friendly, the food was outstanding, the vibe was fun and the bill was reasonable. True, it's a bit of a hassle when you've got more than 4 people, but this is my new favorite thing in San Francisco. Butter mochi wrapped in nori? Everything wrapped in bacon?  Holy mackerel, just go already.
author: dan t.

description:
I'm the kind of gal who loves variety in my meals (family style eating, 3 course meals, and straight up "give me a bite of your food now!"), so when I'm craving non-sushi Japanese food, I always find myself at Halu. Last night's meal tasted even better than I remember even though I've had most of the same grilled items before. Even without bacon wrapped everything, the meats and vegetables are perfectly seasoned. You can see the "good salt" sprinkled on the beautifully presented skewers. When I skewer meat, it's never that pretty... I would never attempt to butterfly a chicken wing. Other delicious grilled items include stuffed mushrooms, shishito peppers (apparently only 1 of 5 are actually hot), and I always forget what those little silver fish that always seem to be pregnant are called. 

And when the small yakitori items are not enough, we always order a bowl of the chashu ramen. Delicious chewy noodles with piping hot broth. And really what sent me there was Omar's review of their new okonomiyaki (no curry last night). How many places in the bay area actually have this? They were also offering up a stew later that night. I'm sure having such a small kitchen makes it easier for the family to really experiment with the dishes they cook at home. You can easily eat here for $20/person without alcohol. 

I'm no music aficionado at all, lazily listening to radio and whatever friends download onto my laptop. But I grew up loving old time Rock 'n Roll, Motown, doo wop, etc. I cry a little inside whenever another member of the Four Tops passes. It must be because I loved watching Dance Party on KOFY when I was like 8 (apparently they're rebroadcasting old episodes!). But Halu gives me that fix that I can't get anywhere else. Last night they were playing the Beatles' early Motown cover songs. And among all the Rock 'n Roll memorabilia, there are little touches of their daughters' influences (girly hearts on the specials board, leopard print menu holder). It really warms my robotic heart to see the whole family involved in the business. I love this place. 

Been listening to this as I wrote my review. Heard the Beatles' version last night, but I prefer Smokey's: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y2EsZpobWJs
author: Mimi L.

description:
This place is great for small groups/couples. The fried chicken ramen is amazing, as are the bacon wrapped scallops.... If you like 60s memorabilia and the Beatles, this is the place for you. It's fun, fast, and friendly.... 
Don't expect sushi although it's a Japanese Restaurant.
author: Angela M.

description:
Friendly service and tasty yakitori. Not many authentic Japanese yakitori places in SF. I usually get the gyu-tan, harami, tontoro, mochi bacon, yamaimo and age-dashi tofu.

Don't come here for the ramen because it's not good. Come here for the Yakitori.
author: Kei T.

description:
Just came back from Halu and $70 (for 2) will buy you a lot of food.  Highlights of the evening are as follows:

Okonomiyaki--the pancake was a little thinner than what you'd expect but that just means the sides were nicely crisped.  Also, the chef drizzled a ton of mayo on top and was very generous with the seaweed powder so though it lacked the usual protein, the pancake was very yummy.  

Beef tongue yakitori--if you're not squeamish about eating beef tongue, I'd highly recommend this dish.  It had a great chewy texture and was very well seasoned.  

Chicken skin yakitori--the skin was lightly salted and grilled to perfection!  Not overly chewy or charred.

For all the sake lovers out there, Halu has quite an extensive sake selection.  In fact, it carried two different varieties of my favorite sake--Hakkaisan--so thumbs up just for that.
author: Sandy W.

description:
I was in the mood for ramen and found this place on Yelp. Ramen was average, but I didn't think there was anything special about it. The food took a while to get out from the kitchen. 

What bugged me the most was that my yaki onigiri was being shown the grand tour of this tiny joint. How could two little grilled rice balls take so long to make? I finished my ramen and was still twiddling my thumbs waiting for it. My plate of yaki onigiri was brought to the table behind me and they said they didn't order it. The owner then walked the plate to the back (by the bathroom) and asked the waitress which table it belonged to. For a second time, the plate was brought back to the same exact table with the owner insisting it was theirs. A couple minutes later the waitress took it from the table and plopped it in front of me. For real? I really wanted to like this place, but it just wasn't meant to be.
author: Adelina W.

description:
Yay for the cute sister waitresses.

Yay for the meat on a stick.

Yay for the dark Sapporo.

Meh for The Beatles.

The ramen is not the best but you shouldn't be going there for the ramen.
author: Evan W.

description:
Awesome broth for the Karage Ramen (spicy or normal).  Kushi dishes are tasty (try the shiso beef or the butter soy mochi!)

Nice folks too.
author: Amelia C.

description:
Although the server did not want to give me the secret recipe to the salad dressing, I still have to give 4 stars to Halu!  And once more I would like to remind everyone again that Halu does not serve SUSHI. 

On a cold, rainy Saturday night, I walked in to this little hole-in-the-wall and was greeted by "We do not serve sushi" sign plastered on the door. The warmth of the restaurant and the Beatles memorabilia scattered throughout the walls and on the shelves transported me to a small shop in 60's Tokyo.  Maybe its the food, maybe its the staff, or maybe even the Beatles drumset, but there's something about these yakitori specialists that give Halu an authentic charm.

By no means am I a yakitori specialist, but what I do know is that I love the way Halu does it! I could eat a dozen of those skewers in one sitting if you let me. Halu's agedashi tofu and spicy ramen is pretty bomb too! 

Hopefully during my next visit, they'll reveal their secret dressing recipe to me. :)
author: Lisa T.

description:
BEST RAMEN IN SAN FRANCISCO
easily.  hands down.  Well textured (just chewy enough) noodles, in a nice rich, thick, sesame heavy broth.  Really good.  I prefer their shoyu to their miso stock, but they're both excellent.

Gotta thank nobu-dono for the rec for the tori-momo.  You have to ask for the shiso sometimes, because I've had it before without asking for it, and it didn't have anything on it.

shige and mimi (the owners/chefs) are super friendly and make some seriously awesome food.  Great skewers, both grilled and fried.  Very authentic food.  I love coming here, and the prices are reasonable--usually coming to about $20-30 a person if you order lots of skewers like me.  If you just do ramen and other dishes it will be considerably cheaper.  less than $20.

shige is the drummer for the Shitones, a sorta spin-off band from the more famous Mermen (they have the same guitarist).  So you'll find he plays lots of great beatles tunes in the restaurant, and has lots of great rock paraphernalia on the wall  .

My favorite skewers (they're all good, but these are my fave)
1) chicken hearts
2) chicken gizzard
3) momo (chicken thigh)
4) short ribs
5) pork and onion
6) bacon and enoki
7) shishito (grilled hot peppers... really really good, and not too hot)

and yes, THEY HAVE ECHIGO.  I hope they get Hitachino soon, and then they will be complete!!!

You seriously can't lose with this place.  great food, comfortable environment, friendly service, good prices.
author: Fong L.

description:
+1 star just for the Beatles!

Came here recently after reading all the positive Yelp reviews.

They took over the tiny space for the restaurant that I can't even remember that took over from Mama-San a few years ago.  Still miss the family feel of that place.

My friend and I ordered a whole bunch of Yakitori to share.  They were all quite good.  ESPECIALLY ...  Bacon wrapped scallops ... love scallops ... and bacon wrapped ANYTHING's always awsome.

Will be back again to try their ramen.

They're actually a 5 star (if you add that Beatles 1 star) ... but I'll probably re-evaluate after my ramen trip.
author: Winnie C.

description:
After much anticipation and many failed attempts at coming here (the past few times I've come they've been closed), I finally got to try it!

GF and I were looking for something to eat and after driving by decided this was the spot. The ambiance is small, but homey, with lots of Beatles memorabilia all over the place. 

The ramen was mediocre at best, but I guess that's expected. 

The Yakitori was what stole the show. Each piece, no matter what we got, was nicely seasoned, but only enough to give you a slight contrast as to what you were supposed to be tasting. Some light char on the outside, juicy meats, what else could you ask for? Oh yeah, a large Asahi. That's a must.
author: Derrick L.

description: so disappoited by the food.. skewers were salty. didnt finish the ramen. never gonna be here again.
author: Sunny S.

description: The ramen was substandard, the broth had no taste, while the noodles were too hard. After mentioning this to the waiter, the owner came out to argue about the quality of their food. Appalling attitude!
author: Ivo D.

description:
I had a phase where I was pretty obsessed with Ramen.  I had a craving for good Japanese ramen for practically every other meal.  One day I decided to Yelp which was the top rated Ramen place in SF and stumbled upon this little Jewel in the inner Richmond...Boy was I excited.

My friend and I drove all the way out here and found parking in a jiffy.  We quickly walked to the tiny hole-in-the-wall restaurant, noticing the Beetles memorabilia everywhere.  Not exactly sure how this relates to Japanese ramen, but cool nonetheless.

I ordered the Karaage ramen (imagine popcorn chicken in ramen).  It was delicious!  Seriously one of the best bowls of Ramen I've ever had.  To quote tonight's episode of How I Met Your Mother, "This is so good it makes me wanna staple my ass shut." Seriously - it was that good. The broth had the perfect amount of flavor, the chicken expertly fried, and the ramen had a very nice level of tenderness.  The portion was definitely filling enough for dinner, but I was definitely glad that I had yakatori as an appetizer.

The only negative is that the chefs took a bit long to get the food out.  We waited about 20-25 minutes after we ordered to finally get our ramen.  However, it was worth the wait.  If you're having a random craving for ramen, or you are simply a ramen fanatic, you should definitely make your way to Halu!
author: Johnson L.

description:
I first have to say that I love the vibe in this small place. Talk about a hole in the wall that explodes with personality.

.Sacrilege to some, but I have yet to meet a Japanese ramen bowl that I love, so I've chosen not to get them anymore.

So when my ramen fiend of a friend brought me here, I was super happy that they had donburis that would let me try their fried food.  I got the first donburi, which comes with brown rice, fried chicken and a salad. 

The fried chicken was flavored extremely well - it had a salty tang that was anchored by the brown rice, and the dressing on the salad was light and flavorful as well.  Overall a very balanced, healthy and satisfying dish. 

Serves great honest food in an honest way - they don't make it until you order it, and while you wait you can check out the Beatles decor that's hanging off every nook and cranny.

Get there early and go for a table in the back. This place is popular, so if you sit near the door, it'll be constantly opening and blasting you with cold air from outside.
author: Lucia C.

description:
What an awesome place! :)  Fun interior, good service, good variety of food choices (appetizers, skewers, ramen, etc.) and a bunch of specialties. I asked whether they had BBQ beef tongue skewers, and they did! They also had chicken intestines, etc. .. special stuff that's not on the menu :)

Ordered the spicy ramen with chicken as well, which was great. Really spicy, and didn't feel too heavy.

The atmosphere is a lot of fun. Beatles and Jimmy Hendrick posters all over the place, and Beatles music in the background.

Will definitely go there again.
author: Abid M.

description:
Halu looks like a quiet unassuming restaurant from the outside, but on the inside, it's bursting with personality, flavor and an intimacy that will fog up your glasses.

My party of 3 quickly ordered nearly 10 things off the menu as everything sounded damn good. My favorite izakaya odds and ends were present- heart, gizzards, and tongue served with the right amount of salt and grilling. The ramen was pretty good, not mindblowing. The staff was genuinely friendly and awesome. All in all, this was a dining experience straight out of a Murakami novel, set in San Francisco.
author: Derek L.

description:
"You Won't See Me" refuse ramen and yakitori, especially if the place that carries those dishes is a quick walk from Kate V's flat. If the prices won't upset "The Tax Man" and the menu includes "Piggies" in a few moist and tender forms, I'd be "The Fool on the Hill" to not give it a try. In fact, "The Two of Us" had been talking about eating at this place together for a few weeks prior to my stay in San Francheesy. We even invited "That Boy," who gets the shakes if his diet lacks ramen over the course of a week or so despite his introduction to the particular soup not too "Long Long Long" ago. The power of hot soup and meat makes even the most diverse of individuals "Come Together."

However, we heard absolutely zero songs by the Beatles when we made it to Halu. They were playing an assortment of surf rock arrangements of vaguely familiar songs. I can't be sure whether I'm disappointed by this soundtrack or relieved. I became irrationally fond of the unmanned drum set with a purple cymbal positioned up in a loft.

But of course, you can't dine on trappings alone. We each ordered different bowls of ramen as well as asparagus-wrapped bacon on skewers. You would expect me to fall head over heels with bacon-wrapped-anything on skewers, but I just fell in like. The bacon grease didn't sap the 'gus of its natural crunch or freshness, so it had that going for it. The flavor just turned out to be more subtle than I expected for a bacon yakitori. That's probably a wise choice, because the ramen portions are hefty and could easily suffice as meals by themselves. I approved of the large amounts of noodles, bamboo shoots, and surprising add-in's (who knew corn in ramen would work out?) in each bowl. Now I suspect my salt tolerance is higher than most others', evidenced by my being raised on spam and Sapporo Ichiban top ramen. But the deeper I got into my char-siu bowl, the more the sodium content cloyed. This might not be so bad if the saltiness enhanced the flavor of the broth, but I found the soup's taste to be, again, kind of light. I'd return for another meal, but I'd want to check out other izakayas first. Definitely not an "Eight Days a Week" destination but I hope "Something" about it changes my mind.
author: Kimberly V.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here after reading the Yelp reviews. We both love ramen, which is what we ordered. Neither of us was impressed with the taste of the broth or consistency of the noodles. Actually, everything tasted very salty. Maybe we came on an "off" night. I'm willing to give it another try.

As another reviewer noted, the decor is a little strange. The service also wasn't too great on the night I was there.
author: Ellen S.

description:
We ordered:

1. Karaage Ramen: Very good, flavorful broth, yes it was a little greasy but c'mon.. there's fried chicken in there! and the noodles were just the right consistency.

2. Grilled Mochi: Too salty, we should have ordered the Erichan special instead (has butter and is fried)

Now for the yakitori items:
1. Shiso chicken thigh: I loved it, the shiso adds an interesting kick to the flavor
2. Grilled peppers: The best item of all the yakitoris, MUST TRY
3. Stuffed mushrooms: OMG! Indeed this is the most juiciest stuffed mushroom I've ever had, very good.
4. Shrimp: I wouldn't order this again, after trying new Caledonia shrimp at Sumiya in the South Bay, this just doesn't match up
5. Short ribs: A-OK.. not that great
6. Chicken wings: A-OK.. again not that great
7. Pork with onion: Flavorful, but a little salty for me

There are more but it was ordered by my gf so I'll leave her to review the rest (mostly gizzards)...

The service was great, very friendly, feels like I'm eating at someone's home since it was so cozy (it seats about 20 people in there i think). We got our food pretty quickly since we arrived at opening time and beat the crowd =) The Beatles obsession is rather apparent here as well.. but that doesn't bother me as long as long as the music sounds pleasing. 

An important note: Do keep track of what you ordered and make sure it reflects correctly in the bill, although unintentional, they did mess up on our bill since there was an item that didn't arrive but we were charged anyways. We ordered quite a lot and the bill came out to be around $70 plus with tips... not too bad.

 Overall, I might return primarily for the karaage ramen and just a couple of item from the yakitori list.
author: Kym L.

description:
I like the food here and like the atmosphere. Seems like a traditional Japanese restaurant with Surfboards hanging on the walls and ceilings. I suppose the restaurant is Hawaiian themed.

The ramen here was filling, they give you decent sized portions. It's a great place to go when you're hungry and happen to be in the area.
author: Raymond L.

description:
the ramen broth is super oily! 
ramen dojo in san mateo FTW!

the bacon wrapped mochi is pretty good though. for that, i give 1 star.
I give 1 additional star for the good decor.
author: Cicely T.

description:
The 4 star rating is not really for the food which I would consider more of a 3 star execution but is for what the restaurant has to offer.  While most think Japanese food is teriyaki, sushi and tempura...there is really so much more.  Various grilled mochi, onigiri and of course the yakitori are available.  The place is the old location of Mama-san, which many will miss as an inexpensive but chill J-restaurant in a sea of low priced Chinese restaurant.  The owners of Halu have kept the warm feeling of a neighborhood place and have made it their own personality.

The space is decorated with Beatles and other 60-70 rock memorabilia.  You have to love a place like this.  It's a find.  Relax, have a beer and eat sticks of yakitori.
author: Laurence H.

description:
I am an Izakaya gigolo. All I need are some friends, sake, beer, yakitori, small plates to share, and I'm fine. I truly enjoy drinking with friends at Izakayas because you share stories, talk shit, laugh, and snack on good eats without getting too full so you can still pound sake and beer. 

I came to Halu for the first time on a Saturday night a few months back to meet up with the other Euge, Jen D., Seong, and her friend. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz/jen-d-san-francisco#hrid:aVr-zIEFRcNtSByCK_0vGg

http://www.yelp.com/biz/euge-l-san-francisco#hrid:9H0iuGJ-yTLo3lAV5nFE8g

http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=XkLK2iBsgqF6mWwDfRgqqQ

We had a great time and ordered so much food I can't even remember everything we ate. Wait, I don't even remember if I paid or not. I hope I did because I was really buzzed when we left.  

Good times...
author: Geezy B.

description:
Dropped by on a Saturday night with a close friend. Started off with Shochu mizuwari style.

We ordered an appetizer and various grilled items as well as okonomiyaki, grilled mochi and ochazuke to finish it off.

The vibe is wonderful and cozy. Atmosphere is top notch and if you are a fan of the 60s and the Beatles, even better. I wish they played more of the later Beatles music as the poppy stuff can get a bit tiresome. Luckily, it's quite easy to tune out.

Owned by a husband/wife team, and what looks like their daughters as waitresses, service is friendly and very very warm. I felt like this was one of the hipper downtempo places you see popping up in Japan lately in the Koenji/Shimokita area (ie, reggae bars, themed yakitoris) run by very cool people.

So why the 3 stars? Well, they get everything right, EXCEPT the food. I hate to be picky, but this is what Yelp is for right?

Firstly, the Yakitori wasn't cooked on a true Charcoal grill, so you don't get the smokey flavor that is intrinsic to eating grilled meat. Secondly, everything was much to salty and while this is great with beer, it was just a bit too much.

The Okonomiyaki was decent, but not fluffly enough to really enjoy the batter and ingredients. Ochazuke was quite salty too that I couldn't enjoy the crisp taste of the tea and subtlety of the rice. I really enjoyed the Mountain potato appetizer. It was fresh and lightly garnished with seasoning so I could really appreciate the texture.

It's hard to give a place negative review when everything else is so right on. Complimentary edamame, pickled cabbage and friendly service/atmosphere. 

This is a place if I lived next door, you'd probably find me here often. Solid neighborhood joint. It's a shame it's ALMOST perfect.
author: Sean L.

description:
Fellow yelper Todd L. and I had just been to Rossi Pool for a swim. It had been the kind of swim that made my legs quiver, and I was very excited about eating. 

Almost everything we considered was either inundated with drunk people pretending to be Irish or closed. Then, when we had almost given up, we saw Halu. We decided to give peace a chance.

Halu is an entirely 60's themed Izakaya bar. It's also a total hole in the wall - with a giant flat screen TV. We had a bottle of very enjoyable (only $8!) junmai ginjo style sake. We snacked on edamame, which were not too salty, nutty and perfectly cooked. We also had agadashi tofu, which we enjoyed. 

I was very excited about their miso soup. Miso soup is usually just a bit more exciting than green tea. This broth was flavorful and delicate, and the mushrooms in the soup were eye-catching and tender.

We had three yakitori - two short rib and one chicken. I was full, but I wanted a big pile of them. The chicken yakitori was slightly sweet, with caramelized green onion. The short rib was just an excellent use of salt, beef and a stick.

The service is terrific. Our waitress was helpful, quick, patient, and most of all, totally adorable.
author: H G.

description:
Omg its been too long since I've been here!

Decided to walk over one night with my boyfriend as I was living nearby at the time. The place is so cute!! I love love the Beatles theme and everyone working there seemed really nice and friendly. 

My boyfriend had the yakitori combination where you choose like 7 different ones, they were ALL delicious. I definitely need to visit this place again soon! Highly recommended if you like non-sushi Japanese food and the Beatles. :)
author: Michelle R.

description:
Cutesy. Artsy. Classic.

Walls dizzily plastered with colorful Beatles paraphernalia, cute but random Japanese trinkets and an assortment of colorful bottled sake lining the bar, faux brown bamboo sticks adorning the back wall - this is what I imagine a real Japanese ramen house to look like.

Our server was kind enough to move an extra table from a dining table of 2 to accommodate our 6 (hope that didn't prompt a bad yelp review on their end!) and sweetly forewarned us that our entrees would be staggered due to the small kitchen.  Thanks for the heads up! 

The food wasn't too impressive but the ambiance and service were memorable.  Good for low key date or small group outing.  No wait for our party of 6 at 9PM on Friday night, but no open tables thereafter except at the bar seats.

Veggie Rice bowl - flavorful Asian sauce with canned varietal mushrooms over brown rice and leafy green salad.

Chasu Ramen - Tough slices of pork with half boiled egg, assorted veggies in a saturated-with-sodium-and-various-flavors broth.

$8-10 for ramen and rice bowls, $3-5 for skewers.
author: Jane L.

description:
So many multi-star ratings. I think we must have gone on an off night.
I was really excited to finally try Halu after a couple of friends recommended it. I took my 93 year old mom. We went on a Thursday evening. As we were walking up 2 women were leaving. A server came after them and as my mom walks slowly with a cane we heard most of the conversation. The server asked if everything was alright, the women said yes, but they didn't want to stay. The server said "I know it's crowded, but you can sit at the counter" (the very tiny too close for comfort counter -as it turned out) or  wait for a table though she couldn't say when one would be free. The women declined. The server asked if she had been rude to them. They assured her that that wasn't the case, but that the counter felt  "too claustrophobic." They left. 
On that note my mother and I entered the restaurant and another server pointed to the counter area by the door where there were three padded free standing stools and one hard wooden stool that was attached to the bar so couldn't be moved. Even though tricky for mom to maneuver we sat at the counter leaving one padded stool between her and the man seated at the next stool (otherwise they would have literally been touching that's how tight the space is) and the wooded stool on my right. We were given menus. About 10 minutes later a single man came in. The server who had been outside talking with the people that left greeted him and after a minute she asked my mom and I to move to our right so that he could sit down. I was irked, (we hadn't been greeted, nor offered anything to drink, but I moved onto the wooded stool to find it just as uncomfortable as it looked plus it was a couple inches lower than the other stools. I stated that the stool was not comfortable and that I didn't want to move, but the server just looked at me like "too bad." My mom tried to get up to move, but was struggling , but still the server didn't change her mind. That really got me , so I suggested to my mom that we leave and although she/we were hungry and had wanted to try and like Halu, she agreed. We slowly made our way out without a thanks or sorry or please come again. No one came out after us to ask if they'd been rude. I don't know why the sub-standard, uneven treatment. Was it age-ism? We were the oldest people there. Was it racism? No, mom's Japanese and I'm half and the other customers/servers were either White or Asian. Hmm, why???? This was just about the worst service we've ever gotten. 
Maybe we'll try Halu again one day, but most likely not. SF has too many really good restaurants with way better service.
author: Sarita E.

description:
Dear Halu, 

I'm extremely happy that Eugy has found a place that he loves to eat at that won't make either of us go broke, but do you think you could lay off a little? He comes over 3-4 times a week these days and it's always when I'm working. 

And just last night, he was talking about you in his sleep. Something about "At Halu.... get the chicken skewers... and find someone who uses a camera..." 

I don't know what you did to your chicken skewers and I don't want to even think about what you do with cameras and my wonderful boyfriend, but I would appreciate it if you only allow him to come over 1-2 times a week. And no cameras!

kthxbaiz

PS
Your jalapeno sauce is TO DIE FOR!!!!
author: Jen D.

description: love this place. very Authentic Japanese food. place is small but i like that feeling. waitress were friendly. don't go if you have a big group.
author: B B.

description:
Like Murasaki, good down home food and people (staff/owners.) It's good that they're not competing with similar food. That would not be a good dilemma to ponder, especially if you're a Libra like me. I'm not sure about the music or posters... But I expected something more like - http://www.goear.com/listen.php?v=bc0599c 

Not because Halu is sad or will be leaving, but because it seems so much more mellow and tranquil of a place. A place where it would be the piece de resistance of the day. 

And Piece de resistance is what Halu was yesterday. 

My Korean friend bought a Japo Motorcycle. A Honda. (Nobu can't pronounce Honda, I can't pronounce Futon. Go figure!)
He bought it from a Japo, who this Japo introduced him to.
We had Genki Ramen for lunch, while they prepped the moto. 
After lunch while we continued to wait, we played Wii (Nintendo) on a 52" Sony. 
We drove to pick up the moto in a Lexus. His trademarked forehead was protected by a Japo Shoei helmet.
And ended the day at Halu. There is no better place to end a Japo-themed day, winding down over good Japo food and Japo beer. 

Despite the obvious growing pains, Halu took care of us. The food flew out of the small prep & kitchen area, like you'd expect from a Gordon Ramsey Restaurant (less the expletives.)

We had:

Grilled chicken with brown rice -  it's just as tasty the next day
Chashu Ramen - Better than average. 
Shrimp
Ginko nuts
Grilled rib eye 
Grilled sirloin
Chicken balls 
Zucchini wrapped with bacon
Scallops wrapped with bacon

I'm not sure what else we had, but we sure had more skewers than you could shake a stick at! (I'll let someone else use the poke in the eye with a sharp stick pun.)
author: Kevo M.

description:
What to expect at a typical but authentic Japanese "yakitori" restaurant like Halu.

Negatives: 

1. Small place with limited seating --- Recommended for couples or a small group of 4-5.
2. Small plates --- Each order of skewers usually comes with 2. 
3. You will smell like the food you eat --- The grill will be right behind you or in front of you. You just can't escape the smoke. 
4. You may not be attended at all times --- Limited number of staff trying to serve multiple orders of small plates per table.
5. No sushi, teriyaki chicken or tempura --- Japanese "moms' food" and salty/oily dishes are served to go with sake and other drinks.

If you have ever been to real yakitori places in Japan, you'd know what I mean. Many are hole-in-the-wall small places with unique characters (including interiors and owners). Some can't even seat 10 people. You are supposed to spend time there chatting and drinking while waiting for skewers to come.

On to Positives:

1. Variety of dishes to choose from --- Perfect for those who want to sample little bit of everything.
2. Specials --- Make sure you look up/around for a black/whiteboard listing recommendations and seasonal dishes.
3. Freshly prepared food right off the grill--- Nothing is better than hot, a bit burnt yakitori or deep fried skewers with cold sake.
4. Quality time spent with your guests --- Don't need to scarf down your big plate of food and not speak to each other. Enjoy the time in between dishes and have some more sake.
5. You will be treated like a family --- Go there a few times, try a Japanese word or two, and you will be welcomed with smiles and remembered next time.

My husband (American) and I (Japanese) have enjoyed the food and experience at Halu from the first visit. We went without a reservation and did not have to wait to be seated or for our food (Note: went early around 6pm). We love the family helping each other and are happy to have Halu in our neighborhood. We don't like other overpriced "izakaya" restaurants in SF that serve yakitori. Minor requests I have for Halu (hence 4 stars) is to turn down the music a little and add more "gu" (e.g., veggies, fish cake) to ramen. Make sure to try deep fried stuffed mushrooms and grilled shiso chicken skewer....yum.

Check out Halu once for yourself. Just remember this is not a fancy big restaurant but a cozy relaxing family-owned place. Enjoy the food over sake and good chat with your friends and families!
author: Tomo B.

description:
Great little Japanese restaurant. Easy to miss if you aren't looking for it.
Super Kitschy in an "I Love USA although all I know about it is through the TV/radio" sort of way.  

If you are looking to try something a little different, this is the place.
Skewers are around $5 with some interesting choices like beef heart and  mushrooms stuffed with chicken and cheese then deep fried on a skewer (amazing btw)

$5.75 Large Sopporos and some authentic Japanese beers you probably haven't heard of but go great with this type of food.

Ended with a big bowl of Ramen ($9) with pieces of fried chicken which is a great way to end the meal. Nice warm tummy!

I'll definitely be back!
author: devon m.

description:
The spicy chicken kaarage ramen is great.  They use to make it in miso, but since not many people ordered it - they fully went with shio or shoyu instead.  (MISO WAS BETTER!!)

The yakitori can get a little pricey, but we all expect that when we go to these types of places.  So my top 3 choices are:

1.) Beef Tongue (packed with flavor and cooked to perfection!)
2.) Pork Jowel (Super salty goodness)
3.) Mochi Special

The okonomiyaki is good here too.

Service is friendly and great, but the place can get cramped.  There might be a wait sometimes, but I feel that it is ALWAYS worth it.

I have probably been here about 20 times (if not, more since they have opened).  If you want a place in the city for some good yakitori and ramen, just come here.
author: Bill Z.

description:
I don't understand the yakitori/kushikatsu fascination.  Each kushi, no matter what kind of meat or how it's cooked, tastes exactly the same as the kushi before it...and after it.  The only saving grace was the ponzu/mayo sauce which I wish I could swim in.  The deep fried scallops wrapped in bacon were good but I can't eat 10 sticks of those as my meal.  Or I guess I could but something would be missing.  Maybe some grilled ginkos to round out my food pyramid?  No thanks.  The ramen?  Thin broth; slightly soggy noodles; tasteless stewed pork. 

More entertaining than the food was the company.  It started out as dinner with some lady Yelpers but Yelpers are like ants.  Where there is one, there will be many.  Which made for a raucous dinner. 

I can't fault Halu for the music.  I would rather hear a Beatles' album replayed over and over than traditional (and annoying) Japanese music.  The classic rock theme and the psychedelic posters reminded me of a Japanese movie where this young Japanese couple travels to the US to find Elvis and play some ro-ku andu ro-ru.  Japanese love the West.  Which makes this decor somehow traditional.
author: Shelley H.

description:
I'm late but I'm jumping on the Halu bandwagon.  I had planned to go to dinner and then take a stroll to Green Apple because I'm looking for something.  Nice, mellow evening.  It was not to be however.  

I knew this the moment someone walked in with her own big bottle of booze with no label (Thanks, Wakako!).  It could've been moonshine or rubbing alcohol for all I knew but I drank it because there are some people I can't say no to.  I also tried Echigo for the first time.  I realized how good it was when they ran out and we switched to Sapporo.  

Onto the food:  I asked one of my dinner companions what was good since he's written so many reviews of this place, I thought he was an investor.  He said he actually hadn't had much except for some appetizers, all the yakitori, all the kushi katsu, ramen and some rice things.  Ladies and Gentlemen, that accounts for 4/5 of the menu and left out only the salads and a rice dish with no meat.  

In one night, I managed to sample the entire menu.  My favorites were:  salad with strawberries and avocado (i luv you), okra, chicken wings, stuffed mushrooms, mushroom/salad/avocado/brown rice bowl, chicken karaage and the meatballs.  Looking over my list, I pretty much liked it all except chicken gizzards, especially covered in their jalapeno sauce.  We also got ramen but that came out last and I thought I was going to die.  I need to try it again before I evaluate.

The service was slow here and there which contributed to the length of dinner but since we were chatting about all kinds of nonsense and I remember the slave labor I provided when my parents had a restaurant, I can't hold it against them.  Plus, our waitress was significantly more pleasant and accomodating throughout than I ever was.  What, it's not like I was going to get fired.

I am still stuffed and the thought of eating again is kind of nauseating but I may have to go back this weekend.  

[Hey, Hamburglar, Wako from Katana-ya came through.  She's a hawtie.  Riiiiight?!]
author: Seong P.

description:
So I do as I say. I go in for seconds to try the ramen.

We get the counter -- very uncomfortable for someone with long legs. We get our menu. Not menus. They only have one available -- this happened my first visit, as well. Place our orders -- well, attempt to. As we're giving the girl our order, customers walk in. She actually stops taking the order, goes and seats them, gives them menus, then returns to start the ordering process again. The delay doesn't really matter. It takes a good thirty minutes for the first dish to arrive: the daikon salad...

The daikon salad isn't so good. The vinagrette dressing is a bit bland, and the dish itself tastes more like a radish salad -- it's not just sliced Oriental daikon, but Occidental radish as well. The radish is strong, bitter, and a mismatch for the more delicate daikon. Both are called radishes, but they have very different tastes.

My Ramune-hai (Japanese lime soda with shouchuu) -- not bad. Not bottom of the barrel soju. The tea we ordered? It never arrived -- this almost happened my first visit, as well. (We got tea at the very end of the meal the first time.)

The chashu shoyu ramen -- the broth was cloudy, a sign that the soup probably boiled over. It also didn't have a strong pork flavor -- not enough bones. The fresh Chinese egg noodles were fine. What bothered me the most was the too-fibrous, hard menma (bamboo shoots) from a can -- the kind you find in Chinese stores in the little tins used for stir fry, and not the ones used for ramen.

To finish things off, we tried the sake yaki onigiri (grilled salmon rice balls). I've never had an onigiri where the salmon was in little bits spread throughout the rice ball, as opposed to the normal way with salmon in the middle. And I've definitely never had a salmon onigiri with bones in it before... As for the yaki (grilled) part -- it was barely grilled. The rice was barely browned, and there definitely was no crunch to it. Definitely the weakest dish of the night.

Yeah, I think 1.5 star average is about right...
author: Perci N.

description:
My girlfriend and I just wanted to grab dinner on a weekday and she thought about this ramen place that she heard about. On top of that, we were both feeling like ramen that night. Just a note on parking, it could be challenging since Halu is located near the corner of 8th and Clement. We were just fortunate to find a spot right outside the restaurant. 

Alright, on first impression, Halu felt and looks like a hole-in-the-wall establishment. Despite the "rundown" look and tight interior space, Beatles fans will appreciate the many novelties ranging from posters of the British rock band to the choice of Beatles music over the speakers. Several other interesting decorations also include a giant poster of Jimi Hendrix and The Who. They even have a left-handed stratocaster hanging next to the Hendrix poster. One might have their attention divided between the menu and the posters just as I was distracted myself.

Now on with the food! Four selections were made and it is as follows: Shrimp and Steak Yakitori, Cha Shu Ramen and Onomiyaki. The Shrimp Yakitori was simply shrimp tempura on a skewer. Only thing was that the shrimp wasn't all that big, but it was tasty. It came with a dish with a horseradish based sauce and some other sauce, which I can't remember because the horseradish was awesome. The Steak Yakitori was much much better than the shrimp. Very juicy and tender plus it was the perfect mate for the horseradish! The only problem was the portions. Not very big nor cheap. Regardless of that, it was amazing.

I tried a little bit of the ramen (girlfriend ordered it) and it wasn't too bad. The ramen was at the right amount of chewiness and had a good bounce to it. The broth was flavorful. Portions wise, it fared better than the yakitori, but that's rather an unfair observation since ramen is more entreé than appetizer.

Yes, I ordered the Onomiyaki despite my ramen lust. It's just a matter of fact that onomiyaki doesn't come by as often as ramen does, so why pass a chance to have something different? My Onomiyaki was satisfying. Simple dish with the usual stuff, drizzled with a sweet and salty sauce, that I can't put a name with, and mayo. Only thing is that they could go easy on the sauce. First bite is great until the sauce catches up with you and after that the saltiness can be overwhelming.

Overall, Halu is good, but thanks to my Americanized bias on Japanese food as big and deep-fried, my appreciation for Halu goes as far as I can to try and savor the flavor rather than to stuff myself silly with ridiculous portions. Regardless, Halu has my vote for fresh and flavorful Japanese food.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
Ask and you shall receive!!  Yes, Halu now has shochu by the bottle. Thank you very much.  

This is my favorite restaurant in SF for various reasons...#1 reason being I love the family running this business.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Definitely not your typical Japanese restaurant - but quite charming. The Beatles theme gives it a unique vibe. I had some difficulty deciphering the menu, which made it hard for me to order, but with the help of some friends I ordered what I believe was mushroom donburi, with four different types of mushrooms. It was tasty. The green tea was possibly the best I've had. The miso soup was a little salty, but still good.

We came in here on a Friday night and as predicted, it was packed. We had to sit at the bar at first - however, the staff was kind enough to let us take a table when there was some room. Be prepared to wait. This place is popular.

Also, none of us noticed the additional menu on the wall until after we finished dinner. Slightly inconvenient, but motivation to come back here again. I just wish I'd known they served gyoza.
author: Jon C.

description:
*sigh* This place came highly recommended so I couldn't wait to try it! 
When we walked in, we thought, "wow, this place is cool, and who doesn't like the beatles?"

There are reasons why i am giving this place 3 stars. 
1.  It took approximately 25-30 minutes until we got our ramens AND the ramen came out before we got our appetizers! The kitchen looked extremely busy, like there was so much going on, but no food came out! WTF? The ramen noodles were good, the rest of it, like the soup and all were okay. 

2.  Halfway into our ramen, we finally got our tasty scallop wrapped with bacon. 

3.  We ordered the grilled fish, that was the first thing we ordered, we NEVER got the order and let them know. They completely skipped the order,  I saw them cross it off on our tab. 

Overall, food was not bad BUT service was slow, very slow, you can only look at the beatles poster so many times. If something was wrong with the kitchen, give us a bite or something, like a small plate of edamame to keep us happy.
author: Eva L.

description:
I *heart* small ramen shops. My favorite place for ramen when I was back in Japan was a tiny ramen shop near my university. The small ramen shop atmosphere cannot be beat. They always have some sort of quirky decoration scheme going on, the intimate atmosphere lets you get to talk with the ramen cooks, and you're always jockeying for space in the tiny room.

So when I first came here, I was immediately deluged with memories of that small place in Japan. Of course, it didn't have as much of a musical theme as this place, but it had Japanese wait staff, giving that much more of an authentic edge.

But yeah, the food. Despite the long wait (a very strangely long wait for a small place) I was not disappointed with the ramen that came out. I still give a slight edge to my favorite, Tanpopo, but Halu is definitely up there, a hidden gem in the RIchmond. And it does have something Tanpopo does not have, a good selection of grilled items. I'm always down for a good piece of grilled chicken, and they did it well here. It's a bit pricey, but it's a good alternative to gyoza as a ramen side dish every now and then.
author: Roland C.

description: Definitely a place I would come back to. I was worried about the service (see reviews) but our waitress was attentive and fantastic. Who knew chicken hearts could be so tasty?
author: Joe M.

description:
In My Life, I have traveled many a Long and Winding Road, and even though I've been lucky enough to have eaten at many fine establishments, there's only a few places I actually Get Back to on a regular basis, come Rain or shine.  Unfortunately, some of these places, well some have gone and some remain.  Let It Be.

Halu is a very good place not only for the food, but also because it's one of those cozy places you can bring a gaggle of people and have a grand old time.  It's a little short on the beer and sake selection for an Izakaya, but you'll get by With A Little Help From [your] Friends.

On this day, my Better Half and the Little Man accompanied me.  We were given three seats in a row at the bar.  We did have to wait what seemed like a Long, Long, Long time, but it really was just a few minutes.  The restaurant was packed that day, so the delay can be forgiven.  The waitress and everyone there was very friendly and kind, and all in all, the atmosphere is like a Yellow Submarine.

Wife and I ordered the Charsu-men.  Ah, the little Piggies who gave us their succulent souls to accompany our noodles.  Nice, fatty pork might be the best food in the world, but mix that with noodles, and it's heaven.  The broth was very flavorful, thick and rich, the noodles had an excellent consistency albeit slightly soft (preference really).

May be even better than the ramen though was the yakitori.  We ordered the Chicken Hearts, Flat Iron Steak, Short Ribs and Chicken Thighs.  All were very good.  It was a lot of food, and I Should Have Known Better, but never do.  We finished it off.  The Little Man was amazing.  He scarfed down that food like it was water.  There's definitely Something in the way the little dude can put it down.

All in all, it's one of the places I would love to go after a Hard Day's Night of work.  Grab a beer, a sake and order up some food with your friends.  In a lot of ways, it reminds me of my college days, I remember that like Yesterday, hanging out, having a good time, enjoying good food and good drink in a cozy atmosphere.  Three cheers for (or rather, four cheers) for Halu.  All Together Now.

May be they can open a branch down in the Peninsula, although there is already a ramen place called Halu in San Jose on Saratoga.  May be they can buy the name rights.  Tomorrow Never Knows.

Shout out to the Yelpers who were there that night as well.  Looks like a splendid time was guaranteed for all.

Oh, and the Beatles motif, eh, it's interesting.  ;-)
author: James K.

description:
I really wanted to like this place as it is quaint, family run and friendly. The food was good but with one MAJOR flaw, too much salt! I went here 2 times already and at first I thought it was a fluke, when I went the second time I ordered a bunch of sticks, enough for 2 people!! 

Anyway the first few sticks were great, the gizzard was cooked to perfection and so was the short rib. However mid-way though the meal BAM! a super salty beef tongue. I love salty foods and I do use a lot of salt, but even for me this was too much, it was barely edible. the other sticks were good but after a such a salty stick, my palate was kind of jarred. then came the bacon covered scallops. again, way too salty and the bacon overpowered the scallop. 

overall i liked about 70% of the food served to me, but for the prices you pay (I paid close to $50 for 1 person), having 30% of your meal almost inedible due to saltiness is not a good thing. sadly I do not think I will be coming back for a third visit.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
first time for self....izakaya ramen shack...holed location aged...slim seat barstools...small table 'n' chairs splatter....izakaya comparable/similar tradition to korean soju bang....drinking establishment serving food...yakitori (grilled chicken skewers), kushiyaki (grilled meat and vegetable skewers), karaage (fried chicken), tofu, edamane, tonkatsu (fried breaded pork), etc....added bonus being ramen....medley of grilled gizzards, wings, rib-eye, asparagus and such....$three to $five up......bowls of hearty ramen...easy $eight up....flowing cascade of sake, beer and shochu....shochu? or soju?...who copied who?...japanese or korean?

the food!...delectable chicken gizzard...chicken wings tasty...impeccable and flawless preparation to presentation....meaning?...grilling to light saucing excellent....absolute perfection....followed chashu-men....miso picking....salty thickness broth....so thick, clear skin layer forming top....previous experiencing at santa...thick cm pork chashu slabs...tender prepared suckling goodness....noodle fine and slight al dente....put it out there...fine izakaya meal had.....

non-hectic weekday dinner hours.....world olympic record breaking for longest wait after order~!@!#!!.....consider gleaming "grand openning" banner still flapping....at times quick and easy....other times waiting horror....
author: Hen A.

description:
This is the new rockers haven in the Richmond.!!   Rock posters adorn the walls,rock music is played...and a rock and roll drummer ,Shig ,cooks the amazing food.Mimi,his delightful wife is also behind the counter.
  Halu is billed as a "Different Japanese Restaurant"..meaning for me,no sushi. instead,great yakorti,deep fried or not....ramen bowls...yummy stuff. Lots of veggie options! It's a small place,between Geary and Clement on 8th avenue and there is a nearby public parking lot. High five on the scallop and bacon combo..in a word...Heaven!!
    Refreshing spin on the usual Japanese cuisine offered around the city. Casual atmosphere....fresh and innovative!!! Get hip to Halu!
author: Nan H.

description:
Even though I live within stumbling distance of Halu, my first time was just 2 weeks ago when I heard the buzzzzz. Since then I've been back 3 times and it's now on my "here's a cool place to go to in my hood" list for friends who haven't tried it.

Halu is a clear winner just for being Halu... Why? 

1) Quirky and unique atmosphere
2) Being a rare non-sushi Japanese restaurant in the Richmond. Hell, non-sushi J cuisine without going to like, San Ma-fricken-teo!!
3) Fried stuff on a stick!!

But why do I keep going back and it still just get 3 stars??

1) Menu is on the small side 
2) I haven't found something that I can cling on to and not live without
3) The chef cooks on artist's time so don't expect to get fed asap when you are starvin'.

Regardless, Halu is a great addition to the hood and I'll probably go again very soon.
author: Faffy L.

description:
Ramen wise, it's on par with Genki Ramen but not as good as Katana-Ya! We also got the pancake which was delicious. I loved the mayo design on it.  

What I liked most was the Beatles decor and mementos. They littered the quaint little restaurant and even had Beatles music too. That was a nice touch!
author: James C.

description: Halu makes me happy. I think the service is great, the food is delicious and the ambiance is cozy. A great place to share lots of different small plates and unwind with a beer or two. It's a short walk from my house so I usually go over early to try and snag a seat for my group. It's a small place, so it's good for pairs, and no more than 4 people in your party. I love the yakitori and the special mochi wrapped in nori. I tried the karaage ramen, which was good, but I prefer to stick to the other items that Halu has to offer. One of my favorite places to go when I crave Japanese izakaya food.
author: Manisha M.

description: Came here for dinner with my friend. We didn't wait long to get a seat. I could barely hear my friend talk when we were inside. I don't really care for the food...the ramen I ordered was just ok. Friendly customer service though.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
saturday nite, shop was half full...

GOOD:  chashu ramen, beatles posters everywhere, mom n pop show...

BAD:  had to remind them about our drinks, they also forgot wat drinks we ordered, had to remind them about our enoki bacon appetizer, very stuffy inside, edamame was inconsistent warm/cold...

the other dishes weren't that bad, but service killed it, sorry ladies...

8(
author: Ethan L.

description:
Came here for the first time for dinner on NYE and I'm smitten with this place.

Maybe it was the Tokyo-esque mood Halu emits.
Maybe it was simply Dad working the grill.
Maybe it was all the post-war decor ornamenting the wall.
Maybe it was the pretty, hard working daughter(?) busting her ass on NYE.
Maybe it was because every dish that we ordered, it tasted like how Mom would make it.
Maybe it was because they didn't rape my wallet like every other god damn izakaya establishment in the Bay Area.

Whatever it was that got me love drunk, I thank you for creating such a charming establishment.

Now all you need is a myspace page for me to stalk you at.
author: Tek O.

description:
I went home to SF yesterday (and while I was driving in 90 degree heat, it was nice to walk to Halu from home bundled up in a peacoat) and made it a point to eat here for dinner because of Euge's many reviews. 

I like the fact that it's a few blocks away from home which means no scrambling around Clement for parking!

We got there at a reasonable time...8:30pm-ish on Sunday night. Noticed Beatles memorabilia inside and the classic rock being played. The place itself is cozy, tiny and intimate with a mom and pop feel and there is bar seating in front of the full view kitchen as well. 

Noticed all the yakitori and kushi katsu options and couldn't wait to order away. Started off with the kara age ramen (deep fried chicken pieces). The chicken was really meaty and very seasoned. The broth was very rich and savory though it lacked a bit of saltiness. The noodles were thinner than what I'm used to but they were still good. The chashumen (cha shu ramen) had really good pork. Very fall-off-the-bone good. 

As for skewers, had the bacon wrapped scallop (nice meaty and sweet scallops), bacon wrapped enoki, chicken gizzards, shrimp and the salmon katsu. I really wanted to try the beef tongue but they were out and we canceled our order for the stuffed mushroom because we were so full that there still some salmon katsu that we didn't finish. I do want to try the other skewers that we didn't order. 

The service was great and even though I wasn't really in the mood for beer (I babysat my glass of sapporo), I'd like to come back and have some yakitori and a few bottles of beer for that true izakaya feel and the bonus part is, I don't have to worry about driving home!

Bonus star: I did some research and found out that the owner (the husband) is a drummer for a surf-rock band and that he also used to be a drummer for a Jefferson Airplane spin-off band. How cool is that?!
author: kristin e.

description:
This is a secret gem in the Richmond. Halu is tucked away on a side street off Clement, so be on the lookout for this. You might drive right past it and end up settling at Genki Ramen (which is fair in its own right).

The first thing you'll notice about Halu is its decor. We think the owners love the Beatles or something. There's Beatles pictures, album covers, and posters plastered everywhere. It's a bit random, but that's what makes this place work. The place itself is also very small. It seats no more than 20 people.

The ramen is, of course, pretty good. That's why we come here. It's top five ramen for us. Halu is still a tier below Halu (in Santa Clara) and Santa, but it holds its own in the second tier. The broth is rich but not too salty or fatty and the toppings are solid. 

The only gripe about this place is the slow service. You will understand what we mean by "slow" when you eat here. It's like eating in Europe. Then again, Halu is a small operation, so we tend to cut it some slack. We now find ways to kill the 20-30 wait (after ordering) with conversation. Perhaps that's a good thing. We always seem to get the best conversations at this place. Beatles + long wait = deep conversations

Four solid stars.
author: Kel S.

description:
I opened the door to Halu and was hit by a wave of blaring music...

"It won't be long yeah! (yeah) yeah!  It won't be long yeah! (yeah) yeah!  It won't be long yeah (yeah) til I belong to you!"

I walk in to find a cute ramen and robata joint that apparently loves the Beatles!!!  This tiny, but brightly lit, restaurant served up a decent bowl of ramen and some killer robata skewers.  

I wasn't a huge fan of the shoyu broth, but the ramen noodles were very chewy and the karage that came on the side was nicely fried, so it was a decent bowl for me.  

My dad went with the "omikase" robata meal.  They really know how to grill in that tiny kitchen of theirs!  Every skewer of food was fresh, simple and well seasoned, three signs of great robata.  Order any skewer with bacon wrapped around [insert veggie here] and you're in for a treat!  Also, I recommend trying the grilled onigiri (rice balls).  They are surprisingly good and somewhat filling.

Try to get there early since the restaurant only holds maybe 25 people and it fills up fast...plus the service is a bit slow, so it might not be the place to go if you're already starving (plus robata gets expensive if you order a lot).
author: Krystle S.

description:
Sing along kids... "We all live in a kushi katsu submarine..."  Or something like that.

They sure like The Beatles here.  F*#K off Ascap and BMI!

Had the kushi katsu.  Very fresh ingredients, fried up quite good for a "Mom and Pop" scenario.  Good portions and tasty.  The miso soup was almost your typical "nothing in it but a few bits O tofu" but the broth was really good (most places don't even bother with the broth... amateurs!).  

Chasumen was tasty.  Good broth, and it's VERY rare that I like a ramen broth outside of Japan.

One of the 3 good "family style" Japanese spots in the hood.  I'm down with it. :)
author: Dan M.

description:
The fact that Halu is on Yelp's hot list and supposedly only seats a dozen, I was tempted to call to make a reservation.  Turns out, my friend and I were the only two dining on a Tuesday night.   As a result, the waitress poured us an enormous amount of attention and care.  

Despite her good will and eagerness to please new customers (it is still a "grand opening" restaurant afterall) by explaining extensively the different dishes and her recommendations, we ordered two simple ramen noodles.   My friend had the basic ramen, and I had the cold ramen. 

The taste is on.  Often cold ramen has this tang that is superb when you are eating but leaves a pungent aftertaste in your mouth once you are done.  But in this case, the taste is rich but mild, great for a hot summer day.  

The only thing that was weird to me was the salad in the cold noodles.  I simply don't like lettuce unless it's in a regular salad, so to see leaves perching on top of the noodles just makes me want to put them aside and pretend they never existed.  

My friend had a good time with her ramen.  She cleaned the bowl. 

Lucky us also got a free appetizer: grilled chicken and mushroom.  Tasty, a bit greasy, I imagine them being perfect bar food to go along with sake or something. 

Bill was very reasonable, $7.50 for a bowl of ramen.  We took our time and sat around and chatted.  I almost felt bad when the waitress asked if we wanted some tea---it seems like she is doing an awful lot of work for our pathetic $20 dinner.  

But, I am sure business will pick up---ramen on 8th and Clement?  Seems like a good business idea.  And I will be happy blending in with average diners slurping noodles--no special treatment.
author: Candice B.

description: I know everyone talks about how awsome this place is and I'm not disagreeing I just think it's been overhyped.  I like the kitschy Beatles decor and music.  I sort of like the hipsters eating ramen at the bar.  Some of my food was really good, some of it just tasty because I like meat on sticks and fried stuff.  Not as special as I thought it would be but maybe I'll give it another try and order some different things.  The waitresses were very kind and service was good, plus my parking karma got us a spot right in front.
author: Poppy C.

description:
I've been waiting for a while to write this review because after my first time here I was so giddy with the experience that I could've only attributed it to some magical combination of endorphin rush, sugar high and crack. How could a restaurant possibly make you feel these things? I couldn't decide if it was the food, the beatles blasting through the speakers, or maybe just the other people in the restaurant. In the end it's probably useless to try and disentangle all the stimuli, so I'm just going ahead with the facts. Fact: I've now been here twice and decided that it's my new favorite local - no, scratch that - all time favorite japanese place. Fact: this place is small and easy to miss, and I've been walking by it forever, so thank you yelp(ers) for helping me find things in my neighborhood.  

Food Picks: Okonomiyaki is nice and thin. Slightly crispy on the outside giving way to soft innards. Good ratio of batter to vegetables and other stuff. The chef likes his worchestershire and mayo, so if you like things light like me, better ask em to take it easy with the sauces. 

Vegi-Don with slices of avocado and brown rice (among other vegetables). This isn't for the same person who's ordering the deluxe yakitori dinner package, and it isn't meant to be, but it's very good in its own right. 

Chicken gizzard yakitori. I'm not entirely sure what a gizzard is, but it sure tastes good when prepared on their grill. Its got a texture similar to liver, but with a little more bite, and possibly more gamey. 

Drink Pick: Echigo. It's like Singapore's Tiger beer, but a bit less hoppy and a little more sweet. Get it in a tall boy bottle, or as they say in japan, tall for asia but still short compared to the rest of the world.
author: Alan L.

description:
I cant rave enough about this place.  The food here is great, fabulous Japanese Yakitori dishes and straight out of asia, beer and sake selection. Family run by two super cute sisters and their mom. The personal touch is fabulous with the beatles theme overtaking the place. 

 I will never forget my first time at Halu...and I will most definately add it to my list of favorite small eat spots in the world!! 

 Domo ladies... keep up the great work.
author: Charlie B.

description:
We both got a couple yakitori, kushi katsu - he got deep fried, and I got regular - both were delicious.  My favorite was the stuffed mushroom - stuffed with chicken.   I also had flanksteak, which was good, too.   It was flavorful - I saw other skewers that I wanted to try but didn't get to, like the asparagus wrapped in bacon, so that just means I'll have to come back!

I'm curious about the ramen, but I'm going to have to get through all the yakitori before I get to that.  The only thing I didn't like was the miso -- it was too salty for me - I'm not sure if it was supposed to be like that.  They put onions in it, and I appreciated that.

I liked their extensive drink list --- I kind of would like to just come back for drinks at some point.  I had  a Shochu cocktail...and I really, really liked it.  They even had Ramune cocktails!!!  (the Japenese bottled drink that is sealed with a marble)  They had barley, potato, and sake alcohol

I loved the Beatles theme, including the Beatles drumset above, the Japanese Beatles posters, and the guitars on the wall.  They also play Beatles music the entire time.  It's also just a cute little Japanese restaurant space.  It's lit just right, and so cozy.

Ambiance is huge for me, so I really liked it in here.

Also, for whatever reason, I like the fact that you can walk by and completely not notice that it was there.
author: Liz C.

description:
Go here.
they are hella nice
they rock veggie options
and....
all they play are beatles songs all night
i felt like i was in tutti frutti or toy boat, but eating great food

hella local. hella oldschool. hella down with supporting both
trendy is ok... but these guys are classic
author: Isao K.

description:
Even in cosmpolitan San Francisco, it seems ethnic restaurants feel obliged to look like an American idea of ethnic restaurants, e.g. for Japanese eateries, that often means dressing things up with lanterns, kanji and the like. Halu, though, lets its food do the talking while it fufills its fetish for Beatles, Hendrix and other 60's rock icons. It's like "Hell yeah, we're Japanese, we don't need to write it on our foreheads." So points for that.

More importantly, the food is awesome. Love the skewers, though i always peak with the pork ramen (spicy-version requested). Very tasty and hearty.

Service is also great and I love the cozy atmosphere, though hereinlies Halu's one fault. The place is so tiny getting a seat can be a challenge, and even if you do, you'll often find yourself shivering in the seats by the door. They really need to invest in some sort of double-glazed, insulated door cause even when its closed you can definitely feel the Richmond Chill creeping in. Till then, I make a point of arriving with a sweater or jacket.

But that's a minor ding, otherwise one of my favorites restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Sam S.

description:
Wow, I really dig this place. The ramen is more delicious than Genki (nearby in the hood). You can tell the stock is made with love. Reminds me of that movie Tampopo.

I like ordering off the specials board. You gotta trust in the man... he's decided what you should really be eating today. 

On my last trip, I had the Volcano Ramen. I love spicy and this defeated me, but that only made me love it more. Afterall, who doesn't love to order something called a "volcano". I also loved the special mochi that was wrapped in salty nori, perhaps brushed with shoyu and grilled. Usually Japanese folks are shy about seasoning mochi, but this version was umamilicious!!!! I also had great pork fat skewers (also a special).

Great authentic ramen shop, good yakitori, perfect for cold SF nights.... let's keep this one alive, people!
author: Lauren H.

description: The grilled skewers were good but I decided that it wasn't my thing.  I am really picky with ramen so I wasn't into that either.  I wouldn't rule out a return visit if I was craving yakitori or wanted to try more things on the menu (like the okonomiyaki!).  It's definitely cozy and charming, a nice change if you're in the mood.
author: Erika C.

description: This ramen joint is tiny and narrow with so much Beatles and classic rock memorabilia on the walls making it seem even more claustrophobic.  I ordered a vegetable ramen bowl for $13.50, which is pretty expensive for noodle soup with no meat, and it ended up taking almost half hour to get there.  For a ramen place, they should have all broths ready to go and noodles should only taken a few minutes to heat up.  Half hour is way too long for noodle soup.  Typical Chinese restaurants can get you a bowl of noodle soup within five minutes of ordering.  And I know you might be thinking that you can't compare Japanese ramen to Chinese noodle soups but I gotta let you know that ramen is actually originally Chinese food.  Noodle soups are supposed to be fast and cheap food.  I know we're knee deep in a ramen craze these days but high prices and long waits shouldn't be the norm.  Keep the prices more reasonable and hire more people in the kitchen and you'll get customers in and out quick and the restaurant won't be as cramped and crowded.  It's definitely doable but Halu isn't there.  Oh yeah, and we ordered hot tea when we first got there and they didn't give it to us until AFTER we got the ramen so it took longer than half hour to get hot tea.  And they charged us $2.75 for the tea.  It should be FREE NINETY NINE.
author: Law C.

description:
My wife and I stumbled upon this hidden gem a few months ago because we were craving ramen. So began our hunt on Yelp for a decent ramen house in our new neighborhood. 

First off, I'm not going to let my own personal disliking of the Beatles hinder my experience at this place because my first impression from walking into this place is that they must really love the Beatles. The walls are covered with Beatles memorabilia along with a Beatles movie playing in the background. There were a few pics of Hendrix and other similar era artists as well but the Beatles were the obvious house favorites. 

This place is quite small inside and would be unbearable if it was played out like most hip restaurants in this city. The staff were very kind and hospitable and it looked like a small family run business. 

Now the food. We started off with the shiitake mushroom skewers that were very good and full of flavor. I would (and have) ordered again. I ordered the "spicy kara age ramen" which contains a few vegetables and little fried chicken pieces and my wife ordered the "spicy vegetable ramen". It took about 15 minutes for our food so I'd recommend ordering a libation or two in between. The ramen came out piping hot and we both fell in love from the first slurp of their broth. YUM!!! The noodles were cooked perfect and the spices were evident. When my wife asked for a little extra spice the cook (which was the owner) came out to our table and actually mixed the spices into my wife's soup for her.

I hear that ramen is not their specialty so if their other dishes are anything close to as flavorful as their ramen then I could see this place becoming very popular in the years to come.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I've been here a few times now and I've enjoyed every single morsel I put in my mouth. 

The ramen was good. Big portion and very satisfying. It's too bad they don't have one with a vegetarian or fish broth, but I understand that they have a limited menu. I also enjoyed the rice bowl with the mushrooms (vegetarian). It was very satisfying and made you feel like you had a hearty meal that was also healthy.

All the grilled items are the highlights. Every thing we tried was good. The beef, chicken, seafood, and veggies were all good. I can't remember which were the best, but i think I remember being blown away by some of the simple ones like the mushrooms and the grape tomatoes. 

Give it  a try if you're in the neighborhood. It a small place so don't try to go with a big group. It's a great place to get a decent, cheap meal, if you don't go crazy ordering everything on the menu. Also, try the sake and soju. I really liked one of the soju cocktail-things that tasted like an orange creamcicle!
author: Kitty H.

description:
I'm not a huge ramen fan, but I do have the occasional cravings.

There isn't a whole lot of ramen choices here, but I was pleasantly surprised.  I had the cashew w/egg ramen. The soup was thick, but not as thick as Santa Ramen's.  The reason for the dings in the stars is:

- The service was on and off.  The waitress got our orders mixed up.
- Salty.  A lot of the non-ramen dishes were really salty, and the ramen itself was saltier than other ramen joints.

The place is cozy, and we even coincidentally met an old friend of ours we haven't seen in ages.  It was a really homey experience and that was awesome.
author: Alfred Y.

description:
Meh.

Waited forty minutes for a plate of daikon salad and a bowl of ramen that was underwhelming.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
To everyone that works at Halu, you guys are great! You have a sweet little gem and we really had a great time. The two young girls were great. The chef was crazy good with the cooking. Thanks. 

The yakitori was great (beef tongue, chicken gizzards, chicken hearts)! The ramen and broth, out of this world. 

We got there early, found a seat, entertained by the crazy poster and Beatles music (which I loved). 

I can't say enough about this little gem. We'll be back and we're going to bring the gang.
author: Mozelle L.

description:
If possible, we'd give Halu NEGATIVE 5 stars.  The customer service we had tonight was one of the worst that we've experienced in a long time -- that's saying a lot because we eat at a lot of Chinese restaurants. 

We thought we'd go to one of our local Japanese restaurants for a causal Friday night dinner.  We arrived and were immediately seated, which, unfortunately, was the highlight of our evening.   

After we were seated, it took a few minutes longer than expected to take our order, but that was expected since there was only 2 wait staff for the small restaurant.  We've eaten here several times before and recognize the kitchen can be a little slow on Friday and Saturday nights.  That being said, what we experienced was unacceptable by any stretch of the imagination.

We order the agadashi tofu, chashu ramen and karage donburi -- something very simple, we thought. After 50 minutes, and watching several people who were seated after us receive their meals, we asked the waitress why our meals were taking so long.  Her response: "we're not a ramen house."
