WTF?!?!?!?  It's Japanese restaurant that doesn't serve sushi and only has a limited number of entree options, and nearly half of those are ramen.  So, if you're not a ramen house, then why is it on the menu???  

So, after another 10 minutes the donburi shows up, but no tofu or ramen to be seen.  It takes an additional 5 minutes for the tofu to arrive.  We ask again how much longer before the ramen comes out and the waitress says it'll be soon.  We start with the tofu, but after waiting ANOTHER 5 minutes, we decide to split the donburi because it's getting cold.  We finish the tofu and about 2/3 of the donburi before the ramen finally shows up.

After nearly 80 minutes, the ramen shows up and it's not even hot.  The broth and egg were salty beyond belief.  We received a half-hearted apology about the wait time and felt rushed to finish our meal, so they could turn the table.  

We should have walked out after 40 minutes.  Needless to say, this was the last time we dine at Halu.
author: S Y.

description:
After driving around the neighorhood, we saw a little place called "Halu - Not your regular Japanese restaurant". That piqued our curiosity so we decided to try it. 

Luckily there was no line at that time (Reading the other reviews , it seems that we were lucky to have to not wait).

It was a fantastic dining experience. Filled with Beatles memorabilia, this place has the ambience of a tiny restaurant that you might find in an indie movie.

The food is great too - especially for yakitori and noodle soup lovers. I, for one, prefer this kind of Japanese cuisine to the sushi. I tried the basic yakitori and some specials, All dishes were above average.

Great place for a date as well as a relaxed sunday evening dinner. Try to find a time when there's no wait though.
author: Kunal S.

description:
Came here once on a date with a ladyfriend, as per her suggestion, and I've gotta say, I was impressed.

First of all, the decor of the place is amazing. Mostly Beatles paraphanelia, and whether you like them or not (who doesn't?) it gives the place a real unique homey comfortable feeling. The only thing is the place is rather small, you probably can't come here with a party of more than 4 people. Right as you enter, there's a counter to the right facing the chef making his yakitori. A couple two-seater tables to the left, and there were maybe 4-5 4seater tables in the back, and that was about it. 

We mainly came here for the yakitori. Usually when people think "Japanese" they think sushi, ramen or izakaya style so it's pretty damn hard to find a good yakitori place in the US. We're both Japanese, which makes us a bit spoiled, so when we go out to eat Japanese, it better be f*ckin good, and Halu was just that.  

First off, we went there with no reservation, I think it was a weekend night, so there were a couple groups lined up before us. No problem though, we left our name and phone number with the waitress and walked around a bit, within 15 or so minutes she called us and we were seated. Originally we were seated at the counter, which was cool, but before out food arrived, when a table for two opened up the waitress was nice enough to move us to that seat. Overall I would like to give the waitress a 5 star because she was really nice and accommodating the whole meal. Constantly giving us suggestions, seeing how we were doing, etc.

Finally, the food, like I said before we came here exclusively for the yakitori. We started off with some of the standard yakitori menu items, I think we ordered a kushi-katsu or two? They come two skewers on one plate (or you can just get one skewer, just have to ask). Every dish was amazing. When the dishes arrived, the waitress explained which dish was which, which I thought was nice because a lot of restaurants just give you the food and leave it up to you to figure what is what. After we were done with the original order, we noticed their special menu on the wall and ordered a few from there. Everything was delicious. I think we ordered a total of ~10 dishes? with alcoholic drinks, came out to over $100. I wanna say each yakitori dish (with 2 skewers) was around $6-7, which I guess is not too bad. Regardless I would definitely come here again, maybe to try the ramen everyone else seems to be raving about.
author: Ren P.

description:
Went here because it was recommended by a friend, loved it. 

Hubby ordered the butter corn ramen, me regular ramen, both came in large bowels, piping hot, tasty very tasty. There was lots of noodles, Chau Siu (pork), veggies, mine came with Soy Egg (kinda salty) but still really delish on a cold night.

We also ordered the skewers: fried chicken, zucchini and bacon, and asparagus and bacon. Everything was so good, made to order.

Halu is going to be my neighborhood place for good eats. 

Bonus: It's decorated with Beatles memoriabilia and Beatles' music playing and the owner is super nice.
author: J. C.

description: best place ever for great ramen and and amazing aesthetic. perfect size, perfect beers, and perfect company! the karage ramen is amazing well anything you order here is amazing. try it all be adventurous and take the waitress's sake recommendations! can't wait to go back and order more gyoza
author: Vannessa G.

description:
Ramen = YUM

The yakitori was good.
The pancake was good. 
The spicy ramen was excellent!

If you wanna eat here, make sure you have plenty of time. The wait is long because the place is very small.
author: Mai H.

description: I like this little Ramen house with a theme of the Rock n Roll period of 60-70s. Too bad they have an odd hours of operations.
author: Tom T.

description:
my friend was craving ramen so we decided to try this place. it's a really small, cute restaurant near my house. i liked the coziness and the staff was super friendly.

when it comes to ramen, this isn't the best spot in the city (katana-ya is my fav). but so far, this is the best that i've found in the richmond. i'm no ramen expert but i have to say that the ramen was pretty authentic, better than genki ramen. i had the chashu-men and i can see how some may think the broth is too salty but i love overly salty things so i didn't think it was too much. the soft boiled egg, the bamboo shoots, bean sprouts, corn, the "al dente" style noodles all contributed to a yummy ramen experience. the portion you get is pretty substantial too.

we also got a large sapporo in a can. it was ginormous and great for sharing!

and if you love guitars, make sure to visit the bathroom.
author: elsie k.

description:
Good noodles, chewy and not soggy until the last 5 bites, which was about 20 minutes later.  The noodles was thinner than other ramen places.  The soap was tasty, flavorful and considerably thicker.  

We also got chicken gizzard and the rib eye steak skewers.  They were both only marinated with salt, but it really didnt need anything else on it.  They had enough flavor on their own.  I was hoping to get the beef tongue, but they didnt have it that night. 

Its a small place though, when we left there were people waiting to get in outside the door.   

Oh and the staff (the one waitress) is mighty nice too.
author: Janet S.

description:
Me and my new ramen buddy were able to stop by here towards 9pm, and surprisingly, there was still a full house in here. The restaurant was small and cozy, with some nice decor to give it a more welcoming feeling. 

We started off with some appetizers. I was able to try their asparagus wrapped with bacon. TASTY! Then came my drink, which was a Guava Shochu. It was definitely Guava, but I wasn't sure how much Shochu was in there, and finally our Chicken Karaage before the main attraction. The batter on it was light, and it wasn't the super deep fried Karaage, it was the nice and golden kind. I actually liked this style more because the chicken was actually tender and juicy.  

The ramen took a little longer than we thought, but it came to us hot! At first, the soup base tasted a bit on the saltier side, but after sipping more and more of it, the soup just started to settle in. The soup was a little bit more on the heavy side, but I thought that was fine. They must use a nice pork broth, because I saw bits of fat and oil floating around everywhere. The noodles weren't too soft as well, which is what I love about ramen houses! I ordered the Chasu ramen, and was surprised to see corn in there. I love corn (and no, not just because I'm corny either)!  I enjoyed the Chashu slices as well. They were nicely cut pieces that were extremely tender. 

Over all, I thought it was a decent meal, but I'm giving it a 3 star because I thought it was overly hyped. The serving size was decent for about $8 for the bowl. I honestly feel that Suzu was better. 

Next time, I'll try the Yakitori! If all turns out well, I'll probably bump this place up a star!
But, brownie points for being in a residential area for the locals!
author: Andrew W.

description: Maybe the best ramen I've had in SF. OK, Katana ya is good too but I think this place has it beat because they have yakitori. So Halu is a tiny spot so not good at all for a big party. Six at the most. This place might hold 20 at the most. They have the lava ramen which is spicy. Not painful spicy but sweaty spicy. If you catch my drift. Their chicken livers and gizzards are yummy. Apparently the owner played in a band called The Shitones and he has old music posters of them as well as the Beatles, Jimi Hendirx, etc... up on the wall. Very cool spot.
author: David C.

description:
All I know is that whoever doesn't like this place knows squat about Asian food. OK, I'd be specific but my recollection of this place is kinda hazy after two bottles of sake and a big bottle of beer. All I know is, that bacon-wrapped scallop was darn good! I also remember talking to the wait staff, the chef, and maybe one of the owners, and my friend Kenny W. promising to go back with a big bottle of Waketake sake.

http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/Mj6jfcwx6Yqx2APcFQGv8g/l
http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/JAXNYf6AYAWitkbnRbhzpQ/l

I'd have to go back to re-order everything we had, maybe less sake this time.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Had a really hard time deciding whether to give this 3 or 4 stars :)  Had the chasu ramen - the broth and the butabara are absolutely delicious, savory in the best way.  Thought the touch of ginger and corn were interesting and a good complement.
However...I have to keep my ramen rankings intact :)  Kahoo is still at the top with 5 stars (sorry SF peeps - it's all the way down in San Jose), Ryowa and Orenchi next and then Santa Ramen and Halu.
But, to clarify, this place is still good and a ton better than Katana Ya!
author: Cathy L.

description: Definitely coming back. Yakitori selection is tops. Ramen is okayyyy. Broth is a bit flat, although the pork itself was well tasty. Satisfies a ramen craving, but it's clear it's not the emphasis here. Place is small, service is snail-slow, but if your date is anything like mine, it won't matter will it? Lots of stuff to look at, great tunes that don't get in the way of conversation, and a young hip crowd you won't mind rubbing elbows with.
author: Erica L.

description:
Heard some good things about this place and decided to give it a try. Nothing really appealed to me on the yakitori menu so I just went with the safe choice: ramen.

I went with the chicken karaage ramen. They were about the same price as any ramen place. The broth lacked the same richness in comparison and a tad bit too salty. =T

A little disappointed experience, but at least there were some interesting pieces of decorations to glance at while we were there.

Good to try once.
author: Jimmy N.

description: Family owned business!  Yakitori is delish!  The deep fried stuff mushrooms are my fav.  When you need to satisfy a spicy kick, have the spicy pork ramen...fire red broth will keep you nice and toasty!  Only place I know with Beetles stools at the bar; truly there is no other restaurant with such charm!
author: Anna L.

description:
I really really want to give this place a 4 star review, but I just couldn't do it.  I thought the ramen was great.  The flavor packed a punch and the noodles tasted just right.

Why doesn't that deserve a 4 star?  The food definitely gets it, but the service was a different story.  There was one other party there when we arrived when my friends and I came.  We were seated promptly but only given one menu.  That wasn't too bad because it didn't take us very long to find out what we wanted.  We all placed our order in.  15-20 min. later two bowls came out for me and a friend.  The waitress told us they ran out of hot water so the other two bowls will be another 10 min.  That was sad.  I didn't want to start eating before my friends got their food but she said, and I quote "it will taste nasty if you wait."  I wasn't going to wait after that.  It could have just been that one day I went, and I'll definitely go there to eat again, but the service was just too slow..
author: Tom Y.

description: This place has amazing food, drinks, awesome service, and great prices. My new favorite Japanese place to eat in the city. Went with a friend for his birthday filled up on beer, food, and sake for 60 bucks total. YES!
author: Michaelyn S.

description: Great food, music, and service.  Super cute--can only seat probably 25 people max so be prepared to wait for a table....but believe me its worth it.  Amazing ramen, I recommend the lava bowl.  Be sure to get a bunch of skewers beforehand, i recommend the shisa peppers, bacon wrapped mochi, and galbi ribs.  I'll be back
author: Ryan H.

description: My son and I stopped in here because I wanted him to try ramen that was other than the kind  you buy for a quarter at Safeway. He loved it, which is saying something for a 10 year old palate. We had some delicious beef skewers and pork ramen. The food was delicious, the atmosphere was fun, and the service was great. I really want to come back with a group of friends so we can try more stuff!
author: Jeff G.

description:
i brought a friend from out of town here to try their ramen and yakitori one night because i heard it was pretty good.

we found parking right in front, which was great, and didn't have to wait to get seated. we ordered the scallop and bacon yakitori and chasu ramen. the yakitori came out pretty fast and we devoured it! delicious! but right after our ramen came out..... the restaurant went black.

the electricity for the entire street went out so the vent wouldn't work either. i couldn't see my food and was breathing in all this nasty fried oil smell. they didn't want to open the door because it was cold out but man! it was already cramped in there... and now i can't breathe. we had to eat by candlelight and the ramen wasn't even good! i can make better packaged ramen! only their yakitori was worth going there for.

and after we ate... they asked if we had cash.. which is understandable since their was no electricity but i didn't want to use the cash i had on me since i needed it later on that night, so i told them no, and if i could write them a check instead. they refused and told us to walk two blocks down to use the wellsfargo atm... even though i told her i used boa. 

so of course, i ended up using the cash that i didn't want to use, embarrassed that my friend had to endure all of that, and left after an unsatisfying meal.
author: amelia g.

description:
Yelp 2008 list - http://yelp.typepad.com/files/100bestchecklistsf-1.pdf

#100 - Yakitori - I still preferred the yakitori to the kushi katsu b/c I don't like the batter. Mmm, chicken innards are so yummy!

Finally tried the ramen but what wow'ed me was the cold ramen with chicken and veggies....please do try!
author: Katie K.

description: The Lava ramen burns!  Its borderline almost inedible.  The meats on a stick were good.  They are more like appetizers than entrees.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Dont know why people are raving about this place.  The food was awful. I left with that stomach-full-of-cement feeling.  Agedashi tofu was super greasy and the broth was very salty.  Pork jowl yakitori was very good, but chicken heart yakitori tasted like liver.  seafood pancake was terrible - covered in mayo, rubbery seafood that tasted a few days old.  All around terrible food here.  At the waitress's recommendation we tried the stuffed mushrooms, and they were really really bad.   The service people were very nice.  Chicken kara-age was just ok- seasoning was ok, chicken itself was mediocre, and the fry was very oily.  Didn't try the ramen, but I can't imagine it would be very good given the standards on the other food.

I just don't get it.
author: r h.

description: I finally went to Halu after quite a long time of it being on my "places to try" list. I had a great meal and a great time. I went with one other friend so it was easier for us to get a table and we were helped right away (it's a tiny place). We only had izakaya so I can't speak to the ramen and noodles. But the skewers were great- especially those on the specials board (we were in a mood to splurge on new foods). I highly recommend it.
author: El T.

description: Everything about this place is amazing. The atmosphere, the food, and the waitresses -- ALL GREAT. My favorite place for authentic Japanese food when I step into San Fran.
author: Melissa A.

description: While San Mateo will probably remain the hot-hub of Ramen in the Bay Area, Halu provides San Francisco with one of the better Ramen dining experiences.  I've been eating at Halu for 5 or 6 years and recently, they really managed to trim down the fat/oil of their broth.  They must really have listened to customer feedback which is very encouraging.  The broth is both lighter and more enjoyable to drink.  If you go to a ramen place and no one is drinking the broth down to the last drop, they are probably doing something wrong.  They also have a pretty good Japanese beer selection and they do really good grilled meat sticks.  They can definitely get pricy as the meat sticks aren't terribly filling and when you order a bunch, the price really starts adding up rather quickly so buyer beware.  Make sure you order yourself some form of filler or you may feel like you didn't get good value out of your meal.  The bacon wrapped mochi is tasty (but not very filling).  I also like the shitake mushrooms but again, for what you are getting, it's really up to you if you are ok paying the cost of these dishes.  Service is pretty good.  Sometimes they are short staffed and things get backed up (FYI, 2 waitresses would be the standard number you'd want to see for things to move smoothly).  There can and almost always is a wait in line to get seated but they conveniently take your cell number and call you over so you can kind of relax while you wait.  3.5 stars.  Nice Beatles decor and good drunk food as well.
author: Nat L.

description: Halu is a very small and cozy restaurant with a rock and roll theme. Specials are listed on the white boards on the wall with collected pictures of some special rock and roll stars! Oh my goodness! So many items to choose from! Here's the list of items that I remember, but I know we ordered more. We had the gizzards, chicken hearts, beef and asparagus, ribeye,cow tongue, pork jowl, bacon wrapped scallops, bacon wrapped mochi, and chicken skin. Once we got the items, we just engulfed it. The items were so delicate and tasty that all I can do is wait in anticipation for the next plate to come out. My favorites were the bacon wrapped mochi, bacon wrapped scallops, and chicken skin. Oh wow! The mochi was warm with the bacon. It makes me reminisce of being in Hawaii eating mochi, cheese, and nori. Yum! Generally, chicken skin is just very fatty, but sooo good. Why not on a stick? Maybe some seaweed or nori to go with it? Oh, wow! The okra looks good! Maybe, next time we'll order that! Hmmm...so many possibilities! Also, I love the Hakkai-san sake! It was so crisp and clean! Great service and great food! Thank you Eri-san and her family! I can't wait to come back here again!
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description:
Cute! This place reminds me of the small mom and pop eateries in Japan including the kitchy Beatles paraphenalia. We were greeted by the staff in Japanese (Always a plus), and were seated promptly. We blew through $100 at one sitting and that's just 60% skewer orders.  My friends wanted to have double orders of chicken skins, hearts, gizzards, thighs, and pork/onions...some were good to great. Sandy M. tried the char-siu ramen which was okay, although the portions were huge. I liked Izakaya Sozai's ramen better. We definitely had to try the seafood okonomiyaki, which I heard was done in Yokohama style. It was flatter than I'm used to but the edges were crispy and delicious. I would have added corn and caramelized onions to flesh out the flavors more. John M. ordered the chicken donburi with salad...we girls loved the salad...bitter greens and not a lot of crappy iceberg cabbage...that's what we like! The rice is brown rice and it's healthier...I kept thinking, take that Uncle Ben (haha).

Unfortunately they haven't developed a dessert menu beyond ice cream, so that's something they will have to work on in the future...as for the peeps...
We were outnumbered by the okasans and obasans that kept the place hopping. Lots of cries of "oishii" filtered through the air...all in all, a real good homemade feeling from the food. It was lovely!

Come here early and sit by the counter stools to chat it up with the staff, they are very friendly!
author: Pauline L.

description: Slowwwwww service. Took literally an hour to get our food. Broth was flavorless. Ordered SPICY LAVA ramen and it was not spicy at all. Pickled ginger was an  unecessary topping and was very unpleasant. Meat was fatty. Overpriced for that ramen. Never again!!
author: Jackie A.

description: This is the real deal and staffed by Japanese people. All the yakitori was quite good. My ramen was good, but not authentic to Northern Japan where I fell in love with ramen. The noodles were tasty, and the broth was good as well. The tonkotsu broth was in a style I can only call gravy-like. It has an extremely rich pork taste and is similar to the broth at Izakaya Sozai. To my taste, it needed more complexity and less richness, but it was still very very good. I will try the okonomiyaki next time on Nobu K's recommendation.
author: Adam C.

description: My background on this place is this - we got there around 8:30 sat night and waited about an hour (it's a small place).  You know a place is going to be good when people leaving the place come out smiling, see you waiting outside, and say to you "it's totally worth the wait."  As you can see from my other reviews, I enjoy noodles:  these ramen noodles had a really (good) unique taste, compared to anything that I'd had.  I'm always partial to hole in the wall places like this, but I would say that this place is definitely worth checking out.  It's got this cool British/Japanese theme thing going on, and a whole bunch of unique stuff on the menu.  You could prob go here on a date
author: Charles C.

description: I would never known this restaurant without Euge's review of his local cafeteria... it looks like he should have a personalized chair here. We came in about 6:30 pm on a weeknight after finding parking a 1/2 block away. We scored the last table for four (there were three of us) and quickly got our menus. Following Euge's game plan, we ordered a few yakitori (scallops and chicken) to share and individual bowls of ramen. Seeing the specials on the wall, I ordered the spicy Cha Siu Ramen. For a typical cool SF evening, this was perfect to get my blood flowing again. The sniffles from the heat were testament to the spiciness. Between dishes, I couldn't help but notice how the atmosphere was like a time machine. My brother is a HUGE Beatle fan and would have loved to see the various postings on their walls. The background music was .... what else, Beatle music. The ramen ran $7.00 to $9.00 per bowl while the appetizers were in the $5.00 to $9.00 range. 3.5 stars for the food, 1 star for the atmosphere, minus 0.5 star for slightly slow and inattentive service (hopefully, chalk it up as a bad night for her). Yes, I'll be back with my brother one of these nights. Got to get this into his life!
author: Mike C.

description:
Halu has really good chicken karage! It was very tasty and garlic-y. The ramen was okay, nothing special. It didn't really taste home made, but I am not too sure. I ordered a buttercorn ramen. The soup base was shoyu and it came warm. The soup was good but it wasn't super tasty. After awhile, the taste just went away. Well, at least it didn't leave me thirsty.

Halu was decorated with Beetles posters, and it also plays Beetle's music. It seems like this place is Japanese family-run, which is a pretty good thing...more authentic. =]
author: Mandy C.

description: Walk into the rockabilly closet-sized, heavenly scented sanctuary that is Halu, and hope that space is there to be found. If not, you're free to wait outside of the door, or at one of the surrounding bars a few blocks down from it. I was informed that there was not a table available, so took the standing approach, which I wouldn't do on another cold night as it was. Their food was incredible, but the service a bit negligent. My friend and I were overlooked at our corner table, and they served the people who arrived after us, and who ordered after us, first. There was some serious lack of priority/timing. When we finally got our delicious food, it was amazing...but it took nearly an hour to arrive. That's a long time, and this was on a week night...not some crazy, demanding Friday or Saturday, but if I recall, a Wednesday. The food was all around, lovely, but te service left me with much to be desired. I'll go back because it's yummy, but I hope that they can change my perspective around.
author: Brianna S.

description:
Halu is my favorite izakaya in San Francisco, hands down. It's pretty tiny, but somehow I never feel super cramped or wanting for more space. You can still have a conversation without having to yell, but it's not so quiet that you'd feel super awkward for laughing hella loudly at a joke your friend made. Servers are nice and the Beatles memorabilia on the walls are cool too. Drinks are great as well! I usually get an Asahi or Sapporo now, but during my first time here I tried their Calpico shochu drink. I've drank Calpico since I was kid so trying a more "mature" variation was a trip- a very good one. Beer has ended up to be a better fit with the skewers for me, but Calpico shochu would be a fine alternate.

On to the food! All the skewers I've had are above average but the two standouts for me were the beef tongue and the bacon wrapped scallops skewers. Halu cemented my love for beef tongue. It was tender and juicy and well seasoned. And anything wrapped in bacon is bound to be delicious but the combo of scallops makes it amazing. The scallops kinda just melt in your mouth. Definitely on the salty side so be prepared to drink often. And the ramen. I've tried both the chashu-men and the butter corn ramen. First, the ramen is a little pricey, but the portions they serve are pretty big. The chashu-men's broth is way different that those at Santa or Hakata. The noodles are a little thin but are cooked perfectly, and the chashu is not skimped on. My favorite has to be the butter corn ramen though. With a pretty sizable piece of butter and corn sprinkled in the broth, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the soup wasn't too heavy or too salty, but just right. Noodles were cooked well, not too soggy. It was one of the better ramen I've had since I left Los Angeles. 

In short, I love Halu, and I can't wait to go back again!
author: Amanda K.

description:
On the reviews of other yelpers, I decided to try Halu. This, plus it's close to the Bitter End, a nice regular drinking establishment in the Richmond District.

It was much smaller than I thought, but this is a good thing. We were instantly at ease in Halu's intimate setting. We ordered some sake and beer and then browsed the menu for some good eats.

The menu is a good in both size and selection, without it being overbearing with too many choices.

All the Yakitori we had were great (both the breaded and non-breaded types)... then this is where things get a bit fuzzy, as the sake kept pouring and the conversation kept going too... 

I remember talking to the owners and finding out they'd only been open for about 6-months (that put's their opening around July 2008). The next thing I remember is making sure they knew I was going to be coming back for New Year's Eve dinner...

Now, I'd like to tell you more details about the food, but I cannot... I can tell you that all of it was very delicious, tasty and cooked to perfection. The prices are very affordable and the staff is very friendly. With all of these attributes, plus sake and beer, what else could one ask for.

Please stop by and enjoy the food and drink... 

Kampai!
author: Kenny W.

description:
I love this place for Ramen.  It has a very Osaka feel to it.  The Yakitori skewers are fantastic too!  I think it's one of the best Japanese restaurants in SF!  Well, to place a condition on the previous statement, best values.  It's definitely more Izakaya style, Japanese comfort food, but I love that.  

Try them you will like it!
author: Mark K.

description:
4.5  excellent yakitori, almost as good as sumika.  great flavor.  had the momo, teba, shiso beef (the shiso leaf flavor), bacon asparagus.  don't miss the specials board on the wall.
cheaper than sumika since you get 2 for $4.  chashu and karaage ramen, not my fave shoyu but decent
hopefully you like the beatles.
author: Rob C.

description:
been wanting to try this place out for awhile.  nice, little restaurant.  so many options, too little of a tummy.  i got the bacon-wrapped mochi...yeah, you heard that correctly.  i'm a sucker for mochi, and don't get me started on the pig.  it was good.  

the chicken karaage was excellent.  my friends all got that too, so i can't really go into much detail about their other offerings.  the noodles were good.  i just got the donburi version...i'm not much into soup noodles.  wish they had some yakisoba, but that's neither here nor there.  

we also got the okonomiyaki was pretty good.  

funky decor, a bit loud in there (just because it's a small space), but really a great place.  i definitely want to go there some more and try out some of their yakitori.
author: Miss P.

description: unique atmosphere. good food. small place, but definitely got that gig. perfect late night hang out place.
author: Sweet N Sour Chicken C.

description:
This is the first yelp review that I have written since I created a yelp account just to write about this restaurant since it's THAT GOOD. This is by far the cutest, most unique japanese restaurant you will find. It is a tiny restaurant, but the perfect size for a casual dinner. We came across this restaurant for my birthday and I was definitely not disappointed. 
it is a beatles themed izakaya that serves delicious yakitori sticks. We tried the bacon-wrapped mochi, bacon-wrapped scallops, bacon-wrapped enoki mushrooms, panko-crusted stuffed mushrooms, and the short-ribs. All of them were delicious. I especially liked the short-ribs and the panko-crusted stuffed mushrooms. My boyfriend had the salmon onigiri and he said it was fantastic. 
Halu was exactly what I was looking for because I am allergic to fish, and they have absolutely no sushi. Which is awesome. 
They do take credit cards, but when we went there, their credit card machine was temporarily broken. Thus we had to pay with the cash that we had on us, which was just enough to cover the bill with only a dollar tip. We told our server this and she graciously said it was alright. We will definitely come back to eat there again in order to eat more delicious food and to give our amazing server the proper tip!
author: Jen A.

description: REAL Japanese food. Ramen is good. Yakitori reminds me of home... The decor is as cool as it can be. TOTALLY beats going fancy places. Get cozy in a small space, so many conversational stuff all around the wall, and enjoy the a small peace of Japanese food...  yah good stuff.
author: A O.

description: Yummy Yummy Yummy!  I finally found my Yakitori restaurant!  I've been asking my friends and random people to open up a good Yakitori place.  Well here it is!  When you walk in, it's filled with the Beatles posters, Beatles pictures, Beatles everything and anything you could imagine.  It's a total ROCK-&-ROLL feel.  I love how it's small and cozy and the service is awesome.  I pretty much ordered everything that I wanted to try, but unfortunately their beef tongue wasn't ready to be served that day.  Well I'll definitely be back for sure to try it and pretty much everything else that I tasted.  But I have to say one of their sauces on the beef Yakitori was a bit salty for mine and my bf's taste, maybe we'll ask for less sauce?  I also noticed that they serve Ramen too!  OOH I love finding good Ramen.  Maybe I'll try a combination of Yakitori and Ramen.   I'm just glad I found this place!
author: Paige L.

description:
halu gets a very solid 4-stars for a wonderfully delicious and cozy thursday night dinner. no okonomiyaki was on the menu when we visited, but the ramen and yakitori (along with the unusual anime and psychedelic guitar rock) were in full swing.

my boyfriend and i shared the yakitori dinner and the chicken karaage ramen, both of which were great introductions to the flavors of the restaurant. the yakitori dinner came with one skewer each of the stuffed mushrooms (with chicken meatball stuffing), flank steak, chicken with green onion, chicken meatballs, okra with salt, shrimp, and chicken wings accompanied by a small side of salad greens with some crazy delicious dressing on it... i could have had a whole bowl of that simple salad on its own! all the skewers were excellent and would have been great with a nice beer or hot sake.

the chicken karaage ramen was also quite good with a rich flavorful broth, fresh noodles, tender fried chicken and corn. the serving size was pretty big and definitely worth the $9 or so. not the absolute best ramen in town, but it ranks up there.

together with the nice and sincere service, this was all in all a good meal and i'm definitely looking forward for a return visit!
author: Andrey C.

description:
ok so you know how some things are just better on second look.  the more you look at it the more beautiful it becomes.  ok dont take it so literal.  but i came back to halu a second and third time a few days later and love this place!  

these two times we ordered almost exclusively off the specials menu on the whiteboard on the wall - the lava ramen, mochi wrapped in bacon, okonomiyaki.  from the menu - shishamo and daikon salad.  everything was so good.  on cold days like these in sf, and ok sf wimps its not THAT cold.  but the lava ramen really hits the spot.  it is mouth tingling-ly spicy!  the noodles are aldente and chewy.  the broth is oily but oh well. fat keeps us warm!  grilled mochi bacon.  anything wrapped in bacon is good.  and their okonomiyaki is thin and very good too!
author: claudia y.

description: Thanks to some good friends introducing me to Halu! I have never had this style of Japanese food.....the service was so accomodating, informative and sweet! The grilled aspargus was grilled  perfectly, everything was grilled and cooked perfectly. my 8 year old even loved it! The flavors were so good! We will be back!
author: B G.

description: i remember sitting at the bar here with my bf on a cold sf evening before leaving for hong kong. hot ramen, skewers, and okonomiyaki definitely hit the spot. i didn't mind the draft that blows in whenever another party arrived as the place is so small and cozy that it quickly warmed up in there. beatles music might have helped as well! i just recommend getting there when it opens to avoid the wait, food takes a while. looking forward to going back when i come home
author: Diana B.

description:
The food was great, but service was definitely a 2-3.

Split the kushi-katsu and the chicken karaage.
The karaage was very juicy and seasoned well. the zucchini salty but tasty with brown rice!

The assortment was nice-- i'll go back for single orders of the stuffed mushroom, pork and okra. 

Main service complains were that it was slow and unprofessional. The katsu sauce for the katsu was all of 3 mL. When we asked for more, it took a while and the server took our sauce dishes back to refill them and the returned to us... slightly sketchy. I would have preferred new sauce dishes personally. Granted, I wouldn't have minded as much had I not waited 10 minutes and had to remind her I needed sauce!

the omeboshi shochu drink was very omeboshi-- just like grandma makes you drink when you visit her... minus the shochu of course.

i'll go back to try the ramen and gizzards!
author: Miss C.

description:
It was freezing in the city Sat. night (49 degrees to be exact) so we wanted something warm to fill our bellies. I've had Halu bookmarked forever so we decided to give it a try. 

Got to Halu at 730pm on Saturday night. There was two couples in front us along with a group of teeny boppers (7 of them)... so I was thinking the wait would be be horrendous but it was like 20 min. Not bad. 

We were seated at the counter and quickly checked the board for the specials of the day. Bf got the Lava Ramen and I chose the Spicy karage ramen plus the shisho beef and shishito peppers and a beer to share. Our order was taken quickly and our beer was brought out quickly. When we sat down we noticed the first couple that was seated before us didn't have their food. Okay so that's about 30 min later...hmm... *thinking* I hope this doesn't take forever... 

So about 20 min into our wait...we're enjoying the Beatles music and all the cutesy decorations...40 min into our wait we're staring at each other and order another beer...55 min into our wait... our friends call us wondering where we are... 60 min after ordering...OMG food arrives!!! Our shisho beef and shishito peppers came!!! YAAY! Food. Now mind you we are starving so we inhaled the yakitori. I had hoped the beef would be dripping with gold of some sort or be a huge portion but no, it was 2 little skewers.... I ate mine in two bites (yes I know not very lady like but i was starving) and it was above average. I would have liked it if it was cooked med rare rather than well done. I did enjoy the shishito peppers. I ate all of them in one swoop. So this is one hour of sitting at the counter...tick tock..where is our ramen? We noticed once we got our yakitori everyone around us (people that had come in later and ordered after us) all got their yakitori orders as well... huuuh waat..? Then suddenly our ramen arrives!!!

My ramen was spicy and delicious! It came with 4 pieces of chicken and I loved that the spicy didn't mean a huge oil puddle of spicy chili oil. I immediately dove into the ramen and didn't look back! My ramen's spicy color was indeed more red than the bf's lava ramen. We both finished our ramen in record setting time and then paid and left. Eating at Halu took about 2 hours of our lives. The ramen was GOOD..the yakitori ... hmm... i'll have to come back and give it a re-try. Seems that they cook all the yakitori at once and then all the ramens at once...

-They do accept credit cards
-It says no reservations but it seems that large groups call ahead anyway
-Definitely look at the special board to order
-No paper to "sign up" for a table. You just wait outside in a line....
-We had 2 beers and some yakitori and ramen and we weren't "stuffed"..portion size for ramen on the smaller side

Even though I wasted a bunch of time here, I think the ramen saved them from a 3 or 2 star review. Our waitress was pretty attentive and nice as well.
author: Julie F.

description: I LOVED their ramen here. It was cooked right, the noodles weren't too soft or hard, and the broth was tasty, not too salty. I also came here on a rainy day so I guess it added to the greatness of the ramen haha. It's been almost two years since I've been so I can't recall much, just that the ambiance was great, the food was excellent, and I enjoyed it all so much.
author: Jenny O.

description: Best restaurant in San Francisco. I will fight you if you disagree. I'm not joking either.
author: Jason G.

description:
Note: only open for dinner

Ramen is okay.. had better.
Atmosphere was interesting has a large beattles fan club to it. with beattles music in the background.  Very limited space and seating.  Waitresses are very nice and polite.

The Okay:
Ramen- had the soy ramen to compare to the normal ones, believe it was the shoyu ramen. noodles were normal sized and soup was not as flavorful.

The Good:
The yakatori was awesome. Definitely a must try, had the chicken hearts and chicken gizzard and asparagus wrapped in bacon.  Loved the flavor of the chicken.
author: Tony T.

description:
My boy recommended that we check out Halu, and after a brief conversation about how strange and un-Japanese the name sounded to us, we came with another friend and got us some ramen.

I like the feel of the place. It's not too wild or extravagant like so many "HEY, WE'RE A REALLY NICE AND AUTHENTIC YET HIP JAPANESE RESTAURANT!!"-type places out there. It's small, simple, laid back and there are lots of Beatles artwork on the walls. 

Our waitress seemed really busy and a bit rushed. After we placed our orders, I must say it took quite a while for our ramen bowls to get out. Halu isn't a very big place, so why would it take so long to cook up some ramen? It's really a pretty simple thing to make.

Regardless, the ramen wasn't bad. I ordered the Chicken Kara Age Ramen and while it wasn't anything spectacular, it was pretty good. 8 bucks is an acceptable price for what I got, and I'll have to come back another time to find out how I really feel about this place.
author: Edmund C.

description: Small pop and mom shop .Great service and good food , love all the yakitori dishes and their veggie don
author: Tam T.

description: Simple, delicious yakitori. We tried just about all the skewers tonight with the bacon wrapped items as well as the chicken stuffed mushroom among the best we tried. Contrary to some of the other reviews our food came out almost immediately. On the other hand it was 6:30 and we were some of the only people there. When we left an hour later the place had completely filled up. We also tried the pork ramen which was good but I've definitely had better in SF. Overall a good experience and well worth a return trip. Total cost for three with enough food to stuff ourselves and three beers was about $110.
author: Procter F.

description:
Great place to impress friends that does not require a lot of money!!!

Bacon wrapped asparagus, stuffed mushrooms, great miso soup, few vegi skewers, okonomiyaki ( my favorite) and a bottle of sake was a great filling dinner for two that cost us less than $50!!!

I also like to come to this place on a hot day for cold buckwheat soba noodles or on a cold day for a bowl of ramen!!!

I would suggest to come early because the wait list after 8pm. can be quite long.
author: Regina A.

description:
great variety of yakitori but it's really the ramen that stays with me. flavorful broths, quality meat, and great noodles - firm and perfectly cooked. 

spicy butter corn ramen? oh yeah.
author: Will R.

description: It's rare to have Japanese own restaurants that offers combination of yakitori, ramen and okonomiyaki in one place. The yakitori are authentic because they serve pork belly and chicken skin that many yakitori place doesn't serve. The ramen noodles are very good and the broth is decent and can be great with beer. The okonomiyaki is pretty good considered one of the better ones in SF and they don't put noodles in there. Overall, it's a great place to get your drink on with your friends and eat beer snacks.  Yum Yum!!!
author: Aylee G.

description:
This place is own by Japanese and dishes here is very Osaka style.
I assume this place totally own by Japanese.

The inside of restraunt strongly reflect I guess owner's hobby which is lot of 60's 70's music. 


It was interesting Beatles drum set on the upper floor.

We order Kara-age Ramen, Chasyu Ramen, Okonomiyaki and Kushikatsu dinner.

The Ramen is just OK. Just little salty and not much flavor.
Actually my friend told me he can taste some burn.

The Kara-age is quite taste but little cold. Chasyu is just so ordinary.
But also this Chasyu was cold.

Okonomiyaki is kinda too thin not much in it.
I guess I like Hiroshima Style Okonomiyaki than Osaka.
But I never taste Osaka style so I am not sure.

I like the Kushikatsu best. I guess this place good with something good with fried or Grill.

I heard this place Yakitori is quite good so.

I would like to try next time.

Service is kinda slow here. The girls seems very busy. 

But over all is just OK.
author: Faith I.

description:
very close to my house, very close to my heart. i love places like this, very closely related to dim sum and tapas. since i live so close, i often suggest the place for close company. the place is small and not too loud. i suggest good friends as they go great with delicious food and cold beer.

my suggestions are: kushi katsu stuffed musrooms, chicken spleen, chicken skin, bacon enoki and chicken karaage. add beer and laughter, and the first prt of you night will fly by.

if you're short on time and want noodles, i suggest any of the ramens. noodles are perfect, rich broth and always fulfilling.
author: Victor W.

description:
Eleanor Rigby
Meat grilled on sticks over flame
Smiley Sake served

This was my first visit to Halu and it will not be my last.  I found this restaurant while walking in the area in search of a sweater for an Ugly Christmas Sweater Contest - I won the contest by the way- write and I'll tell you about the sweater I made.  Anyway, I saw the place from the street - consulted Yelp on my handy portable device and noted that this was a place I needed to visit.

I finally visited last night with my girlfriend and some friends and we all loved the place.  It is small.  It is very small.  The tables were all full and we were kindly seated at the counter.  There are fun toys to play with and anime on a flat panel above our heads.  Beatles music played on speakers and the smell of meat wafted through the air.  We ordered a bottle of Sake and it was terrific.  We placed our appetizer orders, pan-fried mochi in nori and a japanese pizza.  Before they had arrived we were reseated - as was promised - at a table and we were served.  Both dishes were very good and very unusual for me and I loved them both a lot.  We then ordered Ramen and several of the Yakitori skewers: Pork jowl, oyster chicken, Shishito peppers and enoki chicken.  Each of them were excellent.  The enoki chicken was wrapped in bacon with the enoki mushrooms inserted into the chicken making the dish look somewhat like a small octopus.  We were all very excited and the dish was super excellent.

The waitstaff was very friendly and helpful in majking suggestions.

It was a very fun experience and it felt like something one might find in a small alley near the center of Tokyo.  Japanese Kitch.
author: Bill G.

description:
It was aite!  I can't say that this place has any real stand out quality besides the Beatles interrupting our conversation...My bff and I was pretty hyped up by the yelp reviews - and was kind of let down by the food.  

We went with the chashu ramen - noodles were too soft for both of us.  Broth wasn't too flavorful.  Ordered the Yakitori combo - again...nothing too awesome.   I guess the chef decides what will go in this yakitori combo - we ended up with chicken wings, okra, shrimp, beef, beef ball...lets just say - I thought it was mediocre at best.  I'm willing to give this place another shot tho - just because service was so attentive.  Have to give the miso soup a thumbs up!
author: Julie H.

description:
watch out. limited seating. fresh ramen noodles. yakitori! 
we all live in the yellow submarine, yellow submarine, yellow submarine.
author: Oanh N.

description:
Halu is located on 8th Ave. between Geary and Clement, in the midst of New China Town. 

First thing you'd notice is how they spell the name of this restaurant differently from the dictionary notation. (Halu, instead of Haru. ) As some of you already knew, there's no Rs in the Japanese language, and what's spelled as "R" is actually pronounced as "L" (reasonably close sound, if not exact). The owner is aware of the issue and wrote out the name according to the correct sound. Cool enough,,,though it's a trifling matter. 

When you enter the place, you may start wondering "how come there's no Chinese people dining here despite the location?". When you don't see many local people in a restaurant, that's usually a bad sign. 

One of the following should explain why few Chinese people go to Halu. 

1. Food isn't up to par. 
2. Something in the restaurant repels them. 
3. Expensive 
4. All of above 

IMO, the answer is 2. I think it's the British music being played there all the time that turns Chinese people down at the gate. Mr Lee forfeits and never gets to the 2nd floor to meet Dan Inosanto or a Korean Hapkido Master. Game over. 

While I was having my dinner, they made me listen to 2 Beatles album (Please Please Me, and A Hard Day's Night) at medium volume. It did not bother me because I love Beatles as well as Jimi Hendrix and Pete Townshend that were found in the posters on their wall. The middle aged owner of Halu obviously like those classic anglo-american rock music from 60's and so do I (#1). However, the average Chinese people will probably find it otherwise unless they grew up in America or Japan or developed openness to the cultural diversity. This place may not be for the family-oriented people. 

OK, I wrote enough about them being an unusual Asian eatery in the Chinese neighbourhood. The rest of my review will be on food and service. 

I had several kinds of Yakitori (grilled poultry meat usually skewed w/wo onions) and kara-age (deep-fried chicken thigh). They are cooked properly and they taste OK except beef skews that weren't too fresh. Like any after-5 food should be, they are good to drink with. I personally prefer a charcoal grill (#2) because of the smokey flavor it creates, but I'll cry instead. 

My server was a Japanese speaking young girl who might not be the most attentive one, but I thought she was nice and her Americanized character and attitude fit very well in the international atmosphere. 

I recommend this place to anyone who likes small, cozy oriental restaurants that aren't crowed with homogeneous Asian faces. 


(#1) Japan has some of the geekiest fab-4 maniacs in the world, and that's one of the cool things about Japan that isn't the same in the other Asian countries.

(#2) Cooking Area is pretty much covered up, but I'm sure they don't use chacoal to grill meats.
author: yota L.

description:
Solid 4 stars.  I'm going back this weekend with friends.  I have a good feeling about this place.  Seriously, a gem of a find.  Thank you fellow Yelpers for the recommendation!!!

You ever go to a restaurant on a whim, review the menu and realize there are more items you want to try than you had room for?  That is exactly what my wife and I had to deal with this past weekend.  We showed some self-control and earmarked few items for our future visits but there was still a lot of negotiating back and forth.

I love their ramen; it was simple (sometime Japanese restaurants tend to over do it with... stuff), tasty, and just the right amount of food.  The taste reminded me of my time in Japan.  If a bowl of ramen can bring back memories of Japan, you know its solid.

My recommendation:  Definitely go with Karaage Ramen (soy base) and Chicken stuffed mushroom.  Off da hook!!!  Damn, I thought the whole salivating thing only worked on dogs.
author: Chad N.

description: Halu is one of the most unique establishments in SF.  The family is precious, the food is delicious, the space is small, fun, full of art&rock&smiles.  This is healthy food that brings an element of Japan to SF like no other restaurant I've been to.  They work hard to make the food authentic, unusual and so tasty that you cannot wait to return.
author: Diana M.

description: They should call it Halo because these people are SAINTS! Pork Belly Yakitori? OH-MA-ZING. Some of the best Gyoza in the city, I PROMISE. Also, Japanese comfort food is WAY more comfy with awesome music (Beatles, Seeds, Kinks) and a nice little beer and sake selection. How did I not know about this spot until a month before moving away?
author: jacob g.

description:
This place replaced the oft mentioned Mamasan, which was popular..we went and noticed it was now Halu.  Still being a new place we gave them a chance....

Ordered some food.  Got 2 skewers of shrimp. I piece of shrimp on each skewer for 4.50.  Nothing special about it.  Salt and Pepper and Grilled.  

Took 20+ mins for Ramen.  Decided not to stick around. 

Paid bill... 9 dollars for 2 pieces of shrimp and 2 pieces of salmon skewer....7 dollars for really crappy Sake...

No thanks....

Not recommended...

Rock posters..big deal..Im not in HS anymore...
author: Sharif R.

description:
Koumi Don was, again, delicious and their Avocado Kinoko Veggie Don was also delicious. In the Yakitori items, their chicken wings are salted just right and tsukune are so flavorful.

The last time we were here, the restaurant was busy, although we didn't have to wait for a table, they didn't bring yakitori dinner set in order... first they brought yakitori plate, then five to ten minutes later its rice came, then another 5 minutes later salad came, then another whatever minutes later misoshiru came... Anyway, my point is that when they were busy, the kitchen was not working efficiently enough to bring the set menu at once, and that was why I rated 4 stars previously. The server was very good and pleasant though.

This time, we came in around 6:10pm and we were the first customers of the night, or at least no one was eating in the restaurant when we came in. The food came out so efficiently and the service was again very good. The server here is very smart and nice. I can see myself coming to this restaurant more often, in the earleer time of night.
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
just also recently tried katana ya and i have to say that halu is better. good service and our party of 6 didn't even have to wait for a table at dinner time on a saturday night.

kara age ramen + suntory malt = perfect dinner.
author: Michelle K.

description: This place is soooo good!!! service was great and food was great! atmosphere = super cute!
author: Doro C.

description: I was disappointed that SF didn't have Izakaya Yakitori places like NY till I found Halu. The yakitori selection was phenomenal. The grill gizzard has the perfect crunchy exterior and chewy inside. The beef tongue was equally good. But the Pièce de résistance has to be the butter mochi grill with nori and soy.
author: Cokeaholix X.

description:
Pretty good hole in the wall spot located in the Inner Richmond.  This is the kind of spot I think I would love to visit if I ever made my way to Japan.  Good Ramen, tasty yakatori and beer to knock down while you are at it.  

On my first visit here, all I tried was their Ramen but I think this would be a really cool place to just chill with friends, drink beer and eat some yakitori skewers.  Not sure how late they stay open though.  But if they did open late, it would be a great night out.  

The broth for the Ramen had just the right consistency.  Very tasty.  We had the Lava one, which they advertise as very spicy, seriously!  And I would tend to agree with them.  I can usually eat very spicy and I would say this broth was on the high side of the spectrum.  We also had the Chasu Ramen.  I really liked the taste and tenderness of the meat.  It reminded me of some places in the Chinese cuisine that make really tender beef stew.  The only thing is, I wish they gave a little more meat and even a little more noodles.  Maybe it tasted so good I wanted more.  Or maybe because these bowls of noodles were on the pricier side of what I like to pay for noodle soups.  The Lava one was $9 and the Chasu was $8.75.  I know Good Quality Ramen places are a little trendy right now and popular but hopefully, when even more places open up, competition will set in and prices will have to drop a bit.  
 
I will say I now prefer Halu to Genki, which is a few blocks away.  Genki is still okay but I do feel like they were a lot better the first couple times I tried them.   

The only other drawback was the wait.  They were a little busy on a Saturday evening prime time for dinner but I would think if you go eat at a noodle house, you are wanting or expecting quick service.  Some of my friends have told me in Japan, when you go to Ramen houses, the service is quick.  You order, the food comes out quickly and you are done.  They told me that the places are small so they want you to get in and out so they can maximize their business.  

But I guess since this place is also a Yakitori and beer kind of place, that's the kind of place you don't mind service to be slow.  More or less, you are kicking back with friends when you are eating like that.  

I definitely have to try that experience here at Halu sometime.  I think it'd be LOTS OF FUN.....
author: Mark W.

description:
I love raman. And I love hole in the wall places. So, I love Hulu. But what sets Hulu apart from other raman places is that in their chicken raman they put fried chicken rather than regular, old, run of the mill strips of over poached chicken bites. At first, while you read this, that might seem gross. It's not. It also might seem like a bastardization of Japanese raman. I guess it is. Oh well. Regardless, it's amazing. 

There were also some apps we had that were notably tasty as well. I would try the crunchy but cooked potatoes and the bacon wrapped scallops (I mean, doesn't everything wrapped in bacon taste good?).

So when you want your raman fix, this is your place. Although, one thing, it's not as speedy as more average, not so tasty raman places...the food and the "vintage" decor make up for this in spades.
author: Jacky H.

description: Oh my. They do yakitori SO WELL. We tried the bacon mochi (grilled mochi cubes wrapped with bacon), shiso beef, mushroom wrapped with chicken and with cheese (I think), agedashi tofu, and chashu-men. We were pleasantly surprised with how tasty and good everything was! We shared everything and the yaki were definitely the best part of the meal! Nicely seasoned and grilled just perfectly, they were just so nice. I would definitely go back to try more!
author: Reese W.

description: I didn't even know this was here! I had always gone to Genki Ramen. This place literally has 4-5 tables, and some bar stools. I got the Chasu-men and it was delicious. The portion didn't look that excessive, but I was stuffed by the time I finished! It's pretty good, and I'll probably definitely be back here!
author: Jennifer H.

description: If you like The Beatles, like yummy skewers, and like ramen then why not come here??? Its tiny so seating is scarce but when you do get that table its a great place to be. I been here many times and unlike others the service I have experienced here has been great. Love the Beatles decor and there volcano ramen mMm :)
author: Anthony S.

description:
i never understood the name, or the subname. 

"Halu: A Different Japanese Restaurant"

I thought this referenced the fact that there used to be a different japanese restaurant in the same space. And why is there an L in the name? Very confusing. But decided to try on the merit of its Yelp rating.

Um, super cutes. I'd been looking for a homey little restaurant with no sushi. Bingos! Super homey and little and cute. Beatles memorabilia, little tchotchkes everywhere, and an unfussy attitude.

Got the Yakitori Dinner, a large Sapporo, and the Kara-age ramen.

the Yakitori dinner was amazing. best yakitori i've had stateside. the little meatball had delicious mysteries hidden inside, and everything was cooked beautifully. I was happily surprised by how good the chicken was. Chicken, for me, is always a blah blah meat because its usually dry and tasteless. THIS chicken was mother-clucking good. $16 though. but for a little girl like myself, half was enough food to be satisfied.

The ramen wasn't as good though. I thought the broth was too thick and salty. Won't go on too much about it; but I wouldn't order it again. Just yakitori. AND they have kushi-age! haven't tried it, but its on my to-do. hurray for non-sushi Japanese food!
author: Jade L.

description: Little hole in the wall restaurant we found on a list of Best Ramen in the City. Small seating and slow service due to Mom doing the cooking while the daughters provide the service but very charming. Chicken Kaarage Ramen was yummy. The noodles are thinner than what I'm used to but a nice bite. The fried chicken was crispy and juicy and accompanied the bean sprouts and green onions in the ramen. We also ordered various yakitori (pork jowl, gizzards and chicken skin) which were good but salty. We ordered a beer to go with the yakitori and it was a perfect combination. Cute place but will probably only go if I'm ever in the neighborhood.
author: gail c.

description: Beatles and Jimi Hendrix memorabilia, a sign outside that says "No sushi allowed past this door, do not ask for sushi," Ramen, Yakitori, Ume, Japanese Pizza, and if you're really adventurous: gizzards, heart, organs, etc. As others have said, the space is really small, but the staff was great, and this place is just - awesome!
author: Ken L.

description: Great! No MSG. Real-tasting ramen, great place. Love it!
author: Dr K.

description: I might give it a rating if this place was open during business hours or at least had a sign explaining why it's closed at 6:30 on a Friday. I had such high hopes for the yakitori and was starving by the time I got to inner richmond. I suppose I should have called before making the trek, but usually only Jamaican joints aren't open during advertised business hours. Huge letdown, blood sugar non-existent, I'm mad.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
This is a legit Japanese place that is great if you are craving all of the lovely little plates that Japanese cuisine has to offer.  The place is small and  can feel cramped, but the friendly and accommodating makes up for that.  This place winds up feeling warm and cozy.  
The food is lovely and they have the best yakitori I have tasted outside if Japan.   They also have a good selection of sakes and traditional fare to go with beer or sake.  The sushi was fresh and they got the rice just right, which is of the upmost importance.  I would pass on the ramen, but it is not all that bad.  Be prepared to order four or five dished for a couple as the portions are small, which goes along with the cuisine.
author: Pandy F.

description:
wow - the spicy ramen was great!  and hot!  and i'm no sissy with the spicy!  the soup coupled with the most yummy bacon wrapped scallop yakitori and beer and sake straight from Japan made for a most excellent meal.  

the atmosphere is really cool, too.  all the old beatles and 60's rock memorabilia with complementary music playing was unexpected at first, but really added to the charm.

I'll definitely go again!
author: Aimee D.

description: the best japanese izakaya in sf, just be careful before you know it your bill is bigger than your belly!  However it is worth every penny just show up early and be prepared to wait large parties beware, and remember closed on sunday.
author: Justin S.

description:
entered a few minutes before closing and was greeted as usual by the whole loving halu family.  sat at the booth and erichan and her mama told us about the curry they just made which i was soo thrown off by as i never saw it on the menu before.

along with that sayachan said the oden was another new dish we should test drive, which made me wet my pants as the last few times i have been here i simply ordered my routine of grilled okra, ribeye, mochi (get the erichan special!), ramen and drinks...now we have these other dishes i listed along with a rare find in the bay- OKONOMIYAKI!!! (kanto-style)

so the curry was impeccable, on par or better than muracci's.  the oden broth was savory, comforting and sweet enough to offset the flavorful mustard they provided for dipping of the various yummy morsels.

they made a small dish of sliced green beans flavored with a light miso w/ crushed walnuts and it was such a treat.

shortly after closing the father and master griller- Shigsan ran off like he usually does to go play drums for his band the Shitones over at park chalet and it was so adorable how his wife was all excited and went off to support him, they even invited us!!!

we were laughing with eri and saya as their parents ran off to play and i commented to them how fun they are..so much flavor ; P  sayachan said yes they are different!  just like halu. my home away from home.
author: omar b.

description:
Oh my goodness. So expensive. I went here with two friends and we ordered a bunch of yakitori and the katsu plate. We spent $89 and we weren't even full. We hit up Volcano Curry afterward just to fill up some more.

The yakitori was ok. Nothing impressive or amazing except for the mochi and bacon yakitori. Now that was the FREAKKING bomb. 'nuff said. That's the only item I'll be going back for.
author: S. H.

description:
I had a high expectation of this place because of the reviews I read.  I knew it is a hole in a wall kind of place - and yes, it was small and very narrow.
We mainly ordered various types of veg and yakitori.  They were all very good.  Tsukune (meat ball) was rather spicy, but each item had its own distinctive authentic flavor.  They were friendly to kids.  Beetles' music was blasting and very casual.  Not a romantic Japanese dinner kind of place, but cosy and casual.  We will go back there to enjoy and try other things on the menu next time.
author: Miinno N.

description:
kaarage bowl
served with Beatlemania
yakitori yum!
author: Mel H.

description:
Super friendly staff and cool vibe.  Ordered mostly off the specials board.  I was bummed they didn't have the marinated fresh octupus.  We did have the 
chicken skin yakitori-  i expected it would be at least a little crispy but it was totally chewy.  don't get me wrong, i'm the kind of person that likes my bacon chewy vs. crispy but it just wasn't what i expected
trumpet mushroom yakitori- meaty and hearty
chicken gizzard yakitori - not for me - i don't like the texture of gizzard but heard it was the tastiest
pork belly yakitori- the best bang for the buck and yummy
karaage ramen - noodles had good texture and broth was pretty good but i think KatanaYa is still better
agedashi tofu -surprised they used such a soft tofu for this but the broth was sooooooo good
okra kushi - i love okra, probably would try it yakitori next time
the place is probably a little pricey given the hole in the wall vibe but I'd come back!
author: Amina B.

description: One of the most authentic yakitori places in town. Great experience.  I have been there many times already. You won't find a better place for yakitori in the bay area! The food is prepared by the Japanese owners (which means, they know what they are doing). The ramen is great. The menu has many options despite the fact that it is a small restaurant.  I have lived in Japan for two years and I have learned about good Japanese food. So you won't be disappointed.
author: Ana Paula F.

description: Halu is a very small and cozy Japanese restaurant offers everything but sushi. the place has very interesting appetizers as well as its famous ramen and pancakes. i will definitely go back again.
author: Connie H.

description:
This place is great. Food is good, family owned, casual and this place is actually run and owned by Japanese! 
and how can you not love meat on sticks?
author: t t.

description:
part of me selfishly doesn't want to leave a review for this place. halu is housed in a thin strip of ground level storefront in the inner richmond. if everyone ends up loving the restaurant as much as my friend and i did, we would never be able to find any seating. 

that said, halu seems to be one of those little restaurant that could, and as you can see from this page of enthusiastic reviews, i'm not the first person to be charmed by their thick, steaming bowls of savory ramen, pungent bowls of seaweed-sesame spinach and cute, flavorful beef skewers.  

the decor is all vintage rock. as you sit under signed electric guitars and mint condition japanese beatles posters, you'll feel as though you're dining in the hipster district of tokyo in the 1960s. and at the end of the meal, the bill will make you feel even more as if you've stepped into some kind of time warp. our meal of appetizers, bbq skewers,  drinks and ramen came to less  than $25 for two people.
author: annie l.

description: Of course with the Beatles Rock Band coming out and all I'm sure some many people will enjoy the decor of this place. The owners are awesome and have a great relationship with the locals who frequent this place. It was my first time and I from the beginning enjoyed the service, and if I'm not mistaken mostly if not all Beatles tracks. My friend enjoyed the Yaki-tori and I tried the Ramen (Vegetarian dish has 10 types of vegetables). I have to say this place is authentic and has many elements that create an enjoyable experience with a smaller group of friends, as it is a small shop.
author: Triangle T.

description: I've been to Halu many times.  It's time I wrote a review.for one of my favorite izakaya in the city!  I recommend coming early because this place gets PACKED and also trying the mushroom/avocado/vegetarian donburi dish (cannot recall the name now).  I know it does not sound like much and trust me I am an avid meat-eater, but this dish will satisfy any carnivore.  It is savory, earthy, and buttery.  YUM YUM YUM!!!
author: Sarah K.

description:
I ordered the pork ramen but they gave us the vegetable one... which was still good, we didn't notice that the pork was missing until 5 minutes into eating. Either we were really hungry, or it was that good. Prices are average for a ramen place. 

It is very small inside, be ready to wait. The Beatles memorabilia is cool and interesting to look at.
author: Retired B.

description: I haven't rated a place five stars in a while and I almost knocked it down to 4 due to the slow service. Do not come here if you are in a hurry. Having said that, this place is the closest I have come to a true Izakaya outside of Japan. Great skewers and likely the best Ramen in the city. If it wasn;t for my 9 month old starting to turn to the dark side, I would have spent another hour here just filling up. I am getting excited just thinking about it and eagerly waiting my next trip....sans baby
author: John D.

description:
We ordered yaki onigiri & seaweed mochi which was not that great, and also some yakitori which we didn't finish.  The only thing we had that was good was the asparagus yakitori and the seaweed salad.

I did enjoy the Beatles music but it was really a let down for us after what we read on yelp.
author: Andrew B.

description: Mediocre ramen (kind of thin, the flavors don't blend together) and super funky decor.  I guess I don't get the classic rock theme.  I didn't like the old Mama-San either, so maybe it's just not for me.
author: Eric W.

description:
hooray for halu!

this joint is just a few blocks from my flat.  finally decided to check them out tonight for a late-ish dinner.  i remember the day they had their grand opening in the neighborhood, a good sized crowd and a live band...festive.  been meaning to try it ever since.

after a quick looksee of their food offerings on yelp, i decide to make the short walk and plunge.

ya know, there's people on yelp who write their reviews on restaurants who begin right away with some negative mindset,  or some comment like, "...i hate [this type of food], so yeah, this food was awful...blah, blah, blah...", so kind of a loaded gun, right?  a pre-disposed dislike, only bolstered by a pre-determined conclusion for the review.  so wtf, why even bother writing it?

so anyways, we went in and remember the size of the space from the previous establishment. it was similarly cozy, but with a fun 1960's vibe with the beatles playing in the background and related retro memorabilia.  our greeter/server was all smiles.  very cute and sat us right down.  i dug my cushy chair pillow.

since we heard to try their specialty of grilled yakatori, that's what we did, got the yakatori deluxe diner, an extra order of asparagus and trumpet mushrooms, a beer to share, the cold tofu appetizer and waited.

sapporo was served icey cold.  japanese beer should never come cool or warmer. sucked that down in short order.

cold tofu was yummy.

yakatori deluxe dinner came and with a slightly different combo of skewers than normal.  our server said they were closed on sundays so they had some extra selections to share with us.  very nice.  the plate we got had the chicken wings, pork short ribs, shrimp, salmon, chicken thigh, okra, & stuffed mushrooms.  we also got our 2 addons too.  all ingredients were fresh, hot, and well prepared.

the miso was really flavorful and HOT. nice, miso soup needs to come HOT.  don't ya just hate tepid miso?  well this wasn't anywhere close.  tasty miso, yay!

well, all in all a very nice grilled japanese skewers dinner.  def hit the spot if you're in the mood for this type of japanese eats.  not a huge menu, but doesn't need to be.  come here for the yakatori.  l'll be back.

:-P
author: Patrick M.

description:
Fantastic and delicious. Yakitori, the ramen and karaage - heaven. Grilled gingko nuts, mochi many ways, grilled pig jowl - unique. Bacon wrapped scallops - OMG!

This is a family-run restaurant, a little neighborhood gem. Unpretentious and simple, serving authentic and amazing Japanese food hard to find in the Bay Area. The service can be a bit slow, but you can see from the SMALL kitchen - where mom and dad cook-  and sisters-servers running around that there's no one slacking here. It would be different if you saw them taking frequent smoke breaks, but they're not. They are busy cooking and serving as best they can in a small place. 

Solution - don't come here rushed; come with someone you really enjoy talking to. Sit back and enjoy the quirkiness of the place, and order another sake. Imagine you're in a beachside bar in Kamakura, which is exactly the vibe. Those bacon-wrapped scallops are totally worth it!
author: R D.

description:
hiya. oh man, the only difference between me and those creepy white people who are obsessed with everything japanese, is that i am japanese.
i so very much wish i was more japanese!!
Halu has some jammin skewer and fried food.  every thing  is so dang good and savory and grilly and deepfriedy,  maybe i would call it japanese soul food. 
for me, it is even more unique than rumblefish.  it is a different sector of japanese cooking that is yet to become a part of mainstream japanese restaurant offerings.
The greatest part of my experience at halu was being able to grub and drink and listen to some rolling stones street fighting man, and led zeppelin i can't quit you baby.  
those songs are the musical equivalent to halu's food.
fucking rock and roll.
author: yayoi s.

description:
Great food in a small place. We were brought here by  knowledgeable culinary friend.
Excellent noodles, but the real gems are the skewers and sides AND fried chicken. Doing it again, I may go all skewers -- though tough to pass on ramen.
Sorta spotty service, a bit hole-in-the-wall, but really, really hard to fail here for great eats.
author: Sa B.

description: Had an awesome time here with some friends.  This is a cozy little place with no more than 5 tables.  We were able to try a huge portion of the menu but it's kind of a hit or miss.  They have a nice selection in the menu and specials posted on the wall but they also have items that I didnt see on the menu, like chicken skin yakitori.
author: Jen L.

description:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T_2FwSTcZvw

(I was alone, I took a ride, I didn't know what I would find there!)

Hello little chicken wings. I love how you're all spread out and skewered so nicely, lightly sprinkled with sea salt and grilled to succulent perfection.

(another road, where maybe I could see another kind of mind there!)

How you doin', bacon-wrapped scallops? A little squeeze of lemon brightens your smokey, tenderness perfectly on my palate.

(Oo, and I suddenly see you! Oo, did I tell you I need you...)

What it is, steamy bowl of chewy ramen! Your soy broth was rich and savory. Too bad I'd had some lousy packaged ramen earlier or I'd happily obliged helping Jeff finish you off (yes, i really wasn't alone). But what up with the corn? 

(Got to get you into my life!)

I'll be seein' you, Halu!  With your fresh salad, brown rice, thinly sliced and grilled zucchini, and Beatles memorabilia accompanying our meal, you have ranked high on my list of favorite places to eat in the Richmond... maybe even SF.

(...every. single. day. of my life!)
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
Hole in the walls, there is something about them that i like and its not that there small, a little too intimate, sometimes hard to get in and have long waits or that you can literally sit next to the kitchen.  Just think of the long list of great restaurants that started off as hole in the walls, mom and pap places, and neighborhood favorties.  In SF, Slanted Door and Delfina in the MIssion, how about Boulevard, owner originally was the chef of an Irish bar in the Richmond just to name of few.  But many great chefs and owners move on to bigger and better things. I'm all about the sweet spot, the time when these restaurants peak.  RIght before they make it big and have to mass produce their food.  When their kitchen and staff is still small enough for the head chef to control and put their personal touch to the preparation of the food.  
The atmosphere:
Sumi is a new hole in the wall restaurant.  I remember previously there was a not so great restaurant at this location, but the owners have done a great job with this little space.  Who can deny Japanese food (this is a yakitori place) and the Beattles theme?  It's such a fun combination, being half Japo, my parents generation would appreciate the theme.  There was a family there with 2 young boys and I could just imagine when they grow up reminiscing about the yakitori restaurant there parents used to take them to as children that used to rock the Beattles.  So its great for the older gen and kids.
The food:
I had the yakitori dinner, which comes with edamame, miso and rice, fyi they have brown rice.  The yt dinner was an assortment of chicken, beef, mushrooms, and shrimp.  The chicken was by far the most tastiest of the assortmnent mmmmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!!!!
