Service was great, as the waitress continually did the check in and asked how the food was, of which the chef could probably hear due to the tinyness of the space.
author: Aaron I.

description: Mmmm. cozy place that feels like an escape into another world. get the seaweed wrapped grilled mochi for sure. get 2. i think it's called ericachan's special? sometimes i've had the yakitori and it's a little too salty, but usually everything is great and perfect. the stuffed mushroom on skewers are good. i like the grilled gingko nuts and the spicy ramen is delicious. not good for a big group and expect a little bit of a wait. worth it. enjoy.
author: s o.

description: Crowd ebbs and flows here. Count yourself lucky if you go during a slow time. Great Japanese food in the Imner Richmond.
author: Keith K.

description: Truthfully thought the ramen was a little disappointing but the yakitori is on point and the atmosphere has it's own charm.
author: Andrew T.

description: If you are a Beatles fan (which I am) you will definitely like this lil joint. The whole restaurant is littered with Beatles memorabilia. When I say little I mean tiny. Only enough seats for about 20 people and that might be pushing it. Great yakitori. No sushi here. If you haven't tryed this style of Japanese food this place is a great introduction. Tasty skewers and little piles of delicious fryed or grilled morsels. Great ramen too!! Mom and Pop type place that makes this a nice izakaya.
author: Christopher T.

description: Specialty restaurants is what makes san francisco a special foodie city.  When coming to Halu, try to look past its crampted location becuase you're in store for some special yakitori goodness.  And I mean the kind other than your normal chicken variety. I'm talking chicken hearts, chicken livers, bacon wrapped inori mushrooms, and beef to name a few.  All of which are charcoaled to perfection and dipped in a teriyaki sauce.  Their chicken karage and ramen comepletes your meal nicely along with a good beer or sake.  Come with cash(cash only) and an empty stomach, you'll leave home full and happy!
author: Jason A.

description:
Mamasan is no more...sad because the owners were so nice.  Not so sad is that Halu took over the spot and I'm really quite happy.  I love izakaya's (its a bar that serves Japanese small plates or big plates) and I think Halu is the closest thing to one in this neighborhood.  The yakitori selection was pretty good.  They even had chicken hearts on the menu...yum!  I was with the bf so no chicken hearts were ordered.  We did get the chicken wings (2 skewers, 2 wings on each)and the bacon wrapped scallop (2 skewers, 2 scallops on each) with two big sapporos.  Any place who serves bacon wrapped scallops holds a special place in my heart, specially the ones who grill it over charcoal.  It was satisfying, but not filling, so we each ordered ramen as well.
The chasu ramen was good, not great like katana-ya, but decent.  It had a rich broth that was made with tender loving care by the rocker chef.  It had layers of flavor that lets you know he didn't just open up a package of MSG and powdered broth and mixed it in water.  The noodles on the other hand were definitely not great quality. It was a little too soft for me. It didn't have that same bite as house made noodles like katana-ya, but of course ramen is not their specialty. I'd definitely order it again.
The service was not bad when I went. I know the other reviews mentioned that they were forgetful.  I can definitely see that happening.  Good thing i'm not above reminding the ladies that  more food and drinks are supposed to hit my table.  They were pretty nice and helpful. Not too bad price wise. I think the bill came out to $34 w/o tip.
author: Maria B.

description: I would have walked right by this place had I not heard about this no sushi Japanese restaurant.  My friend and I shared some yakitori-- the bacon and scallop is great! The chicken gizzard was awesome and zucchini was nice too! I had the chicken karage ramen. Chicken was tasty but the ramen was just so-so. I've had better elsewhere, including in my own kitchen, and thought it could have used more flavor. My friend had the fried chicken don, which comes with a yummy salad and brown rice. She loved it. Decor was kitscy and music all Beatles.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Maybe I'm jaded from living in San Francisco too long, but every time I walked by Halu and saw the "Imagine Peace" sign hanging on their door, I felt the same inner groan that pained me whenever this crazed, aging hippy named Diamond Dave raised his hand during an
Anthro class I took at CCSF.We could be discussing Steel Axes for Stone Age Australians and he would still find a way to talk about the Rainbow Gathering.

That and the ever present Grand Opening sign that has been hanging outside for as long as I can remember, made me suspect of this tiny restaurant.

I couldn't have been more wrong.

I ate there on a whim with fellow Yelper, the lovely Heather G, and was surprised by the fun of the place, which is loaded with Beatles memorabilia and has a huge flat screen that plays old TV footage from music/dance shows circa 1965.

Great miso soup. Great selection of sake and beer. The sauce on the agadashi tofu was so tasty I was sipping it out of the small bowl it was served in and slightly disappointed when the waitress took the bowl away while there was sill some sauce left. The chicken thigh skewers with strips of green onion were sweet and delicious. I found
the short ribs to be a salty on their own, but the fruity sake we had really balanced it out.

The women who served us were sweet and kind. 

This is a great, inexpensive place to get drunk on sake and eat some authentic, inexpensive Japanese food.

PS - My most recent "Diamond Dave" spotting involved him wrongly indicating which direction was North to a group of people performing a
Native American prayer ritual on the CCSF campus. Previous to that, I heard him on NPR, calling in to ask what the "vibe" was going to be
like at the Grateful Dead Archive at UC Santa Cruz.
author: Mr. L.

description:
MY BF is all about the ramen but for me, it's KUSHIKATSU, baby.
Luckily with Halu, we finally have one place that does justice with both of our favorites! Of course, I've only had kushikatsu (soo good! cooked just right for that CRUNCH and juicy in the inside!) and yakitori the last two visits but my bf swears the ramen is good and he's pretty effing picky, if you ask me. If the miso I had with my skewers is any indication of the ramen broth they have, then I say "Right On!" Staff and service is
solid for a new place, never even had to ask for anything. Friendly wait staff was always there refilling water glasses and whatnot. 

The only bad thing is that this place is like mere blocks away from our home...when we're particularly lazy, I think it will be hard to resist coming to this place! ;) Oh and it's kinda sweaty hot if it's a full house...I think a small fan in the back would go a long way...
author: J. L.

description: definitely a new neighborhood fave! the veggie skewers were amazing, and what i sampled of the veggie pancake my boyfriend ordered (and devoured) was really tasty. great food, great atmosphere, and great service.
author: K K.

description:
I was so hopeful.  Hopeful to find a go-to izakaya that served delicious food.  Hopeful that the Ramen would be on par with the Halu of San Jose.  Hopeful that I would have found a great new hole in the wall restaurant.  Hopeful that I would LOVE Halu.

You can wish and hope, but it will not always ring true.  Halu was good and up to standard, but I was not blown away.

The Ramen was good but not amazing.  The noodles were of good texture and the broth was yum.  The Koumi Don gets points for being served with brown rice, but it didn't blow anyone's socks off, the chicken was a bit too greasy.

I might return to Halu for the Yakitori.  And yes, I will be hopeful.
author: Ashley Q.

description: I came upon this looking for good ramen in SF. The ramen is indeed pretty good (for the US), but the yakitori is what really makes this place shine. I would like to go back and explore the menu some more, but I haven't had real yakitori since living in Japan. The variety and flavor is all there. I can see how a little patience with seating and service is necessary, although we got there at 7 on a Wednesday and were able to sit immediately.
author: Jeff L.

description: This is a tiny ramen house on 8th Ave near Clement St. playing cool classic rock videos. We arrived about 5:30pm, there was ample street parking. The restaurant was pretty empty by the time we left close to 7pm, only a total of three tables. The ramen was tasty. Too bad they were sold out of gyoza. The staff was friendly and attentive. We will definitely be back. Only complaint is this place is way too smoky, it's like dining at "Brothers".
author: Rich W.

description: Having lived in Japan for a long time, this place really does it for me. The ramen was excellent, it's tough to find good yakitori anywhere,  the staff awesome and I love the rock and roll environs. Honto ni arigatou!
author: jeffrey s.

description:
Yakitori... Kushiyaki... Sukiyaki... Shabu Shabu... What's with all these new Japanese specialty restaurants? I mean, there are Shabu places popping up all over. Shabu House, Shabusen, Shabuway (imagine William Hung saying "Subway")...  You also have your ramen houses such as Genki (is that Japanese for janky, because the food is), Santa Ramen, etc... 

Now comes the yakitori eateries. Well, at least Halu is the start of it. Sure there are other places that have yakitori, but Halu puts its Yakitori on center stage. So is this the Japanese version of a diner or dive? When you walk in you notice the place is small, the decor is all Beatles memoribilia, and if you look over the counter there's the dinky kitchen. The menu consists of the main categories: yakitori, kushiyaki, and ramen. I'd have to say the yakitori was at times over-salted, but all-in-all very juicy and flavorful. The bacon wrapped scallop was the winner. Sure, it's a great combo that's a proven winner, but you've got to execute which they did. We only tried the zuchni kushiyaki (bascially  tempura on a stick), and that was pretty standard. The simple ramen could've needed a but of livening up, but the noodles tasted fresh and real. Nothing like your college variety Top Ramen.

I can only give this place three stars for now because some of the inconsistencies in the food. But there's something to this place, it's got me hooked.
author: Al L.

description: came here on a Friday night at 10PM, sat at the counter. The waitress was incredibly nice and helpful and the food was great, I had the fried chicken rice bowl and it was the perfect comfort food. The yakitori was flavorful and generous in size, the beef was a little too salty but nothing that would keep me away; the bacon-wrapped scallops and pork and onions were yummy. My boyfriend had the chiasu ramen and the noodles were perfectly chewy, flavorful broth and tender pork. There was some live-recorded rock music on the TV and the beatles memorabilia was charming. There were 2 drunk guys slumped at a table in the back passed out and I have to hand it to the Halu people for their diplomacy and tact in dealing with them. I can't wait to go back. Fantastic comfort food, don't expect a lot of diet-friendly low-fat stuff.
author: Allie D.

description:
came here for the ramen.  friday night 9pm hardly anyone there, sat immediately.  cold tofu (hiya-yakko) and chicken karaage appetizers, then a hefty bowl of ramen each.  the soy broth has a very good taste.  the noodles have a good consistency, and the pork/chashu are good solid slices of tender and not super fatty nor cheap meat.

it's a cute place.  it could be a totally mellow/casual date for some girl who likes good simple food, or could just be a good spot for ramen, and im sure the other foods (but we didn't have any, next time for sure).  i would definitely come back, it's a toss up between here and katana-ya.  this joint is much quieter, obviously easier parking, and i'm leaning towards the noodles and pork here.
author: Jason J.

description: love them!  i still get their ramen, but now i order a lot of their skewers.  SO good.  and somehow we always manage to snag the last table before the rush.  the server came over once to apologize for the delay in our food (before we even noticed) and brought over edamame on the house and she always checks on our pot of tea.  thanks for the pen!  see you soon!!
author: Janice C.

description:
I love this place. The unsual decor, the yummy takitori, the crowded bench, and the wonderful waitresses. The food has never disappointed, although the wait has- what can you expect its a tiny place. 

The gizzards are good, I'd recommend you try it. 
The bacon wrapped scallops were also a must try. 

All the ramen I've tried were good, but nothign to write home about. This place really is all about the yakitori!
author: Josh M.

description: This place is good. The soup of the ramen is very yummy and special! The price is reasonable too. The only thing bothers me is the waiting line is kind of long during weekend but this is a good place to eat!
author: Lisa J.

description:
i've been trying to find a good yakitori place in sf for a while now so when i saw this on yelp, i was really excited to try it but overall i would say it was a bit of a disappointment. i didn't try the ramen but after reading some of the reviews, i should probably go back to try it since i love ramen but instead, we ordered a bunch of different yakitori (gizzard, okra, asparagus, chicken thigh, short rib), a soba noodle dish and some other items i can't even remember much less pronounce.

overall, i thought everything was a little too salty and it can get a little pricy. i do really like the space though, it's decorated with beatles memorabilia everywhere and the tiny space gives it a warm homey feel which i love. 

if you do go, i would definitely check first to see what is on the specials menu since from where we were sitting, it was a bit hidden.
author: georgette y.

description:
We came here after work tonight looking for Miso Ramen and came to find out they do not have it today.....so we both had Soy Char Su Ramen....It was just as good.  The noodle is not as good as Katana-ya but the broth was the bomb.
We also had Daikon Radish salad....awsome as well.
We originally ordered the Chicken liver Yakitori & the Enoki Bacon but they were over whelm with a big table order of them b 4 us and didn't even remember to do it.....They apologize for the mistake but luckily we were full from the Ramen already.  
The place is small but cozy....music is kinda loud but cool!
They are about 1 month old and probably still trying to work out the timing thing as we have to wait for quite sometime to get our food.
Will definitely come back......
BTW....it is Japanese owned and operate!!!
author: Mel T.

description:
Overpriced. Okay food. Not that flavorful. Too expensive for very little meat on 1 stick.  Ramen overrated.  Service slow.

Wait is horrible and seating seems disorderly:
Walked in - 2 of us.  There was an empty table, waitress says there's 1 party ahead of us - 10-15mins wait (not bad..but this was about 9:45pm).  Noone else was waiting though, probably on the phone list/resos?  10mins later, a party of 2 comes in, and another waitress asks them "how many?" and they say 2, and then seats them in that empty table.  We stood in the corner like... What?!  Okay..maybe they were that party and the waitress knew?  Another party comes in 10mins later and asks for the wait and gets seated before we do.  I told that waitress - we were here before these guys.  She picks up the "waitlists" and points to the top of the list where all the names were crossed off, and said they were here first. Bullshit. Because, those guys also knew we were there first, and actually stepped outside.  Pretty much left after that (the 20mins of waiting and looking at the menu and prices also made us realize it wasn't worth it).

Disclaimer - I've been here once before.  Same thing happened.  But, the previous time, we actually benefited and cut a couple of other people because that same waitress is just clueless.  I guess - das is karma.

Cute, friendly girl.  But just perky and clueless.  

Cute place, though.  

Most likely not coming back.  This experience has taught me to be loyal to my other joint, which the yakitori, ramen and everything is just much better.
author: Judy C.

description:
okay, first let's start with their great awning/sign that warns white people from California Ave and beyond to check themselves before they wreck themselves: "A Different Kind of Japanese Restaurant".
great. and so it begins.

This place used to be called Mama-San and all I remember is their Wall of Victims, where photos of first time visitors were sticky-taped to the walls to make you think they were happy regulars. ha~! That illusion only lasted so much. sorry to bust you out, Mama-san~

Halu is a Japanese-family-owned yakitori, ramen and kushikatsu joint. Note the hyphens connecting Japanese and family. Yes, they are a Japanese family. No big deal you may say. But it is quite the big difference. 

I love what they did to the interior of this place, it went from greasy spoon, to cute little place with totally San Francisco appropriate rock posters on the wall. Rock and pop from the 60's/70's plays in the background. Another extra cookie for not playing some Hiroshima or Joe Hisaishi (not that i don't love Hisaishi instrumentals). Halu has its own personality. 

The staff is super nice and attentive, they will ask/answer questions about the food no problem. 

I'm just happy to see a yakitori place by my house. it wasn't the most amazing yakitori i've had (Genki Ramen doing a rather decent job at it not far from here.) but their mushrooms were on point and super tasty. 
Also, the Kushikatsu is not your everyday find in SF, so we're all glad for the crunchy love that is their kushi. 
The roommate had ramen and loved it too much. 

we're definitely coming back. only warning: it's cash only.
author: Tomas V.

description: Pretty darn good first try. A full slate of yakitori, plus ramen and other goodies. The gomaae was excellent, and the ramen tasty (though maybe a step below Katanaya). The donburi used brown rice, which was a nice touch. The staff was super-nice. I was pleasantly reminded of the vibe back when this was Mama San's, back in the late 1990s. The owner has the same name as a former member of the band Hot Tuna. I figure it's the same person.
author: OuterLands X.

description:
Perhaps I've been spoiled by the yakitori in NYC, but I was expecting much better based on the reviews here. The place was pretty empty when I showed up on  Saturday evening. 

The service was very slow, but that's probably b/c there was only one waitress and yakitori does takes some time to cook. 

But, when the food finally arrives, I found it to be too salty and lukewarm. The char-siu in my ramen tasted and smelled of old, re-microwaved pork.

Concept of the place is good, prices are decent, but the food needs some work...
author: Roger R.

description:
For those of you who lament the loss of family-owned, neighborhood restaurants this is the perfect place for you.  Good yakitori and ramen cooked by mom, dad and their daughter - served to you by their other daughter.  What stood out was the friendly way in which they treat their customers but keep in mind, they're a small restaurant where the entire family is working hard to keep things moving along.  If you want efficiency, go to Chili's where everything is pre-made....

Food-wise, the ramen is very good and their lava ramen is quite spicy - right on the border of pain and pleasure.  The ramen noodles have a good bite.  As for the other dishes, all are good and I would recommend the bacon wrapped-mochi and the chicken karaage.
author: Jason M.

description:
after hearing so much about this place, i finally got to go for dinner.  get there early, b/c it gets crowded, and there are not many seats.  i tried the ramen, the veggie heaven salad, the veggie rice bowl (forgot what it's called), and various yakitori skewers.  everything was good, particularly the rice bowl.  i think the fried chicken rice bowl is supposed to be excellent, but i thought the veggie one w/ avocado, greens, and mushrooms was yummy already.  

there are various shochu drinks, and you can get them w/ different mixers w/ your choice of # of shots.  i only got one shot mixed w/ guava juice, was a bit weak, so i'd opt for 2 shots next time.
author: Helen T.

description:
The 1 star is a combination of food but mostly of service.
My friend and i went to the restaurant around 8:05- 8:10 to order some food as she has heard they are quite good. We had no idea what to order so we ask for some suggestion and the staff was very delightful and helpful. once we are done with ordering she said that it will probably take 30 minutes or so, so we said fine no problem.
We came back around 8:45 to check and as I go in she has no idea who I was ( I know the restaurant is busy but seriously how many people that night came in with white shorts?) but eventually she figures out and proceed to tell me that they haven't made our food because they are sooooo busy. At that point I was lost for words. They apologies and said sorry we will make it now and it will be 20 minutes so i bit my tongue and let them prepared our food. Finally at 9:08 I went in again and the food was ready, when I got into the car my friend said did you check if everything was there so I open up and what you know they forgot our order of yaki onigiri.
The staff had the audacity of asking us if we wanted to wait for them to make it, by that time I was beyond upset but all I did was to ask for the money back and walked out.
I know restaurants are busy but if you can't get my order right after WAITING FOR ONE HOUR there's something really wrong here. I'm definitely not looking for freebies or anything but all they did was apologies and walk off. 
I've been to Bake Sale Betty quite often and EVERY SINGLE time either waiting in line or buying a strawberry short cake they will always give a cookie on the house. I know it's silly & stupid but it works and it shows that they care about the people who visit their shop.
OK, back to the nightmare that it HALU. This is what we order, a Kushikatsu set, and a couple items from their Yakitori menu. I have to say all the items we tasted from the Yakitori section are quite good but the fried stuff was such a disappointment, do they know that a little bit of salt goes A LONG WAY??? just because it comes with katsu sauce doesn't mean that you don't have to add any salt.
I much rather pay a little more to eat at Kirala in  Berkeley than to endure this shitty mess again.
author: Andres K.

description: Not your typical Japanese restaurant...there is NO sushi.  They are known for small plates....very unique as we don't have many of this type of Japanese restaurant in the bay area.  I have tried several items and loved them all!  The grilled salmon rice balls, the fried stuffed mushrooms, the chicken meatballs...so yum!  I also tried the ramen which is not the best I've had...I still like Tanpopo in Japantown better.  So many different yakatori options I can't wait to go back and try more!  Also great service from the girls there!
author: Tina L.

description: Halu was adorable.  It seats about 25 people if packed.   The staff, coupled with 50's American rock memorabilia serves delicious pork and onion yakitori as well as shiitake yakitori - variety I did not check everything.  Also ramen looked good as did their rice balls.  They have soju, sake and wine and the best ever attitude.
author: Gwen P.

description: I'm happy and sad.  Happy to have found a nice little Japanese place that serves decent yakitori.  Sad that prolly the masses will come to know about this hidden gem and the wait will be unbearable unless you're talking dinner on a Wednesday at 5:30.  Small place, but I digg the Beatles decor and music.  The yakitori was definitely decent and worth coming back for and the kushi-katsu was tasty too.  Like other reviews have stated, service is a touch slow since there's only one hardworking waitress for the entire joint.  The place can also get pretty loud since the sound reverberates.  Will have to be back for ramen.  In all, great place to chill, have some beer and chicken skewers with couple of friends while listening to Yellow Submarine.
author: Tim L.

description: Halu is a pleasant surprise and very charming. I took my wife here on a Saturday evening and waited for about 10 minutes while listening to the Beatles' "Help!" and "Rubber Soul". Beatles paraphernalia decorates every corner of this cozy space. We ordered the chicken heart yakitori and bacon-wrapped scallop yakitori. Both were delicious! (Chicken heart was a first for me.) We also had the Charshiu Ramen and Kara Age Ramen miso soups. Nothing was too salty as many Japanese places can be. I will definitely return and try something new. Hopefully, they'll be playing the "White Album" on my next visit.
author: Zander M.

description: Super small place that serves a great yakitori dinner combo (7 skewers + miso + salad).  What is better than some good yakitori and koshihikari echigo?
author: Tim G.

description: This is a kinda divey place one might find in Shinjuku where you find like some 1960s Japanese fans of Beatles and American 60s pop working at a small YAKITORI-YA...Pretty funky and fun on a cold San Fran summer night with the fog swirling around you making you hair frizz into an afro of black licorice whisps of "He loves, you Yeah..yeah..Yeah..." a la Beatlemania and a pocketful of cash-a-go-g0. I think they are only open at night and it is right next to the ZIP car and public metered parking lot. Peace out.
author: miriam b.

description: yes, i'm a fan. their ramen noodles are good! it's very "bouncy" (if ur chinese, then u know what i mean) the beef tongue is good! just the way i like it! pricing is a on the expensive side for an izakaya i think... but food is good.  i would def go back from the spicy karage ramen! nom nom nom
author: Kelly H.

description: This hole in the wall reminds me of Japan.  The chicken gizzard and chasu ramen was really good.  They had the shiso beef skewer special that day and it was really good as well.  I will definitely go back and try other things on the menu.
author: Mary L.

description: Beatles on the wall and on the sound system. This is a really small place and I was there with a group of nine. They warned us that our food could not all come out at the same time because our party was large and the kitchen was small. I ordered the Chay-su ramen and stuffed mushroom skewer. The ramen and broth was good but there wasn't enough Chaysu. I'm a meat person. The skewer was good but there were only two mushroom for $2.50. The chicken karage ramen was good and the amount of chicken was more satisfying.
author: Ginny M.

description: I only went here for the Yakitoris after a friend told me about the them. I would've given them 4 stars but  I waited for more than an hour for 8 mediocre yakitori sticks which I finished in less than 10 minutes.  The waitress offered some asparagus yakitoris while I wait , which I thought was enough to soothe my hunger pangs.   If you want some really good yakitoris, head down to San Jose at Sumiya or in LA at shin sen gumi.  I don't think I'll be back at this place again for that kind of service.
author: JB L.

description: The cow tongue, short ribs, and asparagus were some of the highlights. But the entire meal was one of the best I've had in the past few years. Ambiance, service, and food was high quality. Waitress was very engaged, and helped identify the best sake, off menu, to match my personal preferences. This is my new favorite restaurant in the Bay Area.
author: Jocelyne T.

description:
This was one of the best SF dining experiences I have ever had.
Every dish was a view into another world. Yes, the portions are small, but I prefer that over the American stuff yourself attitude. 
Grace, finesse and delicate blending of flavors in each and every dish.
The service was bubbly and great. 
I LOVE THIS RESTAURANT!!!
Looking forward to working my way through their menu. What a treat!
author: Marina S.

description:
I'm gonna forgive Halu for their lack of pork now.  I've been here a jillion times since that incident and haven't had any others.  I think I'm safe.  Plus, I still don't eat pork so I ultimately don't care if they have it or not.  I've had a few different things now so my review can expand.  Most items are winners.  Karaage ramen=awesome.  Even my pork eating boyfriend prefers it after trying the chashumen.  This is not to say it's bad.  Just that it's not as strong.  Yakitori was good but not enough to order it over ramen if you have to choose.  Yakionigiri=awesome.  I don't have anything to compare it to since I've never ordered it elsewhere but if it tastes anywhere near as good as Halu's I'll order it everywhere every chance I get.  Green salad with strawberry=tiny mediocre dressing and not a good value.  The boyfriend tried the katsu sampler.  Some items were really good, most were just ok.  I also tried the karaage and zuchinni brown rice bowl.  Really tasty and the brown rice and salad make eating fried chicken seem healthy.  Kind of.  

As with most restaurants, some items are better than others.  Service can be efficient when not too busy and slow when it is.  Pretty standard for mom and pop restaurants with only 1 server though.  Overall, the concept and execution of the simple menu at Halu works and I really hope it's successful.
author: M M.

description: Their seaweed wrapped mochi and sochu cocktails are the best!
author: C Y.

description: Great yakitori (small japanese plates, grilled). Be  sure to try their specials on the board. A little on the salty side, but hits the spot anyway.
author: Lauren C.

description: In my quest to find the best ramen in sf, I went to Hula. The ramen was fine.  I liked the corn and ginger but the pork was tasteless.  Noodles were good and the broth was a little bland.  I thought Izakaya Sozai was better both for the broth and pork.  The upside was there was no wait and parking was easy on a Friday at 8.
author: rebecca s.

description: I'm just glad that there is some decent tasting ramen in the neighborhood. The broth is pretty tasty and I always love an extra serving of bamboo shoots. Love the beatles decor in there, it gives this lil joint some personality. Love the fact that the menu is pretty diverse with their kushiyaki and yakitori items. We had the scallop and bacon sticks and it was damn good but anything with bacon usually is ;)
author: Topazskye L.

description: this place is small, has a long wait, and is kinda expensive... but overall, its not too bad. i like how they have different things to try on the skewers. their ramen wasnt all that great tho. i rather have Tampopo in J-town!
author: Gordon L.

description: Went here for the first time last night - it was cold and rainy but nice and cozy inside Halu.  We really liked it.  My husband and friend had ramen noodles which looked like a big bowl of heaven!  I had some bites, very tasty and lots of good noodles and broth.  I had a Something Don?? it was fried chicken breast strips on brown rice with a salad all served in a bowl with some tasty sesame ginger dressing.  It tasted fresh and healthy even with the fried chicken aspect.  Nice miso soup and seaweed salad too.  It will be my new local favorite.  Only 4 stars until we have a few more visits to confirm!
author: cece S.

description: I went there and the place smelled like burnt food.  I ordered the ramen with pork and there were some noodles that were stuck together.  The broth was mediocre and the meet was ok.  Its just so sad that this is probably the best that norcal has to offer.  you want really good ramen then you need to go to LA for santouka ramen or hawaii for Tenkaippin Hawaii.  We also got the gyoza and for some reason the chef thought gyoza with a hint of cinnamen would taste good.  Well it tasted like my doo doo that i laid this morning after i ate my bagel with cream cheese.  I am never coming here again.  Terrible.
author: Anton E.

description: the day i went, the deep fryer was broken. so no deep fried dishes were served. no problem, i came for the yakitori.  to keep it short, it was good. the bacon wrapped scallops is a must. my only complaint was finding a RUBBER BAND in my miso soup. At my restaurant, if someone found a rubber band in their miso soup, i would have comped their whole meal, or bought them a bottle of sake, or got them anything on the menu. but nope, i got a "omg, im so sorry" then heres your bill. i know things happen so i know ill be back.
author: Ricky Y.

description: Everything is excellent.  The spicy ramen is wonderful.  Yakitori is the best in the city.
author: Eric L.

description: second visit awesome!!!   i wonder though, does the family ever tire of the beatles music, i mean its' playing all the time..   they should get a widescreen and play endless summer round the clock.
author: Bing S.

description: I thought everything was pretty good, but I must say, the ramen was super excellent.  Everything about the ramen was a "10", except maybe the noodles themselves, which were unremarkable.  The pork was tasty, the broth was rich and multi-dimensional.  Yum.
author: Jocelyn K.

description: From the outside, you would never think this was a restaurant. But looks aside, this little hole in the wall joint serves great Japanese skewers and ramen.  The chicken win skewers and the bacon wrapped mushrooms were delish! I also shared a bowl of the ramen with two friends and it was one of the est ramens I've had, and usually I'm not even a fan of noodle soups. It did take a bit of time to get our food, but worth the wait
author: Theresa R.

description: It's really easy to walk right past this place and think it's closed.  But if you figure out that there is actually an open restaurant inside, you're in for a treat.  The ramen and yakatori are really good - some of the best I've had in the city.  I docked one star because it can be a little salty, but maybe that's what makes it good? Oh, and the chicken karaage is awesome!  Get there early if you actually have more than 2 people and want a table.
author: Charlotte L.

description: Beautiful place with absolutely delicious food at great prices, and the kindest people on earth running the place.
author: Will T.

description: Tried to go there twice - first there was a note taped to the door saying they were at a wedding, then it was "closed for maintenance". Best to call first before trying.
author: Laura w.

description: i have found spring.  just sad that i didn't find it sooner.  HALU is one of those places you don't think much about walking by but is quite homey and comfortable for small group inside.  family run, friendly and fresh food.  price is good, simple choices of veggies, meats, noodles and rice.  yakitoris are good and simple.   i'm glad i finally found spring.
author: Food Is L.

description: A Beatles/Who themed yakitori? YES PLEASE! I love this place. It's not amazing food or ambiance but it has that cool, unique feel where you know you won't find a place like this anywhere else in the country. It's a small mom and pop restaurant that serves traditional yakitori style Japanese food. And the place is plastered with Hendrix, Who and Beatles posters. Obviously, they played great music the whole time we were there and the food was pretty great too. We had the butter fried mochi wrapped in seaweed to start which was a new flavor combination for me which I quite enjoyed. We also had the ground chicken meatball skewers as well as the scallop wrapped in bacon and the asparagus wrapped in bacon. The two bacon wrapped skewers were okay, nothing to write home about but the chicken meatballs were pretty delicious. We also had okonomiyaki (I can never resist okonomiyaki) which was quite good and kara age chicken which is always good (when is fried chicken not good?) Service is fast and friendly and I love how everyone greets you so warmly and gives you menu advice, I was about to order a mountain potato dish but the waitress warned me it can be quite strange for people who had never had it before and so I opted not to try it that night. Can't wait to come back!
author: Cathy T.

description:
Unfortunately, I would like to rate this restaurant higher. However, there were too many things wrong to contribute any more stars to the average. It is harsh that I am obligated to do this because they were kind enough to give up a complementary Yebisu for one of the mistakes. However, as another review mentioned, this was not how all customers were treated that night. What this is really about is how is San Francisco ever going to get anything that is legitimately good and/or authentic when Halu is a 4-Yelp-star restaurant? Do not get me wrong, the food was overall fairly good, and nobody was sick afterward. But, this was a "Meh. I've experienced better." experience, and that's how I have to rate it.

Bear in mind that this is a Wednesday night at 8:30PM. The restaurant is full with nobody else waiting. There is only one server who playing the role of waitress, hostess, food runner and doing random things in the kitchen person. There is also a man, a woman, a younger woman, and a younger man (dishwasher) all behind the scenes. We (party of two) waited 15 minutes or so outside for the two spots at the bar to be clean and ready. We ordered an Asahi dry to share, marinated tako salad, Chashu-men (pork ramen),  10 skewers (ten: 2 thigh, 2 pork+onion, 2 ground chicken, 2 wing, and 2 heart it's important later). Skewers are fairly small so we also ordered mochi bacon and shishito peppers.

Now, I was being complicated by ordering one skewer salted and one skewer with sauce for the 10 meat skewers. But, in a new place, I was hedging against the sauce being really slimey and salty or the salt mixture being just salty and not very flavorful. It was dumb for such a busy waitstaff, I know. In any case, I received 9 (nine) skewers. Some meats were salt, some meats were sauce. Arbitrary, but it's half and half in a way. This is when the older woman behind the counter apologized very graciously, offering to remake them if it wasn't what I wanted. I really couldn't care, and I'm not going to really rub it in about the elusive skewer. The unfortunate part was it was the thigh skewer which was good. But, I was fine with it, and she brought us a beer without any time to reply. For that portion of the meal, the pork skewer was the least favorite, and I actually really enjoyed the wing skewers. On the subject of skewers, the shishito peppers were also good and the mochi bacon was quite texturally mind-blowing. Flavor-wise it's dry bacon wrapped around rice, so it tastes like dry bacon with a rice-flavored chewy center. If you like bacon, it's good. If you like chewy, it's also good.

Now, the ramen came out right near the end there and, rather than the Chashu-men, it was filled with kara-age fried chicken. Not a problem, it's apparently so crazy this Wednesday that things are just flying out of the kitchen willy-nilly. Then the family next to us gets the Chashu-men, uh oh! It hasn't even touched the counter-top when we hear "But, I got the chicken!" wah-waaah.

Ok, long story short. The skewers weren't enough for my belly so I ordered some onigiri. They were very patient before letting us down gently that they were out of white rice. Yes, out of white rice. Don't go here on a Wednesday, it's out-of-control bonkers crazy-town busy. So, our onigiri would be made with brown rice. Hey, something new to try. They were at least prepared fresh, and pretty tasty. I actually highly recommend the mustard green onigiri, but probably with short-grain white rice. The brown's okay, but not my personal preference.

All in all $66.xx for two. Is it the San Francisco rent prices? Or the lack of creative restauranteurs? Why is there such a quality absence in most (but certainly not all!) SF cuisine? I really don't have a lot of incentive to branch out from what I know to be good and worth the cost.
author: Chris C.

description: I was lucky enough to be there on there Grand Opening, I was there enjoying the Mermen/Shitone gang that was playing and taking photographs! I had a handful of appetizers which were certainly nice, but mostly the vibe was GREAT and the owners were friendly.. I was only there that one afternoon and I'm planing on going back. some of the photos are here: http://www.ajphotographer.com/data/web/clientpages/Halu_opening/index.html
author: alex j.

description:
food :everything was ok, not spectacular
they had bacon wrapped mochi yakitori.. which was kinda interesting

decorated with beatle posters,
played doraemon on tv,
played beatle music
author: j s.

description: so i went back to try their ramen and was very pleased.  the noodles were perfectly cooked and and the soup was very flavorful.  i tried their sochu mixed drinks and it was pretty tasty.
author: junie k.

description: The best Yakatori in town. It's a family restaurant operated by a husband and wife along with their twin daughters. It's a small place that is usually packed, but well worth the wait. the Lava Ramen is really good along with fried chicken ramen. Go there to support a local business who serves really great and unique food.
author: nick m.

description: Ok, it's time for 5 stars for this place.  I've been back a couple times since my first encounter and they've all been tremendous.  But this last time took the cake.  I finally tried one of their rice bowls - sauteed mushrooms with greens over brown rice.  So delicious!!  It's the perfect dinner item when you're not feeling too hungry and want to be somewhat healthy.  Of course, I ordered that with karaage (not the best thing for you) but I had to have a little something something to spice up the brown rice!  I think they have the best karaage in the city.  I can't wait to go back there again - I love their vibe and they are the nicest owners in town.
author: Ming Y.

description: I read all the Yelp reviews about this place before I went and many people raved about the bacon wrapped scallops. I love bacon and I love scallops, so I was totally on board.......until they arrived at my table. Maybe I got something different then what everyone has been raving about, but I got raw, chewy, fatty, gross bacon wrapped around a scallop. The bacon was cooked in only 1 small part and the rest was raw, and , frankly pretty disgusting.  The rest of the meal was good. The short rib yakatori was delicious. I liked this place but I am a little confused at to where all these fabulous reviews came from. This place was fine.. average.... no big deal. I dont think I would travel a long distance to eat here. Certainly there are better places to go.
author: angela j.

description:
love this place.  this is more like 4.5 stars.  that extra .5 is for the originality of their decor.  you walk in and you can just tell the owners were old hippies or beatniks.  it's beatlemania!  all the stuff on the walls are from the owners personal collection and it's just awesome.  old record covers, pictures, autographs, posters, you name it.  it even has a beatles drumset uptop.  

on to the food:  really clean and really good.  we got the chashu ramen and the katsu dinner.  the ramen was some of the best i've had in sf and the katsu was really light and flavorful.  i will go back and try more yakitori and other specials that are hung up on the wall.

i'm pulling for this place b/c it was such a pleasant surprise.  it's all beatles all the time in there.  be careful not to mess with the memorabilia, i wouldn't want my personal collection messed with.  it's cool that he shares that stuff.  check it out.
author: shar d.

description: I'd hate to give such a low score because the food was decent BUT... as someone else mentioned the service was lacking and extremely slow.  First off, it took twenty minutes to take our orders, another thirty to get the food and worse off for my friend that ordered a variety of skewers, it took an HOUR AND A HALF to get them!!! The waitress was polite enough to apologize and offered aspargus skewers to him as a peace offering but that was after forty minutes.  Normally I would give it another try but it seems that this is the norm.
author: Erick K.

description: Came here on NYE with a friend. First off, the space is small, kinda awkward near the door with a narrow passage wedged between the bar seats and small tables along the wall. The door literally hits my friend's chair everytime someone comes in. That being said, the size definitely contributes to the cozy factor. The interior is crammed full of Beatles memorabilia and various knick-knacks of dubious vintage. Of course, Beatles music is blasting the whole time. I read somewhere that the owner used to play in a rock band. We got a good sampling of dishes from this place and formed a consensus on likes and dislikes. They fry really well: the age dashi tofu, kara age, and stuffed mushroom kushi katsu were all done well. Not too greasy, and piping hot. The stuffed mushroom was bursting with juices when bitten into, I wished we tried more of the fried items. Their yakitori on the other hand... Everything that we ordered that came with the house sauce was too salty and felt lukewarm, the ingredients simply lacked the freshness and delicious bincho smokiness that I've experienced in places in LA. However, their yakitori selection wasn't a total loss due to the bacon wrapped items. I mean come on, you could wrap plastic in bacon and it'd taste good. But seriously, maybe because there wasn't the salty house sauce to mask the flavors and the food was hotter, the bacon wrapped items were simply sublime. Bits of crisp, charred, smoky bacon interspersed with the unctous lardo parts surround perfectly cooked vegetables and meats= orgasmic. Lastly, we ordered the kara age ramen for the heck of it, which was nothing to write home about, good enough if you're hungry. In summary, stick to fried stuff and bacon wrapped anything and take your statins of choice at home. Also they're closed from 1/1 to 1/5.
author: Cho C.

description: Checked out Halu on my way to Green Apple books a block away. I was not in a rush and had some reading to do so slow service was not a problem. I ordered the yakitori set dinner along with sake and tea. The food was great! Never would have ordered the grilled okra on its own but I loved it. The chicken, beef and shrimp were awesome. I really liked the dressing on the small salad. While eating, I noticed the okonomiyake pancake on the specials board. I had read about this in my Osaka tour guides (while dreaming of Japan travel) and saw Anthony Bourdain scarfing it on TV. I don't know where else you can get this and was thrilled to try it. The pancake, think it was meatless with a mayo sauce on top, was tasty and the leftovers were killer for breakfast. I'm going to bring my husband with the Beatles theme as a lure. I will definitely return to try the scallop, asparagus and ramen. What I like about Halu is it's cozy atmosphere with original, authentic high-quality food. ps. the Yelp listing says they don't take credit cards but they took mine.
author: Michelle L.

description: Good and traditional Japanese food. The owners are very nice people, not like the one in Oyajx. I would say the price is a bit higher than what it should be, but I am sure you can have a great time at this restaurant. The service is very professional and nice, too.
author: Charlie S.

description: Been there twice and counting.  Wonderful yakitori and kushi katsu with authentic flavor.
author: Sean U.

description: I'm so happy that we finally found a decent japenese ramen/ yakitori house! And it's walking distance from the pad..double yay! Came here for the 1st time early friday night with the bf and his 'rents. Place was pretty empty when we arrived but was super crowded when we left. 1st impression: cute, small, cool beatles paraphenelia, but majorly hot and stuffy! Wear layers cause you'll want something to take off! Got loads of appetizers..erichan specail grilled mochi was pretty unique and agedashi tofu was yummy (although I saw another couple have tofu with mushrooms on top that looked yummier), gyoza was odd, and the grilled rice triangle was really tasty. It tastes exactly like the burnt rice at the bottom of the pot..which I love cause it's super crispy! My ramen was really tasty too, the miso broth wasn't salty at all and you could really taste the tonkatsu base. The yakitori dinner also was good. The only complaint...portions were not that huge. If you're a big eater like the bf and his dad...you'll need multiple entree orders. Even I finished ALL my ramen without trouble...I don't know it that means it was just really yummy or if there weren't enough noodles ...you decide.
author: Emily W.
